491<h1 class="content-title">

492The Endocannabinoid System as an Emerging Target of Pharmacotherapy</h1>

493<div class="half_rhythm">

494<div class="contrib-group fm-author">

495<a href="/pubmed/?term=PACHER%20P%5BAuthor%5D&amp;cauthor=true&amp;cauthor_uid=16968947">

496P&#x000c1;L PACHER</a>

497, <a href="/pubmed/?term=B%26%23x000c1%3BTKAI%20S%5BAuthor%5D&amp;cauthor=true&amp;cauthor_uid=16968947">

498S&#x000c1;NDOR B&#x000c1;TKAI</a>

499, and <a href="/pubmed/?term=KUNOS%20G%5BAuthor%5D&amp;cauthor=true&amp;cauthor_uid=16968947">

500GEORGE KUNOS</a>

501</div>

502<div style="display:none" class="contrib-group aff-tip">

503</div>

504</div>

514<div class="fm-authors-info fm-panel hide half_rhythm" id="idm139779474107280_ai" style="display:none">

515<div class="fm-affl" lang="en" id="A1">

516Laboratory of Physiologic Studies, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland</div>

518Address correspondence to: Dr. George Kunos, National Institutes of Health, NIAAA, Laboratory of Physiological Studies, 5625 Fishers Lane, Room 2S-24, Bethesda, MD 20892-9413. E-mail: <a href="mailto:dev@null" data-email="vog.hin.liam@sonukg" class="oemail">

536The publisher's final edited version of this article is available at <a href="/entrez/eutils/elink.fcgi?dbfrom=pubmed&amp;retmode=ref&amp;cmd=prlinks&amp;id=16968947" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" ref="reftype=publisher&amp;article-id=2241751&amp;issue-id=161221&amp;journal-id=319&amp;FROM=Article%7CFront%20Matter&amp;TO=Content%20Provider%7CArticle%7CRestricted%20Access">

537Pharmacol Rev</a>

538</div>

546<div class="sec">

547</div>

548<div id="idm139779474165312" lang="en" class="tsec sec">

549<h2 class="head no_bottom_margin" id="idm139779474165312title">

550Abstract</h2>

551<!--article-meta-->

552<div>

553<p id="P1" class="p p-first-last">

554The recent identification of cannabinoid receptors and their endogenous lipid ligands has triggered an exponential growth of studies exploring the endocannabinoid system and its regulatory functions in health and disease. Such studies have been greatly facilitated by the introduction of selective cannabinoid receptor antagonists and inhibitors of endocannabinoid metabolism and transport, as well as mice deficient in cannabinoid receptors or the endocannabinoid-degrading enzyme fatty acid amidohydrolase. In the past decade, the endocannabinoid system has been implicated in a growing number of physiological functions, both in the central and peripheral nervous systems and in peripheral organs. More importantly, modulating the activity of the endocannabinoid system turned out to hold therapeutic promise in a wide range of disparate diseases and pathological conditions, ranging from mood and anxiety disorders, movement disorders such as Parkinson&#x02019;s and Huntington&#x02019;s disease, neuropathic pain, multiple sclerosis and spinal cord injury, to cancer, atherosclerosis, myocardial infarction, stroke, hypertension, glaucoma, obesity/metabolic syndrome, and osteoporosis, to name just a few. An impediment to the development of cannabinoid medications has been the socially unacceptable psychoactive properties of plant-derived or synthetic agonists, mediated by CB<sub>

5551</sub>

556 receptors. However, this problem does not arise when the therapeutic aim is achieved by treatment with a CB<sub>

5571</sub>

558 receptor antagonist, such as in obesity, and may also be absent when the action of endocannabinoids is enhanced indirectly through blocking their metabolism or transport. The use of selective CB<sub>

5592</sub>

560 receptor agonists, which lack psychoactive properties, could represent another promising avenue for certain conditions. The abuse potential of plant-derived cannabinoids may also be limited through the use of preparations with controlled composition and the careful selection of dose and route of administration. The growing number of preclinical studies and clinical trials with compounds that modulate the endocannabinoid system will probably result in novel therapeutic approaches in a number of diseases for which current treatments do not fully address the patients&#x02019; need. Here, we provide a comprehensive overview on the current state of knowledge of the endocannabinoid system as a target of pharmacotherapy.</p>

561</div>

562</div>

563<div id="S1" class="tsec sec">

564<h2 class="head no_bottom_margin" id="S1title">

565I. Introduction</h2>

566<p id="P2" class="p p-first-last">

567Marijuana, or cannabis, is the most widely used illicit drug in Western societies and also the one with the longest recorded history of human use. The popularity of marijuana as a recreational drug is due to its ability to alter sensory perception and cause elation and euphoria, most vividly described by the 19th century French poet, Charles Baudelaire, in his book <em>

568Les Paradis Artificiels</em>

569 (<a href="#R544" rid="R544" class=" bibr popnode">

570Iversen, 2000</a>

571). However, the ability of extracts of the hemp plant (<em>

572Cannabis sativa</em>

573) to cause a variety of medicinal effects unrelated to its psychoactive properties had been recognized as early as the third millennium BC, when Chinese texts described its usefulness in the relief of pain and cramps (<a href="#R804" rid="R804" class=" bibr popnode">

574Mechoulam, 1986</a>

575). In ancient India, the anxiety-relieving effect of bhang (the Indian term for marijuana ingested as food) had been recorded more than 3000 years ago. The use of cannabis or hashish as a psychoactive substance reached Europe and the Americas through the Arab world in the 19th century. During the same period, cannabis extracts had gained widespread use for medicinal purposes until 1937, when concern about the dangers of abuse led to the banning of marijuana for further medicinal use in the United States. The rather turbulent history of marijuana and the recent resurgence of interest in its medicinal properties have been the subject of excellent reviews (<a href="#R804" rid="R804" class=" bibr popnode">

576Mechoulam, 1986</a>

577; <a href="#R544" rid="R544" class=" bibr popnode">

578Iversen, 2000</a>

579; <a href="#R271" rid="R271" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919791">

580Di Marzo et al., 2004</a>

581; <a href="#R527" rid="R527" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920329">

582Howlett et al., 2004</a>

583; <a href="#R957" rid="R957" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920256">

584Pertwee, 2005a</a>

585; Piomelli, 2005; <a href="#R277" rid="R277" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919252">

586Di Marzo and Petrocellis, 2006</a>

587; <a href="#R725" rid="R725" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920044">

588Mackie, 2006</a>

589; <a href="#R930" rid="R930" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919821">

590Pagotto et al., 2006</a>

591). Added to this interest is the emergence of the endocannabinoid system, offering not only new insights into the mechanisms underlying the therapeutic actions of plant-derived phytocannabinoids but also novel molecular targets for pharmacotherapy. In this overview, we will briefly summarize current thoughts about the role of endocannabinoids in a given physiological or pathological process and then survey attempts to exploit this role for therapeutic gain.</p>

592</div>

593<div id="S2" class="tsec sec">

594<h2 class="head no_bottom_margin" id="S2title">

595II. The Pharmacology of Cannabinoids</h2>

596<div id="S3" class="sec sec-first">

597<h3 id="S3title">

598A. Cannabinoid Receptors and Ligands</h3>

599<p id="P3" class="p p-first">

600Up until the last two decades, marijuana research was a rather esoteric field, of interest to a small number of scientists. A contributory factor was the highly lipophilic nature of the biologically active ingredients, which led to the notion that marijuana elicits its effects nonspecifically by perturbing membrane lipids (<a href="#R665" rid="R665" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919583">

601Lawrence and Gill, 1975</a>

602). The first important breakthrough that ultimately led to a rejection of this concept was the identification by <a href="#R361" rid="R361" class=" bibr popnode">

603Gaoni and Mechoulam (1964)</a>

604 of the correct chemical structure of the main psychoactive ingredient of marijuana, &#x00394;<sup>

6059</sup>

606-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC<sup>

607<a href="#FN3" rid="FN3" class=" fn">

6081</a>

609</sup>

610), and the subsequent demonstration that bioactivity resides in the <em>

611l</em>

612-stereoisomer of this compound (<a href="#R808" rid="R808" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919930">

613Mechoulam and Gaoni, 1967</a>

614), which is one of approximately 60 cannabinoids present in the plant (<a href="#R265" rid="R265" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920370">

615Dewey, 1986</a>

616). This discovery stimulated the generation of a whole range of synthetic analogs in the 1970s that included not only compounds structurally similar to phytocannabinoids (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F1">

617<span>

618Fig. 1A</span>

619</a>

620) but also analogs with different chemical structures, including classic and nonclassic cannabinoids and aminoalkylindoles (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F1">

621<span>

622Fig. 1B</span>

623</a>

624) (<a href="#R526" rid="R526" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920214">

625Howlett et al., 2002</a>

626), as well as the subsequently discovered endogenous arachidonic acid derivatives or endocannabinoids (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F1">

627<span>

628Fig. 1C</span>

629</a>

630), which are discussed in more detail below. Studies of the biological effects of THC and its synthetic analogs revealed strict structural selectivity (<a href="#R517" rid="R517" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919073">

631Hollister, 1974</a>

632) as well as stereo-selectivity (<a href="#R570" rid="R570" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919500">

633Jones et al., 1974</a>

634), telltale signs of drug-receptor interactions. Definitive evidence for the existence of specific cannabinoid receptors was followed soon by the demonstration of high-affinity, saturable, stereospecific binding sites for the synthetic cannabinoid agonist [<sup>

6353</sup>

636H]CP-55,940 in mouse brain plasma membranes, which correlated with both the in vitro inhibition of adenylate cyclase and the in vivo analgesic effect of the compound (<a href="#R263" rid="R263" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919261">

637Devane et al., 1988</a>

638). The availability of a radioligand also allowed the mapping of cannabinoid receptors in the brain by receptor autoradiography (<a href="#R485" rid="R485" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637197">

639Herkenham et al., 1991b</a>

640). This mapping turned out to be of key importance in the subsequent identification of an orphan G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) as the brain receptor for cannabinoids (<a href="#R783" rid="R783" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919242">

641Matsuda et al., 1990</a>

642), later named CB<sub>

6431</sub>

644 receptor, based on the overlapping regional distribution of the mRNA for this GPCR and [<sup>

6453</sup>

646H]CP-55,940 binding sites. CB<sub>

6471</sub>

648 receptors are the most abundant receptors in the mammalian brain but are also present at much lower concentrations in a variety of peripheral tissues and cells. A second cannabinoid GPCR, CB<sub>

6492</sub>

650, is expressed primarily in cells of the immune and hematopoietic systems (<a href="#R863" rid="R863" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920079">

651Munro et al., 1993</a>

652) but recently were found to be present in the brain (<a href="#R1218" rid="R1218" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653472">

653Van Sickle et al., 2005</a>

654; <a href="#R411" rid="R411" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919949">

655Gong et al., 2006</a>

656), in nonparenchymal cells of the cirrhotic liver (<a href="#R577" rid="R577" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919100">

657Julien et al., 2005</a>

658), in the endocrine pancreas (<a href="#R576" rid="R576" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920217">

659Juan-Pico et al., 2005</a>

660), and in bone (<a href="#R587" rid="R587" class=" bibr popnode">

661Karsak et al., 2004</a>

662; <a href="#R537" rid="R537" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919031">

663Idris et al., 2005</a>

664; <a href="#R903" rid="R903" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920176">

665Ofek et al., 2006</a>

666). Two splice variants of CB<sub>

6671</sub>

668 receptors have been also identified: CB<sub>

6691A</sub>

670, which has an altered amino-terminal sequence (<a href="#R1094" rid="R1094" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919414">

671Shire et al., 1995</a>

672), and CB<sub>

6731B</sub>

674, which has an in-frame deletion of 33 amino acids at the amino terminus (<a href="#R1054" rid="R1054" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919546">

675Ryberg et al., 2005</a>

676). The mRNAs of both splice variants are expressed at much lower levels than the CB<sub>

6771</sub>

678 mRNA and, although the receptors expressed from the cDNAs have unique pharmacology (<a href="#R1054" rid="R1054" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919114">

679Ryberg et al., 2005</a>

680), evidence for their natural expression has not been reported.</p>

681<!--fig ft0-->

682<!--fig mode=article f1-->

683<div class="fig iconblock whole_rhythm" id="F1" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F1">

684<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1">

685<!--fig/graphic|fig/alternatives/graphic mode="anchored" m1-->

686<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462227120" class="figure">

687<img loading="lazy" class="fig-image" alt="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f1.jpg" title="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f1.jpg" src="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/bin/nihms38123f1.jpg" />

688</div>

689<div id="largeobj_idm139779462227120" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

690<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/?report=objectonly">

691Open in a separate window</a>

692</div>

693</a>

694<div class="icnblk_cntnt" id="lgnd_F1">

695<div>

696<a class="figpopup" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1">

697Fig. 1</a>

698</div>

699<!--caption a7-->

700<div class="caption">

701<p id="__p2">

702The chemical structure and pharmacological activity of selected plant derived (A), synthetic (B), and endogenous cannabinoids (C).</p>

703</div>

704</div>

705</div>

706<p id="P4">

707An interesting twist on the steric selectivity of cannabinoid receptors has emerged through recent studies of the behaviorally inactive phytocannabinoid (&#x02212;)-cannabidiol (CBD) and its synthetic analogs, which have negligible affinity for either CB<sub>

7081</sub>

709 or CB<sub>

7102</sub>

711 receptors. Paradoxically, some of the synthetic (+)-(+)-stereoisomers of these compounds were found to bind potently to both CB<sub>

7121</sub>

713 and CB<sub>

7142</sub>

715 receptors (<a href="#R91" rid="R91" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920239">

716Bisogno et al., 2001</a>

717) but to display only peripheral and not centrally mediated cannabinoid-like bioactivity, suggesting that they may act as antagonists rather than agonists at central, but not peripheral, CB<sub>

7181</sub>

719 receptors (<a href="#R347" rid="R347" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653408">

720Fride et al., 2005</a>

721).</p>

722<p id="P5">

723Another ligand that displays central versus peripheral selectivity is ajulemic acid, a metabolite of THC that was found to have potent anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties without any overt behavioral or psychoactive effects (<a href="#R136" rid="R136" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919276">

724Burstein et al., 1992</a>

725; <a href="#R290" rid="R290" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918899">

726Dyson et al., 2005</a>

727; <a href="#R838" rid="R838" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919841">

728Mitchell et al., 2005</a>

729). Ajulemic acid was reported to bind to both CB<sub>

7301</sub>

731 and CB<sub>

7322</sub>

733 receptors with reasonably high affinity (<em>

734K</em>

735<sub>

736d</sub>

737 100&#x02013;200 nM) but only to activate the latter (<a href="#R1010" rid="R1010" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919538">

738Rhee et al., 1997</a>

739), which may explain its unique and therapeutically attractive pharmacological profile. A more recent study indicated even higher affinities for CB<sub>

7401</sub>

741 (<em>

742K</em>

743<sub>

744i</sub>

745 6 nM) and CB<sub>

7462</sub>

747 receptors (<em>

748K</em>

749<sub>

750i</sub>

751 56 nM) and specified the role of CB<sub>

7521</sub>

753 in mediating its antihyperalgesic activity in neuropathic pain (<a href="#R290" rid="R290" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919824">

754Dyson et al., 2005</a>

755). This article also documented limited brain penetration of ajulemic acid compared with other cannabinoids, which may account for its favorable therapeutic profile. Ajulemic acid also binds to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor <em>

756&#x003b3;</em>

757 receptors with low (micromolar) affinity, which was proposed to account for its effect on adipocyte differentiation (<a href="#R695" rid="R695" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920013">

758Liu et al., 2003b</a>

759).</p>

760<p id="P6">

761Among the 60 or so cannabinoids present in marijuana, only THC is psychoactive. However, some of the other constituents, such as cannabidiol, have well-documented biological effects of potential therapeutic interest, such as antianxiety, anticonvulsive, antinausea, anti-inflammatory and antitumor properties (<a href="#R813" rid="R813" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919228">

762Mechoulam et al., 2002c</a>

763; <a href="#R436" rid="R436" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919026">

764Grotenhermen, 2004</a>

765; <a href="#R1206" rid="R1206" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919632">

766Vaccani et al., 2005</a>

767). Cannabidiol does not significantly interact with CB<sub>

7681</sub>

769 or CB<sub>

7702</sub>

771 receptors, and its actions have been attributed to inhibition of anandamide degradation or its antioxidant properties (<a href="#R810" rid="R810" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919765">

772Mechoulam and Hanus, 2002</a>

773; <a href="#R813" rid="R813" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920048">

774Mechoulam et al., 2002c</a>

775), or an interaction with as yet unidentified cannabinoid receptors (see below). Another marijuana constituent of potential therapeutic interest is tetrahydrocannabivarin (<a href="#R751" rid="R751" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919983">

776Markus, 1971</a>

777), which has recently been shown to have CB<sub>

7781</sub>

779 antagonist properties (<a href="#R1177" rid="R1177" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919892">

780Thomas et al., 2005</a>

781).</p>

782<p id="P7">

783In addition to CB<sub>

7841</sub>

785 and CB<sub>

7862</sub>

787 receptors, pharmacological evidence has been accumulating over the years to support the existence of one or more additional receptors for cannabinoids (reviewed in <a href="#R57" rid="R57" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919698">

788Begg et al., 2005</a>

789). Two of these possibilities have been more extensively explored: an endothelial site involved in vasodilation and endothelial cell migration (<a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919612">

790J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

791; <a href="#R56" rid="R56" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920173">

792Begg et al., 2003</a>

793; <a href="#R839" rid="R839" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919832">

794Mo et al., 2004</a>

795), and a presynaptic site on glutamatergic terminals in the hippocampus mediating inhibition of glutamate release (<a href="#R451" rid="R451" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653492">

796H&#x000e1;jos et al., 2001</a>

797). Responses elicited at both of these sites were reported to survive genetic ablation of CB<sub>

7981</sub>

799 receptors, yet be sensitive to inhibition by the CB<sub>

8001</sub>

801 antagonist SR141716 or by pertussis toxin but not by the CB<sub>

8021</sub>

803 antagonist AM251 (<a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918840">

804J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

805; <a href="#R450" rid="R450" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919478">

806H&#x000e1;jos and Freund, 2002</a>

807; <a href="#R505" rid="R505" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919740">

808Ho and Hiley, 2003</a>

809; <a href="#R904" rid="R904" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919521">

810Offert&#x000e1;ler et al., 2003</a>

811; <a href="#R916" rid="R916" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653478">

812O&#x02019;Sullivan et al., 2004a</a>

813,<a href="#R917" rid="R917" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653398">

814b</a>

815). However, the two sites are apparently different. The aminoalkylindol WIN 55,212-2 was found to be an agonist and capsazepine an antagonist at the hippocampal (<a href="#R450" rid="R450" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918786">

816H&#x000e1;jos and Freund, 2002</a>

817) but not at the endothelial receptor (<a href="#R1251" rid="R1251" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919460">

818Wagner et al., 1999</a>

819; <a href="#R852" rid="R852" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653522">

820Mukhopadhyay et al., 2002</a>

821). On the other hand, certain atypical cannabinoids with no affinity for CB<sub>

8221</sub>

823 or CB<sub>

8242</sub>

825 receptors behave as agonists (abnormal cannabidiol, O-1602) or antagonists at the endothelial receptor (cannabidiol, O-1918) but not at the hippocampal receptor (<a href="#R57" rid="R57" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919302">

826Begg et al., 2005</a>

827). Arachidonoyl-L-serine, an endogenous lipid discovered in rat brain, has been found to be a vasodilator acting at the endothelial cannabinoid receptor (<a href="#R834" rid="R834" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653383">

828Milman et al., 2006</a>

829), although its activity at the hippocampal receptor has not yet been evaluated. The existence of this latter receptor has recently been called into question, as the ability of WIN 55,212-2 to suppress the same excitatory synapse as studied by <a href="#R451" rid="R451" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653352">

830H&#x000e1;jos et al. (2001)</a>

831 was found to be absent in two different strains of CB<sub>

8321</sub>

833 knockout mice, yet present in their respective wild-type controls (<a href="#R1161" rid="R1161" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653392">

834Takahashi and Castillo, 2006</a>

835). Atypical cannabinoid receptors with pharmacological properties similar to those of the endothelial receptor have been postulated to exist on microglia, where they mediate microglial migration (<a href="#R1261" rid="R1261" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637228">

836Walter et al., 2003</a>

837), and on neurons of the mouse vas deferens (<a href="#R963" rid="R963" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918881">

838Pertwee et al., 2002</a>

839, <a href="#R959" rid="R959" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_539174732">

8402005c</a>

841). Activation of this latter receptor by the CBD analog 7-OH-dimethylheptyl CBD, which is inactive at CB<sub>

8421</sub>

843, CB<sub>

8442</sub>

845, or transient receptor potential vanilloid type 1 (TRPV<sub>

8461</sub>

847) receptors, inhibits electrically evoked contractions of the vas deferens, and the effect is selectively inhibited by CBD itself. A brain cannabinoid receptor distinct from CB<sub>

8481</sub>

849 was also indicated by the ability of anandamide and WIN 55,212-2, but not other agonists, to stimulate GTP<em>

850&#x003b3;</em>

851S binding in brain plasma membranes from CB<sub>

8521</sub>

853 knockout mice (<a href="#R118" rid="R118" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919009">

854Breivogel et al., 2001</a>

855).</p>

856<p id="P8">

857Of interest are recent findings reported in the patent literature that the orphan receptor GPR-55 (<a href="#R1070" rid="R1070" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919361">

858Sawzdargo et al., 1999</a>

859) recognizes a variety of cannabinoid ligands, but not WIN 55,212-2 (<a href="#R124" rid="R124" class=" bibr popnode">

860Brown and Wise, 2003</a>

861; <a href="#R283" rid="R283" class=" bibr popnode">

862Drmota et al., 2004</a>

863). However, GPR-55 is apparently not expressed in the vascular endothelium and is sensitive to HU-210 (<a href="#R283" rid="R283" class=" bibr popnode">

864Drmota et al., 2004</a>

865), a potent synthetic cannabinoid devoid of vasorelaxant properties (<a href="#R1251" rid="R1251" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919665">

866Wagner et al., 1999</a>

867). Furthermore, it couples to G<sub>

86812</sub>

869/G<sub>

87013</sub>

871 and <em>

872&#x003c1;</em>

873 kinase, which have been linked to vasoconstrictor rather than vasodilator responses. This suggests that GPR-55 is not the abnormal cannabidiol-sensitive endothelial receptor. Mice deficient in GPR-55 will help in defining the biological functions of this novel cannabinoid-sensitive receptor.</p>

874<p id="P9">

875Anandamide has been found to be an agonist ligand for the TRPV<sub>

8761</sub>

877 ion channel, although its affinity in the low micromolar range is lower than its affinity for CB<sub>

8781</sub>

879 receptors (reviewed by <a href="#R1211" rid="R1211" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919661">

880van der Stelt and Di Marzo, 2004</a>

881). An in vitro study in rat mesenteric arteries provided evidence that the endothelium-independent component of anandamide-induced vasodilation is mediated via activation of capsaicin-sensitive TRPV<sub>

8821</sub>

883 in sensory nerve terminals. This triggers the release of CGRP, which then dilates the artery by activation of calcitonin gene-related peptide receptors on the vascular smooth muscle (<a href="#R1332" rid="R1332" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919283">

884Zygmunt et al., 1999</a>

885). However, this mechanism does not contribute to the in vivo hypotensive action of anandamide, which is similar in wild-type and TRPV<sub>

8861</sub>

887<sup>

888&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

889 mice (<a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919717">

890Pacher et al., 2004</a>

891).</p>

892<p id="P10">

893Both CB<sub>

8941</sub>

895 and CB<sub>

8962</sub>

897 receptors are G protein-coupled receptors. Surprisingly, they share little sequence homology, only 44% at the protein level or 68% in the transmembrane domains, which are thought to contain the binding sites for cannabinoids (<a href="#R712" rid="R712" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653382">

898Lutz, 2002</a>

899). Despite this, THC and most synthetic cannabinoids have similar affinities for the two receptors, and only recently did synthetic ligands that discriminate between CB<sub>

9001</sub>

901 and CB<sub>

9022</sub>

903 receptors emerge. These include agonists as well as antagonists, as listed in <a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F2/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F2" rid-ob="ob-F2" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F2">

904<span>

905Fig. 2</span>

906</a>

907. The development of potent and highly selective CB<sub>

9081</sub>

909 and CB<sub>

9102</sub>

911 receptor antagonists (<a href="#R1019" rid="R1019" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919820">

912Rinaldi-Carmona et al., 1994</a>

913, <a href="#R1020" rid="R1020" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918969">

9141998</a>

915) is particularly noteworthy as it provided critically important tools to explore the physiological functions of endocannabinoids. For example, as it will be discussed later in this review, the appetite-reducing effects of the CB<sub>

9161</sub>

917 antagonist SR141716 in various rodent models was the first sign to suggest that endocannabinoids may be tonically active orexigenic agents, representing the endogenous counterpart of the &#x0201c;munchies&#x0201d; caused by marijuana smoking.</p>

918<!--fig ft0-->

919<!--fig mode=article f1-->

920<div class="fig iconblock whole_rhythm" id="F2" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F2">

921<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F2/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F2" rid-ob="ob-F2">

922<!--fig/graphic|fig/alternatives/graphic mode="anchored" m1-->

923<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462223072" class="figure">

924<img loading="lazy" class="fig-image" alt="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f2.jpg" title="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f2.jpg" src="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/bin/nihms38123f2.jpg" />

925</div>

926<div id="largeobj_idm139779462223072" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

927<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F2/?report=objectonly">

928Open in a separate window</a>

929</div>

930</a>

931<div class="icnblk_cntnt" id="lgnd_F2">

932<div>

933<a class="figpopup" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F2/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F2" rid-ob="ob-F2">

934Fig. 2</a>

935</div>

936<!--caption a7-->

937<div class="caption">

938<p id="__p3">

939Selective agonists (A) and antagonists (B) of CB<sub>

9401</sub>

941 and CB<sub>

9422</sub>

943 receptors.</p>

944</div>

945</div>

946</div>

947<p id="P11" class="p p-last">

948However, these antagonists, as well as most of the other CB<sub>

9491</sub>

950 and CB<sub>

9512</sub>

952 antagonists developed to date, have inverse agonist properties (<a href="#R110" rid="R110" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919591">

953Bouaboula et al., 1997</a>

954, <a href="#R109" rid="R109" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918738">

9551999</a>

956), so their effects do not necessarily reflect reversal of the tonic action of an endocannabinoid. For this reason, the development of CB<sub>

9571</sub>

958 and CB<sub>

9592</sub>

960 receptor-deficient mouse strains (<a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653486">

961Ledent et al., 1999</a>

962; <a href="#R1325" rid="R1325" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918955">

963Zimmer et al., 1999</a>

964; <a href="#R128" rid="R128" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919706">

965Buckley et al., 2000</a>

966; <a href="#R755" rid="R755" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919197">

967Marsicano et al., 2002b</a>

968; <a href="#R1024" rid="R1024" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920279">

969Robbe et al., 2002</a>

970) was similarly important, as the use of these animals in combination with receptor antagonists can reinforce the putative regulatory roles of endocannabinoids. More recently, the development of conditional mutant mice that lack the expression of CB<sub>

9711</sub>

972 receptors only in certain types of neurons represents another milestone, as it allows linking of specific neuronal populations with a well-defined cannabinoid-modulated behavior (<a href="#R753" rid="R753" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653378">

973Marsicano et al., 2003</a>

974).</p>

975</div>

976<div id="S4" class="sec">

977<h3 id="S4title">

978B. Cannabinoid Receptor Signaling</h3>

979<p id="P12" class="p p-first">

980CB<sub>

9811</sub>

982 and CB<sub>

9832</sub>

984 receptors couple primarily to the G<sub>

985i/o</sub>

986 subtypes of G protein, and their signaling is remarkably complex. Although coupling to adenylate cyclase through G<sub>

987i/o</sub>

988 usually results in inhibition of cyclase activity through the release of G<sub>

989i</sub>

990<em>

991<sub>

992&#x003b1;</sub>

993</em>

994 isoforms, cannabinoids can also stimulate isoforms 2, 4, or 7 of adenylate cyclase via the release of <em>

995&#x003b2;&#x003b3;</em>

996 subunits (<a href="#R1009" rid="R1009" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920180">

997Rhee et al., 1998</a>

998). Activation of adenylate cyclase also occurs when CB<sub>

9991</sub>

1000 and dopamine D<sub>

10012</sub>

1002 receptors are simultaneously activated (<a href="#R400" rid="R400" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637196">

1003Glass and Felder, 1997</a>

1004), probably as a result of heterodimerization of these two types of receptors (<a href="#R592" rid="R592" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919403">

1005Kearn et al., 2005</a>

1006). Although direct evidence for the coupling of CB<sub>

10071</sub>

1008 receptors to G<sub>

1009q/11</sub>

1010 had until recently been lacking (<a href="#R525" rid="R525" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919955">

1011Howlett, 2004</a>

1012), the agonist WIN 55,212-2, but not other cannabinoids, was recently reported to increase intracellular calcium in cultured hippocampal neurons and in human embryonic kidney 293 cells via coupling to G<sub>

1013q/11</sub>

1014 proteins (<a href="#R661" rid="R661" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919355">

1015Lauckner et al., 2005</a>

1016). Receptor dimerization may facilitate such coupling, which may account for CB<sub>

10171</sub>

1018-mediated mobilization of intracellular calcium in NG108-15 neuroblastoma glioma cells (<a href="#R1148" rid="R1148" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919284">

1019Sugiura et al., 1999</a>

1020). Cannabinoids can also inhibit different types of calcium channels (<a href="#R727" rid="R727" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919735">

1021Mackie and Hille, 1992</a>

1022; <a href="#R372" rid="R372" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919232">

1023Gebremedhin et al., 1999</a>

1024) and activate certain potassium channels (<a href="#R728" rid="R728" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637207">

1025Mackie et al., 1995</a>

1026) via G protein <em>

1027&#x003b2;&#x003b3;</em>

1028 subunits (<a href="#R538" rid="R538" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919818">

1029Ikeda, 1996</a>

1030). Cannabinoids can activate members of all three families of multifunctional mitogen-activated protein kinases, including p44/42 MAP kinase (<a href="#R1275" rid="R1275" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918682">

1031Wartmann et al., 1995</a>

1032; <a href="#R244" rid="R244" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920260">

1033Davis et al., 2003</a>

1034), p38 kinase (<a href="#R694" rid="R694" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919445">

1035Liu et al., 2000</a>

1036; <a href="#R258" rid="R258" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919334">

1037Derkinderen et al., 2001</a>

1038), and JUN-terminal kinase (<a href="#R694" rid="R694" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920303">

1039Liu et al., 2000</a>

1040; <a href="#R1048" rid="R1048" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919648">

1041Rueda et al., 2000</a>

1042) and activate the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase pathway (<a href="#R407" rid="R407" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653498">

1043G&#x000f3;mez Del Pulgar et al., 2002a</a>

1044). These effects could be via G protein activation (<a href="#R356" rid="R356" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919585">

1045Galve-Roperh et al., 2002</a>

1046; <a href="#R244" rid="R244" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919760">

1047Davis et al., 2003</a>

1048) or pathways independent of G proteins via other adaptor proteins (<a href="#R1059" rid="R1059" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653431">

1049S&#x000e1;nchez et al., 2001b</a>

1050). Another G protein-independent pathway activated by cannabinoids involves G protein-coupled receptor kinase-3 and <em>

1051&#x003b2;</em>

1052-arrestin-2, which are required for desensitization, but not for internalization, of CB<sub>

10531</sub>

1054 receptors, and the related development of tolerance (<a href="#R563" rid="R563" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637233">

1055Jin et al., 1999</a>

1056). Cannabinoids can also regulate the activity of phosphatases, as ex-emplified the CB<sub>

10571</sub>

1058-mediated regulation of calcineurin (protein phosphatase 2b) (<a href="#R152" rid="R152" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920097">

1059Cannich et al., 2004</a>

1060) or the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphatase 1, which plays an important role in the anti-inflammatory action of anandamide (<a href="#R293" rid="R293" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920232">

1061Eljaschewitsch et al., 2006</a>

1062).</p>

1063<p id="P13">

1064Different structural classes of cannabinoid receptor agonists have the unique ability to activate different signaling cascades which, in turn, influences agonist efficacy. Using an in situ receptor/G protein reconstitution technique, CB<sub>

10651</sub>

1066 receptors were found to efficiently couple and activate both G<sub>

1067i</sub>

1068 and G<sub>

1069o</sub>

1070, whereas CB<sub>

10712</sub>

1072 receptors only activated G<sub>

1073o</sub>

1074. Furthermore, the efficacy of a given agonist was different whether CB<sub>

10751</sub>

1076 receptors coupled to G<sub>

1077i</sub>

1078 or G<sub>

1079o</sub>

1080, demonstrating agonist-selective G protein signaling (<a href="#R401" rid="R401" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919694">

1081Glass and Northup, 1999</a>

1082). <a href="#R985" rid="R985" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920182">

1083Prather et al. (2000)</a>

1084 found that the aminoalkylindol agonist WIN 55,212-2 activated different G<sub>

1085i</sub>

1086<em>

1087<sub>

1088&#x003b1;</sub>

1089</em>

1090 subunits with markedly different potencies. Even more striking is the recent finding that demonstrates cannabinoid agonist-selective activation of different G<sub>

1091i</sub>

1092<em>

1093<sub>

1094&#x003b1;</sub>

1095</em>

1096 subunits (<a href="#R853" rid="R853" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920309">

1097Mukhopadhyay and Howlett, 2005</a>

1098). A possible practical implication of such findings is that unique therapeutic profiles may be achieved through the use of different agonists for the same receptor, and such profiles may differ from one target tissue to the other, depending on the pattern of G protein subunit expression.</p>

1099<p id="P14">

1100At least part of this agonist selectivity in G protein activation may be related to the existence of distinct binding sites on CB<sub>

11011</sub>

1102 receptors for different classes of ligands, as documented by site-directed mutagenesis and molecular modeling studies (see <a href="#R1006" rid="R1006" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919254">

1103Reggio, 2003</a>

1104). These studies indicate that a K3.28A mutation in the third transmembrane domain caused a more than 1000-fold loss in affinity and loss of efficacy for anandamide and nonclassic cannabinoids, without affecting the affinity for WIN 55,212-2 (<a href="#R1125" rid="R1125" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918846">

1105Song and Bonner, 1996</a>

1106). In contrast, mutations at different sites in the third, fifth, and sixth transmembrane helices (F3.36A, W5.43A, and W6.48A) affected the binding of WIN 55,212-2 and SR141716, but not anandamide (<a href="#R788" rid="R788" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918927">

1107McAllister et al., 2003</a>

1108).</p>

1109<p id="P15" class="p p-last">

1110Another important feature of cannabinoid signaling in the brain is the lack of correlation between the density of CB<sub>

11111</sub>

1112 receptors in a given brain region and the efficiency of receptor coupling, as determined by GTP<em>

1113&#x003b3;</em>

1114S binding (<a href="#R119" rid="R119" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920225">

1115Breivogel et al., 1997</a>

1116), which may explain why functionally important responses can be triggered in brain regions with very sparse CB<sub>

11171</sub>

1118 receptor expression, such as the brainstem (<a href="#R992" rid="R992" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653464">

1119Rademacher et al., 2003</a>

1120) or the hypothalamus (<a href="#R554" rid="R554" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919857">

1121Jamshidi and Taylor, 2001</a>

1122). <a href="#R1085" rid="R1085" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920174">

1123Selley et al. (2001)</a>

1124 have shown that the reduction in CB<sub>

11251</sub>

1126 receptor density in CB<sub>

11271</sub>

1128 heterozygote mice was compensated for by an increase in receptor/G protein coupling efficiency for some, but not other, agonists. Although the underlying mechanisms for such compensation are not clear, differences in the degree of receptor multimerization (<a href="#R724" rid="R724" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918960">

1129Mackie, 2005</a>

1130), or changes in signal amplification are possibilities. Recent observations indicate that a considerable proportion of the psychomotor effect of cannabinoids can be accounted for by a signaling cascade in striatal projection neurons involving protein kinase A-dependent phosphorylation of DARPP-32, achieved via modulation of dopamine D<sub>

11312</sub>

1132 and adenosine A<sub>

11332A</sub>

1134 transmission (<a href="#R26" rid="R26" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637248">

1135Andersson et al., 2005</a>

1136). This represents a unique form of amplification of CB<sub>

11371</sub>

1138 signaling, as phosphorylation of DARPP-32 at Thr-34 amplifies downstream signaling via inhibition of protein phosphatase-1 (<a href="#R429" rid="R429" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653379">

1139Greengard, 2001</a>

1140). It would be interesting to test whether the efficiency of CB<sub>

11411</sub>

1142 coupling to DARPP-32 is affected by cellular receptor density.</p>

1143</div>

1144<div id="S5" class="sec sec-last">

1145<h3 id="S5title">

1146C. Endocannabinoids</h3>

1147<p id="P16" class="p p-first">

1148The existence of specific receptors in mammalian cells that recognize a plant-derived substance rekindled the question raised two decades earlier, after brain receptors for morphine had been first described, i.e., is there an endogenous ligand? A positive answer was provided in 1992 by the report by Devane et al. describing the isolation from porcine brain of the lipid arachidonoyl ethanolamide, named anandamide, which bound to the brain cannabinoid receptor with reasonably high affinity and mimicked the behavioral actions of THC when injected into rodents (<a href="#R264" rid="R264" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653365">

1149Devane et al., 1992</a>

1150). Three years later a second endocannabinoid, 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG), was discovered independently by <a href="#R805" rid="R805" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919251">

1151Mechoulam et al. (1995)</a>

1152 and <a href="#R1149" rid="R1149" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918891">

1153Sugiura et al. (1995)</a>

1154. Since then, a number of related endogenous lipids with endocannabinoid-like activity have been reported (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F1">

1155<span>

1156Fig. 1c</span>

1157</a>

1158), but follow-up studies about biosynthesis, cellular transport, metabolism, and biological function have focused on anandamide and 2-AG, with much less information available about the other compounds with endocannabinoid-like properties. The biochemical aspects of endocannabinoids have been recently reviewed by <a href="#R93" rid="R93" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919413">

1159Bisogno et al. (2005)</a>

1160.</p>

1161<p id="P17">

1162Anandamide is a partial or full agonist of CB<sub>

11631</sub>

1164 receptors, depending on the tissue and biological response measured. Although it also binds CB<sub>

11652</sub>

1166 receptors, it has very low efficacy and may act as an antagonist (<a href="#R412" rid="R412" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920318">

1167Gonsiorek et al., 2000</a>

1168). The in vivo biosynthesis of anandamide (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F4/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F4" rid-ob="ob-F4" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F4">

1169<span>

1170Fig. 4</span>

1171</a>

1172) is believed to occur through the enzymatic hydrolysis catalyzed by a phospholipase D of a membrane lipid precursor, <em>

1173N</em>

1174-arachidonoyl phosphatidylethanolamide (NAPE) (<a href="#R1077" rid="R1077" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920342">

1175Schmid et al., 1983</a>

1176), which itself is generated by the enzymatic transfer of arachidonic acid in the <em>

1177sn</em>

1178-1 position in phosphatidylcholine to the amide group of PE (<a href="#R273" rid="R273" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918767">

1179Di Marzo et al., 1994</a>

1180; <a href="#R143" rid="R143" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637238">

1181Cadas et al., 1997</a>

1182). Although a specific transacylase for the latter reaction has not yet been identified, a NAPE-specific PLD has recently been cloned (<a href="#R906" rid="R906" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919594">

1183Okamoto et al., 2004</a>

1184). It is not yet known, however, whether NAPE-PLD is obligatory for the biosynthesis of anandamide, which could make it an attractive target of drug therapy when reduction of tissue anandamide would be of benefit. Indeed, there may be parallel pathways for the generation of anandamide from NAPE. A secretory PLA<sub>

11852</sub>

1186 that can catalyze the hydrolysis of <em>

1187N</em>

1188-acyl-PE to <em>

1189N</em>

1190-acyl-lysoPE, which is then acted on by a lysoPLD to generate <em>

1191N</em>

1192-acyl-ethanolamides, including anandamide, was recently identified in the stomach (<a href="#R1153" rid="R1153" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918813">

1193Sun et al., 2004</a>

1194). An alternative parallel pathway has been identified in our laboratory in RAW246.7 macrophages. This involves hydrolysis of NAPE to phosphoanandamide by a PLC, followed by dephosphorylation through a phosphatase (<a href="#R696" rid="R696" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919286">

1195Liu et al., 2006</a>

1196). This latter pathway rather than PLD is the target of regulation by bacterial endotoxin, which increases anandamide synthesis in macrophages (<a href="#R1221" rid="R1221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919307">

1197Varga et al., 1998</a>

1198; <a href="#R693" rid="R693" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920316">

1199Liu et al., 2003a</a>

1200). The existence of this pathway may also account for the recent finding that anandamide tissue levels are unchanged in NAPE-PLD knockout compared with wild-type mice (<a href="#R678" rid="R678" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920133">

1201Leung et al., 2006</a>

1202).</p>

1203<!--fig ft0-->

1204<!--fig mode=article f1-->

1205<div class="fig iconblock whole_rhythm" id="F4" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F4">

1206<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F4/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F4" rid-ob="ob-F4">

1207<!--fig/graphic|fig/alternatives/graphic mode="anchored" m1-->

1208<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462215168" class="figure">

1209<a class="inline_block ts_canvas" href="/core/lw/2.0/html/tileshop_pmc/tileshop_pmc_inline.html?title=Click%20on%20image%20to%20zoom&amp;p=PMC3&amp;id=2241751_nihms38123f4.jpg" target="tileshopwindow" rel="noopener">

1210<div class="ts_bar small" title="Click on image to zoom">

1211</div>

1212<img loading="lazy" alt="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f4.jpg" title="Click on image to zoom" class="tileshop" src="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/bin/nihms38123f4.jpg" />

1213</a>

1214</div>

1215<div id="largeobj_idm139779462215168" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

1216<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F4/?report=objectonly">

1217Open in a separate window</a>

1218</div>

1219</a>

1220<div class="icnblk_cntnt" id="lgnd_F4">

1221<div>

1222<a class="figpopup" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F4/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F4" rid-ob="ob-F4">

1223Fig. 4</a>

1224</div>

1225<!--caption a7-->

1226<div class="caption">

1227<p id="__p5">

1228Schematic representation of the endocannabinoid system in pre- and postsynaptic neurons. The presynaptic terminal is located in the top, whereas the postsynaptic neuron is located in the bottom. EMT, endocannabinoid membrane transporter; MAGL, monoacylglyceride lipase; DAGL, DAG lipase; AEA, anandamide; NArPE, <em>

1229N</em>

1230-arachidonyl phosphatidylethanolamine; NAT, <em>

1231N</em>

1232-acyltransferase.</p>

1233</div>

1234</div>

1235</div>

1236<p id="P18">

12372-AG is generated from diacylglycerol (DAG) by DAG lipase selective for the <em>

1238sn</em>

1239-1 position (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F4/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F4" rid-ob="ob-F4" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F4">

1240<span>

1241Fig. 4</span>

1242</a>

1243). DAG, an intracellular second messenger that activates protein kinase C, can be generated from phosphoinositides by a phosphoinositide-specific PLC or from phosphatidic acid by phosphatidic acid phosphohydrolase (<a href="#R93" rid="R93" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919142">

1244Bisogno et al., 2005</a>

1245). Two DAG lipase isozymes, <em>

1246&#x003b1;</em>

1247 and <em>

1248&#x003b2;</em>

1249, have been cloned (<a href="#R92" rid="R92" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919967">

1250Bisogno et al., 2003</a>

1251). In the adult brain they are localized in the postsynaptic plasma membrane, in line with their putative role in generating 2-AG involved in retrograde transmission.</p>

1252<p id="P19">

1253Basal levels of 2-AG in the brain are approximately 2 orders of magnitude higher than the levels of anandamide. Despite this, stimulus-induced release resulting in detectable extracellular levels could be demonstrated only for anandamide and not for 2-AG in an in vivo microdialysis study (<a href="#R391" rid="R391" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919145">

1254Giuffrida et al., 1999</a>

1255). This finding illustrates that, despite growing interest in endocannabinoids and their roles as retrograde neurotransmitters (<a href="#R1295" rid="R1295" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653510">

1256Wilson and Nicoll, 2002</a>

1257; Chevaleyre et al., 2006), the mechanism of their release is not well understood. Like prostanoids, endocannabinoids are not stored but generated on demand in response to a depolarization-induced rise in intracellular calcium or activation of various metabotropic receptors (<a href="#R1223" rid="R1223" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637187">

1258Varma et al., 2001</a>

1259; <a href="#R605" rid="R605" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637222">

1260Kim et al., 2002</a>

1261; <a href="#R1300" rid="R1300" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918815">

1262Witting et al., 2004</a>

1263; <a href="#R266" rid="R266" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920359">

1264Di et al., 2005a</a>

1265,<a href="#R268" rid="R268" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920254">

1266b</a>

1267). A putative membrane endocannabinoid transporter involved in the cellular uptake of endocannabinoids (see below) may also be involved in their release. This is suggested by the ability of a transport inhibitor to prevent the release of intracellularly applied anandamide (<a href="#R718" rid="R718" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920248">

1268Maccarrone et al., 2000a</a>

1269; <a href="#R381" rid="R381" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918946">

1270Gerdeman et al., 2002</a>

1271).</p>

1272<p id="P20">

1273Anandamide present in the extracellular space is accumulated by neurons and other cells by facilitated diffusion. This process is driven by its transmembrane concentration gradient, is saturable and temperature-dependent, and does not require ATP or sodium ions. Most importantly for the topic of the present review, anandamide uptake is selectively inhibited by a variety of structural analogs, which suggests the existence of a saturable cellular component involved in anandamide transport (<a href="#R63" rid="R63" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653391">

1274Beltramo et al., 1997</a>

1275; <a href="#R94" rid="R94" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919341">

1276Bisogno et al., 1997</a>

1277; <a href="#R499" rid="R499" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919781">

1278Hillard and Jarrahian, 2000</a>

1279; <a href="#R718" rid="R718" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918739">

1280Maccarrone et al., 2000a</a>

1281). However, a specific anandamide transporter protein has yet to be cloned, and it has been proposed that intracellular degradation of anandamide by fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH) is sufficient to account for anandamide uptake in long incubation periods (<a href="#R393" rid="R393" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920148">

1282Glaser et al., 2003</a>

1283). Studies with cells isolated from FAAH<sup>

1284+/+</sup>

1285 and FAAH<sup>

1286&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1287 mice did not resolve this issue, as the absence of FAAH was found not to affect anandamide uptake (<a href="#R314" rid="R314" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918733">

1288Fegley et al., 2004</a>

1289) or to reduce it substantially (<a href="#R909" rid="R909" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919544">

1290Ortega-Gutierrez et al., 2004</a>

1291), albeit under different experimental conditions. Nevertheless, a FAAH-independent component of anandamide uptake, inhibited by the compound UCM707, was detected in the latter study, supporting the notion of a protein other than FAAH being involved. This notion is also supported by the emergence of a number of synthetic transport inhibitors, the potencies of which to inhibit anandamide uptake does not correlate with their affinities for CB<sub>

12921</sub>

1293, CB<sub>

12942</sub>

1295, or TRPV<sub>

12961</sub>

1297 receptors or their potencies to inhibit FAAH (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F3/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F3" rid-ob="ob-F3" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F3">

1298<span>

1299Fig. 3</span>

1300</a>

1301). However, in view of the important role of FAAH in generating the transmembrane concentration gradient for anandamide, the possibility that a noncatalytic region of FAAH or a FAAH-associated protein may act as anandamide transporter cannot be excluded. Interestingly, the elucidation of the crystal structure of FAAH revealed several channel-like regions in the enzyme, granting it simultaneous access to both the cytosolic and membrane domains (<a href="#R112" rid="R112" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653459">

1302Bracey et al., 2002</a>

1303). Against this possibility, however, is the recent report that the novel, high affinity anandamide transport inhibitor LY2318912 binds with similar <em>

1304K</em>

1305<sub>

1306d</sub>

1307 and <em>

1308b</em>

1309<sub>

1310max</sub>

1311 values to membranes from HeLa cells devoid of FAAH or transfected with FAAH, pointing to a binding site independent of the FAAH molecule (<a href="#R848" rid="R848" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918872">

1312Moore et al., 2005</a>

1313). Arguments for and against the existence of a bidirectional anandamide transporter have been recently reviewed (<a href="#R500" rid="R500" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919864">

1314Hillard and Jarrahian, 2003</a>

1315; <a href="#R333" rid="R333" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919467">

1316Fowler et al., 2004</a>

1317; <a href="#R792" rid="R792" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919918">

1318Mc-Farland and Barker, 2004</a>

1319; <a href="#R394" rid="R394" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919404">

1320Glaser et al., 2005</a>

1321).</p>

1322<!--fig ft0-->

1323<!--fig mode=article f1-->

1324<div class="fig iconblock whole_rhythm" id="F3" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F3">

1325<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F3/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F3" rid-ob="ob-F3">

1326<!--fig/graphic|fig/alternatives/graphic mode="anchored" m1-->

1327<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462219600" class="figure">

1328<a class="inline_block ts_canvas" href="/core/lw/2.0/html/tileshop_pmc/tileshop_pmc_inline.html?title=Click%20on%20image%20to%20zoom&amp;p=PMC3&amp;id=2241751_nihms38123f3.jpg" target="tileshopwindow" rel="noopener">

1329<div class="ts_bar small" title="Click on image to zoom">

1330</div>

1331<img loading="lazy" alt="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f3.jpg" title="Click on image to zoom" class="tileshop" src="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/bin/nihms38123f3.jpg" />

1332</a>

1333</div>

1334<div id="largeobj_idm139779462219600" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

1335<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F3/?report=objectonly">

1336Open in a separate window</a>

1337</div>

1338</a>

1339<div class="icnblk_cntnt" id="lgnd_F3">

1340<div>

1341<a class="figpopup" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F3/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F3" rid-ob="ob-F3">

1342Fig. 3</a>

1343</div>

1344<!--caption a7-->

1345<div class="caption">

1346<p id="__p4">

1347The structure and pharmacological specificity of inhibitors of FAAH and of endocannabinoid membrane transport.</p>

1348</div>

1349</div>

1350</div>

1351<p id="P21">

1352In some in vivo studies, treatment with transport inhibitors unmasked cannabinoid-like tonic effects on pain sensitivity, anxiety-like behaviors, locomotor activity, and muscle spasticity, which is an indication of the potential therapeutic usefulness of such compounds (<a href="#R848" rid="R848" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919829">

1353Moore et al., 2005</a>

1354; <a href="#R108" rid="R108" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488956">

1355Bortolato et al., 2006</a>

1356; <a href="#R652" rid="R652" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919795">

1357La Rana et al., 2006</a>

1358). Similar and more pronounced effects have been reported in response to treatment with FAAH inhibitors, as discussed below.</p>

1359<p id="P22">

1360In contrast to the unsettled status of anandamide transport and a putative transporter protein, the unique role of FAAH in the in vivo degradation of anandamide has been extensively documented (reviewed in <a href="#R800" rid="R800" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919899">

1361McKinney and Cravatt, 2005</a>

1362). Initial evidence for a membrane-associated enzyme in the liver that hydrolyzes <em>

1363N</em>

1364-<em>

1365N</em>

1366-acyl ethanolamides (<a href="#R1078" rid="R1078" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919715">

1367Schmid et al., 1985</a>

1368) was followed by the cloning of FAAH (<a href="#R223" rid="R223" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920402">

1369Cravatt et al., 1996</a>

1370) and the identification of its crystal structure in complex with an active site-directed inhibitor (<a href="#R112" rid="R112" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653493">

1371Bracey et al., 2002</a>

1372). The unique role of FAAH in terminating signaling by anandamide was indicated by the phenotype of FAAH knockout mice, which displayed 10 to 15 times elevated levels of anandamide across the brain, supersensitivity to the actions of exogenous anandamide, and the appearance of tonic signaling by endogenous anandamide, resulting in CB<sub>

13731</sub>

1374 receptor-mediated hypoalgesia (<a href="#R222" rid="R222" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920140">

1375Cravatt et al., 2001</a>

1376; <a href="#R688" rid="R688" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918720">

1377Lichtman et al., 2004b</a>

1378), reduced anxiety (<a href="#R589" rid="R589" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919905">

1379Kathuria et al., 2003</a>

1380), antidepressant activity (Gobbi et al., 2006), and lowering of blood pressure in different models of experimental hypertension (<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653377">

1381B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

1382). <a href="#R225" rid="R225" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920328">

1383Cravatt et al. (2004)</a>

1384 were able to resolve the relative roles of central versus peripheral fatty acid amides by generating mice deficient in FAAH in peripheral tissues only. These mice did not display the hypoalgesia observed in mice with global deficiency in FAAH, but had a similar anti-inflammatory phenotype, indicating that the latter was mediated by elevated fatty acid amides in peripheral tissues (<a href="#R225" rid="R225" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919225">

1385Cravatt et al., 2004</a>

1386). Interestingly, another amidohydrolase catalyzing the same reaction as FAAH but at acidic pH was recently identified and cloned (<a href="#R1192" rid="R1192" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919415">

1387Tsuboi et al., 2005</a>

1388). This lysosomal enzyme is structurally unrelated to FAAH and is widely distributed in tissues, with highest levels in the lung, and has been recently shown to contribute to the physiological degradation of anandamide in macrophages but not in the brain (<a href="#R1154" rid="R1154" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919028">

1389Sun et al., 2005</a>

1390).</p>

1391<p id="P23">

1392Although 2-AG is also hydrolyzed by FAAH under in vitro conditions (<a href="#R417" rid="R417" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920092">

1393Goparaju et al., 1998</a>

1394; <a href="#R651" rid="R651" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920078">

1395Lang et al., 1999</a>

1396), in vivo it is not a substrate of FAAH, as indicated by the unchanged brain levels of 2-AG in wild-type and FAAH<sup>

1397&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1398 mice (<a href="#R914" rid="R914" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919986">

1399Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005a</a>

1400). 2-AG is hydrolyzed in vivo by a monoacylglyceride lipase (MGL) (<a href="#R278" rid="R278" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919054">

1401Dinh et al., 2002a</a>

1402,<a href="#R279" rid="R279" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919691">

1403b</a>

1404; <a href="#R1055" rid="R1055" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919728">

1405Saario et al., 2004</a>

1406). A study of the ultrastructural distribution of FAAH and MGL revealed that in the hippocampus, cerebellum, and amygdala, FAAH is located postsynaptically, whereas MGL is localized in presynaptic axon terminals, including terminals of GABAergic interneurons (<a href="#R445" rid="R445" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920401">

1407Gulyas et al., 2004</a>

1408). Correspondingly, functional studies in hippocampus indicate that depolarization-induced suppression of inhibition (DSI) is unaffected by pharmacological blockade of FAAH (<a href="#R604" rid="R604" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920183">

1409Kim and Alger, 2004</a>

1410), but it is potentiated by blocking MGL (<a href="#R604" rid="R604" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919094">

1411Kim and Alger, 2004</a>

1412; <a href="#R734" rid="R734" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918817">

1413Makara et al., 2005</a>

1414), in agreement with an earlier study implicating 2-AG rather than anandamide in synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus (<a href="#R1139" rid="R1139" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919173">

1415Stella et al., 1997</a>

1416). Further evidence supporting the role of 2-AG as the retrograde transmitter involved in synaptic plasticity is the preferential postsynaptic distribution of the major 2-AG biosynthetic enzyme, diacylglycerol lipase <em>

1417&#x003b1;</em>

1418, in hippocampus and cerebellum (Katona et al., 2006; <a href="#R1309" rid="R1309" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637198">

1419Yoshida et al., 2006</a>

1420).</p>

1421<p id="P24" class="p p-last">

1422However, the behavioral consequences of DSI and its modulation remain unclear: selective knockout of CB<sub>

14231</sub>

1424 receptors from GABAergic interneurons was found to abolish DSI and long-term depression (LTD) of inhibitory synapses, whereas the classic behavioral responses to THC remained unaffected in these animals (<a href="#R844" rid="R844" class=" bibr popnode">

1425Monory et al., 2005</a>

1426). Therefore, at this point it is difficult to predict the potential therapeutic usefulness of selective MGL inhibitors.</p>

1427</div>

1428</div>

1429<div id="S6" class="tsec sec">

1430<h2 class="head no_bottom_margin" id="S6title">

1431III. The Endocannabinoid System as Therapeutic Target in Pathophysiological Conditions</h2>

1432<div id="S7" class="sec sec-first">

1433<h3 id="S7title">

1434A. Diseases of Energy Metabolism</h3>

1435<div id="S8" class="sec sec-first">

1436<p>

1437</p>

1438<h4 id="S8title" class="inline">

14391. Endocannabinoids and Appetite Regulation </h4>

1440<p id="P25" class="p p-first">

1441It has been known since antiquity that use of cannabis in its various forms increases appetite, particularly for palatable foods, and can also result in significant weight gain (<a href="#R281" rid="R281" class=" bibr popnode">

1442Donovan, 1845</a>

1443; <a href="#R75" rid="R75" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920106">

1444Berry and Mechoulam, 2002</a>

1445). Following the identification of THC as the main psychoactive principle in marijuana, the appetite-promoting effect of smoked marijuana could be attributed to THC even before the identification of specific cannabinoid receptors (<a href="#R516" rid="R516" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653497">

1446Hollister, 1971</a>

1447; <a href="#R428" rid="R428" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919296">

1448Greenberg et al., 1976</a>

1449). Animal studies also documented the ability of THC to promote food intake, although consistent effects were only seen with relatively low doses (<a href="#R3" rid="R3" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919079">

1450Abel, 1975</a>

1451), most likely because the significant sedation and motor impairment seen with higher doses interferes with the animals&#x02019; ability to initiate feeding. Variability in the observed changes in THC-induced food intake may also relate to the feeding state of the animal, the orexigenic effect being optimal in presatiated animals with low basal levels of food intake (<a href="#R1289" rid="R1289" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919712">

1452Williams et al., 1998</a>

1453). After the discovery of specific cannabinoid receptors and the introduction of selective antagonists, the increase in food intake caused by THC could be linked to CB<sub>

14541</sub>

1455 receptors, as it was blocked by the selective CB<sub>

14561</sub>

1457 antagonist SR141716, but not by the CB<sub>

14582</sub>

1459 antagonist SR144528 (<a href="#R1288" rid="R1288" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653415">

1460Williams and Kirkham, 2002</a>

1461).</p>

1462<p id="P26">

1463The discovery of endocannabinoids has raised the question of their potential involvement in the physiological control of appetite and energy metabolism. This subject has been the topic of a number of recent reviews (<a href="#R276" rid="R276" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919427">

1464Di Marzo and Matias, 2005</a>

1465; <a href="#R608" rid="R608" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920212">

1466Kirkham, 2005</a>

1467; <a href="#R1090" rid="R1090" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653409">

1468Sharkey and Pittman, 2005</a>

1469; <a href="#R930" rid="R930" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918895">

1470Pagotto et al., 2006</a>

1471), and only a brief summary is provided here. The first indication of a role for endocannabinoids in appetite control was the documented ability of low doses of anandamide to increase food intake, when administered either systemically (<a href="#R1287" rid="R1287" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919058">

1472Williams and Kirkham, 1999</a>

1473; <a href="#R468" rid="R468" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919608">

1474Hao et al., 2000</a>

1475) or into the ventromedial hypothalamus (<a href="#R554" rid="R554" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919138">

1476Jamshidi and Taylor, 2001</a>

1477), and this effect could be attributed to stimulation of CB<sub>

14781</sub>

1479 receptors (<a href="#R1287" rid="R1287" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919446">

1480Williams and Kirkham, 1999</a>

1481). Similar increases in food intake can be elicited by 2-AG administered systemically or into the nucleus accumbens shell region (<a href="#R611" rid="R611" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919928">

1482Kirkham et al., 2002</a>

1483) or into the lateral hypothalamus (<a href="#R609" rid="R609" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653407">

1484Kirkham and Williams, 2001a</a>

1485). Sites for the orexigenic actions of endocannabinoids in both the hypothalamus and the limbic forebrain suggest their involvement in both the homeostatic and hedonic control of eating (<a href="#R471" rid="R471" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919984">

1486Harrold and Williams, 2003</a>

1487; <a href="#R1229" rid="R1229" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919018">

1488Vickers and Kennett, 2005</a>

1489). Interestingly, endocannabinoid activation of hypothalamic centers, such as the paraventricular nucleus, may also occur indirectly via CB<sub>

14901</sub>

1491 receptors on peripheral afferent nerve terminals (<a href="#R410" rid="R410" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637239">

1492Gomez et al., 2002</a>

1493), most likely located in the gastrointestinal tract. Such an &#x0201c;indirect&#x0201d; pathway is compatible with recent findings that CB<sub>

14941</sub>

1495 mRNA is present in cholecystokinin-containing neurons in the nodose ganglion, where CB<sub>

14961</sub>

1497 mRNA expression is up-regulated by fasting and down-regulated by refeeding (<a href="#R131" rid="R131" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637199">

1498Burdyga et al., 2004</a>

1499).</p>

1500<p id="P27">

1501Studies with antagonists provide more direct support for a regulatory function of endocannabinoids on feeding. Treatment of rats with SR141716 and the closely related CB<sub>

15021</sub>

1503 antagonist AM251 reduced food intake under free-feeding (<a href="#R25" rid="R25" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919477">

1504Arnone et al., 1997</a>

1505; <a href="#R194" rid="R194" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919744">

1506Colombo et al., 1998a</a>

1507; <a href="#R1108" rid="R1108" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920312">

1508Simiand et al., 1998</a>

1509; <a href="#R166" rid="R166" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918992">

1510Chambers et al., 2003</a>

1511; <a href="#R1091" rid="R1091" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919125">

1512Shearman et al., 2003</a>

1513) or operant conditions (<a href="#R339" rid="R339" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920266">

1514Freedland et al., 2000</a>

1515; <a href="#R801" rid="R801" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919199">

1516McLaughlin et al., 2003</a>

1517), suggesting antagonism of the tonic orexigenic effect of an endocannabinoid. However, SR141716 and AM251 are inverse agonists (<a href="#R386" rid="R386" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920003">

1518Gifford and Ashby, 1996</a>

1519; <a href="#R110" rid="R110" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918715">

1520Bouaboula et al., 1997</a>

1521), which may be an alternative mechanism by which they reduce food intake.</p>

1522<p id="P28">

1523Definitive evidence for the involvement of endocannabinoids in the control of food intake has been provided through the use of CB<sub>

15241</sub>

1525 receptor-deficient mice. In a study from our laboratory, food-deprived CB<sub>

15261</sub>

1527 knockout mice were found to eat less than their wild-type littermates, and their food intake was unaffected by SR141716 treatment, whereas in wild-type mice SR141716 reduced food intake to the levels seen in the knockout mice (<a href="#R274" rid="R274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919952">

1528Di Marzo et al., 2001b</a>

1529). Similar findings have been subsequently reported by others (<a href="#R1286" rid="R1286" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919275">

1530Wiley et al., 2005</a>

1531). This indicates that part of the hunger-induced increase in food intake is mediated by endocannabinoids acting at CB<sub>

15321</sub>

1533 receptors. CB<sub>

15341</sub>

1535 knockout mice are also resistant to overeating caused by neuropeptide Y (NPY) (<a href="#R976" rid="R976" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919738">

1536Poncelet et al., 2003</a>

1537), and SR141716 inhibits the hyperphagia of leptin-deficient mice even in the absence of temporary food deprivation (<a href="#R274" rid="R274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919753">

1538Di Marzo et al., 2001b</a>

1539). This latter finding suggests that the absence of leptin results in increased endocannabinoid activity. Indeed, hypothalamic levels of endocannabinoids were elevated in leptin-deficient mice and rats and reduced after leptin treatment, suggesting that endocannabinoids are part of the leptin-regulated neural circuitry involved in appetite regulation (<a href="#R274" rid="R274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919803">

1540Di Marzo et al., 2001b</a>

1541). Endogenous leptin may similarly suppress endocannabinoid levels, as indicated by our recent unpublished findings using mice with obesity induced by a high-fat diet, which have elevated plasma leptin levels proportional to their increased fat mass. Anandamide levels were significantly lower in the obese mice compared with their lean controls in the hypothalamus, limbic forebrain, and amygdala, with no difference in the cerebellum. Furthermore, there was a significant inverse correlation between plasma leptin levels and anandamide levels in the above three brain regions involved in appetite control but not in the cerebellum.</p>

1542<p id="P29">

1543A possible hypothalamic site for an interaction between leptin and endocannabinoids is the lateral hypothalamus, where CB<sub>

15441</sub>

1545 receptors are present in orexin-and melanin-concentrating hormone (MCH)-containing neurons (<a href="#R215" rid="R215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919759">

1546Cota et al., 2003</a>
