1547), which also express functional leptin receptors (<a href="#R531" rid="R531" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637234">

1548H&#x000fc;bschle et al., 2001</a>

1549; <a href="#R540" rid="R540" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920373">

1550Iqbal et al., 2001</a>

1551). These neurons project to dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area (<a href="#R308" rid="R308" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920330">

1552Fadel and Deutch, 2002</a>

1553), where they modulate the mesolimbic dopaminergic pathway involved in food reward. Thus, they could also represent a site of integration of hypothalamic and extrahypothalamic structures involved in the orexigenic effect of endocannabinoids. The MCH-containing neurons are tonically inhibited by GABAergic interneurons. <a href="#R564" rid="R564" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918913">

1554Jo et al. (2005)</a>

1555 recently demonstrated that this inhibitory tone can be suppressed by the depolarization-induced release of endocannabinoids from the MCH neurons and their retrograde activation of presynaptic CB<sub>

15561</sub>

1557 receptors on the GABAergic interneurons. The resulting increase in the activity of MCH neurons may contribute to the in vivo appetitive effect of endocannabinoids. Furthermore, this DSI could be blocked by leptin through inhibition of voltage-gated calcium channels in the MCH neurons, whereas it was increased 6-fold in leptin-deficient mice (<a href="#R564" rid="R564" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919844">

1558Jo et al., 2005</a>

1559), mirroring the changes in hypothalamic endocannabinoid content by leptin and leptin deficiency reported earlier (<a href="#R274" rid="R274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919268">

1560Di Marzo et al., 2001b</a>

1561). Another hypothalamic site where a leptin/endocannabinoid interaction may occur is the paraventricular nucleus. At this site, glucocorticoids have been shown to induce endocannabinoid synthesis and endocannabinoid-induced suppression of synaptic excitation via a cAMP-dependent mechanism, and leptin was found to block these effects by a phosphodiesterase 3B-mediated decrease in intracellular cAMP (<a href="#R736" rid="R736" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637237">

1562Malcher-Lopes et al., 2006</a>

1563). These effects may underlie the orexigenic action of glucocorticoids.</p>

1564<p id="P30">

1565Another recent study indicates the importance of lateral hypothalamic orexin neurons in reward-seeking behavior in general (<a href="#R469" rid="R469" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920031">

1566Harris et al., 2005</a>

1567), suggesting that they may also be targets of the effects of endocannabinoids on drug reward (see section III. B.11.). Additionally, cannabinoids can increase the intake of palatable foods by acting at sites in the brainstem (<a href="#R832" rid="R832" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918784">

1568Miller et al., 2004</a>

1569), which also have reciprocal neural connections with forebrain limbic structures (<a href="#R1065" rid="R1065" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918725">

1570Saper, 2002</a>

1571). From a behavioral point of view, cannabinoids are involved in both the appetitive and consummatory aspects of feeding behavior (<a href="#R169" rid="R169" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919847">

1572Chaperon et al., 1998</a>

1573; <a href="#R1182" rid="R1182" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919493">

1574Thornton-Jones et al., 2005</a>

1575), in line with their multiple sites of action in the brain. Such multiple sites of action are also indicated by findings that in THC-naive rats, rimonabant suppressed food-maintained operant responses and metabolic activity in the limbic forebrain, measured by 2-deoxyglucose uptake, whereas in rats made tolerant to THC, an additional metabolic inhibition was detected in the hypothalamus (<a href="#R341" rid="R341" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919630">

1576Freedland et al., 2003</a>

1577). Exposure of rats to a palatable diet containing sucrose and condensed milk resulted in down-regulation of CB<sub>

15781</sub>

1579 receptors in limbic structures involved in the hedonic aspects of feeding, but not in the hypothalamus (<a href="#R470" rid="R470" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919175">

1580Harrold et al., 2002</a>

1581). In the hypothalamus, the very low density of CB<sub>

15821</sub>

1583 receptors is offset by their increased coupling (<a href="#R119" rid="R119" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919162">

1584Breivogel et al., 1997</a>

1585), which may be an alternative target of regulation (<a href="#R46" rid="R46" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919448">

1586Basavarajappa and Hungund, 1999</a>

1587; <a href="#R1267" rid="R1267" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920273">

1588Wang et al., 2003</a>

1589) that needs to be explored.</p>

1590<p id="P31">

1591Within the appetitive neural circuitry, endocannabinoids have been shown to interact with both orexigenic factors such as endogenous opioids, NPY, orexins, and ghrelin, and anorexigenic factors including <em>

1592&#x003b1;</em>

1593-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (<em>

1594&#x003b1;</em>

1595-MSH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and the peptide product of the cocaine and amphetamine-related transcript (CART). Inhibition of food intake by opioid <em>

1596&#x003bc;</em>

1597 receptor antagonists and CB<sub>

15981</sub>

1599 receptor antagonists is supra-additive (<a href="#R610" rid="R610" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653416">

1600Kirkham and Williams, 2001b</a>

1601; <a href="#R1045" rid="R1045" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918783">

1602Rowland et al., 2001</a>

1603; <a href="#R176" rid="R176" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920006">

1604Chen et al., 2004</a>

1605), suggesting a synergism between the endogenous opioid and cannabinoid systems in mediating the reinforcing effect of food (<a href="#R1124" rid="R1124" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919622">

1606Solinas and Goldberg, 2005</a>

1607). Indeed, CB<sub>

16081</sub>

1609-deficient mice fail to self-administer morphine (<a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653401">

1610Ledent et al., 1999</a>

1611; <a href="#R212" rid="R212" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919512">

1612Cossu et al., 2001</a>

1613) or to release dopamine in the nucleus accumbens in response to morphine (<a href="#R771" rid="R771" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918898">

1614Mascia et al., 1999</a>

1615), suggesting that the site of this synergism is in the mesolimbic dopaminergic pathway, which is involved in both drug and food reward (<a href="#R667" rid="R667" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919044">

1616Le Foll and Goldberg, 2005</a>

1617). The observation that SR141716 inhibits the orexigenic effect of morphine microinjected into the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus but not the nucleus accumbens shell suggests additional interactions between the two systems, unrelated to the hedonic aspects of feeding (<a href="#R1228" rid="R1228" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919263">

1618Verty et al., 2003</a>

1619). A further intriguing parallel between the two systems is that opiate <em>

1620&#x003bc;</em>

1621 receptor knockout mice, just as CB<sub>

16221</sub>

1623<sup>

1624&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1625 mice (see below), are resistant to diet-induced obesity (<a href="#R1160" rid="R1160" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919110">

1626Tabarin et al., 2005</a>

1627).</p>

1628<p id="P32">

1629As for interactions with NPY, the similar effectiveness of SR141716 to inhibit food intake in wild-type and NPY<sup>

1630&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1631 mice indicates that endocannabinoids are unlikely to be the primary compensatory factor that accounts for the lack of a lean phenotype in NPY<sup>

1632&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1633 mice (<a href="#R274" rid="R274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920252">

1634Di Marzo et al., 2001b</a>

1635). However, anandamide was found to increase and AM251 to decrease depolarization-induced NPY release in rat hypothalamic explants, suggesting that NPY may contribute to the orexigenic effects of cannabinoids (<a href="#R358" rid="R358" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919042">

1636Gamber et al., 2005</a>

1637). A possible role of orexins in the appetitive effects of endocannabinoids is suggested by the finding that coexpression of the CB<sub>

16381</sub>

1639 and orexin 1 receptors results in a marked potentiation of orexin A-induced signaling (<a href="#R492" rid="R492" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920063">

1640Hilairet et al., 2003</a>

1641). An important site of action of the orexigenic peptide ghrelin is the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus, where its hyperphagic effect can be blocked by SR141716, suggesting that ghrelin may act via the release of endocannabinoids (<a href="#R1193" rid="R1193" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919801">

1642Tucci et al., 2004</a>

1643). Endocannabinoids, in turn, may be involved in ghrelin release, at least in the periphery, as suggested by an SR141716-induced decrease in plasma ghrelin levels in rats (<a href="#R151" rid="R151" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920290">

1644Cani et al., 2004</a>

1645).</p>

1646<p id="P33" class="p p-last">

1647The proopiomelanocortin-derived peptide <em>

1648&#x003b1;</em>

1649-MSH acting at MC-4 melanocortin receptors is part of the leptin-regulated appetitive circuitry as a major anorectic mediator. The observations that SR141716 inhibits the feeding response induced by blocking MC-4 receptors, whereas <em>

1650&#x003b1;</em>

1651-MSH does not affect THC-induced feeding, suggest that CB<sub>

16521</sub>

1653 receptors are downstream from MC-4 receptors and have an obligatory role in <em>

1654&#x003b1;</em>

1655-MSH effects on food intake (<a href="#R1227" rid="R1227" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919845">

1656Verty et al., 2004</a>

1657). The peptide product of CART is also a tonically active anorectic mediator (<a href="#R628" rid="R628" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919748">

1658Kristensen et al., 1998</a>

1659) and, unlike <em>

1660&#x003b1;</em>

1661-MSH, may be a downstream mediator of the effect of endocannabinoids. Such an arrangement is suggested by the finding that SR141716 loses its ability to reduce food intake in CART<sup>

1662&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1663 mice (<a href="#R914" rid="R914" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918766">

1664Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005a</a>

1665). Furthermore, mice deficient in FAAH have reduced levels of CART immunoreactivity in various hypothalamic and extrahypothalamic regions involved in appetite control, which is returned to normal levels by chronic SR141716 treatment (<a href="#R914" rid="R914" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918785">

1666Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005a</a>

1667). These findings suggest that inhibition of CART release by CB<sub>

16681</sub>

1669 activation may be involved in the orexigenic effect of anandamide. Finally, an interaction between endocannabinoids and CRH is indirectly suggested by coexpression of the mRNA for the CB<sub>

16701</sub>

1671 receptor with the mRNA for CRH (<a href="#R215" rid="R215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920154">

1672Cota et al., 2003</a>

1673) or the CRH type 1 receptor (<a href="#R487" rid="R487" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918866">

1674Hermann and Lutz, 2005</a>

1675).</p>

1676</div>

1677<div id="S9" class="sec">

1678<p>

1679</p>

1680<h4 id="S9title" class="inline">

16812. Endocannabinoids and Peripheral Energy Metabolism </h4>

1682<p id="P34" class="p p-first">

1683It is generally accepted that energy intake and utilization are regulated in a coordinated fashion, and factors involved in the central regulation of appetite may also affect peripheral energy metabolism (<a href="#R1084" rid="R1084" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653437">

1684Seeley and Woods, 2003</a>

1685). The first indirect indication that cannabinoids may affect energy homeostasis through a mechanism other than food intake came from a study of marijuana smokers tested in a hospital inpatient setting (<a href="#R428" rid="R428" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919599">

1686Greenberg et al., 1976</a>

1687). In this study, the marijuana-induced increase in caloric intake leveled off after a few days, whereas weight gain continued throughout the rest of the 21-day observation period, suggesting independent effects on appetite and peripheral energy metabolism. After the introduction of SR141716 as the first selective CB<sub>

16881</sub>

1689 receptor antagonist (<a href="#R1019" rid="R1019" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919499">

1690Rinaldi-Carmona et al., 1994</a>

1691), a similar conclusion was reached in normal rats treated with SR141716 for 14 days. Tolerance to the anorectic effect of SR141716 developed within 5 days, whereas the reduction in body weight was maintained throughout the treatment period (<a href="#R194" rid="R194" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919161">

1692Colombo et al., 1998a</a>

1693). Later, similar observations were reported in mice with diet-induced obesity, in which food intake was reduced transiently whereas the reduction in body weight was maintained when the animals were chronically treated with SR141716 (<a href="#R1000" rid="R1000" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653471">

1694Ravinet Trillou et al., 2003</a>

1695) or AM251 (<a href="#R493" rid="R493" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919633">

1696Hildebrandt et al., 2003</a>

1697). These results suggested that factors other than appetite must be involved in the weight-reducing effect of CB<sub>

16981</sub>

1699 antagonists.</p>

1700<p id="P35">

1701Peripheral targets of endocannabinoids include adipocytes, which express CB<sub>

17021</sub>

1703 receptors (<a href="#R67" rid="R67" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919093">

1704Bensaid et al., 2003</a>

1705; <a href="#R215" rid="R215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919685">

1706Cota et al., 2003</a>

1707). Stimulation of CB<sub>

17081</sub>

1709 receptors on adipocytes can affect lipid metabolism through regulating the level of adiponectin production (<a href="#R67" rid="R67" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920147">

1710Bensaid et al., 2003</a>

1711), by increasing lipoprotein lipase activity (<a href="#R215" rid="R215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919396">

1712Cota et al., 2003</a>

1713), or by inhibiting AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) (<a href="#R620" rid="R620" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919982">

1714Kola et al., 2005</a>

1715), which leads to increased lipogenesis and decrease in fatty acid <em>

1716&#x003b2;</em>

1717-oxidation through reducing the phosphorylation and thus disinhibiting acetyl CoA carboxylase-1 (ACC1), the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis. The work by <a href="#R215" rid="R215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919490">

1718Cota et al. (2003)</a>

1719 provided the first clear evidence of peripheral metabolic targets of endocannabinoids in vivo in a mouse model of diet-induced obesity. By careful analysis of body composition, they were able to establish the lean phenotype of CB<sub>

17201</sub>

1721-deficient mice that had escaped earlier attention. Furthermore, the use of a pair-feeding paradigm revealed that hypophagia accounts for the lean phenotype only in young and not in adult animals, which clearly indicated the involvement of peripheral metabolic target(s) in the latter. The additional documentation of functional CB<sub>

17221</sub>

1723 receptors in primary cultured adipocytes and their role in regulating lipogenesis provided one of the likely peripheral targets for the anabolic effects of endocannabinoids. The lean phenotype of CB<sub>

17241</sub>

1725<sup>

1726&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1727 mice in this study was more prominent in male than in female animals, which could suggest that endocannabinoid regulation of adiposity may be subject to modulation by sex hormones.</p>

1728<p id="P36">

1729Although earlier studies failed to detect CB<sub>

17301</sub>

1731 receptors in the liver, more recently they have been identified in the mouse liver using a combination of methods including reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction, in situ hybridization, immunohistochemistry, and Western blotting. In the same study, treatment of mice with the cannabinoid agonist HU-210 increased de novo lipogenesis and the expression of the transcription factor sterol regulatory element binding protein 1c (SREBP1c) as well as of its targets, ACC1 and fatty acid synthase (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919045">

1732Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1733). The role of CB<sub>

17341</sub>

1735 receptors in these effects was indicated by the ability of SR141716 to block them and by their absence in CB<sub>

17361</sub>

1737 knockout mice (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919294">

1738Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1739). The hepatic lipogenic pathway may be also directly activated through a cannabinoid-induced decrease in AMPK phosphorylation and activity in the liver (<a href="#R620" rid="R620" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919799">

1740Kola et al., 2005</a>

1741). CB<sub>

17421</sub>

1743 receptors have been also detected in rat hepatocytes (<a href="#R830" rid="R830" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919635">

1744Michalopoulos et al., 2003</a>

1745), in whole mouse liver (<a href="#R81" rid="R81" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919520">

1746Biecker et al., 2004</a>

1747), and in rat and human hepatic stellate cells (<a href="#R1103" rid="R1103" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920122">

1748Siegmund et al., 2005</a>

1749; <a href="#R1171" rid="R1171" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919574">

1750Teixeira-Clerc et al., 2006</a>

1751).</p>

1752<p id="P37">

1753Fatty acid metabolism in hypothalamic neurons acts as a sensor of nutrient availability (<a href="#R901" rid="R901" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920155">

1754Obici et al., 2003</a>

1755), and its pharmacological modulation influences food intake (<a href="#R603" rid="R603" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920331">

1756Kim et al., 2004</a>

1757). CB<sub>

17581</sub>

1759 activation was reported to increase <em>

1760SREBP1c</em>

1761 and <em>

1762FAS</em>

1763 gene expression in the hypothalamus, and the increased expression of these genes by fasting/refeeding (<a href="#R953" rid="R953" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919881">

1764Paulaskis and Sul, 1988</a>

1765) could be inhibited by SR141716 treatment at the beginning of the refeeding period, which also reduced food intake (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918993">

1766Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1767). Although fatty acid synthesis was not measured directly in the hypothalamus, these findings suggest that the increase in food intake after fasting may involve a CB<sub>

17681</sub>

1769-mediated modulation of the fatty acid synthetic pathway. Modulation of AMPK activity by cannabinoids was documented not only in liver and adipose tissue but also in hypothalamus (<a href="#R620" rid="R620" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919897">

1770Kola et al., 2005</a>

1771), where it has been linked to appetite control (<a href="#R837" rid="R837" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919877">

1772Minokoshi et al., 2004</a>

1773). Thus, the AMPK/ACC1/FAS pathway may represent a common molecular pathway involved in both the central appetitive and the peripheral metabolic effects of endocannabinoids.</p>

1774<p id="P38">

1775Because total caloric intake is similar in wild-type and CB<sub>

17761</sub>

1777<sup>

1778&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1779 mice on a high-fat diet (<a href="#R1001" rid="R1001" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653385">

1780Ravinet Trillou et al., 2004</a>

1781; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919787">

1782Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1783), the resistance of CB<sub>

17841</sub>

1785-deficient mice to diet-induced obesity must be associated with increased energy expenditure. Exposing wild-type C57BL6/J mice to a high-fat diet decreases energy expenditure, as documented by indirect calorimetry (<a href="#R528" rid="R528" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920380">

1786Hu et al., 2004</a>

1787), which may account for the increase in feed efficiency observed in such animals, whereas in CB<sub>

17881</sub>

1789<sup>

1790&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1791 mice feed efficiency was unaffected by a high-fat diet (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919678">

1792Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1793). This suggests that the high-fat diet-induced decrease in energy expenditure is mediated by endocannabinoid activation of CB<sub>

17941</sub>

1795 receptors. Accordingly, HU-210 treatment of wild-type mice decreased and SR141716 treatment increased the activity of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1, the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid <em>

1796&#x003b2;</em>

1797-oxidation (D. Osei-Hyiaman and G. Kunos, unpublished observations).</p>

1798<p id="P39">

1799One of the factors involved in this effect in vivo could be adiponectin, the adipocyte-derived hormone that promotes fatty acid <em>

1800&#x003b2;</em>

1801-oxidation (<a href="#R1304" rid="R1304" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920271">

1802Yamauchi et al., 2002</a>

1803). Indeed, exposure to a high-fat diet resulted in a significant decline in plasma adiponectin in wild-type but not in CB<sub>

18041</sub>

1805<sup>

1806&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1807 mice (<a href="#R914" rid="R914" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919172">

1808Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005a</a>

1809), and CB<sub>

18101</sub>

1811 receptor activation in isolated adipocytes was found to suppress adiponectin expression (Perwitz et al., 2005; <a href="#R780" rid="R780" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488951">

1812Matias et al., 2006</a>

1813). Expression of the thermogenic uncoupling protein-1 was also down-regulated by CB<sub>

18141</sub>

1815 activation, whereas the expression of the insulin-mimetic adipokine visfatin was increased (Perwitz et al., 2005). Conversely, rimonabant increases adiponectin secretion by adipocytes (<a href="#R67" rid="R67" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919532">

1816Bensaid et al., 2003</a>

1817) and adiponectin plasma levels in obese human subjects (<a href="#R260" rid="R260" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919057">

1818Despr&#x000e9;s et al., 2005</a>

1819), which should lead to increased lipid <em>

1820&#x003b2;</em>

1821-oxidation and thermogenesis in vivo. Chronic treatment of <em>

1822ob</em>

1823/<em>

1824ob</em>

1825 mice with SR141716 increased thermogenesis, as indicated by increased oxygen consumption at a thermoneutral temperature measured by whole body calorimetry (<a href="#R698" rid="R698" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653396">

1826Liu et al., 2005</a>

1827). Glucose uptake, subsequently measured in the isolated soleus muscle of these animals, was significantly increased in the SR141716-pretreated group. A similar effect in humans may account for the increased glucose tolerance observed in obese patients treated with rimonabant (<a href="#R1216" rid="R1216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918922">

1828Van Gaal et al., 2005</a>

1829). These observations could suggest the presence of CB<sub>

18301</sub>

1831 receptors in skeletal muscle, which was recently documented (<a href="#R930" rid="R930" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919224">

1832Pagotto et al., 2006</a>

1833). Alternatively, increased glucose tolerance may be secondary to an effect of SR141716 on CB<sub>

18341</sub>

1835 receptors in the liver. It has been proposed that increased lipid synthesis in the liver may produce insulin resistance in other tissues such as muscle (<a href="#R793" rid="R793" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653454">

1836McGarry, 1992</a>

1837), and CB<sub>

18381</sub>

1839 receptor activation has been shown to contribute to the development of hepatic steatosis in diet-induced obesity (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919380">

1840Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1841). Endocannabinoids may also influence insulin secretion directly in islet <em>

1842&#x003b2;</em>

1843-cells via CB<sub>

18441</sub>

1845 (<a href="#R780" rid="R780" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488945">

1846Matias et al., 2006</a>

1847) or CB<sub>

18482</sub>

1849 receptors (<a href="#R576" rid="R576" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919573">

1850Juan-Pico et al., 2005</a>

1851).</p>

1852<p id="P40" class="p p-last">

1853The ability of rimonabant to increase energy expenditure may not be limited to an effect on adiponectin secretion, as indicated by an analysis of the effect of rimonabant treatment on gene expression profiles in lean and diet-induced obese mice as well as CB<sub>

18541</sub>

1855<sup>

1856&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1857 mice (<a href="#R559" rid="R559" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919431">

1858Jbilo et al., 2005</a>

1859). Rimonabant-induced decreases in body weight and adipose tissue mass in obese mice was accompanied by a near-complete reversal of obesity-induced changes in the expression of a wide range of genes. These included genes involved in adipocyte differentiation, lipolysis, generation of futile cycles, and glycolysis. These broad-based targets may underlie the ability of rimonabant to correct symptoms of the metabolic syndrome, as discussed below. They also raise the intriguing possibility that if a CB<sub>

18601</sub>

1861 antagonist that does not cross the blood-brain barrier were available, it could be effective in the treatment of the metabolic syndrome without the risk of adverse CNS side effects (Horvath, 2006).</p>

1862</div>

1863<div id="S10" class="sec">

1864<p>

1865</p>

1866<h4 id="S10title" class="inline">

18673. Obesity and Associated Metabolic Abnormalities </h4>

1868<p id="P41" class="p p-first">

1869Genetic manipulation of the expression of endogenous proteins has been instrumental in uncovering their regulatory role in normal and pathological phenotypes. When CB<sub>

18701</sub>

1871 knockout mice were first introduced, no change in body mass or feeding pattern had been noted (<a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653501">

1872Ledent et al., 1999</a>

1873; <a href="#R1325" rid="R1325" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920339">

1874Zimmer et al., 1999</a>

1875). However, in a subsequent study, CB<sub>

18761</sub>

1877 knockout mice were found to have a life-long, small, but significant, weight deficit compared with their wild-type littermates, which could be attributed to a selective deficit in adipose tissue mass (<a href="#R215" rid="R215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920278">

1878Cota et al., 2003</a>

1879) and was confirmed by others (<a href="#R1001" rid="R1001" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653368">

1880Ravinet Trillou et al., 2004</a>

1881; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920177">

1882Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1883). Parallel to their decreased fat mass, CB<sub>

18841</sub>

1885<sup>

1886&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1887 mice have lower plasma leptin levels and an increased sensitivity to the anorectic effect of exogenous leptin (<a href="#R1001" rid="R1001" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653394">

1888Ravinet Trillou et al., 2004</a>

1889).</p>

1890<p id="P42">

1891The possibility that an increase in the activity of the endocannabinoid system may contribute to at least some forms of obesity was suggested by three sets of findings. First, CB<sub>

18921</sub>

1893 antagonists were significantly more efficacious in reducing caloric intake and body weight in rodents with diet-induced or genetic obesity than in their respective lean controls (<a href="#R274" rid="R274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920222">

1894Di Marzo et al., 2001b</a>

1895; <a href="#R493" rid="R493" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918709">

1896Hildebrandt et al., 2003</a>

1897; <a href="#R1000" rid="R1000" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653488">

1898Ravinet Trillouet et al., 2003</a>

1899; <a href="#R1230" rid="R1230" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919210">

1900Vickers et al., 2003</a>

1901).</p>

1902<p id="P43">

1903Second, CB<sub>

19041</sub>

1905<sup>

1906&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1907 mice are resistant to diet-induced obesity (<a href="#R1001" rid="R1001" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653434">

1908Ravinet Trillou et al., 2004</a>

1909; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920043">

1910Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1911). In both of these studies, overall caloric intake was not different between wild-type compared with CB<sub>

19121</sub>

1913<sup>

1914&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1915 mice receiving the high-fat diet, suggesting that peripheral mechanisms play a dominant role in the control of body weight by CB<sub>

19161</sub>

1917 receptors. CB<sub>

19181</sub>

1919<sup>

1920&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

1921 mice are also resistant to the metabolic changes that accompany diet-induced obesity in normal mice, including hypertriglyceridemia and elevated plasma leptin and insulin levels, indicative of leptin and insulin resistance, respectively (<a href="#R1001" rid="R1001" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653402">

1922Ravinet Trillou et al., 2004</a>

1923; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920100">

1924Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1925). These metabolic changes, collectively defined by some as the &#x0201c;metabolic syndrome&#x0201d;, could also be reversed by SR141716 treatment (<a href="#R1001" rid="R1001" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653376">

1926Ravinet Trillou et al., 2004</a>

1927; <a href="#R975" rid="R975" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653518">

1928Poirier et al., 2005</a>

1929).</p>

1930<p id="P44">

1931As a third line of evidence, recent findings indicate that endocannabinoids and CB<sub>

19321</sub>

1933 receptors are up-regulated in the liver and adipose tissue in various forms of experimental as well as in human obesity. In wild-type mice on a high-fat diet for 3 weeks, the basal rate of de novo hepatic fatty acid synthesis was markedly increased, and the increase was partially reversed by SR141716 treatment (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920114">

1934Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1935). After 3 weeks of diet, the mice were not yet overweight but showed significant hepatic steatosis. Their hepatic content of anandamide was increased 3-fold, and the level of CB<sub>

19361</sub>

1937 receptor protein in liver plasma membranes was also markedly increased (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919159">

1938Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1939). These findings indicate that intake of a high-fat diet activates the hepatic endocannabinoid system, which contributes to increased lipogenesis and the subsequent development of hepatic steatosis and, ultimately, the development of obesity. Exposure of C57BL6/J mice to a high-fat diet has been reported to induce changes characteristic of the metabolic syndrome and also to rapidly induce the expression of SREBP1c and its downstream target lipogenic enzymes (<a href="#R79" rid="R79" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919617">

1940Biddinger et al., 2005</a>

1941). CB<sub>

19421</sub>

1943 receptor knockout mice are resistant to these diet-induced changes, which indicates that endocannabinoids have a major role in mediating them (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919592">

1944Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1945).</p>

1946<p id="P45">

1947An up-regulation of CB<sub>

19481</sub>

1949 receptors has been also reported in adipose tissue of genetically obese compared with lean mice (<a href="#R67" rid="R67" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920249">

1950Bensaid et al., 2003</a>

1951), and elevated endocannabinoid levels have been detected in adipose tissue of obese compared with lean patients (<a href="#R780" rid="R780" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488946">

1952Matias et al., 2006</a>

1953). In a study involving 40 women (<a href="#R302" rid="R302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918957">

1954Engeli et al., 2005</a>

1955), circulating levels of anandamide and 2-AG were significantly increased in 20 obese versus 20 lean subjects, and remained elevated after a 5% diet-induced weight reduction. Although these plasma levels were much too low to exert hormone-like activity, they probably originate from overflow from tissues and thus may reflect functionally relevant changes in endocannabinoid content at or near sites of action. In the same study, FAAH expression was markedly reduced in the adipose tissue of obese subjects and correlated negatively with circulating endocannabinoid levels. Furthermore, the expression of both CB<sub>

19561</sub>

1957 and FAAH increased in mature adipocytes compared with preadipocytes. These findings suggest that the endocannabinoid system is activated in human obesity (<a href="#R302" rid="R302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919534">

1958Engeli et al., 2005</a>

1959).</p>

1960<p id="P46">

1961A genetic missense polymorphism in the <em>

1962FAAH</em>

1963 gene predicting a proline to threonine substitution at position 129, which was reported to result in reduced cellular expression and activity of the enzyme (<a href="#R179" rid="R179" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653487">

1964Chiang et al., 2004</a>

1965), had been earlier found to be significantly associated with problem drug use (<a href="#R1111" rid="R1111" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918901">

1966Sipe et al., 2002</a>

1967). The same polymorphism has been linked to overweight and obesity in both Caucasian and African-American subjects (<a href="#R1112" rid="R1112" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653503">

1968Sipe et al., 2005</a>

1969). Interestingly, the elevated hepatic levels of anandamide in mice receiving a high-fat diet could be attributed to a decrease in FAAH activity (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918838">

1970Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

1971), suggesting that FAAH may play a key role in regulating endocannabinoid &#x0201c;tone&#x0201d; in both experimental and human obesity. Although this finding could suggest the targeting of FAAH in the treatment of eating/metabolic disorders, such an approach will be complicated by the fact that oleylethanolamide, an anorectic lipid that acts on the peroxisome proliferator-proliferator-activated receptor <em>

1972&#x003b1;</em>

1973 (PPAR<em>

1974&#x003b1;</em>

1975) (<a href="#R352" rid="R352" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919418">

1976Fu et al., 2003</a>

1977), is also a substrate for FAAH. The opposing effects of elevated levels of both anandamide and oleylethanolamide after pharmacological blockade of FAAH may therefore result in no net change in appetite and energy metabolism.</p>

1978<p id="P47">

1979That increased endocannabinoid activity may also contribute to obesity and its metabolic consequences in humans was indicated by the highly promising results of recent clinical trials with rimonabant. As in the animal models of diet-induced obesity, rimonabant was effective both in reducing body weight and in reversing many of the associated metabolic abnormalities in obese subjects. In a multicenter, phase III study involving 1507 obese European subjects with a body mass index &#x0003e;30 kg/m<sup>

19802</sup>

1981 or a body mass index &#x0003e;27 kg/m<sup>

19822</sup>

1983 with dyslipidemia and moderate hypertension, rimonabant (20 mg/day) treatment for 1 year, combined with a moderately hypocaloric diet, not only reduced body weight but also reduced plasma triglycerides, increased HDL cholesterol, and decreased plasma insulin and insulin resistance (<a href="#R1216" rid="R1216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920282">

1984Van Gaal et al., 2005</a>

1985). Blood pressure was not significantly affected. The parallel reduction in body weight and waist circumference suggested that the weight loss was predominantly due to loss of visceral fat, which is known to be a predisposing factor for the metabolic syndrome. Rimonabant was well tolerated, with mild to moderate nausea, diarrhea, and mood disorders occurring slightly more in the treatment group than in the placebo group (<a href="#R1216" rid="R1216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919099">

1986Van Gaal et al., 2005</a>

1987).</p>

1988<p id="P48">

1989Essentially similar findings were reported in another large-scale, phase III study (RIO-North America) involving 3045 randomized, obese or overweight subjects. At the end of the 1st year, rimonabant-treated subjects were re-randomized to receive rimonabant or placebo, whereas the placebo group continued onto receive the placebo. During the 2nd year, rimonabant-treated patients retained the improvements achieved during the 1st year, whereas those who switched to placebo regained their original weight (<a href="#R968" rid="R968" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653458">

1990Pi-Sunyer et al., 2006</a>

1991).</p>

1992<p id="P49">

1993In a third study (RIO-Lipids) involving 1036 overweight/obese subjects, 20 mg/day rimonabant taken for 1 year significantly reduced body weight (&#x02212;6.3 &#x000b1; 0.5 kg), weight circumference (&#x02212;5.7 &#x000b1; 0.6 cm), and plasma triglycerides (&#x02212;12.4 &#x000b1; 3.2%), increased HDL cholesterol by 8.1 &#x000b1; 1.5% and increased LDL particle size, improved glucose tolerance, and significantly elevated plasma adiponectin levels, resulting in a 50% decrease in the prevalence of the metabolic syndrome in the study population (<a href="#R260" rid="R260" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918883">

1994Despr&#x000e9;s et al., 2005</a>

1995). In contrast with the other two studies, a statistically significant, small decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure was evident in the group receiving 20 mg of rimonabant, and the decrease was greater for patients with initial hypertension (blood pressure &#x0003e;140/90 mm Hg). Although the reason for the lack of a blood pressure change in the other studies is not clear, the proportion of females was lower in RIO-Lipids (~60%) than in the other two studies where they represented ~80% of subjects. It is possible that a modest reduction in blood pressure by rimonabant occurs preferentially in males. The cumulative finding that blood pressure reduction, if present, is less than expected based on a similar level of weight reduction alone (<a href="#R21" rid="R21" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653354">

1996Appel et al., 2003</a>

1997), is noteworthy. As discussed in section D.1., rimonabant at an i.v. dose of 3 mg/kg causes a pressor response in anesthetized, hypertensive rats, which are supersensitive to the hypotensive effect of endogenous or exogenous anandamide (<a href="#R51" rid="R51" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653455">

1998B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004</a>

1999). Although the pressor effect is much smaller at lower doses of rimonabant comparable with the 20-mg oral dose used in humans or in the absence of anesthesia (S. B&#x000e1;tkai, P. Pacher, and G. Kunos, unpublished observations), careful monitoring of blood pressure, particularly in the early stages of rimonabant treatment, may be advisable. A polymorphism in the <em>

2000FAAH</em>

2001 gene is associated with obesity (<a href="#R1112" rid="R1112" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653444">

2002Sipe et al., 2005</a>

2003), and because of the reduced enzyme activity resulting from this polymorphism, some of the affected individuals may have an elevated endocannabinoid tone, reversal of which by rimonabant could increase blood pressure.</p>

2004<p id="P50">

2005It is noteworthy that part of the rimonabant-induced improvements in the hormonal and lipid abnormalities in the three clinical studies appeared to be independent of weight reduction and, based on the preclinical findings discussed above, are most likely mediated via peripheral sites of action. An interesting alternative mechanism is suggested by the results of a recent meta-analysis of the effects of low carbohydrate, nonenergy-restricted diets on weight loss and cardiovascular risk factors (<a href="#R896" rid="R896" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918774">

2006Nordmann et al., 2006</a>

2007). Such diets were found to lead to significant weight loss for up to 1 year. Surprisingly, they were more favorable than low-fat diets in reducing plasma triglycerides and increasing HDL cholesterol levels, without a favorable effect on total or LDL cholesterol. The pattern of these metabolic changes is similar to that of those caused by 20 mg of rimonabant in the three clinical trials. Rimonabant has been shown to preferentially suppress the preference for sweet compared with normal (<a href="#R1108" rid="R1108" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919943">

2008Simiand et al., 1998</a>

2009) or high-fat reinforcers (<a href="#R1271" rid="R1271" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920267">

2010Ward and Dykstra, 2005</a>

2011) and can cause longer lasting suppression of intake of sweet compared with normal food (<a href="#R384" rid="R384" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919898">

2012Gessa et al., 2006</a>

2013). It is very possible that obese subjects treated with rimonabant unwittingly altered their diet by reducing carbohydrate intake, which may have contributed to the observed effects on triglycerides and HDL cholesterol. Detailed analyses of the effects of rimonabant on dietary habits are warranted.</p>

2014<p id="P51" class="p p-last">

2015Overall, the findings in these three large, multicenter clinical trials strongly support a pathogenic role of increased endocannabinoid activity in obesity and the associated metabolic abnormalities and highlight the unique therapeutic potential of CB<sub>

20161</sub>

2017 blockade. Additional benefits may be gained by combination therapies. The efficacy of statins to preferentially lower LDL cholesterol may be effectively complemented by the ability of rimonabant to increase HDL cholesterol. In the case of insulin, the ability of rimonabant ability to increase insulin sensitivity could reduce the dose requirement for insulin in obese diabetic subjects and could also counteract the tendency of insulin treatment to cause weight gain. Nevertheless, further large-scale studies are warranted in view of the high nonadherence rate observed in the three clinical trials to date, which may have resulted in overestimation of the benefits of treatment (<a href="#R1109" rid="R1109" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653405">

2018Simons-Morton et al., 2006</a>

2019).</p>

2020</div>

2021<div id="S11" class="sec sec-last">

2022<p>

2023</p>

2024<h4 id="S11title" class="inline">

20254. Cachexia and Anorexia </h4>

2026<p id="P52" class="p p-first">

2027A negative energy balance resulting from decreased appetite and food intake and increased energy expenditure, leading to weight loss, can be the consequence of wasting diseases such as AIDS or metastatic cancer, or it could be associated with aging, chemotherapy of cancer, or neuropsychiatric conditions such as anorexia nervosa or various forms of dementia including Alzheimer&#x02019;s disease. Although there is a growing body of evidence documenting the therapeutic effectiveness of synthetic THC or even smoked marijuana as appetite boosters in some of these conditions (<a href="#R1005" rid="R1005" class=" bibr popnode">

2028Regelson et al., 1976</a>

2029; <a href="#R420" rid="R420" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920247">

2030Gorter et al., 1992</a>

2031; <a href="#R884" rid="R884" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919890">

2032Nelson et al., 1994</a>

2033; <a href="#R54" rid="R54" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919109">

2034Beal et al., 1995</a>

2035, <a href="#R55" rid="R55" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919369">

20361997</a>

2037; <a href="#R1183" rid="R1183" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919091">

2038Timpone et al., 1997</a>

2039) (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

2040<span>

2041Table 1</span>

2042</a>

2043), there is only limited information on the potential involvement of the endocannabinoid system in their pathogenesis.</p>

2044<!--table ft1-->

2045<!--table-wrap mode="anchored" t5-->

2046<div class="table-wrap anchored whole_rhythm" id="T1">

2047<h3>

2048TABLE 1</h3>

2049<!--caption a7-->

2050<div class="caption">

2051<p id="__p8">

2052Clinical trials with cannabinoid-related medications in human disease</p>

2053</div>

2054<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462195728" class="xtable">

2055<table frame="hsides" rules="groups" class="rendered small default_table">

2056<thead>

2057<tr>

2058<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2059Disease/Condition</th>

2060<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2061Sample Size, Design, Target Symptoms</th>

2062<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2063Compound (Dose)</th>

2064<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2065Parameters Studied</th>

2066<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2067Results</th>

2068<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2069Adverse Effects</th>

2070<th align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2071Reference</th>

2072</tr>

2077<strong>

2078MS and SCI</strong>

2079</td>

2080</tr>

2081<tr>

2082<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2083&#x02003;MS</td>

2084<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2085Nine patients, DB, PL, spasticity</td>

2086<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2087THC (5- and 10-mg single-dose p.o.)</td>

2088<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2089EMG, clinical</td>

2090<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2091Improved spasticity score (objective)</td>

2092<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2093Minimal</td>

2094<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2095<a href="#R966" rid="R966" class=" bibr popnode">

2096Petro and Ellenberger (1981)</a>

2097</td>

2098</tr>

2099<tr>

2100<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2101&#x02003;MS</td>

2102<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2103Eight patients, SB, PL, tremor, ataxia</td>

2104<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2105THC (5 mg/6 h max three doses p.o.)</td>

2106<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2107Clinical</td>

2108<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2109Improved coordination and sense of well being, decreased tremor (subjective)</td>

2110<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2111Subjective &#x0201c;high&#x0201d; in all patients</td>

2112<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2113<a href="#R187" rid="R187" class=" bibr popnode">

2114Clifford (1983)</a>

2115</td>

2116</tr>

2117<tr>

2118<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2119&#x02003;MS</td>

2120<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

212113 patients, DB, PL, C, spasticity</td>

2122<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2123THC (2.5&#x02013;15 mg daily for 5 days p.o.)</td>

2124<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2125Clinical, questionnaire</td>

2126<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2127Reduced spasticity (subjective); objective function tests not improved</td>

2128<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2129Common</td>

2130<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2131<a href="#R1204" rid="R1204" class=" bibr popnode">

2139One patient, OL, spastic tetraparesis</td>

2140<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2141Cigarette smoke marijuana (one cigarette)</td>

2142<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2143Clinical, tremor recording, EMG</td>

2144<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2145Reduced ataxia and spasticity (objective)</td>

2146<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2147None</td>

2158<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2159Cigarette smoke marijuana (one cigarette; 1.54% THC)</td>

2160<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2161Dynamic posturography, objective balance</td>

2163Impaired posture and balance</td>

2171<tr>

2173&#x02003;MS</td>

2174<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2175One patient, DB, PL, C, spasticity</td>

2176<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2177Nabilone (1 mg/2 days for 16 wk p.o.)</td>

2178<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2179Visual analog scales</td>

2180<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2181Improved painful muscle spasms, mood and well being (subjective); reduced frequency of nocturia</td>

2182<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2183Mild sedation</td>

2184<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2185<a href="#R770" rid="R770" class=" bibr popnode">

2187</td>

2188</tr>

2189<tr>

2190<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2191&#x02003;MS and SCI</td>

2192<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2193Two patients, OL, spasticity</td>

2194<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2195THC (10 or 15 mg p.o. or rectal)</td>

2196<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2197Clinical</td>

2198<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2199Improved walking ability and passive mobility, reduced rigidity, slight pain relief</td>

2200<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2201Temporal deterioration in ability to concentrate and in mood</td>

2202<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2203<a href="#R120" rid="R120" class=" bibr popnode">

2204Brenneisen et al. (1996)</a>

2205</td>

2206</tr>

2207<tr>

2208<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2209&#x02003;MS</td>

2210<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2211One patient, PL, nystagmus</td>

2212<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2213Cigarette smoke marijuana (inhaled)</td>

2214<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2215Eye movement recording</td>

2216<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2217Reduced nystagmus amplitude and improved visual acuity</td>

2218<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2219None</td>

2220<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2222Schon et al. (1999)</a>

2223</td>

2225<tr>

2226<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2227&#x02003;MS</td>

2228<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

222916 patients, DB, PL, C, spasticity</td>

2230<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2231Plant extract of THC (2.5&#x02013;5 mg b.i.d. for 4 wk p.o.)</td>

2232<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2233Clinical, questionnaires, Ashworth score</td>

2234<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2235No improvement in Ashworth scale, worsening global impression</td>

2236<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

223741 adverse events in 16 patients during plant extract treatment</td>

2238<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2239<a href="#R600" rid="R600" class=" bibr popnode">

2240Killestein et al. (2002)</a>

2241</td>

2242</tr>

2243<tr>

2244<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2245&#x02003;MS and SCI</td>

2246<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

224724 patients, DB, PL, C, heterogeneous</td>

2248<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2249Plant extract of THC and CBD 1:1 (2.5&#x02013;120 mg/day for 2 wk sublingual)</td>

2250<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2251Clinical, questionnaires</td>

2252<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2253Improvement of bladder control, muscle spasms, and spasticity and pain relief (subjective) but no in Ashworth scale</td>

2254<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

22554 dropouts due to adverse events</td>

2256<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2257<a href="#R1245" rid="R1245" class=" bibr popnode">

2258Wade et al. (2003)</a>

2259</td>

2260</tr>

2261<tr>

2262<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2263&#x02003;MS</td>

2264<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2265630 patients, DB, R, PL, spasticity</td>

2266<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2267Cannabis extract (Cannador: 2.5 mg &#x00394;<sup>

22689</sup>

2269-THC + 1.25 mg CBD/capsule; Marinol: THC max 25 mg/day for 15 wk p.o.)</td>

2270<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2271Clinical, questionnaires Ashworth score, Rivermead Mobility Index</td>

2272<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2273No change in the Ashworthscore, but improvement in the patient-reported spasticity, pain, and sleep quality; unexpected reduction in hospital admission for relapse in the treatment groups; in 12-mo follow-up, THC improved muscle spasticity measured by the Ashworth scale and the Rivermead Mobility Index</td>

2274<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2275Minimal, similar to placebo</td>

2276<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2277<a href="#R1312" rid="R1312" class=" bibr popnode">

2278Zajicek et al. (2003</a>

2279, <a href="#R1311" rid="R1311" class=" bibr popnode">

22802004)</a>

2281</td>

2282</tr>

2283<tr>

2284<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2285&#x02003;MS</td>

2286<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

228757 patients, DB, R, PL, C, spasticity, various</td>

2288<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2289Cannabis-based capsules (2.5 mg THC and 0.9 mg CBD; max dose 30 mg/day THC p.o.)</td>

2290<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2291Self-report of spasm frequency and symptoms, Ashworth Scale, Rivermead Mobility Index, 10-m timed walk</td>

2292<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2293Improved spasm frequency and mobility in the 37 patients who received at least 90% of their prescribed dose</td>

2294<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2295Minor adverse events were slightly more frequent in treated group</td>

2532<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2533&#x02003;HIV</td>

2534<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2535523 patients, cross-sectional questionnaire study</td>

2536<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2537Cannabis</td>

2538<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2539Questionnaire, various</td>

2540<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2541In most patients who used cannabis to treat symptoms (143/523); reduction in muscle and neuropathic pain</td>

2542<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2543Not discussed</td>

2544<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2545<a href="#R1301" rid="R1301" class=" bibr popnode">

2546Woolridge et al. (2005)</a>

2547</td>

2548</tr>

2549<tr>

2550<td colspan="7" align="left" rowspan="1">

255954 patients, R, DB, weight</td>

2562<td align="left" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

2957</tbody>

2958</table>

2959</div>

2960<div id="largeobj_idm139779462195728" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

2961<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/?report=objectonly">

2962Open in a separate window</a>

2963</div>

2964<div class="tblwrap-foot">

2965<div id="TFN1">

2966<p id="__p9" class="p p-first-last">

2967DB, double blind; PL, placebo-controlled; EMG, electromyography; SB, single blind; C, crossover; OL, open-label; max, maximum; R, randomized; M, multicenter; VAS, visual analog scale; P, prospective; PL, placebo; FMF, familial Mediterranean fever; NIB, nitrogen analog of THC; NK<sub>

29683</sub>

2969 R, neurokinin 3 receptor; SR142801, (<em>

2970R</em>

2971)-(<em>

2972N</em>

2973)-[1-[3-[1-benzoyl-3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)piperidin-3-yl]propyl]-4-phenylpiperidin-4-yl]-<em>

2974N</em>

2975-methylacetamide; SR48692, 2-[(1-(7-chloro-4-quinolinyl)-5-(2,6-dimethoxyphenyl)pyrazol-3-yl)carbonylamino]tricycle(3.3.1.1)decan-2-carboxylic acid}; SR463493B, 1(<em>

2976Z</em>

2977)-[2-(dimethylamino)ethoxyimino]-1(2-fluorophenyl)-3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-2(<em>

2978E</em>

2979)-propene; 5-HT<sub>

29802A/2C</sub>

2981 R, serotonin 2A/2C receptor, WC, waist circumference; BP, blood pressure.</p>

2982</div>

2983</div>

2984</div>

2985<p id="P53">

2986A few studies have reported the effectiveness of THC in stimulating appetite and weight gain in cancer patients, but these therapeutic effects have been more extensively documented in AIDS patients (reviewed by <a href="#R607" rid="R607" class=" bibr popnode">

2987Kirkham, 2004</a>

2988; <a href="#R758" rid="R758" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920287">

2989Martin and Wiley, 2004</a>

2990; <a href="#R454" rid="R454" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920191">

2991Hall et al., 2005</a>

2992) (see also <a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

2993<span>

2994Table 1</span>

2995</a>

2996). Although concerns have been voiced about the potential immunosuppressive effect of cannabinoids in immunocompromised individuals (<a href="#R613" rid="R613" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920269">

2997Klein et al., 1998</a>

2998), repeated THC administration in a randomized, prospective, controlled trial was found to have few if any consistent effects on various immune functions in AIDS patients receiving antiviral treatment (<a href="#R117" rid="R117" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918884">

2999Bredt et al., 2002</a>

3000).</p>

3001<p id="P54">

3002Anorexia may also be associated with normal aging. A number of hormonal factors have been implicated in the loss of appetite in the elderly, including growth hormone, cholecystokinin, leptin, and various cytokines (<a href="#R851" rid="R851" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920206">

3003Morley, 2001</a>

3004). In a recent study in mice, an age-related decline in food and alcohol intake was accompanied by the loss of ability of the CB<sub>

30051</sub>

3006 antagonist SR141716 to reduce food and alcohol intake and a decrease in CB<sub>

30071</sub>

3008 receptor-stimulated GTP<em>

3009&#x003b3;</em>

3010S labeling in the limbic forebrain (<a href="#R1267" rid="R1267" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919430">

3011Wang et al., 2003</a>

3012). These findings suggest that, at least in this animal model, an age-dependent decrease in CB<sub>

30131</sub>

3014 receptor signaling in the limbic forebrain may be related to the parallel decline in appetite for both food and alcohol. Anorexia can also accompany debilitating diseases such as Alzheimer&#x02019;s disease, in which the effectiveness of THC to stimulate appetite has been documented (<a href="#R1238" rid="R1238" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653446">

3015Volicer et al., 1997</a>

3016). Anorexia nervosa is a psychiatric condition that occurs predominantly in younger women and is characterized by self-starvation, weight loss, and a disturbed body image. Plasma anandamide levels have been reported to increase in patients with restricting anorexia nervosa, which may be secondary to a marked decrease in plasma leptin levels in such patients (<a href="#R845" rid="R845" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920075">

3017Monteleone et al., 2002</a>

3018). Although the relationship between brain and plasma levels of anandamide is not clear, a parallel increase in anandamide in brain regions involved in reward may mediate the rewarding effect of self-starvation in anorexic patients (<a href="#R846" rid="R846" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920364">

3019Monteleone et al., 2005</a>

3020). A recent family-based study examined the possible association of a CB<sub>

30211</sub>

3022 receptor gene polymorphism consisting of differences in a trinucleotide repeat with anorexia nervosa. Although no difference was found between parental alleles transmitted or not transmitted to the affected siblings, preferential transmission of different alleles could be established when the patients were subdivided into restricting and binging/purging subgroups (<a href="#R1102" rid="R1102" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653432">

3023Siegfried et al., 2004</a>

3024).</p>

3025<p id="P55" class="p p-last">

3026Endocannabinoids have been also implicated in a unique form of food intake: milk suckling in newborn animals. In an elegant series of studies, <a href="#R347" rid="R347" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653456">

3027Fride et al. (2005)</a>

3028 have proposed a role for 2-AG in the brain to stimulate the suckling response in mouse pups. In their model, endogenous 2-AG in the pup&#x02019;s brain initiated the suckling response via CB<sub>

30291</sub>

3030 receptors, with continued suckling depending on milk-derived 2-AG (<a href="#R346" rid="R346" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919189">

3031Fride, 2004</a>

3032). As predicted by this model, treatment of pups with SR141716 inhibits suckling and leads to death due to failure to thrive, a condition analogous to a human condition known as nonorganic failure to thrive, in which an oral motor defect resulting in deficient suckling (<a href="#R1007" rid="R1007" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919954">

3033Reilly et al., 1999</a>

3034) is similar to the condition in mouse produced by pharmacological blockade or genetic ablation of CB<sub>

30351</sub>

3036 (<a href="#R347" rid="R347" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653422">

3037Fride et al., 2005</a>

3038). The relatively high dose of SR141716 to inhibit suckling and its residual effectiveness in CB<sub>

30391</sub>

3040 knockout mice suggested the additional involvement of a receptor distinct from CB<sub>

30411</sub>

3042 or CB<sub>

30432</sub>

3044 (<a href="#R348" rid="R348" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919966">

3045Fride et al., 2003</a>

3046).</p>

3047</div>

3048</div>

3049<div id="S12" class="sec">

3050<h3 id="S12title">

3051B. Pain and Inflammation</h3>

3052<p id="P56" class="p p-first">

3053One of the earliest uses of cannabis was to treat pain. Historical documents reveal the use of cannabis for surgical anesthesia in ancient China and to relieve pain of diverse origin in ancient Israel, Greece, Rome, and India (reviewed in <a href="#R804" rid="R804" class=" bibr popnode">

3054Mechoulam, 1986</a>

3055; <a href="#R544" rid="R544" class=" bibr popnode">

3056Iversen, 2000</a>

3057; <a href="#R809" rid="R809" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918694">

3058Mechoulam and Hanus, 2000</a>

3059). Numerous early studies have also demonstrated beneficial effects of cannabinoids in animal models of pain (reviewed in <a href="#R1254" rid="R1254" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918770">

3060Walker and Huang, 2002</a>

3061; <a href="#R334" rid="R334" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653505">

3062Fox and Bevan, 2005</a>

3063). In acute pain, anandamide, THC, cannabidiol, and synthetic cannabinoids such as CP55,940 and WIN 55,212-2 are effective against chemical (<a href="#R1123" rid="R1123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918852">

3064Sofia et al., 1973</a>

3065; <a href="#R330" rid="R330" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919061">

3066Formukong et al., 1988</a>

3067; <a href="#R148" rid="R148" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918991">

3068Calignano et al., 1998</a>

3069; <a href="#R213" rid="R213" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653494">

3070Costa et al., 2004a</a>

3071,<a href="#R214" rid="R214" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919618">

3072b</a>

3073; <a href="#R444" rid="R444" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919614">

3074Guindon et al., 2006</a>

3075; <a href="#R1202" rid="R1202" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920119">

3076Ulugol et al., 2006</a>

3077), mechanical (<a href="#R1123" rid="R1123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919449">

3078Sofia et al., 1973</a>

3079; <a href="#R762" rid="R762" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637186">

3080Martin et al., 1996</a>

3081; <a href="#R1116" rid="R1116" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918912">

3082Smith et al., 1998</a>

3083; <a href="#R443" rid="R443" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919017">

3084Guindon and Beaulieu, 2006</a>

3085), and thermal pain stimuli (<a href="#R139" rid="R139" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653430">

3086Buxbaum, 1972</a>

3087; <a href="#R100" rid="R100" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919241">

3088Bloom et al., 1977</a>

3089; <a href="#R686" rid="R686" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919470">

3090Lichtman and Martin, 1991a</a>

3091,<a href="#R687" rid="R687" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919417">

3092b</a>

3093; <a href="#R349" rid="R349" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919127">

3094Fride and Mechoulam, 1993</a>

3095; <a href="#R443" rid="R443" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919542">

3096Guindon and Beaulieu, 2006</a>

3097). Recent animal studies indicate that anandamide and cannabinoid ligands are also very effective against chronic pain of both neuropathic (<a href="#R490" rid="R490" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919777">

3098Herzberg et al., 1997</a>

3099; <a href="#R121" rid="R121" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919588">

3100Bridges et al., 2001</a>

3101; <a href="#R335" rid="R335" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919035">

3102Fox et al., 2001</a>

3103; <a href="#R443" rid="R443" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920365">

3104Guindon and Beaulieu, 2006</a>

3105) and inflammatory origin (<a href="#R1190" rid="R1190" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919923">

3106Tsou et al., 1996</a>

3107; <a href="#R1012" rid="R1012" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920372">

3108Richardson et al., 1998a</a>

3109,<a href="#R1013" rid="R1013" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637220">

3110b</a>

3111,<a href="#R1014" rid="R1014" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919420">

3112c</a>

3113; Li et al., 1999; <a href="#R764" rid="R764" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919105">

3114Martin et al., 1999b</a>

3115; <a href="#R444" rid="R444" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919347">

3116Guindon et al., 2006</a>

3117). Moreover, endocannabinoids and synthetic cannabinoids exert synergistic antinociceptive effects when combined with commonly used nonsteroid anti-inflammatory drugs, which may have utility in the pharmacotherapy of pain (<a href="#R443" rid="R443" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920320">

3118Guindon and Beaulieu, 2006</a>

3119; <a href="#R444" rid="R444" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919381">

3120Guindon et al., 2006</a>

3121; <a href="#R1202" rid="R1202" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919219">

3122Ulugol et al., 2006</a>

3123). Interestingly, a recent study has implicated the endocannabinoid system in the analgesic activity of paracetamol (acetaminophen), the most widely used painkiller (<a href="#R918" rid="R918" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920228">

3124Ottani et al., 2006</a>

3125), and there is also evidence for endocannabinoid involvement in the action of some general anesthetics, such as propofol (<a href="#R948" rid="R948" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918790">

3126Patel et al., 2003</a>

3127; <a href="#R1073" rid="R1073" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919794">

3128Schelling et al., 2006</a>

3129).</p>

3130<p id="P57">

3131Cannabinoids exert their antinociceptive effects by complex mechanisms involving effects on the central nervous system (<a href="#R763" rid="R763" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919153">

3132Martin et al., 1993</a>

3133; <a href="#R511" rid="R511" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919852">

3134Hohmann et al., 1995</a>

3135, <a href="#R513" rid="R513" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653404">

31361998</a>

3137, <a href="#R514" rid="R514" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920335">

31381999</a>

3139; <a href="#R765" rid="R765" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920153">

3140Martin et al., 1995</a>

3141, <a href="#R762" rid="R762" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637210">

31421996</a>

3143, <a href="#R766" rid="R766" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920208">

31441998</a>

3145, <a href="#R761" rid="R761" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919865">

31461999a</a>

3147,<a href="#R764" rid="R764" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919772">

3148b</a>

3149; <a href="#R1011" rid="R1011" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918966">

3150Richardson et al., 1997</a>

3151, <a href="#R1012" rid="R1012" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919390">

31521998a</a>

3153,<a href="#R1013" rid="R1013" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637213">

3154b</a>

3155; <a href="#R823" rid="R823" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920060">

3156Meng et al., 1998</a>

3157; <a href="#R1146" rid="R1146" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919730">

3158Strangman et al., 1998</a>

3159; <a href="#R514" rid="R514" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919519">

3160Hohmann and Walker, 1999</a>

3161; <a href="#R335" rid="R335" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918718">

3162Fox et al., 2001</a>

3163), spinal cord (<a href="#R1303" rid="R1303" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919205">

3164Yaksh, 1981</a>

3165; <a href="#R686" rid="R686" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919686">

3166Lichtman and Martin, 1991a</a>

3167,<a href="#R687" rid="R687" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920102">

3168b</a>

3169; <a href="#R1280" rid="R1280" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920091">

3170Welch and Stevens, 1992</a>

3171; <a href="#R1011" rid="R1011" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918800">

3172Richardson et al., 1997</a>

3173, <a href="#R1012" rid="R1012" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920368">

31741998a</a>

3175,<a href="#R1013" rid="R1013" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637203">

3176b</a>

3177; <a href="#R513" rid="R513" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653355">

3178Hohmann et al., 1998</a>

3179; <a href="#R170" rid="R170" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920009">

3180Chapman, 1999</a>

3181; <a href="#R282" rid="R282" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918950">

3182Drew et al., 2000</a>

3183; <a href="#R873" rid="R873" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919170">

3184Naderi et al., 2005</a>

3185; <a href="#R1156" rid="R1156" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653470">

3186Suplita et al., 2006</a>

3187), and peripheral sensory nerves (<a href="#R148" rid="R148" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920113">

3188Calignano et al., 1998</a>

3189; <a href="#R1014" rid="R1014" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920077">

3190Richardson et al., 1998c</a>

3191; <a href="#R509" rid="R509" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919096">

3192Hohmann and Herkenham, 1999</a>

3193; <a href="#R335" rid="R335" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919317">

3194Fox et al., 2001</a>

3195; <a href="#R565" rid="R565" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920011">

3196Johanek et al., 2001</a>

3197; <a href="#R596" rid="R596" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920213">

3198Kelly et al., 2003</a>

3199; <a href="#R566" rid="R566" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919910">

3200Johanek and Simone, 2004</a>

3201; <a href="#R573" rid="R573" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918746">

3202Jordt et al., 2004</a>

3203; <a href="#R17" rid="R17" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488955">

3204Amaya et al., 2006</a>

3205). This is consistent with the anatomical location of CB<sub>

32061</sub>

3207 receptors in areas relevant to pain in the brain, spinal dorsal horn, dorsal root ganglia, and peripheral afferent neurons (<a href="#R486" rid="R486" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919488">

3208Herkenham et al., 1990</a>

3209, <a href="#R484" rid="R484" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919257">

32101991a</a>

3211; <a href="#R508" rid="R508" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920086">

3212Hohmann and Herkenham, 1998</a>

3213, <a href="#R509" rid="R509" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919088">

32141999</a>

3215; <a href="#R506" rid="R506" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920021">

3216Hohmann et al., 1999</a>

3217; <a href="#R1062" rid="R1062" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653397">

3218Sa&#x000f1;udoPe&#x000f1;a et al., 1999a</a>

3219).</p>

3220<p id="P58">

3221In addition to the role of CB<sub>

32221</sub>

3223 receptors, there is recent evidence implicating CB<sub>

32242</sub>

3225 receptors in the antihyperalgesic activity of cannabinoids in models of acute and chronic, neuropathic pain, especially of inflammatory origin (<a href="#R148" rid="R148" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920369">

3226Calignano et al., 1998</a>

3227; <a href="#R467" rid="R467" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918873">

3228Hanus et al., 1999</a>

3229; <a href="#R735" rid="R735" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918932">

3230Malan et al., 2001</a>

3231; <a href="#R185" rid="R185" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919434">

3232Clayton et al., 2002</a>

3233; <a href="#R534" rid="R534" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919338">

3234Ibrahim et al., 2003</a>

3235, <a href="#R535" rid="R535" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920184">

32362005</a>

3237; <a href="#R870" rid="R870" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920025">

3238Nackley et al., 2003a</a>

3239,<a href="#R871" rid="R871" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919808">

3240b</a>

3241, <a href="#R872" rid="R872" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919758">

32422004</a>

3243; <a href="#R990" rid="R990" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919917">

3244Quartilho et al., 2003</a>

3245; <a href="#R296" rid="R296" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919683">

3246Elmes et al., 2004</a>

3247; <a href="#R507" rid="R507" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918832">

3248Hohmann et al., 2004</a>

3249; <a href="#R1083" rid="R1083" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918678">

3250Scott et al., 2004</a>

3251; <a href="#R1284" rid="R1284" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920398">

3252Whiteside et al., 2005</a>

3253; <a href="#R536" rid="R536" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920338">

3254Ibrahim et al., 2006</a>

3255).
