Cannabinoid agonists may also release endogenous opioids, and a functional interplay between the endocannabinoid and opioid systems in modulating analgesic responses has been suggested by numerous studies (<a href="#R988" rid="R988" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920089">

3256Pugh et al., 1997</a>

3257; <a href="#R746" rid="R746" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919870">

3258Manzanares et al., 1999a</a>

3259,<a href="#R747" rid="R747" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918911">

3260b</a>

3261; <a href="#R524" rid="R524" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918765">

3262Houser et al., 2000</a>

3263; <a href="#R535" rid="R535" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920281">

3264Ibrahim et al., 2005</a>

3265; <a href="#R1174" rid="R1174" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919901">

3266Tham et al., 2005</a>

3267; <a href="#R1232" rid="R1232" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918826">

3268Vigano et al., 2005a</a>

3269,<a href="#R1233" rid="R1233" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919476">

3270b</a>

3271; <a href="#R1290" rid="R1290" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919339">

3272Williams et al., 2006</a>

3273).</p>

3274<p id="P59">

3275As discussed before, anandamide is also a ligand for TRPV<sub>

32761</sub>

3277 receptors, albeit with an affinity lower than its affinity for CB<sub>

32781</sub>

3279 receptors. The potential involvement of TRPV<sub>

32801</sub>

3281 in the analgesic effect of endogenous anandamide has been raised by the findings that the analgesic response to microinjection of a FAAH antagonist into the periaqueductal gray of rats could be inhibited by a similar local microinjection of 6 nmol of capsazepine (<a href="#R733" rid="R733" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919321">

3282Maione et al., 2006</a>

3283). However, others reported that systemic administration of 10 mg/kg capsazepine, which blocked capsaicin-induced analgesia, failed to inhibit endocannabinoid-mediated, stress-induced analgesia, which could be enhanced by a FAAH inhibitor and completely blocked by the CB<sub>

32841</sub>

3285 antagonist rimonabant (<a href="#R1156" rid="R1156" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653433">

3286Suplita et al., 2006</a>

3287).</p>

3288<p id="P60">

3289The analgesic response to exogenous cannabinoids suggested a role for the endocannabinoid system in regulating pain sensitivity, which has received experimental support (reviewed in <a href="#R1255" rid="R1255" class=" bibr popnode">

3290Walker et al., 2000</a>

3291, <a href="#R1257" rid="R1257" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919104">

32922002</a>

3293; <a href="#R225" rid="R225" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919014">

3294Cravatt et al., 2004</a>

3295; <a href="#R102" rid="R102" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919816">

3296Boger et al., 2005</a>

3297). For example, <a href="#R1256" rid="R1256" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918705">

3298Walker et al. (1999)</a>

3299 have demonstrated increased anandamide levels in some brain areas involved in nociception after peripheral nociceptive input in the rat. The functional role of endogenous anandamide was further supported by the predominantly CB<sub>

33001</sub>

3301-mediated analgesic response to FAAH or endocannabinoid transport inhibitors in animal models of acute and chronic pain (<a href="#R685" rid="R685" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920012">

3302Lichtman et al., 2004a</a>

3303; <a href="#R168" rid="R168" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919113">

3304Chang et al., 2006</a>

3305; <a href="#R553" rid="R553" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920283">

3306Jayamanne et al., 2006</a>

3307; <a href="#R652" rid="R652" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920139">

3308La Rana et al., 2006</a>

3309; <a href="#R1156" rid="R1156" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653460">

3310Suplita et al., 2006</a>

3311). Similarly, FAAH knockout mice had elevated brain levels of anandamide and displayed analgesic behavior in acute inflammatory, but not in chronic neuropathic models of pain (<a href="#R688" rid="R688" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919779">

3312Lichtman et al., 2004b</a>

3313). Formation of anandamide and 2-AG is also increased in response to stress in the periaqueductal gray matter, in which inhibition of endocannabinoid degradation was found to enhance stress-induced analgesia in a CB<sub>

33141</sub>

3315 receptor-dependent manner (<a href="#R512" rid="R512" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920024">

3316Hohmann et al., 2005</a>

3317; <a href="#R1156" rid="R1156" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653495">

3318Suplita et al., 2006</a>

3319), confirming and extending an earlier finding that implicated CB<sub>

33201</sub>

3321 receptors and endocannabinoids in stress-induced analgesia (<a href="#R1209" rid="R1209" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920379">

3322Valverde et al., 2000</a>

3323).</p>

3324<p id="P61">

3325In humans, the analgesic activity of THC and other cannabinoids is less clear-cut. There are numerous case reports on the beneficial effects of cannabis or synthetic derivatives of THC in pain associated with multiple sclerosis, cancer, neuropathies, and HIV infection (<a href="#R898" rid="R898" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918829">

3326Noyes et al., 1975a</a>

3327,<a href="#R899" rid="R899" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653526">

3328b</a>

3329; <a href="#R770" rid="R770" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918990">

3330Martyn et al., 1995</a>

3331; <a href="#R204" rid="R204" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919747">

3332Consroe et al., 1997</a>

3333; <a href="#R459" rid="R459" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918858">

3334Hamann and di Vadi, 1999</a>

3335; <a href="#R1274" rid="R1274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920151">

3336Ware et al., 2003</a>

3337; <a href="#R1047" rid="R1047" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919887">

3338Rudich et al., 2003</a>

3339; <a href="#R1272" rid="R1272" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653420">

3340Ware and Beaulieu, 2005</a>

3341; <a href="#R1273" rid="R1273" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919575">

3342Ware et al., 2005</a>

3343; <a href="#R71" rid="R71" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919301">

3344Berlach et al., 2006</a>

3345; reviewed in <a href="#R133" rid="R133" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919704">

3346Burns and Ineck, 2006</a>

3347) (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

3348<span>

3349Table 1</span>

3350</a>

3351). The results of randomized studies conducted before 1999 on the analgesic effect of orally administered synthetic cannabinoids in patients with postoperative, post-traumatic, cancer, or spastic pain had been subjected to a meta-analysis. The authors concluded that cannabinoids were not more effective than codeine in controlling pain, and their use was associated with numerous undesirable, dose-limiting CNS side effects (<a href="#R150" rid="R150" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919077">

3352Campbell et al., 2001</a>

3353).</p>

3354<p id="P62">

3355Recent clinical trials with THC or cannabis extracts containing a 1:1 mixture of THC and cannabidiol (Sativex, GW-1000) have provided mixed results. In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study of 48 patients suffering from central neuropathic pain due to brachial plexus avulsion, oromucosally administered THC or Sativex was ineffective in reducing the pain severity score recorded during the last 7 days of treatment (<a href="#R72" rid="R72" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918880">

3356Berman et al., 2004</a>

3357). Similarly, oral THC (dronabinol) did not improve postoperative (<a href="#R129" rid="R129" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919615">

3358Buggy et al., 2003</a>

3359) and neuropathic pain (<a href="#R31" rid="R31" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918869">

3360Attal et al., 2004</a>

3361) in trials involving small numbers of patients. However, numerous lessons have been learned from these initial human studies on optimal trial design, dose and route of administration of cannabinoids, and more recent larger-scale studies allow reason for more optimism, as outlined below.</p>

3362<p id="P63">

3363THC or Sativex reduced neuropathic pain in patients with traumatic nerve injury or multiple sclerosis in randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover trials (<a href="#R1245" rid="R1245" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919817">

3364Wade et al., 2003</a>

3365; <a href="#R897" rid="R897" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918836">

3366Notcutt et al., 2004</a>

3367). Modest, but clinically relevant analgesic effects were reported in 21 multiple sclerosis patients treated with dronabinol, in a randomized, controlled clinical trial (<a href="#R1157" rid="R1157" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919004">

3368Svendsen et al., 2004</a>

3369). Effective pain relief by orally administered cannabis extract or THC was also reported in a randomized, controlled, multicenter trial involving 611 multiple sclerosis patients (<a href="#R1312" rid="R1312" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919253">

3370Zajicek et al., 2003</a>

3371). Moreover, in a recent study of 66 multiple sclerosis patients, Sativex was effective in reducing central neuropathic pain (<a href="#R1029" rid="R1029" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919606">

3372Rog et al., 2005</a>

3373). A preview of as-yet-unpublished human studies gave an account of a significant benefit of Sativex over placebo in peripheral neuropathic pain characterized by allodynia, in central pain associated with multiple sclerosis, and in opiate-resistant, intractable pain due to cancer (<a href="#R1050" rid="R1050" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920323">

3374Russo, 2006</a>

3375). A multicenter dose-escalation study of the analgesic and adverse effects of an oral cannabis extract (Cannador) in patients with postoperative pain demonstrated significant dose-related improvements in rescue analgesia requirements and significant trends across the escalating dose groups for decreasing pain intensity (<a href="#R519" rid="R519" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919968">

3376Holdcroft et al. 2006</a>

3377). THC (Marinol) was found to suppress otherwise intractable cholestatic pruritus in a case report (<a href="#R882" rid="R882" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920363">

3378Neff et al., 2002</a>

3379). An analysis of pain questionnaires from 523 patients with HIV infections revealed that 90 to 94% of the subjects using cannabis experienced improvement in muscle and neuropathic pain (<a href="#R1301" rid="R1301" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919206">

3380Woolridge et al., 2005</a>

3381). The therapeutic potential of cannabinoids in pain associated with trigeminal neuralgia and migraine has also been the subject of several recent reviews (<a href="#R683" rid="R683" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920241">

3382Liang et al., 2004</a>

3383; <a href="#R1051" rid="R1051" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919379">

3384Russo, 2004</a>

3385, <a href="#R1050" rid="R1050" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919106">

33862006</a>

3387). Preclinical studies (<a href="#R137" rid="R137" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918714">

3388Burstein et al., 1998</a>

3389, <a href="#R138" rid="R138" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919198">

33902004</a>

3391; <a href="#R135" rid="R135" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920169">

3392Burstein, 2000</a>

3393, <a href="#R134" rid="R134" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920016">

33942005</a>

3395; <a href="#R290" rid="R290" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919700">

3396Dyson et al., 2005</a>

3397; <a href="#R838" rid="R838" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920020">

3398Mitchell et al., 2005</a>

3399; <a href="#R1056" rid="R1056" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919309">

3400Salim et al., 2005</a>

3401) and a recent clinical trial of 24 patients with neuropathic pain of varying etiologies demonstrated that ajulemic acid, a major metabolite of THC with CB<sub>

34021</sub>

3403 agonist activity, was effective in reducing pain without causing cannabinoid-like CNS side effects, the first evidence for the separability of the psychotropic and analgesic effects of a THC analog in humans (<a href="#R588" rid="R588" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653508">

3404Karst et al., 2003</a>

3405). Numerous additional human studies are ongoing to determine the effectiveness of THC or cannabis-based extracts against various forms of pain (reviewed in <a href="#R1272" rid="R1272" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653468">

3406Ware and Beaulieu, 2005</a>

3407 reviewed in Ware and Beaulieu, 2006).</p>

3408<p id="P64">

3409Multiple lines of evidence support the important role of the cannabinoid signaling system in the modulation of immune function and inflammation (reviewed in <a href="#R613" rid="R613" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919366">

3410Klein et al., 1998</a>

3411, <a href="#R615" rid="R615" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919904">

34122003</a>

3413; <a href="#R1262" rid="R1262" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919239">

3414Walter and Stella, 2004</a>

3415; <a href="#R612" rid="R612" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919763">

3416Klein, 2005</a>

3417). First, cannabinoid receptors are present on immune cells, where their expression is modulated by microbial antigens or other stimuli that induce immune activation. Second, stimulation of immune cells by bacterial toxins such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS) increases the cellular levels of endocannabinoids and their degrading enzyme(s). Third, cannabinoid agonists modulate immune function both in vitro and in vivo via cannabinoid receptor-dependent and -independent mechanisms.</p>

3418<p id="P65" class="p p-last">

3419The anti-inflammatory effects of cannabinoids are complex and may involve modulation of cytokine (e.g., TNF-<em>

3420&#x003b1;</em>

3421, IL-12, IL-1, IL-6, and IL-10) and chemokine production (e.g., CCL2, CCL5, CXCL8, and CXCL10), modulation of adenosine signaling (<a href="#R158" rid="R158" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919346">

3422Carrier et al., 2006</a>

3423), expression of adhesion molecules (e.g., ICAM-1, P- intercellular adhesion molecule-1 and P-selectin), and the migration, proliferation, and apoptosis of inflammatory cells (reviewed in <a href="#R613" rid="R613" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919357">

3424Klein et al., 1998</a>

3425, <a href="#R615" rid="R615" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920045">

34262003</a>

3427; <a href="#R1262" rid="R1262" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919702">

3428Walter and Stella, 2004</a>

3429; <a href="#R612" rid="R612" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919377">

3430Klein, 2005</a>

3431). To the extent that pain and inflammation accompany many of the disorders discussed in the rest of this review, cannabinoids would be expected to provide significant benefit due to their analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties.</p>

3432</div>

3433<div id="S13" class="sec">

3434<h3 id="S13title">

3435C. Central Nervous System Disorders</h3>

3436<p id="P66" class="p p-first">

3437The emerging role of the endocannabinoid system in a variety of CNS disorders should not come as a surprise given the very high level of expression of CB<sub>

34381</sub>

3439 receptors in the brain. The particularly high density of CB<sub>

34401</sub>

3441 receptors in the cortex, cerebellum, hippocampus, and basal ganglia had drawn early attention to diseases affecting movement, mood and anxiety disorders, and conditions related to altered brain reward mechanisms, as well as processes of memory and learning. The classic behavioral effects of marijuana also provided early clues about potential therapeutic targets, such as the control of pain or appetite. The role of the endocannabinoid system in the pathogenesis and treatment of specific CNS diseases is discussed below.</p>

3442<div id="S14" class="sec">

3443<p>

3444</p>

3445<h4 id="S14title" class="inline">

34461. Neurotoxicity and Neurotrauma </h4>

3447<p id="P67" class="p p-first">

3448The endocannabinoid system plays an important role in neuroprotection both in acute neuronal injury (e.g., traumatic brain injury, stroke, and epilepsy) and in chronic neurodegenerative disorders, such as multiple sclerosis, Parkinson&#x02019;s disease, Huntington&#x02019;s disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and Alzheimer&#x02019;s disease (reviewed in <a href="#R395" rid="R395" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918835">

3449Glass, 2001</a>

3450; <a href="#R811" rid="R811" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653400">

3451Mechoulam et al., 2002a</a>

3452,<a href="#R812" rid="R812" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918926">

3453b</a>

3454; <a href="#R438" rid="R438" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653475">

3455Grundy, 2002</a>

3456; <a href="#R230" rid="R230" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918998">

3457Croxford, 2003</a>

3458; <a href="#R284" rid="R284" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919001">

3459Drysdale and Platt, 2003</a>

3460; <a href="#R550" rid="R550" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918903">

3461Jackson et al., 2005a</a>

3462; <a href="#R997" rid="R997" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919351">

3463Ramos et al., 2005</a>

3464). Although the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood, multiple cannabinoid receptor-dependent as well as receptor-independent processes have been implicated. These include, but are not limited to 1) modulation of excitatory glutamatergic transmissions and synaptic plasticity via presynaptic CB<sub>

34651</sub>

3466 receptors (<a href="#R842" rid="R842" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920251">

3467Molina-Holgado et al., 1997</a>

3468; <a href="#R752" rid="R752" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919108">

3469Marsicano and Lutz, 1999</a>

3470; <a href="#R381" rid="R381" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919217">

3471Gerdeman et al., 2002</a>

3472; reviewed in <a href="#R12" rid="R12" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920324">

3473Alger, 2002</a>

3474; <a href="#R1024" rid="R1024" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920381">

3475Robbe et al., 2002</a>

3476; <a href="#R34" rid="R34" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919078">

3477Azad et al., 2003</a>

3478; <a href="#R345" rid="R345" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919131">

3479Freund et al., 2003</a>

3480; <a href="#R379" rid="R379" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919805">

3481Gerdeman and Lovinger, 2003</a>

3482; <a href="#R972" rid="R972" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919496">

3483Piomelli, 2003</a>

3484; <a href="#R781" rid="R781" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920244">

3485Mato et al., 2004</a>

3486), 2) modulation of immune responses and the release of inflammatory mediators by CB<sub>

34871</sub>

3488, CB<sub>

34892</sub>

3490, and non CB<sub>

34911</sub>

3492/CB<sub>

34932</sub>

3494 receptors on neurons, astrocytes, microglia, macrophages, neutrophils and lymphocytes (<a href="#R1276" rid="R1276" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919871">

3495Watzl et al., 1991</a>

3496; <a href="#R1320" rid="R1320" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918848">

3497Zheng et al., 1992</a>

3498; <a href="#R324" rid="R324" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919828">

3499Fischer-Stenger et al., 1993</a>

3500; <a href="#R140" rid="R140" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919406">

3501Cabral and Fischer-Stenger, 1994</a>

3502; Kusher et al., 1994; <a href="#R132" rid="R132" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919669">

3503Burnette-Curley and Cabral, 1995</a>

3504; <a href="#R142" rid="R142" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919497">

3505Cabral et al., 1995</a>

3506; reviewed in <a href="#R351" rid="R351" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920042">

3507Friedman et al., 1995</a>

3508; <a href="#R1321" rid="R1321" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919896">

3509Zheng and Specter, 1996</a>

3510; <a href="#R1095" rid="R1095" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920205">

3511Shohami et al., 1997</a>

3512; <a href="#R887" rid="R887" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918928">

3513Newton et al., 1998</a>

3514; <a href="#R1132" rid="R1132" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919192">

3515Srivastava et al., 1998</a>

3516; <a href="#R355" rid="R355" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918799">

3517Gallily et al., 2000</a>

3518; <a href="#R614" rid="R614" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919475">

3519Klein et al., 2000a</a>

3520,<a href="#R616" rid="R616" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919726">

3521b</a>

3522, <a href="#R615" rid="R615" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918727">

35232003</a>

3524; <a href="#R1120" rid="R1120" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919697">

3525Smith et al., 2000</a>

3526; <a href="#R156" rid="R156" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919332">

3527Carlisle et al., 2002</a>

3528; <a href="#R382" rid="R382" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919486">

3529Germain et al., 2002</a>

3530; <a href="#R599" rid="R599" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918749">

3531Killestein et al., 2003</a>

3532; <a href="#R582" rid="R582" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920129">

3533Kaplan et al., 2005</a>

3534; <a href="#R996" rid="R996" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637235">

3535Ramirez et al., 2005</a>

3536; reviewed in <a href="#R351" rid="R351" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918760">

3537Friedman et al., 1995</a>

3538; <a href="#R1138" rid="R1138" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919365">

3539Stella, 2004</a>

3540; <a href="#R1262" rid="R1262" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920073">

3541Walter and Stella, 2004</a>

3542; <a href="#R210" rid="R210" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918983">

3543Correa et al., 2005</a>

3544; <a href="#R232" rid="R232" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919030">

3545Croxford and Yamamura, 2005</a>

3546; <a href="#R612" rid="R612" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920280">

3547Klein, 2005</a>

3548;), 3) activation of cytoprotective signaling pathways (<a href="#R431" rid="R431" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919003">

3549Grigorenko et al., 2002</a>

3550), such as protein kinase B/Akt (<a href="#R841" rid="R841" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637202">

3551Molina-Holgado et al., 2002</a>

3552), protein kinase A (<a href="#R606" rid="R606" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920272">

3553Kim et al., 2005</a>

3554), or neurotrophic factors (<a href="#R598" rid="R598" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919953">

3555Khaspekov et al., 2004</a>

3556), 4) modulation of excitability and calcium homeostasis via effects on Ca<sup>

35572+</sup>

3558, K<sup>

3559+</sup>

3560, and Na<sup>

3561+</sup>

3562 channels, <em>

3563N</em>

3564-methyl D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors, gap junctions, and intracellular Ca<sup>

35652+</sup>

3566 stores (<a href="#R163" rid="R163" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919796">

3567Caulfield and Brown, 1992</a>

3568; <a href="#R727" rid="R727" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919371">

3569Mackie and Hille, 1992</a>

3570; <a href="#R726" rid="R726" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919660">

3571Mackie et al., 1993</a>

3572; <a href="#R874" rid="R874" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919029">

3573Nadler et al., 1995</a>

3574; <a href="#R1225" rid="R1225" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919187">

3575Venance et al., 1995</a>

3576; <a href="#R1095" rid="R1095" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918918">

3577Shohami et al., 1997</a>

3578; <a href="#R462" rid="R462" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920158">

3579Hampson et al., 2000b</a>

3580; <a href="#R920" rid="R920" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919611">

3581Oz et al., 2000</a>

3582, <a href="#R919" rid="R919" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920175">

35832004</a>

3584; <a href="#R172" rid="R172" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653362">

3585Chemin et al., 2001</a>

3586; <a href="#R732" rid="R732" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653517">

3587Maingret et al., 2001</a>

3588; <a href="#R895" rid="R895" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919256">

3589Nogueron et al., 2001</a>

3590; <a href="#R1023" rid="R1023" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637223">

3591Robbe et al., 2001</a>

3592; <a href="#R1294" rid="R1294" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920132">

3593Wilson and Nicoll, 2001</a>

3594; <a href="#R1293" rid="R1293" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919168">

3595Wilson et al., 2001</a>

3596; <a href="#R891" rid="R891" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919277">

3597Nicholson et al., 2003</a>

3598; <a href="#R446" rid="R446" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920039">

3599Guo and Ikeda, 2004</a>

3600; <a href="#R256" rid="R256" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919024">

3601del Carmen et al., 2005</a>

3602; <a href="#R256" rid="R256" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919913">

3603del Carmen Godino et al., 2005</a>

3604; <a href="#R1323" rid="R1323" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919370">

3605Zhuang et al., 2005</a>

3606), 5) antioxidant properties of cannabinoids (<a href="#R305" rid="R305" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918744">

3607Eshhar et al., 1995</a>

3608; <a href="#R460" rid="R460" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919111">

3609Hampson et al., 1998</a>

3610; <a href="#R177" rid="R177" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920160">

3611Chen and Buck, 2000</a>

3612; reviewed in <a href="#R461" rid="R461" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919934">

3613Hampson et al., 2000a</a>

3614; <a href="#R754" rid="R754" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919399">

3615Marsicano et al., 2002a</a>

3616), and 6) CB<sub>

36171</sub>

3618 receptor-mediated hypothermia, possibly by reducing metabolic rate and oxygen demand (<a href="#R671" rid="R671" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920056">

3619Leker et al., 2003</a>

3620).</p>

3621<p id="P68">

3622Excitotoxicity, the toxic effects of an overactivation of glutamate receptors, and the resulting oxidative stress may contribute to the pathological processes eventually leading to cellular dysfunction or death in both acute and chronic forms of neurodegeneration (<a href="#R220" rid="R220" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653461">

3623Coyle and Puttfarcken, 1993</a>

3624; <a href="#R802" rid="R802" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919676">

3625McNamara, 1999</a>

3626; <a href="#R713" rid="R713" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919443">

3627Lutz, 2004</a>

3628). Dexanabinol (HU-211), a behaviorally inactive cannabinoid and noncompetitive antagonist of NMDA receptors, protects primary rat neuronal cultures against NMDA and glutamate exposure in vitro (<a href="#R304" rid="R304" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918692">

3629Eshhar et al., 1993</a>

3630; <a href="#R875" rid="R875" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918914">

3631Nadler et al., 1993a</a>

3632,<a href="#R876" rid="R876" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919802">

3633b</a>

3634). THC protects primary cultured neurons against kainate-mediated toxicity in a CB<sub>

36351</sub>

3636-dependent manner (<a href="#R4" rid="R4" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918734">

3637Abood et al., 2001</a>

3638), similar to protectin by WIN 55,212-2 against low extracellular magnesium-induced cell death (<a href="#R1092" rid="R1092" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919319">

3639Shen and Thayer, 1998</a>

3640). Palmitoylethanolamide also improves neuronal survival in a glutamate-induced cell death model (<a href="#R1114" rid="R1114" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919363">

3641Skaper et al., 1996</a>

3642). Intracerebral injection of NMDA in neonatal rats results in a 13-fold increase of cortical anandamide concentrations (<a href="#R463" rid="R463" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919682">

3643Hansen et al., 2001a</a>

3644,<a href="#R464" rid="R464" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919807">

3645b</a>

3646). Both THC and anandamide exerted CB<sub>

36471</sub>

3648-mediated neuroprotective effects in an ouabain-induced rat model of in vivo excitotoxicity (<a href="#R1213" rid="R1213" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637189">

3649van de Stelt et al., 2001a</a>

3650,<a href="#R1214" rid="R1214" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637208">

3651b</a>

3652). Anandamide and synthetic agonists of CB<sub>

36531</sub>

3654 receptors also protected the newborn brain against AMPA-kainate receptor-mediated excitotoxic damage in mice (<a href="#R1099" rid="R1099" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919124">

3655Shouman et al., 2006</a>

3656).</p>

3657<p id="P69">

3658Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is one of the leading causes of disability and mortality in young individuals (<a href="#R520" rid="R520" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919547">

3659Holm et al., 2005</a>

3660), yet the available therapy is very limited (<a href="#R309" rid="R309" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919975">

3661Faden, 2002</a>

3662; <a href="#R715" rid="R715" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919624">

3663Maas et al., 2004</a>

3664). TBI is characterized by cerebral edema, axonal and neuronal injury, increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier, and post-traumatic changes in cognitive and neurological functions (<a href="#R53" rid="R53" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920277">

3665Bayir et al., 2003</a>

3666). TBI can trigger glutamate-induced excitotoxicity, oxidative stress, release of inflammatory cytokines from brain-resident cells (microglia, neurons, and astrocytes), programmed cell death, and cortical blood flow dysregulation (reviewed in <a href="#R1268" rid="R1268" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919909">

3667Wang and Feuerstein, 2000</a>

3668; <a href="#R376" rid="R376" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920349">

3669Gentleman et al., 2004</a>

3670).</p>

3671<p id="P70">

3672The protective effect of cannabinoids in traumatic brain injury was first indicated in studies with the nonpsychotropic cannabinoid dexanabinol (HU-211) (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F1/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F1" rid-ob="ob-F1" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F1">

3673<span>

3674Fig. 1b</span>

3675</a>

3676). These studies have demonstrated reduced brain damage and improved motor and cognitive function in HU-211-treated animals in a rat model of TBI. The favorable effects of a single injection of HU-211 on learning and neurological deficits lasted up to 30 days and could be achieved within a therapeutic window of 6 h (<a href="#R1097" rid="R1097" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918980">

3677Shohami et al., 1993</a>

3678, <a href="#R1096" rid="R1096" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919368">

36791995</a>

3680). Beneficial effects of HU-211 were also demonstrated in an axonal injury model (<a href="#R1308" rid="R1308" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919557">

3681Yoles et al., 1996</a>

3682; <a href="#R1313" rid="R1313" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920235">

3683Zalish and Lavie, 2003</a>

3684). These protective effects were attributed, at least in part, to NMDA receptor blockade, attenuation of Ca<sup>

36852+</sup>

3686 influx and decreased TNF-<em>

3687&#x003b1;</em>

3688 levels (<a href="#R874" rid="R874" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919605">

3689Nadler et al., 1995</a>

3690; <a href="#R1095" rid="R1095" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919386">

3691Shohami et al., 1997</a>

3692; reviewed in <a href="#R811" rid="R811" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653371">

3693Mechoulam et al., 2002a</a>

3694,<a href="#R812" rid="R812" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920146">

3695b</a>

3696; <a href="#R82" rid="R82" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920375">

3697Biegon, 2004</a>

3698). In mice with closed head injury, brain levels of 2-AG increased, and exogenous 2-AG administered 1 h after the head injury reduced infarct size and improved neurological outcome (<a href="#R933" rid="R933" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919195">

3699Panikashvili et al., 2001</a>

3700). Neuroprotection by 2-AG was attributed to CB<sub>

37011</sub>

3702 receptor-mediated inhibition of nuclear factor-<em>

3703&#x003ba;</em>

3704B and of the early expression of proinflammatory cytokines TNF-<em>

3705&#x003b1;</em>

3706, IL-1<em>

3707&#x003b2;</em>

3708, and IL-6 (<a href="#R931" rid="R931" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919602">

3709Panikashvili et al., 2005</a>

3710, <a href="#R932" rid="R932" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920038">

37112006</a>

3712). In a rat model of TBI, BAY 38-7271, a CB<sub>

37131</sub>

3714/CB<sub>

37152</sub>

3716 agonist with predominant action at CB<sub>

37171</sub>

3718 receptors, caused a marked, 70% reduction in infarct volume when administered as a 4-h infusion immediately after induction of subdural hematoma, and even when it was applied with a 3-h delay, infarct volume was reduced by 59% (<a href="#R784" rid="R784" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919739">

3719Mauler et al., 2002</a>

3720).</p>

3721<p id="P71" class="p p-last">

3722A multicenter, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled phase II trial conducted in 67 patients with severe closed head injury found dexanabinol to be safe and well tolerated. The treated patients achieved significantly better intracranial pressure/cerebral perfusion pressure control without jeopardizing blood pressure, and a trend toward faster improvement and better neurological outcome was also observed (<a href="#R618" rid="R618" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919466">

3723Knoller et al., 2002</a>

3724). However, a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled phase III clinical trial of dexanabinol, conducted in 15 countries in 86 specialized centers and involving 861 patients failed to demonstrate any favorable effects (<a href="#R716" rid="R716" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919337">

3725Maas et al., 2006</a>

3726).</p>

3727</div>

3728<div id="S15" class="sec">

3729<p>

3730</p>

3731<h4 id="S15title" class="inline">

37322. Stroke </h4>

3733<p id="P72" class="p p-first">

3734Ischemic stroke is the most common form of stroke, mostly caused by a transient interruption of blood supply to the brain by thrombotic occlusion of blood vessels. It is an important cause of death and disability in industrialized countries, affecting up to 0.2% of the population each year (<a href="#R617" rid="R617" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920362">

3735Klijn and Hankey, 2003</a>

3736; <a href="#R969" rid="R969" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919565">

3737Pinto et al., 2004</a>

3738). One in six patients die in the 1st month after ischemic stroke, and half of the survivors are permanently disabled despite the best efforts to rehabilitate them and to prevent complications (<a href="#R617" rid="R617" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920293">

3739Klijn and Hankey, 2003</a>

3740).</p>

3741<p id="P73">

3742One of the first indications of the neuroprotective effect of cannabinoids came from the field of stroke research, using various in vitro and in vivo models of ischemic injury. Anandamide, 2-AG, and WIN 55,212-2 protected cultured cortical neurons against hypoxia and glucose deprivation (<a href="#R877" rid="R877" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637217">

3743Nagayama et al., 1999</a>

3744; <a href="#R1110" rid="R1110" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919320">

3745Sinor et al., 2000</a>

3746). The effects of various cannabinoid ligands were also investigated in in vivo models of global cerebral ischemia induced by two-vessel occlusion with hypotension or by four-vessel occlusion, or in focal ischemia induced by occlusion of the middle cerebral artery (MCAo), with or without reperfusion. Dexanabinol at doses of 2 to 10 mg/kg decreased infarct size and histological damage and improved neurological score in rat and gerbil models of both global and focal cerebral ischemia (<a href="#R43" rid="R43" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919922">

3747Bar-Joseph et al., 1994</a>

3748; <a href="#R1226" rid="R1226" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653381">

3749Vered et al., 1994</a>

3750 a,b; <a href="#R60" rid="R60" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920306">

3751Belayev et al., 1995a</a>

3752,<a href="#R61" rid="R61" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920126">

3753b</a>

3754,<a href="#R62" rid="R62" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920391">

3755c</a>

3756; <a href="#R672" rid="R672" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919962">

3757Leker et al., 1999</a>

3758; <a href="#R662" rid="R662" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919894">

3759Lavie et al., 2001</a>

3760; <a href="#R1170" rid="R1170" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918708">

3761Teichner et al., 2003</a>

3762). Importantly, this protective effect was observed even when the drug was administered 60 to 180 min after the insult (<a href="#R1226" rid="R1226" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653418">

3763Vered et al., 1994</a>

3764; <a href="#R60" rid="R60" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918910">

3765Belayev et al., 1995a</a>

3766,<a href="#R61" rid="R61" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918807">

3767b</a>

3768,<a href="#R62" rid="R62" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919972">

3769c</a>

3770; <a href="#R672" rid="R672" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918854">

3771Leker et al., 1999</a>

3772; <a href="#R662" rid="R662" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920143">

3773Lavie et al., 2001</a>

3774; <a href="#R1170" rid="R1170" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919888">

3775Teichner et al., 2003</a>

3776).</p>

3777<p id="P74">

3778WIN 55,212-2, at doses of 0.03 and 1 mg/kg but not 3 mg/kg decreased hippocampal neuronal loss after transient global cerebral ischemia in rats. It also reduced infarct size after permanent focal cerebral ischemia induced by MCAo, when given 40 min before 30 min after the occlusion, and these effects were prevented by SR141716 (<a href="#R877" rid="R877" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637212">

3779Nagayama et al., 1999</a>

3780). WIN 55,212-2 also protected cultured cerebral cortical neurons from in vitro hypoxia and glucose deprivation, but in contrast to the receptor-mediated neuroprotection observed in vivo, this in vitro effect was not stereoselective and was insensitive to CB<sub>

37811</sub>

3782 and CB<sub>

37832</sub>

3784 receptor antagonists (<a href="#R877" rid="R877" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637211">

3785Nagayama et al., 1999</a>

3786). BAY38-7271 also decreased infarct size in rats with permanent MCAo even when given intravenously 4 h after the occlusion (<a href="#R784" rid="R784" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919566">

3787Mauler et al., 2002</a>

3788). Similarly, HU-210 reduced infarct size by up to 77% and improved motor disability in a rat model of permanent MCAo (<a href="#R671" rid="R671" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919684">

3789Leker et al., 2003</a>

3790). The protective effect of HU-210 was partially reversed by pretreatment with SR141716, indicating CB<sub>

37911</sub>

3792 receptor involvement. Surprisingly, all protection could be abolished by warming the animals to the body temperature of controls, indicating that CB<sub>

37931</sub>

3794-mediated hypothermia contributed to the neuroprotection (<a href="#R671" rid="R671" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918730">

3795Leker et al., 2003</a>

3796). Likewise, CB<sub>

37971</sub>

3798-mediated hypothermia was responsible for the neuroprotective effects of THC in a mouse transient MCAo model (<a href="#R475" rid="R475" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919812">

3799Hayakawa et al., 2004</a>

3800) and perhaps also in a rat model of global cerebral ischemia (<a href="#R707" rid="R707" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920285">

3801Louw et al., 2000</a>

3802). Consistent with these findings, CB<sub>

38031</sub>

3804 knockout mice had increased mortality from permanent focal cerebral ischemia, increased infarct size, more severe neurological deficits after transient focal cerebral ischemia, and decreased cerebral blood flow in the ischemic penumbra during reperfusion, compared with wild type controls subjected to the same insult (<a href="#R941" rid="R941" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637185">

3805Parmentier-Batteur et al., 2002</a>

3806). NMDA neurotoxicity was also increased in CB<sub>

38071</sub>

3808<sup>

3809&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

3810 mice compared with wild-type littermates (<a href="#R941" rid="R941" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637191">

3811Parmentier-Batteur et al., 2002</a>

3812). Further evidence for a role of CB<sub>

38131</sub>

3814 receptors is their increased expression on neurons in the arterial boundary zone of cortical infarction (<a href="#R562" rid="R562" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919798">

3815Jin et al., 2000</a>

3816). Finally, brain levels of endocannabinoids are increased during ischemic (<a href="#R1075" rid="R1075" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920187">

3817Schmid et al., 1995</a>

3818; <a href="#R1072" rid="R1072" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919680">

3819Schabitz et al., 2002</a>

3820; <a href="#R69" rid="R69" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919191">

3821Berger et al., 2004</a>

3822; <a href="#R868" rid="R868" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919604">

3823Muthian et al., 2004</a>

3824) and other types of brain injury (<a href="#R1150" rid="R1150" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918685">

3825Sugiura et al., 2000</a>

3826; <a href="#R463" rid="R463" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918750">

3827Hansen et al., 2001a</a>

3828,<a href="#R464" rid="R464" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918755">

3829b</a>

3830; <a href="#R933" rid="R933" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919634">

3831Panikashvili et al., 2001</a>

3832).</p>

3833<p id="P75" class="p p-last">

3834Other studies do not support the neuroprotective role of CB<sub>

38351</sub>

3836 receptor activation. For example, CB<sub>

38371</sub>

3838 antagonists by themselves had no effect on the outcome of injury, and in two recent reports, SR141716 and <a id="__tag_814637250" class="tag_hotlink" href="/nuccore/LY320135" ref="/nuccore/LY320135">

3839<span class="tag-json" style="display:none">

3840{"type":"entrez-nucleotide","attrs":{"text":"LY320135","term_id":"1257555575","term_text":"LY320135"}}</span>

3841LY320135</a>

3842 were found to actually reduce infarct size and to improve neurological function in a rat model of MCAo (<a href="#R69" rid="R69" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919509">

3843Berger et al., 2004</a>

3844; <a href="#R868" rid="R868" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919176">

3845Muthian et al., 2004</a>

3846), whereas low doses of WIN 55,212-2 had no protective effect (<a href="#R868" rid="R868" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918897">

3847Muthian et al., 2004</a>

3848). Thus, it appears that both CB<sub>

38491</sub>

3850 agonists and antagonists can be neuroprotective in cerebral ischemia. The reason for the opposite effects of pharmacological blockade versus genetic knockout of CB<sub>

38511</sub>

3852 receptors is not clear and may be related to the CB<sub>

38531</sub>

3854 receptor-independent effects of antagonists (<a href="#R57" rid="R57" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919688">

3855Begg et al., 2005</a>

3856; <a href="#R958" rid="R958" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918863">

3857Pertwee, 2005b</a>

3858,<a href="#R959" rid="R959" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_539174734">

3859c</a>

3860). Clearly, evaluating the potential usefulness of cannabinoid ligands in the treatment of stroke warrants future studies.</p>

3861</div>

3862<div id="S16" class="sec">

3863<p>

3864</p>

3865<h4 id="S16title" class="inline">

38663. Multiple Sclerosis and Spinal Cord Injury </h4>

3867<p id="P76" class="p p-first">

3868Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex, immune-mediated, inflammatory disease of the white matter of the brain, which compromises impulse conduction due to the loss of the myelin sheath of neurons and the secondary axonal loss (<a href="#R1128" rid="R1128" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919262">

3869Sospedra and Martin, 2005</a>

3870). MS affects 2 to 5 million people worldwide and commonly presents with an unpredictable, relapsing-remitting course and a range of clinical symptoms depending on where the demyelination and axonal loss have occurred (<a href="#R199" rid="R199" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919432">

3871Compston and Coles, 2002</a>

3872). Some patients become disabled within a short period of time, whereas others can live their entire lives with only negligible or no disability. The symptoms of MS typically involve tremor, ataxia, visual loss, double vision, weakness or paralysis, difficulty in speaking, loss of bladder control and constipation, cognitive impairment, and painful muscle spasms. Muscle spasticity often leads to reduced mobility, considerable distress from pain, and interference with daily living activities. Spasticity, neuropathic and nociceptive pain, and some of the above symptoms are also common in spinal cord injury (SCI). Although there are numerous drugs available that target the immune system to slow down the progression of the disease, they are only moderately effective, and the treatment of MS remains mostly symptomatic and far from satisfactory (<a href="#R601" rid="R601" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920204">

3873Killestein and Polman, 2005</a>

3874).</p>

3875<p id="P77">

3876Cannabis had been used in ancient Greece, Rome, China, and India for relieving muscle cramps, spasm, and pain (reviewed in <a href="#R804" rid="R804" class=" bibr popnode">

3877Mechoulam, 1986</a>

3878, <a href="#R806" rid="R806" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918925">

3879Mechoulam et al., 1998</a>

3880; <a href="#R809" rid="R809" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918844">

3881Mechoulam and Hanus, 2000</a>

3882) and its therapeutic application in MS is a topic of recent lively debate (<a href="#R438" rid="R438" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653519">

3883Grundy, 2002</a>

3884; <a href="#R956" rid="R956" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919056">

3885Pertwee, 2002</a>

3886; <a href="#R35" rid="R35" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653421">

3887Baker and Pryce, 2003</a>

3888; <a href="#R230" rid="R230" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919204">

3889Croxford, 2003</a>

3890; <a href="#R602" rid="R602" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919701">

3891Killestein et al., 2004</a>

3892; <a href="#R1113" rid="R1113" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919342">

3893Sirven and Berg, 2004</a>

3894; <a href="#R550" rid="R550" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920103">

3895Jackson et al., 2005a</a>

3896; <a href="#R986" rid="R986" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918687">

3897Pryce and Baker, 2005</a>

3898; <a href="#R1025" rid="R1025" class=" bibr popnode">

3899Robson, 2005</a>

3900; <a href="#R1119" rid="R1119" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919711">

3901Smith, 2005</a>

3902). <a href="#R714" rid="R714" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919126">

3903Lyman et al. (1989)</a>

3904 examined the effects of parenteral THC in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in rats, a laboratory model of MS. THC treatment not only reduced CNS inflammation and improved neurological outcome but also improved survival compared with placebo. &#x00394;<sup>

39058</sup>

3906-THC, a less psychotropic and more stable analog of THC, also reduced the severity and incidence of neurological deficits in rats with EAE (<a href="#R1296" rid="R1296" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919032">

3907Wirguin et al., 1994</a>

3908). The nonpsychotropic dexanabinol also suppressed inflammatory responses in the brain and spinal cord of rats with EAE and improved their neurological symptoms (<a href="#R6" rid="R6" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919643">

3909Achiron et al., 2000</a>

3910). Although CB<sub>

39111</sub>

3912 receptor density is decreased in the striatum and cortex of EAE rats, this is compensated for by increased coupling to G protein-mediated signaling, ensuring the effectiveness of treatment with cannabinoid agonists (<a href="#R74" rid="R74" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919258">

3913Berrendero et al., 2001</a>

3914).</p>

3915<p id="P78">

3916In a mouse model of chronic relapsing EAE, intravenous administration of THC, WIN 55,212-2, JWH-133, or methanandamide reduced spasticity and tremor, whereas the same symptoms were exacerbated by treatment with either CB<sub>

39171</sub>

3918 or CB<sub>

39192</sub>

3920 antagonists (<a href="#R36" rid="R36" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920115">

3921Baker et al., 2000</a>

3922). These mice with EAE had increased levels of anandamide, 2-AG, and palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in areas associated with nerve damage (<a href="#R37" rid="R37" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920112">

3923Baker et al., 2001</a>

3924). Furthermore, spasticity could be relieved not only by administration of exogenous anandamide, 2-AG, or PEA but also by selective inhibitors of endocannabinoid transport or hydrolysis, which suggests tonic control of muscle tone by the endocannabinoid system in EAE (<a href="#R37" rid="R37" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919102">

3925Baker et al., 2001</a>

3926; <a href="#R689" rid="R689" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919392">

3927Ligresti et al., 2006a</a>

3928). Additional evidence for this has emerged through the use of CB<sub>

39291</sub>

3930-deficient mice, which tolerated inflammatory and excitotoxic insults poorly and developed substantial neurodegeneration after the induction of EAE (<a href="#R987" rid="R987" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919358">

3931Pryce et al., 2003</a>

3932). <a href="#R551" rid="R551" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920299">

3933Jackson et al. (2005b)</a>

3934 reported that the absence of CB<sub>

39351</sub>

3936 receptors was associated with increased caspase activation and a greater loss of myelin and axonal/neuronal proteins after the induction of chronic EAE. Interestingly, CB<sub>

39371</sub>

3938 knockout mice had increased caspase 3 levels before the induction of EAE, suggesting a neuroprotective tone mediated by CB<sub>

39391</sub>

3940 receptors (<a href="#R550" rid="R550" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920211">

3941Jackson et al., 2005a</a>

3942,<a href="#R551" rid="R551" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920051">

3943b</a>

3944). In mice with EAE, WIN 55,212-2 inhibited leukocyte/endothelial interactions via activation of CB<sub>

39452</sub>

3946 receptors (<a href="#R889" rid="R889" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919664">

3947Ni et al., 2004</a>

3948). Interestingly, a recent study suggests that the high levels of IFN-<em>

3949&#x003b3;</em>

3950 present in the CNS of mice with EAE can counteract endocannabinoid-mediated neuroprotection by disrupting P2X7 purinergic receptor signaling, a key step in endocannabinoid production by glia (<a href="#R1299" rid="R1299" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919826">

3951Witting et al., 2006</a>

3952).</p>

3953<p id="P79">

3954Another murine model of MS is Theiler&#x02019;s murine encephalomyelitis virus-induced demyelinating disease. In mice with Theiler&#x02019;s murine encephalomyelitis virus-induced demyelinating disease, treatment with WIN 55,212-2 slowed the progression of symptoms, down-regulated delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions and interferon-<em>

3955&#x003b3;</em>

3956 production, and inhibited the expression of proinflammatory cytokines in the CNS (<a href="#R231" rid="R231" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918686">

3957Croxford and Miller, 2003</a>

3958). In another study using this model, treatment with WIN 55,212-2, ACEA, or JWH-015 caused long-lasting improvements in neurological deficits in the established disease and reduced microglial activation, abrogated major histocompatibility complex class II antigen expression, and decreased the number of CD4<sup>

3959+</sup>

3960 infiltrating T cells in the spinal cord. These changes were paralleled by extensive remyelination (<a href="#R24" rid="R24" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637240">

3961Arevalo-Martin et al., 2003</a>

3962). Treatment of Theiler&#x02019;s murine encephalomyelitis virus-infected mice with the transport inhibitors OMDM1 and OMDM2 enhanced anandamide levels, down-regulated inflammatory responses in the spinal cord, and ameliorated motor symptoms (<a href="#R829" rid="R829" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919921">

3963Mestre et al., 2005</a>

3964), and similar findings were reported using the transport inhibitor UCM707 (<a href="#R910" rid="R910" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919489">

3965Ortega-Gutierrez et al., 2005</a>

3966). In these two studies, the treatments were also shown to reduce the surface expression of major histo-compatibility complex class II molecules, the production of the proinflammatory cytokines (TNF<em>

3967&#x003b1;</em>

3968, IL-1<em>

3969&#x003b2;</em>

3970, and IL-6), and the expression of inducible NO synthase.</p>

3971<p id="P80">

3972Consistent with the animal data, cannabinoids have shown promise in the treatment of MS in humans (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

3973<span>

3974Table 1</span>

3975</a>

3976). A possible underlying mechanism is suggested by a recent study in which the endocannabinoid system was found to be highly activated during CNS inflammation in MS patients and to protect neurons from inflammatory damage by activating a negative feedback loop in microglial cells via CB<sub>

39771/2</sub>

3978-mediated epigenetic regulation of mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphatase 1 expression <strong>

3979(</strong>

3980<a href="#R293" rid="R293" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920014">

3981Eljaschewitsch et al., 2006</a>

3982).</p>

3983<p id="P81">

3984There have been anecdotal reports of the effectiveness of marijuana smoking in relieving symptoms of MS and SPI (<a href="#R433" rid="R433" class=" bibr popnode">

3985Grinspoon and Bakalar, 1993</a>

3986, <a href="#R434" rid="R434" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653476">

39871998</a>

3988), which were supported by the results of early open or single-blind observations with orally given THC or smoked marijuana, involving small numbers of patients (<a href="#R289" rid="R289" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919721">

3989Dunn and Davis, 1974</a>

3990; <a href="#R965" rid="R965" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919709">

3991Petro, 1980</a>

3992; <a href="#R966" rid="R966" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919508">

3993Petro and Ellenberger, 1981</a>

3994; <a href="#R187" rid="R187" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919719">

3995Clifford, 1983</a>

3996; <a href="#R814" rid="R814" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919895">

3997Meinck et al., 1989</a>

3998; <a href="#R120" rid="R120" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920371">

3999Brenneisen et al., 1996</a>

4000; <a href="#R1079" rid="R1079" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919186">

4001Schon et al., 1999</a>

4002). The most consistent finding was a subjective improvement in spasticity, although benefits for mobility, tremor, nystagmus, mood, and bladder control were also reported. In a double-blind crossover study of a single MS patient, nabilone treatment improved muscle spasms, nocturia, and general well-being (<a href="#R770" rid="R770" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919328">

4003Martyn, 1995</a>

4004). In contrast, <a href="#R427" rid="R427" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919209">

4005Greenberg et al. (1994)</a>

4006 reported impairments of both balance and posture after a single dose of smoked cannabis in a placebo-controlled study of 10 MS patients and 10 normal subjects. In an anonymous survey of 112 MS patients who self-medicated with cannabis, 30 to 97% of the subjects reported relief from a wide variety of symptoms by smoking marijuana (<a href="#R204" rid="R204" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918847">

4007Consroe et al., 1997</a>

4008). These encouraging reports have triggered numerous larger, population-based clinical trials of cannabis-based medicines in MS, which have yielded mixed results.</p>

4009<p id="P82">

4010Using a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover design, <a href="#R600" rid="R600" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920192">

4011Killestein et al. (2002)</a>

4012 have evaluated the effects of oral THC, two doses of 2.5 to 5 mg/day or a <em>

4013Cannabis sativa</em>

4014 plant extract administered over a 4-week period, in 16 MS patients with severe spasticity. Spasticity and disability, quantified using the objective Ashworth scale (<a href="#R30" rid="R30" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919288">

4015Ashworth, 1964</a>

4016) and the Expanded Disability Status Scale were not improved. However, a significant improvement in the subjective rating of spasm frequency and trends toward improved mobility were noted, with no effect on tremor, sleep quality, or lower urinary tract symptoms. Both THC and the plant extract worsened the patients&#x02019; global impression of their conditions, with plant extracts causing more adverse side effects. It should be mentioned, however, that the dose of THC used was lower than that in subsequent studies with more positive outcome, and as was noted in an accompanying editorial (<a href="#R1181" rid="R1181" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920085">

4017Thompson and Baker, 2002</a>

4018), the study was not powered to detect efficacy.</p>

4019<p id="P83">

4020A large multicenter study involving 33 clinical centers and 660 MS patients in the United Kingdom and United States and supported by the UK Medical Council aimed to explore the effects of cannabis extract (Cannador) or synthetic THC (Marinol) versus placebo on spasticity, pain, tremor, bladder function, and cognitive function [Cannabinoids in Multiple Sclerosis (CAMS) study; <a href="#R1312" rid="R1312" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920157">

4021Zajicek et al., 2003</a>

4022, <a href="#R1311" rid="R1311" class=" bibr popnode">

40232004</a>

4024]. There was no change in Ashworth score, tremor, irritability, depression, or tiredness after 15 weeks of treatment with Marinol or Cannador. However, there were significant improvements in patient-reported spasticity, pain, and sleep quality. Unexpectedly, there was also a reduction in hospital admissions for relapse in the two active treatment groups. Adverse side effects were generally minor and similar to those with placebo. Remarkably, in the 12-month follow-up of the original CAMS study of 657 patients, muscle spasticity measured by the Ashworth scale was significantly improved in the THC-treated group. The Rivermead Mobility Index was also improved, indicative of reduced disability. The effect of Cannador on tremor was also studied in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover trial in 14 patients with MS. Consistent with an earlier report (<a href="#R1312" rid="R1312" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920218">

4025Zajicek et al., 2003</a>

4026), no significant therapeutic effects were noted (<a href="#R336" rid="R336" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919103">

4027Fox et al., 2004</a>

4028). In another study of similar design, administration of oral capsules containing 2.5 mg of &#x00394;<sup>

40299</sup>

4030-THC plus 0.9 mg of CBD (maximal dose of 30 mg of &#x00394;<sup>

40319</sup>

4032-THC/day) caused improvements in spasm frequency and mobility in 37 MS patients who received at least 90% of their prescribed dose (<a href="#R1215" rid="R1215" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919082">

4033Vaney et al., 2004</a>

4034).</p>

4035<p id="P84">

4036In a double-blind, placebo-controlled study involving 18 patients with MS, THC and CBD decreased self-reported spasticity and pain and improved bladder symptoms, whereas spasticity measured by the Ashworth scale was not significantly improved (<a href="#R1245" rid="R1245" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918688">

4037Wade et al., 2003</a>

4038). The therapeutic effect of Sativex delivered by oromucosal spray (2.7 mg of THC and 2.5 mg of CBD at each actuation) was evaluated in 160 outpatients with MS (<a href="#R1118" rid="R1118" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653429">

4039Smith, 2004</a>

4040). Patients were allowed to self-titrate the dose to achieve optimal effects, up to a maximal daily dose of 120 mg of THC and CBD. Efficacy was assessed by using a modified Ashworth scale to assess spasticity, whereas daily living, mobility, cognitive function, and tremor were quantified through the use of various scales and questionnaires (<a href="#R1244" rid="R1244" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918939">

4041Wade et al., 2004</a>

4042). There was no significant difference in the Ashworth scale, tremor, and pain at 6 weeks between the Sativex and placebo groups. However, visual analog scales showed significant improvement in patients whose primary symptom had been spasticity (<a href="#R1244" rid="R1244" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919687">

4043Wade et al., 2004</a>

4044). Sativex was well tolerated and effective against central neuropathic pain and sleep disturbances associated with MS in a randomized, controlled trial involving 66 patients (<a href="#R1029" rid="R1029" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919065">

4045Rog et al., 2005</a>

4046). Sativex was approved and launched in Canada in 2005 for the treatment of neuropathic pain associated with MS and is currently being investigated for various other therapeutic indications (<a href="#R1051" rid="R1051" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918924">

4047Russo, 2004</a>

4048, <a href="#R1050" rid="R1050" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918857">

40492006</a>

4050).</p>

4051<p id="P85">

4052In a recent case report, a 46-year-old woman was diagnosed with MS after having entered treatment with the CB<sub>

40531</sub>

4054 receptor antagonist rimonabant for obesity, and recovery to near normal was noted within weeks after discontinuation of the treatment (<a href="#R1217" rid="R1217" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919211">

4055van Oosten et al., 2004</a>

4056). This report, coupled with the more severe neurodegenerative process when MS is induced in CB<sub>

40571</sub>

4058 knock-out mice or in mice treated with a CB<sub>

40591</sub>

4060 receptor antagonist, could suggest that CB<sub>

40611</sub>

4062 antagonism may exacerbate inflammatory demyelinating diseases in humans (<a href="#R1217" rid="R1217" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918916">

4063van Oosten et al., 2004</a>

4064). However, the occurrence of MS in this one patient may have been purely coincidental.</p>

4065<p id="P86">

4066Although the results of the above clinical studies (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

4067<span>

4068Table 1</span>

4069</a>

4070) are somewhat equivocal, patients treated with cannabis experienced improvements in the most disturbing symptoms including pain and spasticity compared with those receiving placebo, without experiencing significant side effects. These studies also suggest that the Ashworth scale as a primary measure of spasticity in MS does not accurately assess the complex collection of symptoms associated with spasticity, which may be more accurately evaluated using subjective measures. Indeed, the use of the Ashworth scale as a primary measure of spasticity in MS has often being criticized, and many commonly used antispasticity medications have also failed to generate statistically significant improvements according to this scale (<a href="#R502" rid="R502" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918861">

4071Hinderer and Gupta, 1996</a>

4072; <a href="#R1087" rid="R1087" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919041">

4073Shakespeare et al., 2003</a>

4074). Accurate assessment of the clinical effectiveness of cannabinoids in MS may be complicated by the difficulty in achieving the most appropriate individual oral dose (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

4075<span>

4076Table 1</span>

4077</a>

4078). Peak plasma concentrations and their timing vary greatly because of the low water solubility of cannabis components and the large variability in their absorption from the gastrointestinal tract. An additional disadvantage of oral administration is the hepatic first-pass effect. This can result in the formation of large quantities of the psychoactive metabolite 11-OH-THC, which may be responsible for some of the side effects observed (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

4079<span>

4080Table 1</span>

4081</a>

4082). Delivery of cannabis-based extracts as an oromucosal spray may minimize these drawbacks and may allow patients to better optimize their individual daily dose by self-titration (<a href="#R1050" rid="R1050" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920041">

4083Russo, 2006</a>

4084).</p>

4085<p id="P87" class="p p-last">

4086In conclusion, controlled clinical trials with cannabinoids have demonstrated their efficacy in eliciting symptomatic improvements in MS patients. These results suggest that there is place for the use of cannabis in the treatment of MS, which should be confirmed in further larger-scale clinical trials.</p>

4087</div>

4088<div id="S17" class="sec">

4089<p>

4090</p>

4091<h4 id="S17title" class="inline">

40924. Movement Disorders (Basal Ganglia Disorders) </h4>

4093<p id="P88" class="p p-first">

4094Endocannabinoid involvement in the central regulation of motor functions and in movement disorders is based on multiple lines of evidence. First, CB<sub>

40951</sub>

4096 receptors are highly expressed in the basal ganglia, especially in the substantia nigra and in the cerebellum (<a href="#R486" rid="R486" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918801">

4097Herkenham et al., 1990</a>

4098, <a href="#R484" rid="R484" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918894">

40991991a</a>

4100,<a href="#R485" rid="R485" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637229">

4101b</a>

4102; <a href="#R730" rid="R730" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919503">

4103Mailleux and Vanderhaeghen, 1992</a>

4104; <a href="#R1189" rid="R1189" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919367">

4105Tsou et al., 1998</a>

4106; <a href="#R510" rid="R510" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919926">

4107Hohmann and Herkenham, 2000</a>

4108; <a href="#R840" rid="R840" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919903">

4109Moldrich and Wenger, 2000</a>

4110; <a href="#R526" rid="R526" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919654">

4111Howlett et al., 2002</a>

4112), areas involved in motor control. Second, endocannabinoids are also abundant in these brain regions (<a href="#R89" rid="R89" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920400">

4113Bisogno et al., 1999a</a>

4114; <a href="#R275" rid="R275" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919220">

4115Di Marzo et al., 2000</a>

4116). Third, endogenous, plant-derived, and synthetic cannabinoids have potent, mostly inhibitory, effects on motor activity (<a href="#R227" rid="R227" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919869">

4117Crawley et al., 1993</a>

4118; <a href="#R349" rid="R349" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920348">

4119Fride and Mechoulam, 1993</a>

4120; <a href="#R1285" rid="R1285" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919886">

4121Wickens and Pertwee, 1993</a>

4122; <a href="#R1117" rid="R1117" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919245">

4123Smith et al., 1994</a>

4124; <a href="#R1033" rid="R1033" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919822">

4125Romero et al., 1995a</a>

4126,<a href="#R1034" rid="R1034" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919453">

4127b</a>

4128, <a href="#R1035" rid="R1035" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919246">

41292002b</a>

4130; reviewed in <a href="#R1063" rid="R1063" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653359">

4131Sa&#x000f1;udo-Pe&#x000f1; a et al., 1999b</a>

4132). Fourth, CB<sub>

41331</sub>

4134 receptor and endocannabinoid levels are altered in the basal ganglia both in experimental models (<a href="#R1318" rid="R1318" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919863">

4135Zeng et al., 1999</a>

4136; <a href="#R929" rid="R929" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918975">

4137Page et al., 2000</a>

4138; <a href="#R1032" rid="R1032" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920302">

4139Romero et al., 2000</a>

4140; <a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919010">

4141Lastres-Becker et al., 2001a</a>

4142,<a href="#R658" rid="R658" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919134">

4143b</a>

4144, <a href="#R654" rid="R654" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919171">

41452002a</a>

4146,<a href="#R659" rid="R659" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919165">

4147b</a>

4148; <a href="#R415" rid="R415" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653474">

4149Gonzalez et al., 2006</a>

4150) and human forms of movement disorders (<a href="#R399" rid="R399" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918704">

4151Glass et al., 1993</a>

4152, <a href="#R398" rid="R398" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918681">

41532000</a>

4154, <a href="#R402" rid="R402" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920053">

41552004</a>

4156; <a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918909">

4157Lastres-Becker et al., 2001a</a>

4158; reviewed in <a href="#R1035" rid="R1035" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919157">

4159Romero et al., 2002b</a>

4160). Fifth, the endocannabinoid system interacts with several neurotransmitter pathways at various levels of the basal ganglia circuitry (<a href="#R396" rid="R396" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918806">

4161Glass et al., 1997a</a>

4162; <a href="#R831" rid="R831" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919146">

4163Miller et al., 1998</a>

4164; <a href="#R1064" rid="R1064" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919937">

4165Sa&#x000f1;udo-Pe&#x000f1; a and Walker, 1998</a>

4166; <a href="#R391" rid="R391" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919741">

4167Giuffrida et al., 1999</a>

4168; <a href="#R1027" rid="R1027" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919806">

4169Rodriguez De Fonseca et al., 2001</a>

4170; <a href="#R123" rid="R123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919990">

4171Brotchie, 2003</a>

4172; <a href="#R1210" rid="R1210" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919672">

4173van der Stelt and Di Marzo, 2003</a>

4174; <a href="#R246" rid="R246" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919505">

4175de Lago et al., 2004a</a>

4176).</p>

4177<div id="S18" class="sec">

4178<p>

4179</p>

4180<h5 id="S18title" class="inline">

4181a. Parkinson&#x02019;s disease and levodopa-induced dyskinesia </h5>

4182<p id="P89" class="p p-first">

4183Parkinson&#x02019;s disease (PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disease of adult onset, with incidence of 16 to 19/100,000 people worldwide (<a href="#R1195" rid="R1195" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919577">

4184Twelves et al., 2003</a>

4185). PD is caused by a severe loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), resulting in reduced dopamine levels and a loss of dopaminergic neurotransmission in the striatum, which interferes with motor function and coordination. Although excitotoxicity, oxidative stress, inflammation, mitochondrial dysfunction, and environmental and hereditary factors have all been implicated in the pathogenesis of PD, the exact cause of the loss of dopaminergic neurons remains elusive (<a href="#R474" rid="R474" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920172">

4186Hattori and Mizuno, 2004</a>
