4187; <a href="#R303" rid="R303" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919236">

4188Eriksen et al., 2005</a>

4189). Clinically, PD is characterized by the classic triad of resting tremor, muscular rigidity, and bradykinesia/akinesia (slowness of movement or postural immobility). Current therapies include oral dopamine replacement via the dopamine precursor levodopa, anti-cholinergic agents, and monoamine oxidase B inhibitors (<a href="#R522" rid="R522" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918875">

4190Horn and Stern, 2004</a>

4191). Although dopamine replacement therapy can be effective in most patients by controlling the symptoms in the short term, their long-term use is associated with diminishing efficacy and severe side effects such as levodopa-induced dyskinesia (LID) (involuntary movements), which often lead to treatment discontinuation and severe disability.</p>

4192<p id="P90">

4193In PD, there are secondary abnormalities in nondopaminergic transmission within the basal ganglia that are thought to contribute to the inhibition of motor function. Inhibitory GABAergic transmission from the striatum to the external region of the globus pallidus (GPe) is increased, making the GPe hypoactive. This results in decreased GABAergic input from the GPe to the subthalamic nucleus which, together with increased activity of glutamatergic efferents to this nucleus, results in its hyperactivity. In turn, the hyperactive subthalamic nucleus increases the activity of the SNr and internal globus pallidus (GPi) through glutamatergic efferents. Because both the SNr and GPi provide inhibitory output to motor nuclei outside the basal ganglia (e.g., motor thalamus and brain stem locomotor regions), this mechanism is thought to contribute to the excessive motor inhibition in PD (<a href="#R900" rid="R900" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918988">

4194Obeso et al., 2000</a>

4195; <a href="#R76" rid="R76" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920186">

4196Bezard et al., 2001</a>

4197). In general, changes opposite to those described above are likely to be involved in LID. The final outcomes of the dysregulation of neuronal circuits are abnormal patterning, firing rate, and synchronization of basal ganglia outputs (<a href="#R900" rid="R900" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920265">

4198Obeso et al., 2000</a>

4199; <a href="#R76" rid="R76" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920358">

4200Bezard et al., 2001</a>

4201). Importantly, nondopaminergic mechanisms may counterbalance the loss of dopamine and are probably responsible for the lack of parkinsonian symptoms until the loss of &#x0003e;80% of striatal dopamine. They may also attenuate the severity of symptoms once symptoms develop. As discussed below, the endocannabinoid system may play an important regulatory role in PD,PD and LID as well as in the compensatory mechanisms.</p>

4202<p id="P91">

4203Overactivity of endocannabinoid transmission, as reflected by increased tissue levels of endocannabinoids and CB<sub>

42041</sub>

4205 receptors as well as decreased rates of endocannabinoid transport and degradation by FAAH, have been found in the basal ganglia in the 6-hydroxydopamine-lesioned or reserpine-treated rat models of PD (<a href="#R731" rid="R731" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919593">

4206Mailleux and Vanderhaeghen, 1993</a>

4207; <a href="#R1032" rid="R1032" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919314">

4208Romero et al., 2000</a>

4209; <a href="#R439" rid="R439" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637231">

4210Gubellini et al., 2002</a>

4211; <a href="#R165" rid="R165" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919408">

4212Centonze et al., 2005</a>

4213; <a href="#R320" rid="R320" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919306">

4214Fernandez-Espejo et al., 2005</a>

4215; <a href="#R415" rid="R415" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653351">

4216Gonzalez et al., 2006</a>

4217). In basal ganglia from 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine-lesioned marmosets, a primate model of PD, and in basal ganglia of PD patients, the density of striatal CB<sub>

42181</sub>

4219 receptors and CB<sub>

42201</sub>

4221 receptor-G-protein coupling were found to be increased (<a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920050">

4222Lastres-Becker et al., 2001a</a>

4223). The above changes in 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine-treated marmosets and 6-hydroxydopamine-lesioned rats were reversible by chronic L-dopa treatment, which indicates that the similar changes observed in PD patients were unlikely to have been induced by the replacement therapy (<a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919183">

4224Lastres-Becker et al., 2001a</a>

4225; <a href="#R721" rid="R721" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919343">

4226Maccarrone et al., 2003</a>

4227). There is broad agreement that the endocannabinoid system becomes overactive in the basal ganglia in PD (reviewed in <a href="#R123" rid="R123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919597">

4228Brotchie, 2003</a>

4229), although some studies report a reduction (<a href="#R1107" rid="R1107" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919495">

4230Silverdale et al., 2001</a>

4231) or no change in CB<sub>

42321</sub>

4233 receptor expression (<a href="#R484" rid="R484" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920164">

4234Herkenham et al., 1991a</a>

4235) or a dependence on L-DOPA cotreatment of the increased CB<sub>

42361</sub>

4237 receptor expression in the basal ganglia of animals with experimental PD (<a href="#R1318" rid="R1318" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919095">

4238Zeng et al., 1999</a>

4239).</p>

4240<p id="P92">

4241If the enhanced CB<sub>

42421</sub>

4243 receptor signaling in the striatum is viewed as an attempt of the dopamine-deficient brain to normalize striatal function, the pharmacological amplification of this signaling might alleviate symptoms of PD, e.g., by reducing striatal glutamate release (<a href="#R378" rid="R378" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919255">

4244Gerdeman and Lovinger, 2001</a>

4245; <a href="#R381" rid="R381" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919435">

4246Gerdeman et al., 2002</a>

4247; <a href="#R439" rid="R439" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637219">

4248Gubellini et al., 2002</a>

4249). On the other hand, enhanced CB<sub>

42501</sub>

4251 receptor signaling, if focused on the other part of the circuitry (e.g., GPe), can enhance GABA transmission, leading to inhibition of GPe and thereby contributing to the symptoms of PD. Likewise, CB<sub>

42521</sub>

4253 antagonism could have either pro-parkinsonian effects, if it targets the striatum, or antiparkinsonian effects, if it targets the GPe. Accordingly, both agonists and antagonists might have therapeutic potential, both in PD and LID (reviewed in <a href="#R123" rid="R123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919693">

4254Brotchie, 2003</a>

4255).</p>

4256<p id="P93">

4257Treatment with CB<sub>

42581</sub>

4259 receptor agonists can decrease the tremor associated with overactivity of the subthalamic nucleus (<a href="#R1061" rid="R1061" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918864">

4260Sa&#x000f1;udo-Pe&#x000f1; a et al., 1998</a>

4261, <a href="#R1063" rid="R1063" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653389">

42621999b</a>

4263), improve motor impairment seen with dopaminergic agonists (<a href="#R19" rid="R19" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919036">

4264Anderson et al., 1995</a>

4265; <a href="#R744" rid="R744" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919118">

4266Maneuf et al., 1997</a>

4267; <a href="#R1061" rid="R1061" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919117">

4268Sa&#x000f1;udo-Pe&#x000f1; a et al., 1998</a>

4269), protect against dopaminergic cell death (<a href="#R660" rid="R660" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920284">

4270Lastres-Becker et al., 2005</a>

4271), and delay or reduce the incidence of LID (<a href="#R1104" rid="R1104" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919279">

4272Sieradzan et al., 2001</a>

4273; <a href="#R337" rid="R337" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919214">

4274Fox et al., 2002a</a>

4275; <a href="#R323" rid="R323" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919858">

4276Ferrer et al., 2003</a>

4277; <a href="#R387" rid="R387" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918700">

4278Gilgun-Sherkiet et al., 2003</a>

4279). However, cannabinoid agonists are unlikely to be used for reducing bradykinesia in PD because of their hypokinetic profile both in primates and humans (<a href="#R200" rid="R200" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919116">

4280Consroe, 1998</a>

4281; <a href="#R857" rid="R857" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653441">

4282M&#x000fc;ller-Vahl et al., 1999a</a>

4283; <a href="#R1030" rid="R1030" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653515">

4284Romero et al., 2002</a>

4285; <a href="#R123" rid="R123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919584">

4286Brotchie, 2003</a>

4287; <a href="#R230" rid="R230" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920074">

4288Croxford, 2003</a>

4289; <a href="#R231" rid="R231" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920070">

4290Croxford and Miller, 2003</a>

4291).</p>

4292<p id="P94">

4293On the other hand, dysfunction of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons can be associated with overactivity of endocannabinoid transmission in the basal ganglia (see above). CB<sub>

42941</sub>

4295 receptor antagonists may therefore be useful for alleviating the bradykinesia of PD or LID, because they attenuate CB<sub>

42961</sub>

4297 signaling in GPe or GPi. (<a href="#R731" rid="R731" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919974">

4298Mailleux and Vanderhaeghen, 1993</a>

4299; <a href="#R275" rid="R275" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919625">

4300Di Marzo et al., 2000</a>

4301; <a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918954">

4302Lastres-Becker et al., 2001a</a>

4303,<a href="#R658" rid="R658" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920238">

4304b</a>

4305; <a href="#R439" rid="R439" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637209">

4306Gubellini et al., 2002</a>

4307; reviewed in <a href="#R123" rid="R123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919174">

4308Brotchie, 2003</a>

4309; Fernandez-Espejo et al., reviewed in <a href="#R123" rid="R123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918724">

4310Brotchie, 2003</a>

4311; 2005; <a href="#R322" rid="R322" class=" bibr popnode">

4312Fernandez-Ruiz and Gonzalez, 2005</a>

4313). Notwithstanding the above, studies using SR141716 in rat (<a href="#R275" rid="R275" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918999">

4314Di Marzo et al., 2000</a>

4315) and primate models of PD or LID (<a href="#R827" rid="R827" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919856">

4316Meschler et al., 2001</a>

4317; <a href="#R1212" rid="R1212" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919340">

4318van der Stelt et al., 2005</a>

4319) provided conflicting results. Rimonabant treatment also failed to influence dyskinesia in the first small-scale, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled human study (<a href="#R828" rid="R828" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919793">

4320Mesnage et al., 2004</a>

4321). However, the dose used in this human study was approximately 10-fold lower (0.3 mg/kg versus. 3 mg/kg), than in a recent primate study with positive outcome (<a href="#R1212" rid="R1212" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919838">

4322van der Stelt et al., 2005</a>

4323). As suggested by a recent report (<a href="#R320" rid="R320" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920304">

4324Fernandez-Espejo et al., 2005</a>

4325), it is also possible that CB<sub>

43261</sub>

4327 receptor blockade is effective only at the very advanced stages of the disease. More recently, using Park-2 knockout mice, a genetic model of early PD, <a href="#R414" rid="R414" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919561">

4328Gonzalez et al. (2005)</a>

4329 observed gender-dependent differences for both the levels of CB<sub>

43301</sub>

4331 receptors and motor responses to agonists or antagonists, extending earlier data obtained in humans and in animal models of PD.</p>

4332<p id="P95" class="p p-last">

4333Taken together, although the above studies do not offer a complete understanding of the role of endocannabinoids and cannabinoid receptors in PD and LID, they support the notion that the endocannabinoid system plays an important role in movement disorders, including PD, and may provide the framework for novel therapeutic approaches in the future.</p>

4334</div>

4335<div id="S19" class="sec">

4336<p>

4337</p>

4338<h5 id="S19title" class="inline">

4339b. Huntington&#x02019;s disease </h5>

4340<p id="P96" class="p p-first">

4341Huntington&#x02019;s disease (HD) is an inherited, autosomal dominant, progressive neuropsychiatric disorder of the midlife, caused by an unstable expansion of a trinucleotide polyglutamine repeat in the N-terminal domain of a protein termed huntingtin, which leads to degeneration of neurons in the basal ganglia and cortical regions. The disease is characterized by motor disturbances, such as chorea (involuntary movements) and dystonia, psychiatric symptoms, and dementia (<a href="#R820" rid="R820" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918942">

4342Melone et al., 2005</a>

4343). The prevalence of HD is similar to that of ALS (see below), but much lower than that of most of the other neurodegenerative illnesses discussed above or below. The therapy of HD is very limited and includes antidopaminergic drugs to reduce the hyperkinesias and antiglutamatergic agents to reduce excitotoxicity (<a href="#R820" rid="R820" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919452">

4344Melone et al., 2005</a>

4345).</p>

4346<p id="P97">

4347It has been clearly demonstrated, both in postmortem human tissue (<a href="#R399" rid="R399" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920378">

4348Glass et al., 1993</a>

4349, <a href="#R398" rid="R398" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919710">

43502000</a>

4351; <a href="#R1015" rid="R1015" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919322">

4352Richfield and Herkenham, 1994</a>

4353) and in chemically induced and transgenic animal models (<a href="#R257" rid="R257" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919388">

4354Denovan-Wright and Robertson, 2000</a>

4355; <a href="#R929" rid="R929" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920296">

4356Page et al., 2000</a>

4357; <a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919874">

4358Lastres-Becker et al., 2001</a>

4359, <a href="#R654" rid="R654" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919537">

43602002a</a>

4361,<a href="#R659" rid="R659" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918811">

4362b</a>

4363; <a href="#R1105" rid="R1105" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919523">

4364Sieradzan and Mann, 2001</a>

4365; <a href="#R58" rid="R58" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919290">

4366Behrens et al., 2002</a>

4367; <a href="#R402" rid="R402" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920357">

4368Glass et al., 2004</a>

4369; <a href="#R790" rid="R790" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919971">

4370McCaw et al., 2004</a>

4371) that a decrease in CB<sub>

43721</sub>

4373 receptor level and signaling activity in the basal ganglia is one of the earliest changes in HD, preceding nerve loss and clinical symptoms. Furthermore, decreased levels of anandamide and 2-AG in the striatum and an increase of anandamide in the ventral mesencephalon, where the substantia nigra is located, have been documented in a rat model of HD (<a href="#R655" rid="R655" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918878">

4374Lastres-Becker et al., 2001</a>

4375). Thus, it appears that endocannabinoid signaling in the basal ganglia is hypofunctional in HD, which probably contributes to the hyperkinesia associated with the disease. These studies also suggest that the endocannabinoid system is involved in the pathogenesis and/or progression of HD, and cannabinoid agonists could be of significant therapeutic benefit in HD because of their anthyperkinetic and neuroprotective effects (reviewed in <a href="#R657" rid="R657" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919745">

4376Lastres-Becker et al., 2003b</a>

4377). A recent study identified a novel population of progenitor cells expressing CB<sub>

43781</sub>

4379 receptors in the subependymal layer of the normal and Huntington&#x02019;s diseased human brain. This finding raises the intriguing possibility that these cells could be a source of replacement of cells lost due to neurodegenerative disease (<a href="#R236" rid="R236" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919313">

4380Curtis et al., 2006</a>

4381).</p>

4382<p id="P98">

4383Indeed, data from animal models demonstrated that both CB<sub>

43841</sub>

4385 agonists and inhibitors of endocannabinoid transport are able to reduce hyperkinesia (<a href="#R659" rid="R659" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918707">

4386Lastres-Becker et al., 2002b</a>

4387, <a href="#R656" rid="R656" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919048">

43882003a</a>

4389). Interestingly, direct agonists of CB<sub>

43901</sub>

4391 receptors, such as CP55,940, only produced a very modest effect compared with the anandamide transport inhibitor AM404, which also exhibits affinity for the VR<sub>

43921</sub>

4393 receptor (<a href="#R1331" rid="R1331" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919098">

4394Zygmunt et al., 2000</a>

4395). This latter property of AM404 may account for its ability to reduce hyperkinesia (<a href="#R659" rid="R659" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919312">

4396Lastres-Becker et al., 2002b</a>

4397, <a href="#R656" rid="R656" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918904">

43982003a</a>

4399), as other transport inhibitors such as VDM11 and AM374, which are not active at TRPV<sub>

44001</sub>

4401 receptors, were devoid of antihyperkinetic effects in HD rats (<a href="#R656" rid="R656" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920145">

4402Lastres-Becker et al., 2003a</a>

4403), and the most potent transport inhibitor to date, UCM707, only produced a modest effect (<a href="#R248" rid="R248" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919653">

4404de Lago et al., 2002</a>

4405, <a href="#R249" rid="R249" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919782">

44062004b</a>

4407, <a href="#R247" rid="R247" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918782">

44082006</a>

4409). Arvanil, a hybrid endocannabinoid and vanilloid compound, was also reported to alleviate hyperkinesias in a rat model of HD (<a href="#R250" rid="R250" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920276">

4410de Lago et al., 2005</a>

4411). These results suggest that TRPV<sub>

44121</sub>

4413 receptors alone, or in combination with CB<sub>

44141</sub>

4415 receptors, might represent novel therapeutic targets in HD (reviewed in <a href="#R657" rid="R657" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919734">

4416Lastres-Becker et al., 2003b</a>

4417).</p>

4418<p id="P99" class="p p-last">

4419There have been few human trials on the effects of cannabinoid agonists in HD, and the results do not live up to the promise of the animal data. Small trials with the synthetic THC analog nabilone and with the nonpsychoactive cannabidiol showed no efficacy or even increased choreic movements in HD patients (<a href="#R201" rid="R201" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919764">

4420Consroe et al., 1991</a>

4421; <a href="#R859" rid="R859" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653364">

4422M&#x000fc;ller-Vahl et al., 1999b</a>

4423). These negative results could be related to dosing issues, to the lack of TRPV<sub>

44241</sub>

4425 receptor activity of the compounds tested, or to the advanced stage of the disease. Nevertheless, further studies are warranted to explore the therapeutic potential of cannabinoids in HD.</p>

4426</div>

4427<div id="S20" class="sec sec-last">

4428<p>

4429</p>

4430<h5 id="S20title" class="inline">

4431c. Gilles de la Tourette&#x02019;s syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, and dystonia </h5>

4432<p id="P100" class="p p-first-last">

4433Based on its ubiquitous presence in motor regions of the brain, the endocannabinoid system might be involved in other extrapyramidal disorders such as Gilles de la Tourette&#x02019;s syndrome (TS), tardive dyskinesia, and dystonia. TS is a neurological syndrome that becomes evident in early childhood and is characterized by multiple motor and vocal tics lasting for more than 1 year. Plant-derived cannabinoids have been found to be effective in the treatment of tics and behavioral problems in TS (<a href="#R855" rid="R855" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918776">

4434M&#x000fc;ller-Vahl et al., 1997</a>

4435, <a href="#R856" rid="R856" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920305">

44361998</a>

4437, <a href="#R861" rid="R861" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653451">

44381999c</a>

4439, <a href="#R860" rid="R860" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920037">

44402002</a>

4441, <a href="#R858" rid="R858" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653410">

44422003a</a>

4443,<a href="#R862" rid="R862" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653380">

4444M&#x000fc;ller-Vahl et al., b</a>

4445; <a href="#R854" rid="R854" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919587">

4446M&#x000fc;ller-Vahl, 2003</a>

4447). Beneficial effects of cannabinoids have been also reported in dystonia, both in animal models (<a href="#R1016" rid="R1016" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919596">

4448Richter and L&#x000f6;scher, 1994</a>

4449, <a href="#R1017" rid="R1017" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919752">

44502002</a>

4451) and in humans (<a href="#R338" rid="R338" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919830">

4452Fox et al., 2002b</a>

4453; <a href="#R549" rid="R549" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919742">

4454Jabusch et al., 2004</a>

4455). In addition, as described in the sections above, cannabinoids have potential in the management of the LID in PD and of the spasticity and tremor in MS. On the other hand, in patients chronically treated with neuroleptic drugs, a correlation between chronic cannabis use and the presence of tardive dyskinesia has been described previously (<a href="#R1315" rid="R1315" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918706">

4456Zaretsky et al., 1993</a>

4457).</p>

4458</div>

4459</div>

4460<div id="S21" class="sec">

4461<p>

4462</p>

4463<h4 id="S21title" class="inline">

44645. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis </h4>

4465<p id="P101" class="p p-first">

4466ALS (also known as Lou Gehrig&#x02019;s disease) is the most common adult-onset human motor neuron disease with a prevalence of 5 to 7/100,000. It is characterized by rapid, progressive degeneration of motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, which ultimately leads to progressive weakness, paralysis, and premature death (<a href="#R1044" rid="R1044" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919297">

4467Rowland and Shneider, 2001</a>

4468). Although weak, patients are cognitively intact and thus are completely aware of their progressive disability. The disease strikes adults at any age, and most patients die within 3 to 5 years after the onset of symptoms. Although most cases of ALS are sporadic and are probably acquired, approximately 10% are familial, usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Despite a variety of putative underlying mechanisms, including oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, autoimmunity, a defect in neuronal glutamate transport and glutamate toxicity, neurofilament accumulation, exogenous factors (virusesor toxins), mitochondrial dysfunction, and mutations in the superoxide dismutase (<em>

4469SOD1</em>

4470) gene, the pathogenesis of ALS is incompletely understood (<a href="#R42" rid="R42" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919282">

4471Barnham et al., 2004</a>

4472). Tragically, available treatment options are limited and do not prevent disease progression and death (<a href="#R1044" rid="R1044" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919940">

4473Rowland and Shneider, 2001</a>

4474).</p>

4475<p id="P102" class="p p-last">

4476Based on the well-known protective effect of cannabinoids against oxidative cell damage and excitotoxicity (<a href="#R460" rid="R460" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920298">

4477Hampson et al., 1998</a>

4478; <a href="#R1093" rid="R1093" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919559">

4479Shen and Thayer, 1999</a>

4480; <a href="#R4" rid="R4" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919052">

4481Abood et al., 2001</a>

4482; <a href="#R1213" rid="R1213" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637221">

4483van der Stelt et al., 2001a</a>

4484), combined with their antispastic effect in MS, <a href="#R159" rid="R159" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920134">

4485Carter and Rosen (2001)</a>

4486 have proposed the use of marijuana for the pharmacological management of ALS. Indeed, in a pilot study of the safety and tolerability of THC in ALS patients, symptomatic benefits were seen for spasticity, insomnia, and appetite (<a href="#R373" rid="R373" class=" bibr popnode">

4487Gelinas et al., 2002</a>

4488). Consistent with this clinical report, studies using transgenic mice expressing a mutant form of human SOD1 (hSOD1<sup>

4489G93A</sup>

4490 mice) as an experimental model of ALS have demonstrated that either THC or WIN55,212-2 administered after the onset of the disease or genetic ablation of FAAH delayed disease progression (<a href="#R995" rid="R995" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918754">

4491Raman et al., 2004</a>

4492; <a href="#R87" rid="R87" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918997">

4493Bilsland et al., 2006</a>

4494). Furthermore, THC potently reduced oxidative and excitotoxic damage in spinal cord cultures in vitro and prolonged survival in SOD1 mutant mice (<a href="#R995" rid="R995" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918973">

4495Raman et al., 2004</a>

4496). Surprisingly, neither WIN55,212-2 nor FAAH ablation affected the life span of SOD1(G93A) mice, whereas deletion of the CB<sub>

44971</sub>

4498 receptor significantly extended life span without affecting the disease onset (<a href="#R87" rid="R87" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919692">

4499Bilsland et al., 2006</a>

4500). These results suggest that cannabinoids have significant neuroprotective effects in a mouse model of ALS but that these beneficial effects may be mediated by non-CB<sub>

45011</sub>

4502 receptor mechanisms.</p>

4503</div>

4504<div id="S22" class="sec">

4505<p>

4506</p>

4507<h4 id="S22title" class="inline">

45086. Alzheimer&#x02019;s Disease </h4>

4509<p id="P103" class="p p-first">

4510Alzheimer&#x02019;s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that accounts for the vast majority of age-related dementia and is one of the most serious health problems in the industrialized world. The disease is characterized by the formation of neuritic plaques rich in <em>

4511&#x003b2;</em>

4512-amyloid (A<em>

4513&#x003b2;</em>

4514) peptide, neurofibrillary tangles rich in hyperphosphorylated <em>

4515&#x003c4;</em>

4516 protein, gliosis, and a neuroinflammatory response involving astrocytes and microglia, inevitably leading to progressive global cognitive decline (<a href="#R1279" rid="R1279" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918695">

4517Weksler et al., 2005</a>

4518). These studies have engendered new perspectives on the possible role of the endocannabinoid system in neurodegenerative processes associated with inflammation (reviewed in <a href="#R1262" rid="R1262" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919002">

4519Walter and Stella, 2004</a>

4520), including those in AD (reviewed in <a href="#R954" rid="R954" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918825">

4521Pazos et al., 2004</a>

4522).</p>

4523<p id="P104">

4524In an in vitro cell culture model of AD, anandamide prevented A<em>

4525&#x003b2;</em>

4526-induced neurotoxicity through CB<sub>

45271</sub>

4528-mediated activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway (<a href="#R835" rid="R835" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919344">

4529Milton, 2002</a>

4530). In rat microglia cells in culture, CB<sub>

45311</sub>

4532 receptor stimulation also dose dependently inhibited the release of NO, which had been implicated in the neurotoxic effects of A<em>

4533&#x003b2;</em>

4534 peptide (<a href="#R1253" rid="R1253" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919360">

4535Waksman et al., 1999</a>

4536). In PC12 cells, protection against A<em>

4537&#x003b2;</em>

4538-induced neurotoxicity was also observed with cannabidiol, which does not bind to CB<sub>

45391</sub>

4540/CB<sub>

45412</sub>

4542 receptors (<a href="#R543" rid="R543" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919964">

4543Iuvone et al., 2004</a>

4544). Interestingly, CB<sub>

45451</sub>

4546 receptor blockade by SR141716 improved the memory deficit induced by administration of A<em>

4547&#x003b2;</em>

4548 peptide in mice, presumably by increasing hippocampal acetylcholine levels (<a href="#R785" rid="R785" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919951">

4549Mazzola et al., 2003</a>

4550). However, analyses of brain tissue samples obtained from AD patients (<a href="#R1282" rid="R1282" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919000">

4551Westlake et al., 1994</a>

4552) or animal models of AD (<a href="#R1031" rid="R1031" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919517">

4553Romero et al., 1998</a>

4554; <a href="#R64" rid="R64" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637195">

4555Benito et al., 2003</a>

4556) indicate that CB<sub>

45571</sub>

4558 receptors are not dramatically affected. In contrast, CB<sub>

45592</sub>

4560 receptors and FAAH are overexpressed in microglia associated with neuritic plaques in the brain of AD patients (<a href="#R64" rid="R64" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637194">

4561Benito et al., 2003</a>

4562). Senile plaques in AD patients express both CB<sub>

45631</sub>

4564 and CB<sub>

45652</sub>

4566 receptors together with markers of microglial activation, and CB<sub>

45671</sub>

4568-positive neurons, present in high numbers in control cases, are greatly reduced in areas of microglial activation (<a href="#R996" rid="R996" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637230">

4569Ramirez et al., 2005</a>

4570). CB<sub>

45711</sub>

4572 receptor protein levels and G protein coupling were also markedly decreased in AD brains, coupled with increased nitration of the CB<sub>

45731</sub>

4574 and CB<sub>

45752</sub>

4576 receptor proteins (<a href="#R996" rid="R996" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637214">

4577Ramirez et al., 2005</a>

4578). Intracerebroventricular administration of WIN 55,212-2 to rats prevented A<em>

4579&#x003b2;</em>

4580-induced microglial activation, cognitive impairment and loss of neuronal markers. HU-210, WIN 55,212-2, and JWH-133 blocked A<em>

4581&#x003b2;</em>

4582-induced activation of cultured microglial cells, as judged by mitochondrial activity, cell morphology and TNF-<em>

4583&#x003b1;</em>

4584 release, and these effects were independent of the antioxidant action of ligands. Furthermore, cannabinoids abrogated microglia-mediated neurotoxicity after addition of A<em>

4585&#x003b2;</em>

4586 to rat cortical cocultures (<a href="#R996" rid="R996" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637215">

4587Ramirez et al., 2005</a>

4588). Although there are no data available on the endocannabinoid content in AD brain tissue are available, increased levels have been reported in the brain after inflammatory events and in neurodegenerative disorders associated with inflammation (reviewed in <a href="#R1262" rid="R1262" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919151">

4589Walter and Stella, 2004</a>

4590 and see also sections above).</p>

4591<p id="P105" class="p p-last">

4592Based on the above, one might hypothesize that A<em>

4593&#x003b2;</em>

4594 deposition induces the release of endocannabinoids from neurons and glia, which activate CB<sub>

45951</sub>

4596-mediated neuroprotective pathways and modulate the release of inflammatory mediators in microglia through CB<sub>

45972</sub>

4598 receptors. If this hypothesis is confirmed by future studies, the beneficial effects of CB<sub>

45991</sub>

4600/CB<sub>

46012</sub>

4602 agonists and FAAH antagonists in AD could be explored. Intriguingly, in a recent open-label pilot study of six patients in the late stages of dementia (five patients with AD and one patient with vascular dementia), treatment with 2.5 mg of dronabinol daily for 2 weeks significantly improved the Neuropsychiatric Inventory total score and the subscores for agitation and aberrant motor and nighttime behaviors (<a href="#R1263" rid="R1263" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919185">

4603Walther et al., 2006</a>

4604).</p>

4605</div>

4606<div id="S23" class="sec">

4607<p>

4608</p>

4609<h4 id="S23title" class="inline">

46107. Epilepsy </h4>

4611<p id="P106" class="p p-first">

4612If the balance between inhibitory and excitatory communications among neurons is disturbed, the intensity of excitatory transmission may exceed a certain threshold, leading to epileptic seizures. Stimulation of postsynaptic neurons is known to trigger the on-demand synthesis of endocannabinoids via an increase in intracellular calcium and/or stimulation of metabotropic receptors (reviewed in <a href="#R972" rid="R972" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918842">

4613Piomelli, 2003</a>

4614; <a href="#R713" rid="R713" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919642">

4615Lutz, 2004</a>

4616). Thereafter, endocannabinoids are released and reach presynaptic CB<sub>

46171</sub>

4618 receptors retrogradely to modulate both inhibitory GABAergic and excitatory glutamatergic transmissions via multiple mechanisms (<a href="#R752" rid="R752" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919528">

4619Marsicano and Lutz, 1999</a>

4620; <a href="#R12" rid="R12" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918902">

4621Alger, 2002</a>

4622, <a href="#R13" rid="R13" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918978">

46232004</a>

4624; <a href="#R381" rid="R381" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919362">

4625Gerdeman et al., 2002</a>

4626; <a href="#R1024" rid="R1024" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918740">

4627Robbe et al., 2002</a>

4628; <a href="#R34" rid="R34" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919051">

4629Azad et al., 2003</a>

4630; <a href="#R345" rid="R345" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920390">

4631Freund et al., 2003</a>

4632; <a href="#R379" rid="R379" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919815">

4633Gerdeman and Lovinger, 2003</a>

4634; <a href="#R604" rid="R604" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920360">

4635Kim and Alger, 2004</a>

4636; <a href="#R542" rid="R542" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918979">

4637Isokawa and Alger, 2005</a>

4638).</p>

4639<p id="P107">

4640Multiple pathways, eventually culminating in neuronal death, are triggered by excessive excitatory activity through a process known as excitotoxicity (<a href="#R802" rid="R802" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919308">

4641McNamara, 1999</a>

4642). Excitotoxicity is believed to contribute to the progression of numerous degenerative central nervous system disorders such as Parkinson&#x02019;s disease, Alzheimer&#x02019;s disease, and various forms of epilepsy. More than 1% of the human population is affected by epilepsy and the incidence is highest in elderly persons or during the first years of life (reviewed in <a href="#R521" rid="R521" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919034">

4643Holmes and Ben-Ari, 1998</a>

4644; <a href="#R791" rid="R791" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919644">

4645McCormick and Contreras, 2001</a>

4646). Epileptic syndromes are classified as generalized seizures, which affect the entire forebrain, or partial seizures, which occur within localized brain regions. Conventional antiepileptic treatment is not fully effective in ~30% of patients, therefore justifying the search for new targets (<a href="#R653" rid="R653" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653439">

4647LaRoche and Helmers, 2004</a>

4648).</p>

4649<p id="P108">

4650Cannabis has been used to treat epilepsy for centuries. Hashish was reported to cure the sick son of the chamberlain of the Caliphate Council in Baghdad by the medieval Arab writer Ibn al-Badri (<a href="#R804" rid="R804" class=" bibr popnode">

4651Mechoulam, 1986</a>

4652; <a href="#R544" rid="R544" class=" bibr popnode">

4653Iversen, 2000</a>

4654). Almost four centuries later, W. B. O&#x02019;Shaughnessy, an Irish physician and scientist working at the Medical College of Calcutta, confirmed the benefit of hashish for treating pain, emesis, muscle spasms, and convulsions (reviewed in <a href="#R585" rid="R585" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919724">

4655Karler and Turkanis, 1981</a>

4656; <a href="#R804" rid="R804" class=" bibr popnode">

4657Mechoulam, 1986</a>

4658). The benefit of cannabis in epilepsy was also reported by a British neurologist (<a href="#R1008" rid="R1008" class=" bibr popnode">

4659Reynolds, 1890</a>

4660), but the medicinal use of cannabis was prohibited in the early 20th century in most countries.</p>

4661<p id="P109">

4662After the identification of the structure of THC (<a href="#R361" rid="R361" class=" bibr popnode">

4663Gaoni and Mechoulam, 1964</a>

4664), several groups investigated its antiepileptic effects (reviewed in <a href="#R418" rid="R418" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918789">

4665Gordon and Devinsky, 2001</a>

4666; <a href="#R713" rid="R713" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919885">

4667Lutz, 2004</a>

4668). THC was originally characterized as an anticonvulsant, but it has a variety of excitatory and depressant effects, ranging from convulsions to ataxia, depending on the dose, experimental model, and the animal species used (<a href="#R585" rid="R585" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919788">

4669Karler and Turkanis, 1981</a>

4670; reviewed in <a href="#R418" rid="R418" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919773">

4671Gordon and Devinsky, 2001</a>

4672; <a href="#R713" rid="R713" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919426">

4673Lutz, 2004</a>

4674). Further complicating the picture, animal studies also document a rebound effect to THC with enhanced CNS excitability and increased sensitivity to convulsions (<a href="#R181" rid="R181" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920040">

4675Chiu et al., 1979</a>

4676; <a href="#R585" rid="R585" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920190">

4677Karler and Turkanis, 1981</a>

4678; <a href="#R584" rid="R584" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919194">

4679Karler et al., 1986</a>

4680). This withdrawal hypersensitivity implies that in susceptible patients, the use of marijuana may be associated with withdrawal seizures (<a href="#R585" rid="R585" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919976">

4681Karler and Turkanis, 1981</a>

4682).</p>

4683<p id="P110">

4684Only case reports on the effects of THC in epileptic patients are currently available. Two reports described decreased seizure frequency after marijuana use (<a href="#R206" rid="R206" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653353">

4685Consroe et al., 1975</a>

4686; <a href="#R295" rid="R295" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919813">

4687Ellison et al., 1990</a>

4688) and an epidemiological study found that chronic marijuana use is protective against seizures (<a href="#R888" rid="R888" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920274">

4689Ng et al., 1990</a>

4690). According to a questionnaire completed by 215 epileptic patients using marijuana regularly, 7.4% experienced a reduction, 2.3% an increase, and 90.2% no change in seizure frequency (<a href="#R418" rid="R418" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919732">

4691Gordon and Devinsky, 2001</a>

4692). In contrast, marijuana smoking was associated with an increase in seizure frequency in another study (<a href="#R593" rid="R593" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919271">

4693Keeler and Reifler, 1967</a>

4694). Small-scale clinical studies have shown that the nonpsychotropic cannabidiol either reduced seizure frequency or had no significant effect on it (<a href="#R235" rid="R235" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919364">

4695Cunha et al., 1980</a>

4696; <a href="#R18" rid="R18" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920163">

4697Ames and Cridland, 1986</a>

4698; <a href="#R418" rid="R418" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918699">

4699Gordon and Devinsky, 2001</a>

4700).</p>

4701<p id="P111">

4702As in human studies, cannabinoids were found to exert both anti- and proconvulsive activity in animal models of epilepsy, largely depending on the stimulus applied to induce seizures (chemical, electrical, light, or fever) and the species used (<a href="#R569" rid="R569" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920109">

4703Johnson et al., 1975</a>

4704; <a href="#R1172" rid="R1172" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918793">

4705Ten Ham et al., 1975</a>

4706; <a href="#R1242" rid="R1242" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918996">

4707Wada et al., 1975a</a>

4708,<a href="#R1243" rid="R1243" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920156">

4709b</a>

4710; <a href="#R209" rid="R209" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919412">

4711Corcoran et al., 1978</a>

4712; <a href="#R181" rid="R181" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920301">

4713Chiu et al., 1979</a>

4714; <a href="#R287" rid="R287" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919152">

4715Duncan and Dagirmanjian, 1979</a>

4716; <a href="#R326" rid="R326" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920125">

4717Fish et al., 1981</a>

4718; <a href="#R585" rid="R585" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920393">

4719Karler and Turkanis, 1981</a>

4720; <a href="#R190" rid="R190" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919834">

4721Colasanti et al., 1982</a>

4722; <a href="#R325" rid="R325" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919786">

4723Fish and Consroe, 1983</a>

4724; <a href="#R583" rid="R583" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919529">

4725Karler et al., 1984</a>

4726, <a href="#R584" rid="R584" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920007">

47271986</a>

4728; <a href="#R203" rid="R203" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920027">

4729Consroe and Mechoulam, 1987</a>

4730; <a href="#R960" rid="R960" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919515">

4731Pertwee et al., 1991</a>

4732; <a href="#R476" rid="R476" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919524">

4733Hayase et al., 2001a</a>

4734,<a href="#R477" rid="R477" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920354">

4735b</a>

4736; reviewed in <a href="#R418" rid="R418" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918742">

4737Gordon and Devinsky, 2001</a>

4738; <a href="#R713" rid="R713" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918696">

4739Lutz, 2004</a>

4740).</p>

4741<p id="P112">

4742Anandamide and its metabolically stable analog, O-1812, dose dependently inhibited electroshock-induced seizures in rats, and this effect was abolished by SR141716 (<a href="#R1259" rid="R1259" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918900">

4743Wallace et al., 2002</a>

4744). In a rat model of febrile seizures, the expression of presynaptic CB<sub>

47451</sub>

4746 receptors in hippocampal GABAergic interneurons was increased (<a href="#R175" rid="R175" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919703">

4747Chen et al., 2003</a>

4748), and the CB<sub>

47491</sub>

4750 receptor-mediated DSI was enhanced (<a href="#R12" rid="R12" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920224">

4751Alger, 2002</a>

4752), suggesting that the endogenous cannabinoid system is protective. Remarkably, in a rat model of pilocarpine-induced status epilepticus, CB<sub>

47531</sub>

4754 receptor agonists were more effective in reducing seizure frequency than clinically used anticonvulsants, such as phenytoin or phenobarbital. Consistently, CB<sub>

47551</sub>

4756 receptor blockade increased seizure frequency, and the seizure activity was associated with increased brain levels of CB<sub>

47571</sub>

4758 receptors and 2-AG (<a href="#R1258" rid="R1258" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919991">

4759Wallace et al., 2003a</a>

4760).</p>

4761<p id="P113">

4762With use of the kainic acid-induced excitotoxic epileptiform seizure model in wild type and CB<sub>

47631</sub>

4764 knockout mice, recent studies have established that the seizure-induced increase of intracellular calcium, a hallmark of epilepsy (<a href="#R1004" rid="R1004" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919149">

4765Raza et al., 2001</a>

4766), triggers the synthesis of anandamide, which activates CB<sub>

47671</sub>

4768 receptors in glutamatergic neurons in the hippocampus and cerebral cortex (<a href="#R753" rid="R753" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653361">

4769Marsicano et al., 2003</a>

4770; <a href="#R598" rid="R598" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919291">

4771Khaspekov et al., 2004</a>

4772). Such &#x0201c;on-demand&#x0201d; activation of CB<sub>

47731</sub>

4774 receptors was suggested to protect against excitotoxicity by various mechanisms, including inhibition of calcium channels and stimulation of potassium channels to decrease neuronal excitability and the activation of extracellular signal regulated kinases (<a href="#R753" rid="R753" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653442">

4775Marsicano et al., 2003</a>

4776; <a href="#R598" rid="R598" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919936">

4777Khaspekov et al., 2004</a>

4778). In contrast to these findings, FAAH knockout mice or mice treated with a CB<sub>

47791</sub>

4780 agonist were found to have increased sensitivity to kainic acid-induced seizures (<a href="#R186" rid="R186" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637224">

4781Clement et al., 2003</a>

4782). The lack of protection in this latter study may be related to the nonselective activation of CB<sub>

47831</sub>

4784 receptors on both inhibitory (proconvulsive effect) and excitatory neurons (anticonvulsive effect) and by the life-long rather than on-demand activation of CB<sub>

47851</sub>

4786 receptors present in FAAH knockout animals.</p>

4787<p id="P114" class="p p-last">

4788In summary, the use of cannabinoids for the treatment of epilepsy is still controversial, although recent experimental studies provide some new insight. To date, there have been no large-scale, controlled clinical trials to examine the beneficial effects of cannabinoids in various forms of epilepsy. The potential use of the nonpsychotropic cannabidiol and of inhibitors of anandamide transport or degradation warrants further investigation.</p>

4789</div>

4790<div id="S24" class="sec">

4791<p>

4792</p>

4793<h4 id="S24title" class="inline">

47948. Mental Disorders </h4>

4795<p id="P115" class="p p-first">

4796The well-known psychotropic effects of cannabinoids and the distribution of cannabinoid receptors across important emotional circuits in the brain suggest that the endocannabinoid system may be involved in various psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia and mood disorders (reviewed in <a href="#R1210" rid="R1210" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919906">

4797van der Stelt and Di Marzo, 2003</a>

4798; <a href="#R455" rid="R455" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919572">

4799Hall et al., 2004</a>

4800; <a href="#R679" rid="R679" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919810">

4801Leweke et al., 2004</a>

4802; <a href="#R748" rid="R748" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920257">

4803Manzanares et al., 2004</a>

4804; <a href="#R1200" rid="R1200" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918828">

4805Ujike and Morita, 2004</a>

4806; <a href="#R28" rid="R28" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918958">

4807Ashton et al., 2005</a>

4808; <a href="#R359" rid="R359" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919656">

4809Gambi et al., 2005</a>

4810; <a href="#R1086" rid="R1086" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919988">

4811Semple et al., 2005</a>

4812; <a href="#R1234" rid="R1234" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919090">

4813Vinod and Hungund, 2005</a>

4814).</p>

4815<div id="S25" class="sec">

4816<p>

4817</p>

4818<h5 id="S25title" class="inline">

4819a. Schizophrenia </h5>

4820<p id="P116" class="p p-first">

4821Schizophrenia is the second most common mental disorder with a lifetime prevalence of approximately 0.2 to 2% worldwide (<a href="#R40" rid="R40" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920033">

4822Ban, 2004</a>

4823). The disease usually begins in early adulthood or late adolescence and is characterized by psychotic episodes with positive symptoms including delusions and/or hallucinations, loose associations, and distortion of perception. The psychotic episodes are separated by periods with negative symptoms consisting of apathy, anhedonia, reduced social drive, loss of motivation, poverty of speech and thought, and blunting of affect. With disease progression, behavioral impairment can lead to complete social isolation. Although recent advances in the pharmacotherapy of schizophrenia produced great improvement in the clinical symptoms and the quality of life of patients, there is room for further improvements (<a href="#R40" rid="R40" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919481">

4824Ban et al., 2004</a>

4825; <a href="#R843" rid="R843" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919323">

4826Moller, 2005</a>

4827).</p>

4828<p id="P117">

4829Numerous theories have been put forth regarding the etiology of schizophrenia, ranging from developmental or neurodegenerative processes, environmental factors, neurotransmitter abnormalities (dopamine or glutamate), and infectious or autoimmune processes, but also including the cannabinoid hypothesis (reviewed in <a href="#R1173" rid="R1173" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919912">

4830Thaker and Carpenter, 2001</a>

4831; <a href="#R681" rid="R681" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920200">

4832Lewis et al., 2005</a>

4833). It appears that hypoglutamatergic and hypodopaminergic transmission in the prefrontal cortex is involved in the negative symptoms, whereas hyperactivity of dopamine neurotransmission in the mesencephalic projections to the nucleus accumbens may underlie the positive symptoms (<a href="#R1173" rid="R1173" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920088">

4834Thaker and Carpenter, 2001</a>

4835; <a href="#R681" rid="R681" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919331">

4836Lewis et al., 2005</a>

4837).</p>

4838<p id="P118">

4839According to the endocannabinoid hypothesis of schizophrenia, overactivity of the endocannabinoid system may lead to a hyperdopaminergic and hypoglutamatergic state, which may underlie some of the symptoms (<a href="#R301" rid="R301" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920268">

4840Emrich et al., 1997</a>

4841, reviewed in <a href="#R1200" rid="R1200" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919872">

4842Ujike and Morita, 2004</a>

4843; <a href="#R663" rid="R663" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488950">

4844Laviolette and Grace, 2006</a>

4845). The endocannabinoid hypothesis is supported by multiple lines of evidence. First, the use of large amounts of cannabis and THC may produce psychotic symptoms in normal individuals, including delusions, hallucinations, and cognitive impairment, which resemble schizophrenia (<a href="#R1130" rid="R1130" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920240">

4846Spencer, 1971</a>

4847; <a href="#R452" rid="R452" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919989">

4848Halikas et al., 1972</a>

4849; <a href="#R182" rid="R182" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919348">

4850Chopra and Smith, 1974</a>

4851; <a href="#R796" rid="R796" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919762">

4852McGuire et al., 1994</a>

4853; <a href="#R301" rid="R301" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919601">

4854Emrich et al., 1997</a>

4855; <a href="#R567" rid="R567" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920300">

4856Johns, 2001</a>

4857; <a href="#R286" rid="R286" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919939">

4858D&#x02019;Souza et al., 2004</a>

4859). Second, cannabis and THC may worsen psychotic symptoms in schizophrenic patients, contribute to poor outcome, increase the possibility of relapse, and decrease the effectiveness of antipsychotic drugs (<a href="#R116" rid="R116" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918987">

4860Breakey et al., 1974</a>

4861; <a href="#R1188" rid="R1188" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919985">

4862Treffert, 1978</a>

4863; <a href="#R883" rid="R883" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919980">

4864Negrete, 1989</a>

4865; <a href="#R1194" rid="R1194" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920341">

4866Turner and Tsuang, 1990</a>

4867; <a href="#R692" rid="R692" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919059">

4868Linszen et al., 1994</a>

4869; <a href="#R768" rid="R768" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918792">

4870Martinez-Arevalo et al., 1994</a>

4871; <a href="#R1241" rid="R1241" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919419">

4872Voruganti et al., 2001</a>

4873; <a href="#R285" rid="R285" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920124">

4874D&#x02019;Souza et al., 2005</a>

4875). Third, the use of cannabis may precipitate the onset of schizophrenia in individuals susceptible to psychosis (<a href="#R20" rid="R20" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919977">

4876Andreasson et al., 1987</a>

4877; <a href="#R833" rid="R833" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920405">

4878Miller et al., 2001</a>

4879). Fourth, postmortem radioligand studies document increased CB<sub>

48801</sub>

4881 receptor density in the dorsolateral and anterior cingular regions and subregions of the prefrontal cortex in schizophrenia (<a href="#R245" rid="R245" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919670">

4882Dean et al., 2001</a>

4883; <a href="#R1317" rid="R1317" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919354">

4884Zavitsanou et al., 2004</a>

4885; <a href="#R886" rid="R886" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919849">

4886Newell et al., 2006</a>

4887). Fifth, the levels of anandamide are increased in cerebrospinal fluid or blood from schizophrenic patients (<a href="#R680" rid="R680" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919536">

4888Leweke et al., 1999</a>

4889; <a href="#R251" rid="R251" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920221">

4890De Marchi et al., 2003</a>

4891; <a href="#R390" rid="R390" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919087">

4892Giuffrida et al., 2004</a>

4893). Sixth, treatment with neuroleptics appears to normalize the imbalance in endocannabinoid signaling in blood cells in schizophrenic patients (<a href="#R251" rid="R251" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918931">

4894De Marchi et al., 2003</a>

4895) and also decreases CB<sub>

48961</sub>

4897 receptor binding in the rat nucleus accumbens (<a href="#R1155" rid="R1155" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653525">

4898Sundram et al., 2005</a>

4899). Last, the hebephrenic type of schizophrenia shows a strong association with polymorphisms in the <em>

4900CNR1</em>

4901 gene encoding CB<sub>

49021</sub>

4903 receptors (<a href="#R676" rid="R676" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918798">

4904Leroy et al., 2001</a>

4905; <a href="#R1201" rid="R1201" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919169">

4906Ujike et al., 2002</a>

4907).</p>

4908<p id="P119" class="p p-last">

4909Taken together, the above evidence suggests that the endocannabinoid system may be a novel therapeutic target in schizophrenia. It is also tempting to speculate that CB<sub>

49101</sub>

4911 antagonists may be beneficial against some, most likely the negative, symptoms of the disease. Some preclinical and clinical evidence also suggests that cannabidiol may have antipsychotic potential (reviewed in <a href="#R1326" rid="R1326" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918850">

4912Zuardi et al., 2006</a>

4913).</p>

4914</div>

4915<div id="S26" class="sec sec-last">

4916<p>

4917</p>

4918<h5 id="S26title" class="inline">

4919b. Anxiety and depression </h5>

4920<p id="P120" class="p p-first">

4921Mood disorders such as generalized anxiety or panic disorder, major depressive disorder and bipolar disorder (manic depressive illness) are very common, often serious, and potentially life-threatening conditions. More than 20% of the adult population experiences a mood disorder at some point during their life. In up to 15% of individuals with major depressive disorder the cause of death is suicide. According to a World Health Organization forecast, by the year 2020 depression will become the second leading cause of premature death and disability worldwide (<a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919927">

4922Pacher and Kecskem&#x000e9;ti, 2004</a>

4923). Although significant advances have been made in the treatment of mood disorders during the past decades, ~30% of the population do not respond to current therapies, and the search for novel pharmacological approaches continues (reviewed in <a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919494">

4924Pacher and Kecskem&#x000e9;ti, 2004</a>

4925).</p>

4926<p id="P121">

4927Many of the psychological effects of cannabis and THC are biphasic and bidirectional, depending on mode of administration, dose, personality, time frame, degree of tolerance, and various other environmental and individual factors (<a href="#R949" rid="R949" class=" bibr popnode">

4928Paton and Pertwee, 1973</a>

4929; <a href="#R29" rid="R29" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920229">

4930Ashton et al., 1981</a>

4931, <a href="#R28" rid="R28" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919244">

49322005</a>

4933; <a href="#R1235" rid="R1235" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919996">

4934Viveros et al., 2005</a>

4935). The acute effects in normal subjects can range from euphoria, relaxation, excitation, heightened perception, and increased motor activity to dysphoria, anxiety, sedation, perceptual distortion, and incoordination. THC, under certain conditions and at certain doses, exerts anxiolytic, antidepressant, and hypnotic effects in patients suffering from pain associated with cancer or multiple sclerosis and improves mood and general well-being in normal subjects (<a href="#R1005" rid="R1005" class=" bibr popnode">

4936Regelson et al., 1976</a>

4937; <a href="#R403" rid="R403" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920057">

4938Glass et al., 1980</a>

4939; <a href="#R29" rid="R29" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919839">

4940Ashton et al., 1981</a>

4941; <a href="#R307" rid="R307" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920061">

4942Fabre and McLendon, 1981</a>

4943; <a href="#R539" rid="R539" class=" bibr popnode">

4944Ilaria et al., 1981</a>

4945; <a href="#R770" rid="R770" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918731">

4946Martyn et al., 1995</a>

4947; <a href="#R27" rid="R27" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919784">

4948Ashton, 1999</a>

4949; <a href="#R1245" rid="R1245" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919130">

4950Wade et al., 2003</a>

4951). However, under different conditions and at higher doses, cannabis or THC can produce dysphoric reactions, anxiety, panic paranoia, and psychosis (<a href="#R1130" rid="R1130" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919545">

4952Spencer, 1971</a>

4953; <a href="#R452" rid="R452" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920029">

4954Halikas et al., 1972</a>

4955; <a href="#R182" rid="R182" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920120">

4956Chopra and Smith, 1974</a>

4957; <a href="#R29" rid="R29" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920015">

4958Ashton et al., 1981</a>

4959, <a href="#R28" rid="R28" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918956">

49602005</a>

4961; <a href="#R796" rid="R796" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920286">

4962McGuire et al., 1994</a>

4963; <a href="#R301" rid="R301" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918941">

4964Emrich et al., 1997</a>

4965; <a href="#R567" rid="R567" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919471">

4966Johns, 2001</a>

4967; <a href="#R952" rid="R952" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919123">

4968Patton et al., 2002</a>

4969; <a href="#R1185" rid="R1185" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919621">

4970Tournier et al., 2003</a>

4971; <a href="#R239" rid="R239" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920062">

4972Dannon et al., 2004</a>

4973; <a href="#R286" rid="R286" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919767">

4974D&#x02019;Souza et al., 2004</a>

4975; reviewed in <a href="#R518" rid="R518" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918944">

4976Hollister, 1986</a>

4977; <a href="#R453" rid="R453" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920171">

4978Hall and Solowij, 1998</a>

4979).</p>

4980<p id="P122">

4981CBD also possesses anxiolytic, antipsychotic and anticonvulsant properties, which are not mediated by classic cannabinoid receptors (<a href="#R155" rid="R155" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920322">

4982Carlini et al., 1975</a>

4983; <a href="#R205" rid="R205" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920336">

4984Consroe and Wolkin, 1977</a>

4985; <a href="#R202" rid="R202" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919231">

4986Consroe et al., 1981</a>

4987; <a href="#R1328" rid="R1328" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918986">

4988Zuardi et al., 1982</a>

4989, <a href="#R1327" rid="R1327" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919714">

49901995</a>

4991, <a href="#R1326" rid="R1326" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918810">

49922006</a>

4993; <a href="#R18" rid="R18" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920150">

4994Ames and Cridland, 1986</a>

4995; <a href="#R757" rid="R757" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919527">

4996Martin et al., 1987</a>

4997; <a href="#R441" rid="R441" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920108">

4998Guimaraes et al., 1990</a>

4999, <a href="#R442" rid="R442" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919156">

50001994</a>

5001; reviewed in <a href="#R813" rid="R813" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919101">

5002Mechoulam et al., 2002c</a>

5003; <a href="#R435" rid="R435" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919021">

5004Grotenhermen, 2003</a>

5005; <a href="#R703" rid="R703" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919400">

5006Long et al., 2006</a>

5007). The mode of action of CBD is not completely understood; it may involve blockade of anandamide and serotonin reuptake (<a href="#R91" rid="R91" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919627">

5008Bisogno et al., 2001</a>

5009; <a href="#R803" rid="R803" class=" bibr popnode">

5010McPartland and Russo, 2001</a>

5011), inhibition of the enzymatic hydrolysis of anandamide (<a href="#R811" rid="R811" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653469">

5012Mechoulam et al., 2002</a>

5013), or an interaction with as yet unidentified receptors (<a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919655">

5014J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

5015; <a href="#R963" rid="R963" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919250">

5016Pertwee et al., 2002</a>

5017).</p>

5018<p id="P123">

5019Animal studies yielded further support to the biphasic and bidirectional effects of cannabinoids on anxiety, with low doses being anxiolytic and high doses being anxiogenic. Indeed, low doses of CP55,940 (<a href="#R374" rid="R374" class=" bibr popnode">

5020Genn et al., 2003</a>

5021; <a href="#R749" rid="R749" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919350">

5022Marco et al., 2004</a>

5023), nabilone (<a href="#R907" rid="R907" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919555">

5024Onaivi et al., 1990</a>

5025), and THC (<a href="#R73" rid="R73" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918921">

5026Berrendero and Maldonado, 2002</a>

5027) exerted anxiolytic-like effects in the light-dark crossing test and in the elevated plus-maze in adult rodents. Low-dose CP55,940 was also anxiolytic in other models of anxiety in adult, juvenile, or infant rodents (<a href="#R1030" rid="R1030" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653499">

5028Romero et al., 2002a</a>

5029; <a href="#R105" rid="R105" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918745">

5030Borcel et al., 2004</a>

5031; <a href="#R375" rid="R375" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920035">

5032Genn et al., 2004</a>

5033). In contrast, at medium to high doses, CP55,940 or HU-210 displayed anxiogenic effects in the same or other experimental paradigms in adult as well as in juvenile or infant animals (<a href="#R794" rid="R794" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920135">

5034McGregor et al., 1996a</a>

5035,<a href="#R795" rid="R795" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919862">

5036b</a>

5037; <a href="#R1028" rid="R1028" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919823">

5038Rodriguez de Fonseca et al., 1996</a>

5039; <a href="#R392" rid="R392" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920067">

5040Giuliani et al., 2000</a>

5041; <a href="#R23" rid="R23" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920246">

5042Arevalo et al., 2001</a>

5043; Marin et al., 2002; <a href="#R103" rid="R103" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920195">

5044Romero et al., 2002</a>

5045; <a href="#R374" rid="R374" class=" bibr popnode">

5046Genn et al., 2003</a>

5047;<a href="#R374" rid="R374" class=" bibr popnode">

50482003</a>

5049;<a href="#R375" rid="R375" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920095">

50502004</a>

5051; <a href="#R749" rid="R749" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919882">

5052Marin Marco et al., 2004</a>

5053). Although several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the biphasic effects of cannabinoids on anxiety, including distinct receptors (<a href="#R457" rid="R457" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920194">

5054Haller et al., 2004a</a>

5055,<a href="#R458" rid="R458" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919628">

5056b</a>

5057) or neuroanatomically separated CB<sub>

50581</sub>

5059 receptors with a differential sensitivity to the anxiolytic versus anxiogenic effects of cannabinoids, these need to be confirmed in future studies (reviewed in <a href="#R1235" rid="R1235" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919122">

5060Viveros et al., 2005</a>

5061).</p>

5062<p id="P124">

5063The high level of CB<sub>

50641</sub>

5065 receptors in the hippocampus, amygdala, and prefrontal and anterior cingular cortex, key regions in the regulation of anxiety, may suggest that the endocannabinoid system plays a role in the control of anxiety (<a href="#R486" rid="R486" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920377">

5066Herkenham et al., 1990</a>

5067, <a href="#R484" rid="R484" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920005">

50681991a</a>

5069,<a href="#R485" rid="R485" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637201">

5070b</a>

5071; <a href="#R397" rid="R397" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919960">

5072Glass et al., 1997b</a>

5073; <a href="#R590" rid="R590" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637193">

5074Katona et al., 2001</a>

5075; <a href="#R450" rid="R450" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918796">

5076H&#x000e1;jos and Freund, 2002</a>

5077; <a href="#R1196" rid="R1196" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637190">

5078Tzavara et al., 2003</a>

5079; <a href="#R973" rid="R973" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919637">

5080Pistis et al., 2004</a>

5081). Further support of this theory came from studies using CB<sub>

50821</sub>

5083 receptor antagonists or CB<sub>

50841</sub>

5085 receptor knockout mice. SR141716 produced anxiogenic effects in the elevated plus-maze and the defensive withdrawal tests in adult rats (<a href="#R881" rid="R881" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919243">

5086Navarro et al., 1997</a>

5087; <a href="#R23" rid="R23" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919464">

5088Arevalo et al., 2001</a>

5089). Furthermore, SR141716 not only reversed the anxiolytic effects of the CB<sub>

50901</sub>

5091 agonist CP55,940 but also was anxiogenic in the ultrasonic vocalization test in rat pups when administered alone (<a href="#R794" rid="R794" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919819">

5092McGregor et al., 1996a</a>

5093). In contrast, <a href="#R456" rid="R456" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919696">

5094Haller et al. (2002)</a>

5095 found SR141716 to be anxiolytic in the plus-maze in mice, but this effect was not mediated by CB<sub>

50961</sub>

5097 receptors as indicated by its presence in CB<sub>

50981</sub>

5099 knockout mice. Furthermore, another selective CB<sub>

51001</sub>

5101 receptor antagonist, AM251, increased anxiety-like behavior in wild-type mice but had no effect in the knockouts, in support of a CB<sub>

51021</sub>

5103 receptor-mediated anxiolysis. As discussed before, SR141716, but not AM251, also inhibits a CB<sub>

51041</sub>

5105-like receptor that mediates presynaptic inhibition of glutamate release in the hippocampus (<a href="#R450" rid="R450" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918818">

5106H&#x000e1;jos and Freund, 2002</a>

5107). Thus, the findings of <a href="#R456" rid="R456" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919549">

5108Haller et al. (2002)</a>

5109 could suggest that the anxiolytic effect of SR141716 is mediated by such a CB<sub>

51101</sub>

5111-like receptor, activation of which would be anxiogenic.</p>

5112<p id="P125">

5113CB<sub>

51141</sub>

5115 knockout mice displayed increased anxiogenic responses in the light-dark box, plus-maze, and social interaction tests, an increased aggressive response in the resident-intruder test, and marked alterations in the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis coupled with impaired action of known anxiolytic drugs such as buspiron and bromazepam (<a href="#R456" rid="R456" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918879">

5116Haller et al., 2002</a>

5117, <a href="#R458" rid="R458" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919455">

51182004b</a>

5119; <a href="#R760" rid="R760" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920250">

5120Martin et al., 2002</a>

5121; <a href="#R1205" rid="R1205" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918710">

5122Urig&#x000fc;en et al., 2004</a>

5123). However, <a href="#R754" rid="R754" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920334">

5124Marsicano et al. (2002)</a>

5125 were unable to demonstrate anxiogenic-like response in CB<sub>

51261</sub>

5127 knockout mice in the plus-maze. This may be related to differences in the genetic background of the CB<sub>

51281</sub>

5129 knockout mice used and/or different experimental conditions. The importance of the latter is also indicated by the confounding effect of stress on anxiogenic behaviors and their modulation by endocannabinoids (<a href="#R457" rid="R457" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919915">

5130Haller et al., 2004a</a>

5131; <a href="#R946" rid="R946" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919013">

5132Patel et al., 2005</a>

5133). Stress-induced down-regulation of hippocampal endocannabinoid signaling may contribute to problems in behavioral flexibility and may play a role in the development of perseveratory and ruminatory behaviors in stress-related neuropsychiatric disorders (<a href="#R497" rid="R497" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920292">

5134Hill et al., 2005</a>

5135). Collectively, a majority of evidence supports a role for CB<sub>

51361</sub>

5137 receptors in the control of emotional behavior and suggests the existence of an anxiolytic endocannabinoid tone. Facilitation of such a tone by inhibiting the degradation of endocannabinoids in vivo may be therapeutically exploited, as indicated by the reduced anxiety-like behavior and potent antidepressant-like effects in mice and rats treated with a FAAH or anandamide transport inhibitor and the blockade of this effect by SR141716 or AM281 (<a href="#R589" rid="R589" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919425">

5138Kathuria et al., 2003</a>

5139; <a href="#R404" rid="R404" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919853">

5140Gobbi et al., 2005</a>

5141; <a href="#R108" rid="R108" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488954">

5142Bortolato et al., 2006</a>

5143; <a href="#R1053" rid="R1053" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919330">

5144Rutkowska et al., 2006</a>

5145).</p>

5146<p id="P126">

5147The mechanisms responsible for the effects of cannabinoids on anxiety-related responses are complex and may involve modulation of numerous neurotransmitter systems. For example, stimulation of CB<sub>

51481</sub>
