5149 receptors in rodents activates the HPA axis through the release of CRH (<a href="#R1277" rid="R1277" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919020">

5150Weidenfeld et al., 1994</a>

5151; <a href="#R1281" rid="R1281" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919754">

5152Wenger et al., 1997</a>

5153; <a href="#R767" rid="R767" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918773">

5154Martin-Calderon et al., 1998</a>

5155; <a href="#R746" rid="R746" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920032">

5156Manzanares et al., 1999a</a>

5157; <a href="#R749" rid="R749" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918713">

5158Marco et al., 2004</a>

5159), which could account for the anxiogenic effects of high doses of cannabinoids (<a href="#R1028" rid="R1028" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919040">

5160Rodriguez de Fonseca et al., 1996</a>

5161; Marin et al., 2002). In contrast, there are also examples of negative modulation of HPA function by endocannabinoids (<a href="#R267" rid="R267" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637232">

5162Di et al., 2003</a>

5163; <a href="#R947" rid="R947" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920179">

5164Patel et al., 2004</a>

5165). Cannabinoids also modulate GABAergic transmission and the release of the peptide cholecystokinin, which may contribute to both anxiolytic and anxiogenic effects (<a href="#R907" rid="R907" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919143">

5166Onaivi et al., 1990</a>

5167; <a href="#R591" rid="R591" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637192">

5168Katona et al., 1999</a>

5169, <a href="#R590" rid="R590" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637226">

51702001</a>

5171; <a href="#R752" rid="R752" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919846">

5172Marsicano and Lutz, 1999</a>

5173; <a href="#R1191" rid="R1191" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919218">

5174Tsou et al., 1999</a>

5175; <a href="#R59" rid="R59" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919716">

5176Beinfeld and Connolly, 2001</a>

5177; <a href="#R1043" rid="R1043" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920203">

5178Rotzinger and Vaccarino, 2003</a>

5179). Furthermore, cannabinoids enhance the release of endogenous opioids and a functional interplay between the endocannabinoid and opioid systems modulates analgesic responses and is involved in antidepressant-like effects and in various addiction-related processes (<a href="#R988" rid="R988" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918717">

5180Pugh et al., 1997</a>

5181; <a href="#R747" rid="R747" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919428">

5182Manzanares et al., 1999b</a>

5183; <a href="#R524" rid="R524" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918908">

5184Houser et al., 2000</a>

5185; <a href="#R1324" rid="R1324" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637242">

5186Zimmer et al., 2001</a>

5187; <a href="#R385" rid="R385" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637227">

5188Ghozland et al., 2002</a>

5189). From studies with THC and CP55,940, it appears that <em>

5190&#x003bc;</em>

5191- and <em>

5192&#x003b4;</em>

5193-opioid receptors mediate certain anxiolytic effects, whereas activation of <em>

5194&#x003ba;</em>

5195-opioid receptors leads to increased anxiety (<a href="#R988" rid="R988" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919479">

5196Pugh et al., 1997</a>

5197; <a href="#R524" rid="R524" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918934">

5198Houser et al., 2000</a>

5199; <a href="#R1324" rid="R1324" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637218">

5200Zimmer et al., 2001</a>

5201; <a href="#R73" rid="R73" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920236">

5202Berrendero and Maldonado, 2002</a>

5203; <a href="#R385" rid="R385" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637216">

5204Ghozland et al., 2002</a>

5205; <a href="#R750" rid="R750" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919267">

5206Marin et al., 2003</a>

5207). There are also interactions between the endocannabinoid and serotonergic systems (<a href="#R23" rid="R23" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919616">

5208Arevalo et al., 2001</a>

5209; <a href="#R741" rid="R741" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919933">

5210Malone and Taylor, 2001</a>

5211; <a href="#R350" rid="R350" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919316">

5212Fride and Shohami, 2002</a>

5213; <a href="#R750" rid="R750" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919776">

5214Marin et al., 2003</a>

5215; <a href="#R749" rid="R749" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919891">

5216Marco et al., 2004</a>

5217; <a href="#R1135" rid="R1135" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920080">

5218Steffens and Feuerstein, 2004</a>

5219; reviewed in <a href="#R1235" rid="R1235" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919850">

5220Viveros et al., 2005</a>

5221), although their role in anxiety-like behaviors has not been explored</p>

5222<p id="P127">

5223In contrast to earlier dogma, recent findings indicate that neurogenesis occurs in the adult brain. Furthermore, stress and depression decrease neurogenesis, particularly in the hippocampus, whereas electroconvulsive therapy and chronic treatment with conventional antidepressants increases this process (reviewed in <a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920234">

5224Pacher et al., 2004a</a>

5225). It has been recently demonstrated that the endocannabinoid system drives neural progenitor cell proliferation (<a href="#R10" rid="R10" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920264">

5226Aguado et al., 2005</a>

5227, <a href="#R11" rid="R11" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637188">

52282006</a>

5229), and cannabinoids promote neurogenesis (<a href="#R70" rid="R70" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919987">

5230Berghuis et al., 2005</a>

5231; <a href="#R560" rid="R560" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919237">

5232Jiang et al., 2005</a>

5233). Furthermore, CB<sub>

52341</sub>

5235 receptors appear to be required for neuronal survival in the hippocampus (<a href="#R86" rid="R86" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919136">

5236Bilkei-Gorzo et al., 2005</a>

5237). These findings are particularly exciting, as they raise the possibility of a role for endocannabinoids in antidepressive drug action. Indeed, CB<sub>

52381</sub>

5239 receptor density in the hippocampus and hypothalamus is increased by chronic tricyclic antidepressant treatment (<a href="#R496" rid="R496" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488949">

5240Hill et al., 2006</a>

5241), and the amplification of the actions of endocannabinoids by the FAAH inhibitor URB597 was found to produce antidepressant-like effects in the mouse tail-suspension and rat forced-swim tests, without eliciting reward-related effects indicative of addictive potential (<a href="#R404" rid="R404" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919916">

5242Gobbi et al., 2005</a>

5243). It should not be surprising, however, that based on the basis of the bimodal action of cannabinoids on mood and anxiety, a case could be made for the opposite, i.e., for the antidepressive potential of CB<sub>

52441</sub>

5245 <em>

5246antagonism</em>

5247. CB<sub>

52481</sub>

5249 antagonists were reported to elicit antidepressant-like behavioral effects in rodents and can increase the synaptic concentration of biogenic amines, much like antidepressants do (reviewed in <a href="#R1298" rid="R1298" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919855">

5250Witkin et al., 2005</a>

5251). Thus, pharmacological modulation of the endocannabinoid system holds considerable promise in the treatment of both anxiety-related and mood disorders.</p>

5252<p id="P128" class="p p-last">

5253The results of a recent study implicated endocannabinoids and CB<sub>

52541</sub>

5255 receptors in the extinction of aversive memories by demonstrating that CB<sub>

52561</sub>

5257 knockout mice show impaired extinction in auditory fear-conditioning tests, and this could be mimicked in wild-type mice by treatment with SR141716 (<a href="#R755" rid="R755" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919289">

5258Marsicano et al., 2002b</a>

5259). These exciting findings raise the possibility that pharmacological amplification of CB<sub>

52601</sub>

5261 signaling, for example, by FAAH inhibitors, may have therapeutic value in obsessive-compulsive disorder or post-traumatic shock syndrome.</p>

5262</div>

5263</div>

5264<div id="S27" class="sec">

5265<p>

5266</p>

5267<h4 id="S27title" class="inline">

52689. Insomnia </h4>

5269<p id="P129" class="p p-first">

5270Insomnia, the most common sleep disorder, is defined as difficulty with the initiation, maintenance, duration, or quality of sleep that results in the impairment of daytime functioning, despite adequate opportunity and circumstances for sleep (<a href="#R1106" rid="R1106" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919919">

5271Silber, 2005</a>

5272). The cause for insomnia is often not known, but frequently it may be a consequence of a chronic disease associated with pain or depression.</p>

5273<p id="P130">

5274Early studies documented the fact that marijuana and THC affect sleep patterns both in humans (<a href="#R342" rid="R342" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653491">

5275Freemon, 1972</a>

5276, <a href="#R343" rid="R343" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919873">

52771982</a>

5278; <a href="#R974" rid="R974" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919638">

5279Pivik et al., 1972</a>

5280; <a href="#R44" rid="R44" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919422">

5281Barratt et al., 1974</a>

5282; <a href="#R318" rid="R318" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920196">

5283Feinberg et al., 1975</a>

5284, <a href="#R317" rid="R317" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919576">

52851976</a>

5286) and in experimental animals (<a href="#R847" rid="R847" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919075">

5287Monti, 1977</a>

5288; <a href="#R130" rid="R130" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919652">

5289Buonamici et al., 1982</a>

5290). More recently, <a href="#R890" rid="R890" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919181">

5291Nicholson et al. (2004)</a>

5292 have studied the effects of cannabis extracts on nocturnal sleep, early-morning performance, memory, and sleepiness in a placebo-controlled, double-blind, crossover study in eight healthy volunteers. They found that 15 mg of THC was sedative, whereas 15 mg of CBD had alerting properties as it increased wake activity during sleep and counteracted the residual sedative activity of THC (<a href="#R890" rid="R890" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920317">

5293Nicholson et al., 2004</a>

5294).</p>

5295<p id="P131">

5296Anandamide was also found to modulate sleep by increasing slow-wave sleep two and rapid eye movement sleep in a CB<sub>

52971</sub>

5298 receptor-dependent manner in rats (<a href="#R867" rid="R867" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919603">

5299Murillo-Rodriguez et al., 1998</a>

5300, <a href="#R866" rid="R866" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919081">

53012001</a>

5302). Moreover, CB<sub>

53031</sub>

5304 receptor expression in the pons of rats was modulated by the light/dark cycle and by sleep (<a href="#R769" rid="R769" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919514">

5305Martinez-Vargas et al., 2003</a>

5306), and endocannabinoids and CB<sub>

53071</sub>

5308 receptors were also implicated in rapid eye movement sleep rebound (<a href="#R878" rid="R878" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919920">

5309Navarro et al., 2003</a>

5310). Interestingly, a recent study has demonstrated that anandamide not only induced sleep but also increased levels of the sleep-inducing substance adenosine in the basal forebrain, and both of these effects were blocked by SR141716 (<a href="#R865" rid="R865" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918919">

5311Murillo-Rodriguez et al., 2003</a>

5312).</p>

5313<p id="P132">

5314Oleamide is a fatty acid amide with a variety of in vitro effects, including inhibition of gap junction-mediated cell-cell communication (<a href="#R101" rid="R101" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920347">

5315Boger et al., 1998a</a>

5316,<a href="#R103" rid="R103" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920394">

5317b</a>

5318), modulation of 5-HT<sub>

53191</sub>

5320, 5-HT<sub>

53212A,C</sub>

5322, and 5-HT<sub>

53237</sub>

5324 receptors (<a href="#R1178" rid="R1178" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919690">

5325Thomas et al., 1997</a>

5326, <a href="#R1179" rid="R1179" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918994">

53271999</a>

5328; <a href="#R478" rid="R478" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919025">

5329Hedlund et al., 1999</a>

5330), and modulation of inhibitory ionotropic receptors such as the GABA<sub>

5331A</sub>

5332 receptor (<a href="#R221" rid="R221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920344">

5333Coyne et al., 2002</a>

5334). Oleamide accumulates in the cerebrospinal fluid of sleep-deprived cats (<a href="#R224" rid="R224" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653356">

5335Cravatt et al., 1995</a>

5336) and rats (<a href="#R49" rid="R49" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919234">

5337Basile et al., 1999</a>

5338) and induces sleep, an effect which could be blocked by SR141716 (<a href="#R822" rid="R822" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919037">

5339Mendelson and Basile, 1999</a>

5340). Initially, it was suggested that inhibition of anandamide degradation by FAAH rather than the activation of CB<sub>

53411</sub>

5342 receptors was responsible for the sleep-inducing effect of oleamide (<a href="#R106" rid="R106" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653512">

5343Boring et al., 1996</a>

5344; <a href="#R807" rid="R807" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920002">

5345Mechoulam et al., 1997</a>

5346), but this is a matter of dispute (<a href="#R331" rid="R331" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919569">

5347Fowler, 2004</a>

5348; <a href="#R669" rid="R669" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920367">

5349Lees and Dougalis, 2004</a>

5350; <a href="#R670" rid="R670" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920227">

5351Leggett et al., 2004</a>

5352).</p>

5353<p id="P133" class="p p-last">

5354Although little is known about the role of the endocannabinoid system in the pathophysiology of sleep disorders, clinical studies uniformly report significantly improved sleep quality in patients taking cannabinoids for symptomatic treatment of multiple sclerosis, cancer, chronic pain, or intractable pruritus. Although psychotropic cannabinoids are unlikely to gain acceptance for the treatment of insomnia, FAAH inhibitors were shown to enhance certain endocannabinoid-mediated behaviors without evidence for addictive properties (<a href="#R589" rid="R589" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920189">

5355Kathuria et al., 2003</a>

5356). The sleep-inducing property of some potent FAAH inhibitors, such as the endogenous lipid 2-octyl <em>

5357&#x003b3;</em>

5358-bromoacetoacetate (<a href="#R101" rid="R101" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919184">

5359Boger et al., 1998a</a>

5360), could therefore be therapeutically exploited.</p>

5361</div>

5362<div id="S28" class="sec">

5363<p>

5364</p>

5365<h4 id="S28title" class="inline">

536610. Nausea and Emesis </h4>

5367<p id="P134" class="p p-first">

5368Nausea and vomiting can present as symptoms of a variety of diseases or as secondary consequences of chemotherapy or radiotherapy of cancer. It is for this latter indication that THC has gained acceptance as a highly efficacious therapeutic agent, often effective in cases resistant to other, more conventional, medications (reviewed by <a href="#R758" rid="R758" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918868">

5369Martin and Wiley, 2004</a>

5370; <a href="#R1" rid="R1" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918743">

5371Aapro, 2005</a>

5372; <a href="#R454" rid="R454" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919402">

5373Hall et al., 2005</a>

5374). Emesis is thought to involve activation of specific receptors on sensory nerve endings in the gut and also in brainstem regions including the medullary chemoreceptor trigger zone and the lateral reticular formation. Activation of 5-HT<sub>

53753</sub>

5376 receptors appears to play a dominant role in acute emesis, whereas activation of NK<sub>

53771</sub>

5378 (substance P) receptors is more important in the delayed emesis after chemotherapy, as indicated by the effectiveness of the respective receptor antagonists in controlling these different stages of the emetic response (<a href="#R1" rid="R1" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918716">

5379Aapro, 2005</a>

5380). Although the mechanism of the antiemetic action of cannabinoids is not quite clear, an interaction with 5-HT<sub>

53813</sub>

5382 is suggested by the colocalization of CB<sub>

53831</sub>

5384 and 5-HT<sub>

53853</sub>

5386 receptors on GABAergic neurons where they have opposite effects on GABA release (<a href="#R850" rid="R850" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920076">

5387Morales et al., 2004</a>

5388). Also, cannabinoids may directly inhibit 5-HT<sub>

53893</sub>

5390-gated ion currents by a mechanism not involving CB<sub>

53911</sub>

5392 receptors (<a href="#R310" rid="R310" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919164">

5393Fan, 1995</a>

5394; <a href="#R41" rid="R41" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920210">

5395Barann et al., 2002</a>

5396). Such a CB<sub>

53971</sub>

5398 receptor-independent effect is also suggested by the ability of cannabidiol, a natural constituent of marijuana which does not bind to the CB<sub>

53991</sub>

5400 receptor, to reduce lithium-induced vomiting in the house musk shrew (<a href="#R940" rid="R940" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920343">

5401Parker et al., 2004</a>

5402). Nevertheless, the involvement of CB<sub>

54031</sub>

5404 receptors is clearly indicated by the ability of SR141716 to reverse the effects of THC and synthetic agonists in suppressing vomiting caused by cisplatin (<a href="#R242" rid="R242" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918831">

5405Darmani, 2001b</a>

5406) or lithium chloride (<a href="#R940" rid="R940" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918860">

5407Parker et al., 2004</a>

5408), or by the ability of these agonist to reverse the emesis elicited by SR141716 in the least shrew (<a href="#R241" rid="R241" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919022">

5409Darmani, 2001a</a>

5410). These latter findings suggest that the emetic circuitry is tonically controlled by endocannabinoids.</p>

5411<p id="P135" class="p p-last">

5412In line with such a possibility, a recent human study found an association between chronic marijuana use, which probably results in desensitization of cannabinoid receptors, and cyclical hyperemesis: in the 19 subjects studied, the hyperemetic episodes subsided upon discontinuation of cannabis use and reappeared upon rechallenge with cannabis (<a href="#R14" rid="R14" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918748">

5413Allen et al., 2005</a>

5414). A meta-analysis of 30 randomized comparisons of cannabis (nabilone, dronabinol, or levonantradol) with placebo or standard antiemetics, involving a total of 1366 patients, concluded that cannabinoids are slightly more effective than conventional antiemetics, and the patients prefer them because of their mood enhancing and sedative effects. However, they were also more toxic, with dizziness, dysphoria, hallucinations, and paranoia being the most prominent undesirable side effects (<a href="#R1186" rid="R1186" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653489">

5415Tram&#x000e9;r et al., 2001</a>

5416). This led to the recommendation to limit the use of cannabinoids as antiemetics to patients with chemotherapy-related sickness, in whom their mood-enhancing effects would be of added benefit.</p>

5417</div>

5418<div id="S29" class="sec sec-last">

5419<p>

5420</p>

5421<h4 id="S29title" class="inline">

542211. Drug Addiction and Alcohol Disorders </h4>

5423<p id="P136" class="p p-first">

5424The positive reinforcing effect of natural rewards, such as those derived from eating, drinking, work, or sexual activity, are mediated by the brain&#x02019;s reward circuitry. Neuroanatomically, this circuitry consists of three series of coupled pathways. First-order neurons project from structures in the ventral limbic forebrain (orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate area) to the mesencephalic ventral tegmental area (VTA) where they synapse onto dopaminergic neurons. These second-order neurons project primarily to neurons in the shell of the nucleus accumbens (nAc), but also to cortical areas and to the amygdala. Third-order neurons in the nAc, some of which are GABAergic, project to the ventral pallidum and other regions involved in mediating reward-related behaviors (recently reviewed by <a href="#R711" rid="R711" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919158">

5425Lupica et al., 2004</a>

5426; <a href="#R367" rid="R367" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919959">

5427Gardner, 2005</a>

5428). It is believed that addictive drugs activate or &#x0201c;hijack&#x0201d; the same pathway. Genetic vulnerability to drug addiction has been linked to a functional deficiency in the second-order dopaminergic neurons at their interface with third-order neurons in the nAc (<a href="#R885" rid="R885" class=" bibr popnode">

5429Nestler, 2003</a>

5430). In human subjects prone to addiction, a deficiency in D<sub>

54312</sub>

5432 dopamine receptors in the nAc could be documented by brain imaging (<a href="#R1240" rid="R1240" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918679">

5433Volkow et al., 1997</a>

5434, <a href="#R1239" rid="R1239" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918775">

54351999</a>

5436).</p>

5437<p id="P137">

5438A common denominator among different addictive drugs interacting with distinct receptors is their ability to activate the mesolimbic dopaminergic reward pathway and increase dopamine levels in the nAc, which is believed to be responsible for their addictive properties (<a href="#R621" rid="R621" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919790">

5439Koob, 1992</a>

5440; <a href="#R1297" rid="R1297" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919970">

5441Wise, 2004</a>

5442). Similar to other drugs of abuse, THC increases extracellular dopamine levels in the nAc via activation of CB<sub>

54431</sub>

5444 receptors (<a href="#R174" rid="R174" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919571">

5445Chen et al., 1990</a>

5446; <a href="#R1162" rid="R1162" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919247">

5447Tanda et al., 1999</a>

5448) and also lowers the reward threshold for electrical brain stimulation (<a href="#R368" rid="R368" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919631">

5449Gardner et al., 1988</a>

5450), a phenomenon known to involve activation of the mesolimbic dopamine system. THC also increases the firing rate of the second-order VTA-nAc dopaminergic neurons via CB<sub>

54511</sub>

5452 but not opiate receptors (<a href="#R344" rid="R344" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920345">

5453French, 1997</a>

5454), and withdrawal from THC increases corticotropin-releasing factor levels in the central nucleus of the amygdala (<a href="#R1026" rid="R1026" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653452">

5455Rodriguez de Fonseca et al., 1997</a>

5456), another hallmark of drugs of abuse (<a href="#R622" rid="R622" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919641">

5457Koob, 1996</a>

5458).</p>

5459<p id="P138">

5460THC and related synthetic cannabinoid agonists also fulfill the reward-related behavioral criteria for drugs of abuse: they support conditioned place preference (CPP) under appropriate conditions (<a href="#R675" rid="R675" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920295">

5461Lepore et al., 1995</a>

5462; <a href="#R1208" rid="R1208" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918870">

5463Valjent and Maldonado, 2000</a>

5464; <a href="#R1314" rid="R1314" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637246">

5465Zangen et al., 2006</a>

5466), they are self-administered intravenously or intracerebrally in a CB<sub>

54671</sub>

5468 antagonist-sensitive manner (<a href="#R756" rid="R756" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920193">

5469Martellotta et al., 1998</a>

5470; <a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653384">

5471Ledent et al., 1999</a>

5472; <a href="#R114" rid="R114" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653523">

5473Braida et al., 2001</a>

5474; <a href="#R1314" rid="R1314" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637236">

5475Zangen et al., 2006</a>

5476), and they reinstate cocaine-or heroine-seeking behavior in rats previously extinguished from self-administration (<a href="#R255" rid="R255" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920245">

5477De Vries et al., 2001</a>

5478).</p>

5479<p id="P139">

5480An issue of intense interest is the location of the CB<sub>

54811</sub>

5482 receptors mediating these effects. Similar to cannabinoids, opiates also increase the activity of dopaminergic neurons in the VTA. This effect has been shown to result from <em>

5483&#x003bc;</em>

5484 receptor-mediated inhibition of GABA release from the terminals of inhibitory GABAergic interneurons, i.e., through a &#x0201c;disinhibitory&#x0201d; mechanism (<a href="#R568" rid="R568" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637184">

5485Johnson and North, 1992</a>

5486). A similar mechanism has been postulated for cannabinoids by <a href="#R171" rid="R171" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919646">

5487Cheer et al. (2000)</a>

5488, who reported that local application of the cannabinoid agonist HU-210 to brain slices containing the VTA increased dopaminergic neuronal activity, which could be blocked by the GABA<sub>

5489A</sub>

5490 antagonist bicuculline. In line with this, WIN 55,212-2 was found to suppress electrically evoked, but not muscimol-induced, inhibitory postsynaptic currents via CB<sub>

54911</sub>

5492 receptors in brain slices containing the VTA (<a href="#R1159" rid="R1159" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920374">

5493Szabo et al., 2002</a>

5494). However, cannabinoids also inhibit glutamate release in the VTA, which would have an opposite effect on dopaminergic activity (<a href="#R817" rid="R817" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637244">

5495Melis et al., 2004a</a>

5496). There is evidence for additional sites of action, such as CB<sub>

54971</sub>

5498 receptors on the terminals of GABAergic projection neurons that target GABA<sub>

5499B</sub>

5500 receptors on VTA dopamine neurons resulting in their disinhibition (<a href="#R1018" rid="R1018" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_539174733">

5501Riegel and Lupica, 2004</a>

5502). This pathway may be activated by ethanol, as indicated by the ability of the GABA<sub>

5503B</sub>

5504 agonist baclofen to antagonize the increase in ethanol drinking caused by WIN 55,212-2 treatment of alcohol-preferring rats (<a href="#R198" rid="R198" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920170">

5505Colombo et al., 2004</a>

5506). Activation of CB<sub>

55071</sub>

5508 receptors on glutamatergic terminals in the nAc was reported to inhibit glutamate release onto GABAergic neurons in the nAc that project to the VTA, which may also result in disinhibition of VTA dopaminergic neurons (<a href="#R1023" rid="R1023" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637206">

5509Robbe et al., 2001</a>

5510). Indeed, both the VTA and the nAc may be sites of the rewarding effects of cannabinoids, as documented by the propensity of rats to self-administer THC into either site (<a href="#R1314" rid="R1314" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637241">

5511Zangen et al., 2006</a>

5512).</p>

5513<p id="P140" class="p">

5514Regardless of the exact location of presynaptic CB<sub>

55151</sub>

5516 receptors, their natural activation occurs through retrograde transmission, with their endogenous ligands being released from postsynaptic cells (<a href="#R627" rid="R627" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919043">

5517Kreutzer and Regehr, 2001</a>

5518; <a href="#R905" rid="R905" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919736">

5519Ohno-Shosaku et al., 2001</a>

5520; <a href="#R1294" rid="R1294" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918702">

5521Wilson and Nicoll, 2001</a>

5522). This mechanism has also been implicated in LTD (<a href="#R381" rid="R381" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918923">

5523Gerdeman et al., 2002</a>

5524; <a href="#R1024" rid="R1024" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919484">

5525Robbe et al., 2002</a>

5526), a form of synaptic plasticity that can be initiated by drugs of abuse (<a href="#R1180" rid="R1180" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653414">

5527Thomas et al., 2001</a>

5528), and may be involved in certain features of compulsive drug use (<a href="#R380" rid="R380" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919201">

5529Gerdeman et al., 2003</a>

5530). A further indication that endocannabinoids may be involved in mechanisms of drug reward is findings that the neurochemical and behavioral responses to different classes of drugs of abuse can be inhibited by the CB<sub>

55311</sub>

5532 receptor antagonists. These findings suggests that endocannabinoid activation of CB<sub>

55331</sub>

5534 receptors in the mesolimbic reward pathway may be part of a &#x0201c;common pathway&#x0201d; of drug reward (reviewed in <a href="#R254" rid="R254" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920165">

5535De Vries and Schoffelmeer, 2005</a>

5536; <a href="#R737" rid="R737" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653484">

5537Maldonado et al., 2006</a>

5538). Examples of this are discussed below.</p>

5539<div id="S30" class="sec">

5540<p>

5541</p>

5542<h5 id="S30title" class="inline">

5543a. Opiates </h5>

5544<p id="P141" class="p p-first">

5545There is a large body of evidence indicating a reciprocal relationship between the endocannabinoid and endogenous opioid systems in drug dependence (recently reviewed by <a href="#R312" rid="R312" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919097">

5546Fattore et al., 2005</a>

5547; <a href="#R1232" rid="R1232" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919046">

5548Vigano et al., 2005a</a>

5549,<a href="#R1233" rid="R1233" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920000">

5550b</a>

5551). This fact is not surprising, given that opioids and cannabinoids have a similar pharmacological profile at both the behavioral level (e.g., analgesia, hypothermia, catalepsy, and motor impairment) and cellular/molecular levels (both CB<sub>

55521</sub>

5553 and opiate <em>

5554&#x003bc;</em>

5555 receptors are predominantly presynaptic, they are coupled to and share the same pool of G<sub>

5556i</sub>

5557/G<sub>

5558o</sub>

5559 proteins, and have an overlapping brain distribution). There are numerous examples for opioid or cannabinoid reward-related effects being inhibited by both CB<sub>

55601</sub>

5561 and opiate <em>

5562&#x003bc;</em>

5563 antagonists (<a href="#R312" rid="R312" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918874">

5564Fattore et al., 2005</a>

5565; <a href="#R367" rid="R367" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919373">

5566Gardner, 2005</a>

5567; <a href="#R1232" rid="R1232" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919675">

5568Vigano et al., 2005a</a>

5569,<a href="#R1233" rid="R1233" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919394">

5570b</a>

5571). The mechanisms underlying these reciprocal interactions are not clear, but they may involve heterodimerization of CB<sub>

55721</sub>

5573 and <em>

5574&#x003bc;</em>

5575 opiate receptors, depletion of shared G protein pools and/or utilization of common postreceptor signaling pathways. In addition, the opiate/cannabinoid synergism observed in nAc/striatal neurons appears to require adenosine and A2a receptor signaling (<a href="#R1305" rid="R1305" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920319">

5576Yao et al., 2006</a>

5577).</p>

5578<p id="P142" class="p p-last">

5579Here we will only review evidence that pertains to the potential involvement of endocannabinoids in the addictive, reward-related actions of opioids. Such evidence is based on the ability of pharmacological or genetic ablation of CB<sub>

55801</sub>

5581 receptors to prevent or inhibit opioid effects. CB<sub>

55821</sub>

5583 knockout mice were reported to be unable to acquire morphine self-administration (<a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653357">

5584Ledent et al., 1999</a>

5585; <a href="#R212" rid="R212" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920216">

5586Cossu et al., 2001</a>

5587), to have reduced morphine withdrawal symptoms (<a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653490">

5588Ledent et al., 1999</a>

5589), and not to develop CPP for morphine (<a href="#R759" rid="R759" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919866">

5590Martin et al., 2000</a>

5591). A possible neurochemical correlate of these changes is the lack of morphine-induced dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens of CB<sub>

55921</sub>

5593 receptor knockout mice (<a href="#R771" rid="R771" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920259">

5594Mascia et al., 1999</a>

5595), although more recently CB<sub>

55961</sub>

5597 blockade was found to reverse the morphine-induced decrease in ventropallidal GABA overflow without affecting the morphine-induced increase in dopamine release in the nAc (<a href="#R144" rid="R144" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919554">

5598Caill&#x000e9; and Parsons, 2006</a>

5599). Treatment of wild-type mice and rats with a CB<sub>

56001</sub>

5601 antagonist elicits similar phenotypes (<a href="#R1046" rid="R1046" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920105">

5602Rubino et al., 2000</a>

5603; <a href="#R774" rid="R774" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918917">

5604Mas-Nieto et al., 2001</a>

5605; <a href="#R880" rid="R880" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637243">

5606Navarro et al., 2001</a>

5607, <a href="#R879" rid="R879" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919140">

56082004</a>

5609). These observations raise the therapeutic potential of chronic treatment with a CB<sub>

56101</sub>

5611 receptor antagonist in preventing or reversing the development of opiate dependence.</p>

5612</div>

5613<div id="S31" class="sec">

5614<p>

5615</p>

5616<h5 id="S31title" class="inline">

5617b. Nicotine </h5>

5618<p id="P143" class="p p-first-last">

5619Nicotine is the main neuroactive component in tobacco smoke and is responsible for its addictive properties. Nicotine&#x02019;s rewarding effects are mediated by the same mesolimbic dopaminergic pathway that is involved in the rewarding effects of many other addictive drugs (<a href="#R977" rid="R977" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919613">

5620Pontieri et al., 1996</a>

5621). Therefore, it should not be unexpected that there is a positive synergism between nicotine and THC in paradigms used to reveal reinforcing effects (<a href="#R1208" rid="R1208" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919492">

5622Valjent and Maldonado, 2000</a>

5623). A role of endocannabinoids in the rewarding effects of nicotine is indicated by the absence of nicotine-induced CPP in CB<sub>

56241</sub>

5625 knockout mice (<a href="#R161" rid="R161" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919421">

5626Castane et al., 2002</a>

5627), although the acquisition of nicotine self-administration was not affected by the absence of CB<sub>

56281</sub>

5629 receptors in another study using an acute reinforcement paradigm (<a href="#R212" rid="R212" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920326">

5630Cossu et al., 2001</a>

5631). On the other hand, SR141716 was reported to decrease nicotine operant self-administration (<a href="#R189" rid="R189" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918968">

5632Cohen et al., 2002</a>

5633) and nicotine-induced CPP in rats (<a href="#R666" rid="R666" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919071">

5634Le Foll and Goldberg, 2004</a>

5635; Forget et al., 2006) and also to inhibit nicotine-induced dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens shell (<a href="#R189" rid="R189" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919893">

5636Cohen et al., 2002</a>

5637). SR141716 also inhibited nicotine self-administration sustained by nicotine-associated cues in the absence of nicotine itself (<a href="#R188" rid="R188" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920082">

5638Cohen et al., 2005</a>

5639), and chronic exposure to nicotine was reported to induce endocannabinoid release (<a href="#R413" rid="R413" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920107">

5640Gonzalez et al., 2002</a>

5641). Furthermore, SR141716 abolished the anxiolytic effects of low-dose nicotine in mice and potentiated its anxiogenic effects at higher doses (<a href="#R38" rid="R38" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919154">

5642Balerio et al., 2006</a>

5643). Together, these findings justified testing rimonabant in clinical trials to promote smoking abstinence. Indeed, the results of a recent multicenter phase III clinical trial in the United States indicate that a 10-week treatment of smokers with a daily oral dose of 20 mg of rimonabant with a follow-up period of 42 weeks doubled the odds of quitting smoking, was well tolerated, and also reduced the post-cessation weight gain by &#x0003e;80% (<a href="#R238" rid="R238" class=" bibr popnode">

5644Dale and Anthenelli, 2004</a>

5645).</p>

5646</div>

5647<div id="S32" class="sec">

5648<p>

5649</p>

5650<h5 id="S32title" class="inline">

5651c. Cocaine </h5>

5652<p id="P144" class="p p-first">

5653Unlike THC, opiates and nicotine, cocaine does not increase the activity of dopaminergic neurons in the VTA but elevates synaptic levels of dopamine in the nAc by blocking dopamine reuptake at the dopamine transporter (<a href="#R389" rid="R389" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918777">

5654Giros et al., 1996</a>

5655). Therefore it is not surprising that cocaine-induced increases in dopamine in the nAc were found to be unaffected by genetic ablation of CB<sub>

56561</sub>

5657 receptors (<a href="#R1127" rid="R1127" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919667">

5658Soria et al., 2005</a>

5659). Accordingly, CB<sub>

56601</sub>

5661 receptors do not appear to participate in the acute rewarding properties of cocaine, as indicated by the preserved acute cocaine self-administration and cocaine-induced CPP in CB<sub>

56621</sub>

5663 knockout mice (<a href="#R759" rid="R759" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920376">

5664Martin et al., 2000</a>

5665; <a href="#R212" rid="R212" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919084">

5666Cossu et al., 2001</a>

5667; <a href="#R677" rid="R677" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920023">

5668Lesscher et al., 2005</a>

5669; <a href="#R1127" rid="R1127" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919578">

5670Soria et al., 2005</a>

5671) or in mice treated with SR141716 (<a href="#R1163" rid="R1163" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919792">

5672Tanda et al., 2000</a>

5673; <a href="#R255" rid="R255" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920353">

5674De Vries et al., 2001</a>

5675; <a href="#R144" rid="R144" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919833">

5676Caill&#x000e9; and Parsons, 2006</a>

5677). SR141716 treatment also did not affect the threshold-lowering effect of cocaine in the intracranial self-stimulation paradigm, although treatment with WIN 55,212-2 was able to achieve this, suggesting that CB<sub>

56781</sub>

5679 receptor stimulation might inhibit the reinforcing properties of cocaine (<a href="#R313" rid="R313" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919956">

5680Fattore et al., 1999</a>

5681; <a href="#R1237" rid="R1237" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918948">

5682Vlachou et al., 2003</a>

5683).</p>

5684<p id="P145" class="p p-last">

5685Other studies indicate, however, that endocannabinoid activation of CB<sub>

56861</sub>

5687 receptors may mediate the reinforcing effects of cocaine. SR141716 treatment decreased the sensitivity of rats to the reinforcing effects of cocaine in an intracranial self-stimulation paradigm (<a href="#R259" rid="R259" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653399">

5688Deroche-Gamonet et al., 2001</a>

5689). The ability to acquire operant self-administration of cocaine was reduced in CB<sub>

56901</sub>

5691 knockout mice or in SR141716-treated wild-type mice, which also displayed a reduced maximal effort to obtain cocaine infusion in a progressive ratio schedule, compared with untreated wild-type mice (<a href="#R759" rid="R759" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919842">

5692Martin et al., 2000</a>

5693; <a href="#R1127" rid="R1127" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919270">

5694Soria et al., 2005</a>

5695). Furthermore, prior use of cannabis was found to enhance the &#x0201c;high&#x0201d; elicited by subsequent use of cocaine in humans (<a href="#R327" rid="R327" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918981">

5696Foltin et al., 1993</a>

5697; <a href="#R709" rid="R709" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918930">

5698Lukas et al., 1994</a>

5699) and also to hasten relapse in abstinent former cocaine users (<a href="#R1002" rid="R1002" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918989">

5700Rawson et al., 1986</a>

5701). Furthermore, a recent genetic study found an association between an (AAT)n triplet repeat polymorphism in the <em>

5702CNR1</em>

5703 gene encoding the CB<sub>

57041</sub>

5705 receptor with cocaine addiction in an African-Caribbean population (<a href="#R39" rid="R39" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653423">

5706Ballon et al., 2006</a>

5707). Treatment with HU-210 promoted reinstatement of cocaine-seeking behavior in rats, whereas treatment with SR141716 prevented reinstatement (<a href="#R255" rid="R255" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919055">

5708De Vries et al., 2001</a>

5709). Thus, the endocannabinoid system may be involved in the acquisition and consolidation of cocaine addiction as well as in relapse, through mechanisms other than an effect on the cocaine-induced increase in dopaminergic transmission in the nAc. These latter studies also predict the possible effectiveness of rimonabant in the treatment of cocaine addiction.</p>

5710</div>

5711<div id="S33" class="sec">

5712<p>

5713</p>

5714<h5 id="S33title" class="inline">

5715d. Alcohol </h5>

5716<p id="P146" class="p p-first">

5717Several lines of evidence indicate the involvement of the endocannabinoid system in alcohol drinking behavior (recently reviewed by <a href="#R197" rid="R197" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919069">

5718Colombo et al., 2005</a>

5719). Chronic alcohol intake increases endocannabinoid levels in the limbic forebrain (<a href="#R413" rid="R413" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919016">

5720Gonzalez et al., 2002</a>

5721) and decreases CB<sub>

57221</sub>

5723 receptor binding and signaling (<a href="#R47" rid="R47" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653435">

5724Basavarajappa and Hungund, 2002</a>

5725). Studies in the late 1990s indicated the effectiveness of SR141716 in reducing voluntary ethanol intake in rodent models of ethanol drinking (<a href="#R25" rid="R25" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918984">

5726Arnone et al., 1997</a>

5727; <a href="#R195" rid="R195" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919318">

5728Colombo et al., 1998b</a>

5729; <a href="#R340" rid="R340" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919409">

5730Freedland et al., 2001</a>

5731), whereas cannabinoid agonists promoted drinking (<a href="#R354" rid="R354" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918856">

5732Gallate et al., 1999</a>

5733; <a href="#R196" rid="R196" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920083">

5734Colombo et al., 2002</a>

5735). Operant self-administration of ethanol and relapse to drinking are also inhibited by SR141716 (<a href="#R183" rid="R183" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920311">

5736Cippitelli et al., 2005</a>

5737; <a href="#R291" rid="R291" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919387">

5738Economidou et al., 2006</a>

5739) and potentiated by chronic exposure to a cannabinoid agonist (<a href="#R704" rid="R704" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637200">

5740Lopez-Moreno et al., 2005</a>

5741).</p>

5742<p id="P147">

5743The possible role of the endocannabinoid system in ethanol preference was further indicated by observations of reduced voluntary ethanol drinking in CB<sub>

57441</sub>

5745 knockout compared with wild-type mice (<a href="#R533" rid="R533" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918736">

5746Hungund et al., 2003</a>

5747; <a href="#R976" rid="R976" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918952">

5748Poncelet et al., 2003</a>

5749; <a href="#R1267" rid="R1267" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919375">

5750Wang et al., 2003</a>

5751; <a href="#R647" rid="R647" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919457">

5752Lallemand and de Witte, 2004</a>

5753; <a href="#R869" rid="R869" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919516">

5754Naassila et al., 2004</a>

5755; <a href="#R1175" rid="R1175" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920242">

5756Thanos et al., 2005</a>

5757), although no difference was noted in one study (<a href="#R991" rid="R991" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637204">

5758Racz et al., 2003</a>

5759). Sensitivity to alcohol is inversely related to the chance of becoming an alcoholic among humans (<a href="#R1080" rid="R1080" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920382">

5760Schuckit, 1997</a>

5761), and the same inverse relationship was noted in CB<sub>

57621</sub>

5763 knockout mice and their wild-type littermates (<a href="#R869" rid="R869" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920263">

5764Naassila et al., 2004</a>

5765). The reduced voluntary ethanol intake in CB<sub>

57661</sub>

5767 knockout mice was associated with reduced alcohol-induced CPP (<a href="#R523" rid="R523" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918822">

5768Houchi et al., 2004</a>

5769; <a href="#R1175" rid="R1175" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919474">

5770Thanos et al., 2005</a>

5771), a further indication of the role of CB<sub>

57721</sub>

5773 receptors in the rewarding effects of alcohol.</p>

5774<p id="P148">

5775Similar to cannabinoids and other drugs of abuse, alcohol intake can also result in increased dopamine release in the nAc (<a href="#R1278" rid="R1278" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919293">

5776Weiss et al., 1993</a>

5777; <a href="#R149" rid="R149" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919659">

5778Campbell and McBride, 1995</a>

5779). The reported absence of such release in CB<sub>

57801</sub>

5781 knockout mice and the ability of SR141716 to block ethanol-induced dopamine release in wild-type mice further suggest the involvement of endocannabinoids in the reinforcing effects of ethanol. However, the brain site where ethanol-induced endocannabinoid release and CB<sub>

57821</sub>

5783 receptor activation occur is not yet known. The recent observation that microinjection of SR141716 into the prefrontal cortex of alcohol-preferring AA rats inhibited ethanol self-administration suggests that this region may be one of the sites involved (<a href="#R465" rid="R465" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488953">

5784Hansson et al., 2006</a>

5785). In the same study, FAAH activity and CB<sub>

57861</sub>

5787 signaling were both reduced in the same brain region of AA rats compared with their nonpreferring ANA counterparts, and microinjection of the FAAH inhibitor URB597 increased ethanol self-administration (<a href="#R465" rid="R465" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488947">

5788Hansson et al., 2006</a>

5789). Analogous findings in female FAAH knockout mice are their increased voluntary ethanol intake and decreased alcohol sensitivity (<a href="#R48" rid="R48" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919679">

5790Basavarajappa et al., 2006</a>

5791). These findings suggest that increased anandamide tone secondary to decreased FAAH activity in the prefrontal cortex may be causally linked to high alcohol preference. Such a scenario would be compatible with evidence for an association between problem drug and alcohol use and a missense mutation in the human FAAH gene (<a href="#R1111" rid="R1111" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918906">

5792Sipe et al., 2002</a>

5793).</p>

5794<p id="P149" class="p p-last">

5795A number of mediators have been implicated in the control of appetite for both food and alcohol. In the case of endocannabinoids, the regulation is &#x0201c;unidirectional&#x0201d;, i.e., endocannabinoids promote both food intake (see section III.A.3.) and alcohol drinking. Because both food intake and alcohol drinking activate the brain reward pathways, one might postulate that the role of endocannabinoids in promoting drinking behavior would be most prominent in the type of alcoholics who drink for the rewarding effects of alcohol, such as young binge-drinkers. The high alcohol preference of C57BL6 mice and the role of the endocannabinoid system mediating it were found to be age-dependent (<a href="#R1267" rid="R1267" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920397">

5796Wang et al., 2003</a>

5797), which is compatible with such a possibility. In contrast, the effects of NPY and CRH on food intake and ethanol consumption are bidirectional: NPY increases food intake (<a href="#R184" rid="R184" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920152">

5798Clark et al., 1984</a>

5799) but reduces ethanol consumption (<a href="#R1176" rid="R1176" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918834">

5800Thiele et al., 1998</a>

5801), whereas CRH is anoretic (<a href="#R122" rid="R122" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918778">

5802Britton et al., 1982</a>

5803) but promotes ethanol drinking (<a href="#R377" rid="R377" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919582">

5804George et al., 1990</a>

5805). The effects of NPY and CRH on alcohol preference correlate with their effects on anxiety-like behaviors, NPY being anxiolytic (<a href="#R479" rid="R479" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919485">

5806Heilig et al., 1989</a>

5807) and CRH being anxiogenic (<a href="#R623" rid="R623" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920142">

5808Koob and Thatcher-Britton, 1985</a>

5809). We would predict that CB<sub>

58101</sub>

5811 antagonists will be more effective in reducing the drive to drink in younger people who drink for the rewarding effects of alcohol, whereas CRH antagonists or NPY agonists would be more effective in older, chronic alcoholics who more likely drink to suppress the negative affect and anxiety of alcohol withdrawal. This hypothesis may be tested by appropriately designed clinical trials. Studies to test the safety and efficacy of rimonabant in the treatment of alcoholism and alcohol abuse are currently underway at the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.</p>

5812</div>

5813<div id="S34" class="sec sec-last">

5814<p>

5815</p>

5816<h5 id="S34title" class="inline">

5817e. Psychostimulants </h5>

5818<p id="P150" class="p p-first-last">

58193,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, Ecstasy) is a psychostimulant abused for its euphorigenic and stimulant properties, and it is often used in combination with marijuana. Intracerebral self-administration of MDMA was found to be reduced in the presence of the cannabinoid agonist CP55,940 and increased after treatment with SR141716. These findings were interpreted to indicate synergism between the reinforcing effects of cannabinoids and MDMA and a reduction in the motivational value of MDMA by CB<sub>

58201</sub>

5821 blockade (<a href="#R115" rid="R115" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919374">

5822Braida and Sala, 2002</a>

5823). In another study, the authors found that SR141716 blocked MDMA-induced CPP (<a href="#R113" rid="R113" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919326">

5824Braida et al., 2005</a>

5825). Amphetamine-induced long-term synaptic depression in the amygdala could be blocked by the CB<sub>

58261</sub>

5827 antagonist AM251, mimicked by the agonist WIN 55,212-2, and occluded by the transport inhibitor AM404, suggesting that amphetamine-induced LTD and related behavioral effects may be mediated via endocannabinoid release (<a href="#R530" rid="R530" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637205">

5828Huang et al., 2003</a>

5829). Together, these findings suggest that CB<sub>

58301</sub>

5831 antagonists may be of value in the treatment of addiction to psychostimulants, including amphetamine and MDMA.</p>

5832</div>

5833</div>

5834</div>

5835<div id="S35" class="sec">

5836<h3 id="S35title">

5837D. Cardiovascular and Respiratory Disorders</h3>

5838<p id="P151" class="p p-first">

5839Besides their well known neurobehavioral and immunological actions, cannabinoids and their endogenous and synthetic analogs exert important cardiovascular effects. The underlying mechanisms are complex, involving direct effects on the vasculature (<a href="#R372" rid="R372" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919295">

5840Gebremedhin et al., 1999</a>

5841; <a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920069">

5842J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

5843; <a href="#R1249" rid="R1249" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920389">

5844Wagner et al., 2001b</a>

5845; <a href="#R1246" rid="R1246" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920159">

5846Wagner et al., 2005</a>

5847) and myocardium (<a href="#R104" rid="R104" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918933">

5848Bonz et al., 2003</a>

5849; <a href="#R773" rid="R773" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920055">

5850Maslov et al., 2004</a>

5851; <a href="#R1141" rid="R1141" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918982">

5852Sterin-Borda et al., 2005</a>

5853), as well as modulation of autonomic outflow through sites of action in the central (<a href="#R893" rid="R893" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919411">

5854Niederhoffer and Szabo, 2000</a>

5855; <a href="#R967" rid="R967" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918943">

5856Pfitzer et al., 2004</a>

5857) and the peripheral nervous systems (<a href="#R541" rid="R541" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919671">

5858Ishac et al., 1996</a>

5859; <a href="#R739" rid="R739" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653449">

5860Malinowska et al., 1997</a>

5861; <a href="#R1158" rid="R1158" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918779">

5862Szabo et al., 2001</a>

5863; <a href="#R892" rid="R892" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653513">

5864Niederhoffer et al., 2003</a>

5865). As for endogenous cannabinoids, their effects are also complicated by their rapid metabolism, which liberates arachidonic acid that can be further metabolized into vasoactive prostanoids (reviewed in <a href="#R806" rid="R806" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919978">

5866Mechoulam et al., 1998</a>

5867; <a href="#R637" rid="R637" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919965">

5868Kunos et al., 2000</a>

5869; <a href="#R998" rid="R998" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918756">

5870Randall et al., 2002</a>

5871; <a href="#R994" rid="R994" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919461">

5872Ralevic et al., 2002</a>

5873).</p>

5874<p id="P152">

5875Studies to date indicate that CB<sub>

58761</sub>

5877 receptors are much more important than CB<sub>

58782</sub>

5879 receptors in cardiovascular regulation, the latter so far being implicated only in ischemic preconditioning and ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury of the myocardium (see below). CB<sub>

58801</sub>

5881 receptors have been detected in the human, rat, and mouse myocardium where they mediate negative inotropy (<a href="#R104" rid="R104" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919012">

5882Bonz et al., 2003</a>

5883; <a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653520">

5884B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

5885; <a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919266">

5886Pacher et al., 2004</a>

5887, <a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918805">

5888b</a>

5889, <a href="#R922" rid="R922" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918791">

58902005a</a>

5891,<a href="#R923" rid="R923" class=" bibr popnode">

5892b</a>

5893,<a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653438">

5894d</a>

5895; <a href="#R302" rid="R302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919141">

5896Engeli et al., 2005</a>

5897; <a href="#R1246" rid="R1246" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918936">

5898Wagner et al., 2005</a>

5899) and also in vascular tissues (<a href="#R372" rid="R372" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919771">

5900Gebremedhin et al., 1999</a>

5901; <a href="#R694" rid="R694" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920308">

5902Liu et al., 2000</a>

5903), where their activation leads to vasodilation, and both of these effects appear to be involved in the hypotensive effect of anandamide (<a href="#R1247" rid="R1247" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919089">

5904Wagner et al., 2001a</a>

5905,<a href="#R1249" rid="R1249" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919651">

5906b</a>

5907; <a href="#R51" rid="R51" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653419">

5908B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004a</a>

5909,<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653360">

5910b</a>

5911; <a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920072">

5912Pacher et al., 2004</a>

5913, <a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919076">

5914b</a>

5915, <a href="#R922" rid="R922" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919636">

59162005a</a>

5917,<a href="#R923" rid="R923" class=" bibr popnode">

5918b</a>

5919,<a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653511">

5920d</a>

5921) in anesthetized rodents. Sympathetic nerve terminals contain presynaptic CB<sub>

59221</sub>

5923 receptors, stimulation of which inhibits norepinephrine release (<a href="#R541" rid="R541" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919391">

5924Ishac et al., 1996</a>

5925), which contributes to the bradycardic effects of anandamide in vivo (<a href="#R1249" rid="R1249" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919843">

5926Wagner et al., 2001b</a>

5927). Anandamide-induced cardiovascular depressor effects are devoid of a centrally mediated component (<a href="#R1220" rid="R1220" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919677">

5928Varga et al., 1996</a>

5929), in contrast to the effects of certain synthetic cannabinoids, which cause centrally mediated sympathoexcitation (<a href="#R893" rid="R893" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919063">

5930Niederhoffer and Szabo, 2000</a>

5931; <a href="#R363" rid="R363" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920355">

5932Gardiner et al., 2001</a>

5933, <a href="#R365" rid="R365" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919451">

59342002b</a>

5935).</p>

5936<p id="P153">

5937The vasorelaxant effect of endocannabinoids and synthetic cannabinoids in vitro are complex and display tissue and interspecies differences. They may involve CB<sub>

59381</sub>

5939 and TRPV<sub>

59401</sub>

5941 receptor- and NO-mediated or NO-independent mechanisms and also as yet undefined endothelial site(s) of action. A detailed discussion of these in vitro vasodilatory effects can be found in recent reviews (<a href="#R498" rid="R498" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919797">

5942Hillard, 2000</a>

5943; <a href="#R637" rid="R637" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920275">

5944Kunos et al., 2000</a>

5945, <a href="#R636" rid="R636" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919336">

59462002</a>

5947; <a href="#R994" rid="R994" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919167">

5948Ralevic et al., 2002</a>

5949; <a href="#R998" rid="R998" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918703">

5950Randall et al., 2002</a>

5951, <a href="#R999" rid="R999" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919925">

59522004</a>

5953; <a href="#R57" rid="R57" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920289">

5954Begg et al., 2005</a>

5955; <a href="#R922" rid="R922" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920202">

5956Pacher et al., 2005a</a>

5957,<a href="#R923" rid="R923" class=" bibr popnode">

5958b</a>

5959) and is beyond the scope of this review.</p>

5960<p id="P154">

5961Compared with the growing body of information on the vascular effects of cannabinoids, less is known about cannabinoid-induced direct cardiac effects. Anandamide, <em>

5962R</em>

5963-methanandamide, and HU-210 dose dependently decrease contractile performance in isolated, electrically paced human atrial muscle, an effect blocked by the potent CB<sub>

59641</sub>

5965 antagonist AM251, whereas the involvement of CB<sub>

59662</sub>

5967 receptors, NO, or prostanoids could be excluded (<a href="#R104" rid="R104" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918712">

5968Bonz et al., 2003</a>

5969). HU-210 also decreased left ventricular developed pressure in isolated perfused rat hearts through CB<sub>

59701</sub>

5971 receptor activation (<a href="#R773" rid="R773" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919372">

5972Maslov et al., 2004</a>

5973; <a href="#R630" rid="R630" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918920">

5974Krylatov et al., 2005</a>

5975). Another study using isolated, perfused, rat Langendorff heart preparations to study the effects of anandamide, <em>

5976R</em>

5977-methanandamide, and palmitoylethanolamide on coronary perfusion pressure and left ventricular developed pressure suggested the involvement of a cardiac site of action distinct from CB<sub>

59781</sub>

5979 and CB<sub>

59802</sub>

5981 receptors (<a href="#R328" rid="R328" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919120">

5982Ford et al., 2002</a>

5983).</p>

5984<p id="P155">

5985Several studies have examined the in vivo hemodynamic effects of endocannabinoids and their synthetic analogs in rodents (recently reviewed in <a href="#R57" rid="R57" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919027">

5986Begg et al., 2005</a>

5987; <a href="#R922" rid="R922" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919292">

5988Pacher et al., 2005a</a>

5989,<a href="#R923" rid="R923" class=" bibr popnode">

5990b</a>

5991). Intravenous administration of anandamide causes a triphasic blood pressure response in anesthetized mice and rats, in which a prolonged hypotensive effect (phase III) is preceded by a transient, vagally mediated, fall in heart rate, cardiac and contractility, and blood pressure and an increase in total peripheral resistance (phase I) followed by a brief, pressor response (phase II) associated with increased cardiac contractility (<a href="#R1219" rid="R1219" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918762">

5992Varga et al., 1995</a>

5993; <a href="#R646" rid="R646" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919548">

5994Lake et al., 1997b</a>

5995; <a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920346">

5996Pacher et al., 2004</a>

5997, <a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918809">

5998b</a>

5999, <a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653412">

60002005d</a>

6001). Inhibition of the phase I bradycardic response by TRPV<sub>

60021</sub>

6003 receptor antagonists in rats (<a href="#R740" rid="R740" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653466">

6004Malinowska et al., 2001</a>

6005) and the absence of both phase I and phase II responses in TRPV<sub>

60061</sub>

6007<sup>

6008&#x02212;/&#x02212;</sup>

6009 mice (<a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919780">

6010Pacher et al., 2004</a>

6011) imply that these components are mediated by TRPV<sub>

60121</sub>

6013 receptors. Additional central and vascular mechanisms may also be involved in the brief pressor response (phase II) in anesthetized rats (<a href="#R640" rid="R640" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919107">

6014Kwolek et al., 2005</a>

6015). The third, prolonged hypotensive phase (phase III) is characterized by marked decreased cardiac contractility and slightly decreased total peripheral resistance, and it lasts up to 10 min in anesthetized mice (<a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920383">

6016Pacher et al., 2004b</a>

6017, <a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653387">

60182005d</a>

6019), similar to the hypotensive effect previously described in anesthetized but not conscious rats (<a href="#R1137" rid="R1137" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918797">

6020Stein et al., 1996</a>

6021; <a href="#R1220" rid="R1220" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919851">

6022Varga et al., 1996</a>

6023; <a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653467">

6024Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6025,<a href="#R646" rid="R646" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919274">

6026b</a>

6027; <a href="#R364" rid="R364" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920004">

6028Gardiner et al., 2002a</a>

6029; <a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653403">

6030B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6031) and also observed with synthetic cannabinoids (<a href="#R1231" rid="R1231" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920118">

6032Vidrio et al., 1996</a>

6033; <a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653390">

6034Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6035; <a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653480">

6036Pacher et al., 2005d</a>

6037).</p>

6038<p id="P156" class="p">

6039The anandamide-induced phase III hypotension and decreased cardiac contractility, as well as similar hemodynamic responses to synthetic cannabinoids, are mediated by CB<sub>

60401</sub>

6041 receptors. First, these effects are prevented or reversed by selective CB<sub>

60421</sub>

6043 antagonists both in normal rodents (<a href="#R1219" rid="R1219" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919498">

6044Varga et al., 1995</a>

6045, <a href="#R1220" rid="R1220" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918735">

60461996</a>

6047; <a href="#R147" rid="R147" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919564">

6048Calignano et al., 1997</a>

6049; <a href="#R921" rid="R921" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918935">

6050Pacher et al., 2004</a>

6051, <a href="#R926" rid="R926" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919884">

6052b</a>

6053, <a href="#R922" rid="R922" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920026">

60542005a</a>

6055,<a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653406">

6056d</a>

6057) and in mice lacking FAAH, which exhibit increased sensitivity to hypotensive and cardiodepressant effects of anandamide (<a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653363">

6058Pacher et al., 2005d</a>

6059). Second, there is a positive correlation between the concentrations of various cannabinoid agonists in producing half-maximal hypotensive and bradycardic responses (EC<sub>

606050</sub>

6061) and in their affinity constants for binding to CB<sub>

60621</sub>

6063 receptors in the brain (<a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653440">

6064Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6065). Third, cannabinoid-induced hypotension and bradycardia are absent in mice lacking the CB<sub>

60661</sub>

6067 receptor (<a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920181">

6068J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

6069; <a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653463">

6070Ledent et al., 1999</a>

6071). The involvement of the endocannabinoid system in various cardiovascular disorders is reviewed below.</p>

6072<div id="S36" class="sec">

6073<p>

6074</p>

6075<h4 id="S36title" class="inline">

60761. Hypertension </h4>

6077<p id="P157" class="p p-first">

6078Chronic use of cannabis in humans as well as both acute and prolonged administration of THC to experimental animals elicits a long-lasting decrease in blood pressure and heart rate (<a href="#R1039" rid="R1039" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653481">

6079Rosenkratz and Braude, 1974</a>

6080; <a href="#R65" rid="R65" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920297">

6081Benowitz and Jones, 1975</a>

6082), whereas the acute effect of smoking cannabis usually increases heart rate with no consistent change in blood pressure (<a href="#R581" rid="R581" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919995">

6083Kanakis et al., 1976</a>

6084). In a recent study conducted in 63 male cannabis smokers, 22% of subjects experienced symptomatic hypotension, which could be reversed by the administration of 30 or 90 mg but not lower doses of rimonabant, indicating that CB<sub>

60851</sub>

6086 receptors mediate the hypotensive effect of cannabis smoking in humans (<a href="#R419" rid="R419" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918893">

6087Gorelick et al., 2006</a>

6088).</p>

6089<p id="P158">

6090More than three decades ago, several studies explored the potential use of cannabinoids to treat hypertension (<a href="#R88" rid="R88" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919783">

6091Birmingham, 1973</a>

6092; <a href="#R22" rid="R22" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653521">

6093Archer, 1974</a>

6094; <a href="#R1222" rid="R1222" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918827">

6095Varma and Goldbaum, 1975</a>

6096; <a href="#R9" rid="R9" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918787">

6097Adams et al., 1977</a>

6098; <a href="#R226" rid="R226" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919880">

6099Crawford and Merritt, 1979</a>

6100; <a href="#R1316" rid="R1316" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919942">

6101Zaugg and Kyncl, 1983</a>

6102). Unfortunately, the initial high anticipation was tempered by a report of the development of rapid tolerance to the hypotensive and bradycardic effects of THC (<a href="#R8" rid="R8" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918711">

6103Adams et al., 1976</a>

6104) and by the failure to separate the cardiovascular and neurobehavioral effects of cannabinoids. Albeit a later study in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) demonstrated no tolerance to the same effects during a 10-day treatment period (<a href="#R625" rid="R625" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918690">

6105Kosersky, 1978</a>

6106), interest in this issue had vanished for the next two decades.</p>

6107<p id="P159">

6108As with many other effects of marijuana, the discovery of endocannabinoids has focused attention on their possible role in cardiovascular regulation. Studies with SR141716 indicated that the hypotensive/bradycardic effects of exogenous anandamide, THC, and potent synthetic cannabinoids are mediated by CB<sub>

61091</sub>

6110 receptors (<a href="#R1219" rid="R1219" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919424">

6111Varga et al., 1995</a>

6112; <a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653477">

6113Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6114). CB<sub>

61151</sub>

6116 receptor knockout mice have normal blood pressure (<a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920199">

6117J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

6118; <a href="#R668" rid="R668" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653425">

6119Ledent et al., 1999</a>

6120) and the blood pressure of normotensive mice and rats is unaffected or slightly reduced by CB<sub>

61211</sub>

6122 antagonists (<a href="#R1219" rid="R1219" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919645">

6123Varga et al., 1995</a>

6124; <a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653374">

6125Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6126;Varga B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b). In anesthetized rats, anandamide elicits only a modest and short-lasting hypotensive response (<a href="#R1219" rid="R1219" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920392">

6127Varga et al., 1995</a>

6128; <a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653482">

6129Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6130), whereas in conscious normotensive rats it has no hypotensive effect at all (<a href="#R1137" rid="R1137" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920315">

6131Stein et al., 1996</a>

6132; <a href="#R646" rid="R646" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919969">

6133Lake et al., 1997b</a>

6134; <a href="#R364" rid="R364" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919562">

6135Gardiner et al., 2002</a>

6136). Furthermore, inhibitors of anandamide transport or FAAH do not lower blood pressure in normotensive animals (<a href="#R147" rid="R147" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920356">

6137Calignano et al., 1997</a>

6138; <a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653436">

6139B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>
