6140), and mice deficient in FAAH have normal baseline hemodynamic characteristics and baroreceptor reflex function (<a href="#R925" rid="R925" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653395">

6141Pacher et al., 2005d</a>

6142). As pointed out by a recent editorial (<a href="#R33" rid="R33" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653427">

6143Awumey et al., 2005</a>

6144), these observations indicate a lack of involvement of endogenous cannabinoids in cardiovascular regulation under normal conditions.</p>

6145<p id="P160">

6146In contrast, a number of observations indicate that endocannabinoids <em>

6147are</em>

6148 involved in cardiovascular regulation in hypertension. Both THC (<a href="#R625" rid="R625" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920036">

6149Kosersky, 1978</a>

6150) and anandamide (<a href="#R646" rid="R646" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918752">

6151Lake et al., 1997b</a>

6152, <a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653424">

6153B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6154) induce larger and longer lasting hypotension in anesthetized SHR compared with normotensive controls, and the hypotensive effect of anandamide is preserved in conscious SHR (<a href="#R646" rid="R646" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919552">

6155Lake et al., 1997b</a>

6156). Interestingly, inhalation of THC also resulted in a greater and longer lasting decrease of arterial blood pressure in hypertensive compared with normotensive individuals (<a href="#R226" rid="R226" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920350">

6157Crawford and Merritt, 1979</a>

6158). By using a sophisticated pressure-volume analysis system, the hemodynamic effects of cannabinoid agonists and antagonists were evaluated in three different models of experimental hypertension (<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653462">

6159B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6160). In anesthetized SHR, the CB<sub>

61611</sub>

6162 antagonists AM251 and SR141716 both caused marked and sustained further increases in blood pressure and cardiac contractility (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F5/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F5" rid-ob="ob-F5" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F5">

6163<span>

6164Fig. 5</span>

6165</a>

6166). Conversely, preventing the degradation or uptake of endogenous anandamide by treatment with the FAAH inhibitor URB597 or the transport inhibitor OMDM2 reduced blood pressure, cardiac contractility, and vascular resistance to levels observed in normotensive controls, and these effects were prevented by pretreatment with a CB<sub>

61671</sub>

6168 antagonist. Similar effects were seen in Dahl salt-sensitive rats and rats with angiotensin II-induced hypertension, whereas in the respective normotensive controls the same parameters remained unaffected by any of these treatments (<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653369">

6169B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6170) (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F5/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F5" rid-ob="ob-F5" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F5">

6171<span>

6172Fig. 5</span>

6173</a>

6174). Anandamide and HU-210 induced more pronounced and longer lasting hypotension in SHR than in WKY rats. Unexpectedly, decreased cardiac contractility rather than a reduction in peripheral resistance was primarily responsible for the antihypertensive effect of anandamide, which was fully prevented by CB<sub>

61751</sub>

6176 antagonists, but was unaffected by the TRPV<sub>

61771</sub>

6178 antagonist capsazepine. In the same study, the expression of CB<sub>

61791</sub>

6180 receptors was found to be increased in the myocardium and the aortic endothelium of SHR compared with WKY rats.</p>

6181<!--fig ft0-->

6182<!--fig mode=article f1-->

6183<div class="fig iconblock whole_rhythm" id="F5" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F5">

6184<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F5/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F5" rid-ob="ob-F5">

6185<!--fig/graphic|fig/alternatives/graphic mode="anchored" m1-->

6186<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462208928" class="figure">

6187<img loading="lazy" class="fig-image" alt="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f5.jpg" title="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f5.jpg" src="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/bin/nihms38123f5.jpg" />

6188</div>

6189<div id="largeobj_idm139779462208928" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

6190<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F5/?report=objectonly">

6191Open in a separate window</a>

6192</div>

6193</a>

6194<div class="icnblk_cntnt" id="lgnd_F5">

6195<div>

6196<a class="figpopup" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F5/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F5" rid-ob="ob-F5">

6197Fig. 5</a>

6198</div>

6199<!--caption a7-->

6200<div class="caption">

6201<p id="__p6">

6202Effects of anandamide, URB597, SR141716, and AM251 on left ventricular (LV) function in normotensive and spontaneously hypertensive rats. Representative left ventricular pressure-volume (PV) loops from WKY rats (a, d, and g) and SHR (b, c, e, f, h, and i) before (black) and after (red) treatment with indicated agents or their combinations. A leftward shift of PV loops and an increase in amplitude (pressure) indicate increased LV contractility, whereas a rightward shift and decrease in amplitude indicate decreased LV function. Experiments were repeated in three more animals in each treatment group with similar results. AEA, anandamide. Reproduced with permission from <a href="#R51" rid="R51" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653465">

6203B&#x000e1;tkai et al. (2004)</a>

6204 <em>

6205Circulation</em>

6206 <strong>

6207110:</strong>

62081996&#x02013;2002; &#x000a9; Lippincott Williams and Wilkins.</p>

6209</div>

6210</div>

6211</div>

6212<p id="P161">

6213These findings point to the existence of an endocannabinoid tone in hypertension that limits the elevation of blood pressure and cardiac contractile performance through tonic activation of cardiac and probably vascular CB<sub>

62141</sub>

6215. A possible underlying mechanism is the observed up-regulation of cardiac and vascular CB<sub>

62161</sub>

6217 in SHR compared with their normotensive controls, although increased coupling of these CB<sub>

62181</sub>

6219 receptors may also contribute to the augmented sensitivity to the cardiovascular effects of anandamide (<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653386">

6220B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6221). A proposed alternative mechanism would involve up-regulation of vascular TRPV<sub>

62221</sub>

6223 receptors in hypertension, based on the reported ability of capsazepine to partially inhibit the hypotensive effect of anandamide and <em>

6224R</em>

6225-methanandamide in hypertensive but not in normotensive rats (<a href="#R682" rid="R682" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918698">

6226Li et al., 2003</a>

6227; <a href="#R1269" rid="R1269" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919349">

6228Wang et al., 2005</a>

6229). However, capsazepine is known to have nonspecific effects even at low concentrations (<a href="#R1003" rid="R1003" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637225">

6230Ray et al., 2003</a>

6231), and up-regulation of TRPV<sub>

62321</sub>

6233 cannot account either for the increased hypotensive potency of HU-210 (<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653411">

6234B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6235), which is not a ligand for TRPV<sub>

62361</sub>

6237 receptors (<a href="#R1332" rid="R1332" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919658">

6238Zygmunt et al., 1999</a>

6239), or for the dominant cardiac component in the hypotensive effect of exogenous or endogenous anandamide (<a href="#R52" rid="R52" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653502">

6240B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004b</a>

6241). Also, physiological concentrations of endogenous anandamide are at least an order of magnitude lower than the micromolar concentrations required to activate TRPV<sub>

62421</sub>

6243 receptors.</p>

6244<p id="P162" class="p p-last">

6245A practical implication of these findings is that enhancing endocannabinoid tone by blocking the enzymatic degradation or cellular uptake of anandamide could be a novel therapeutic approach in the treatment of hypertension. Such a strategy has a number of desirable features: 1) unlike the generalized activation of CB<sub>

62461</sub>

6247 receptors by direct acting agonists, inhibition of FAAH causes a more restricted profile of cannabinoid-like effects with no indication of psychoactivity (<a href="#R589" rid="R589" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919705">

6248Kathuria et al., 2003</a>

6249; <a href="#R404" rid="R404" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918763">

6250Gobbi et al., 2005</a>

6251), probably related to the discrete distribution of FAAH in the brain; 2) FAAH or transport inhibitors have no hemodynamic effects under normotensive conditions, which predicts the absence of postural hypotension or other side effects; and 3) having a major effect on the inappropriately increased cardiac contractility, such treatment may be effective in reversing the cardiac hypertrophy that usually accompanies chronic hypertension.</p>

6252</div>

6253<div id="S37" class="sec">

6254<p>

6255</p>

6256<h4 id="S37title" class="inline">

62572. Circulatory Shock </h4>

6258<p id="P163" class="p p-first">

6259The profound hypotension that can be elicited through pharmacological activation of CB<sub>

62601</sub>

6261 receptors (<a href="#R645" rid="R645" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653516">

6262Lake et al., 1997a</a>

6263) triggered numerous studies to investigate the role of the endocannabinoid system in the hypotension associated with various forms of shock, including hemorrhagic (<a href="#R1250" rid="R1250" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920008">

6264Wagner et al., 1997</a>

6265; <a href="#R145" rid="R145" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919958">

6266Cainazzo et al., 2002</a>

6267), endotoxic (<a href="#R1221" rid="R1221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919932">

6268Varga et al., 1998</a>

6269; <a href="#R1270" rid="R1270" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920010">

6270Wang et al., 2001</a>

6271; <a href="#R693" rid="R693" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920340">

6272Liu et al., 2003a</a>

6273; <a href="#R51" rid="R51" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653524">

6274B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004a</a>

6275; <a href="#R366" rid="R366" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653426">

6276Gardiner et al., 2005</a>

6277; <a href="#R578" rid="R578" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920366">

6278Kadoi et al., 2005</a>

6279), and cardiogenic shock (<a href="#R1247" rid="R1247" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919836">

6280Wagner et al., 2001a</a>

6281, <a href="#R1248" rid="R1248" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920001">

62822003</a>

6283), and the shock associated with necrotizing pancreatitis (<a href="#R782" rid="R782" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919811">

6284Matsuda et al., 2005</a>

6285). Initial studies demonstrated that the putative CB<sub>

62861</sub>

6287 receptor antagonist SR141716 prevented or reversed the hypotension associated with hemorrhagic, endotoxic, and cardiogenic shock (<a href="#R1250" rid="R1250" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920022">

6288Wagner et al., 1997</a>

6289, <a href="#R1247" rid="R1247" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919212">

62902001a</a>

6291,<a href="#R1249" rid="R1249" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918812">

6292b</a>

6293; <a href="#R1221" rid="R1221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920384">

6294Varga et al., 1998</a>

6295). Likewise, SR141716 reversed the hypotension associated with advanced liver cirrhosis (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918819">

6296B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

6297; <a href="#R1036" rid="R1036" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919876">

6298Ros et al., 2002</a>

6299), which is possibly secondary to the endotoxemia frequently found in patients with late-stage cirrhosis (<a href="#R710" rid="R710" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919222">

6300Lumsden et al., 1988</a>

6301). Observations that circulating macrophages and platelets from endotoxemic or cirrhotic animals or humans had elevated levels of endocannabinoids and, when isolated and injected into normal rats, these cells elicited SR141716-sensitive hypotension also pointed toward the involvement of CB<sub>

63021</sub>

6303 receptors in many of these conditions (<a href="#R1250" rid="R1250" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919180">

6304Wagner et al., 1997</a>

6305; <a href="#R1221" rid="R1221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920090">

6306Varga et al., 1998</a>

6307; <a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920262">

6308B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

6309; <a href="#R720" rid="R720" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919483">

6310Maccarrone et al., 2001</a>

6311, <a href="#R717" rid="R717" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919389">

63122002</a>

6313; <a href="#R1036" rid="R1036" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919405">

6314Ros et al., 2002</a>

6315; <a href="#R693" rid="R693" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918781">

6316Liu et al., 2003a</a>

6317).</p>

6318<p id="P164">

6319Several recent reports demonstrated that anandamide and some atypical cannabinoids can cause both cardiodepressant and vasodilatory effects via as-yet-undefined receptors sensitive to inhibition by SR141716 but not by AM251 (<a href="#R556" rid="R556" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919444">

6320J&#x000e1;rai et al., 1999</a>

6321; <a href="#R328" rid="R328" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919941">

6322Ford et al., 2002</a>

6323; <a href="#R505" rid="R505" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919751">

6324Ho and Hiley, 2003</a>

6325; <a href="#R917" rid="R917" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653417">

6326O&#x02019;Sullivan et al., 2004b</a>

6327), a selective CB<sub>

63281</sub>

6329 antagonist equipotent with SR141716 (<a href="#R371" rid="R371" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653375">

6330Gatley et al., 1997</a>

6331). A recent study compared the effects of SR141716 and AM251 in rats on the acute hypotensive effect of bacterial endotoxin (LPS) administered as an intravenous bolus. Hypotension in this model is fully attributable to the decreased cardiac contractility, whereas peripheral vascular resistance is increased, indicating vasoconstriction (<a href="#R78" rid="R78" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919155">

6332Biber et al., 1988</a>

6333; <a href="#R178" rid="R178" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653413">

6334Cheng et al., 2003</a>

6335). Using this model, the cardiodepressant and hypotensive effects of LPS were inhibited by SR141716 but not by AM251. Furthermore, LPS induced SR141716-sensitive hypotension in wild-type mice and in mice deficient in CB<sub>

63361</sub>

6337 or both CB<sub>

63381</sub>

6339 and CB<sub>

63402</sub>

6341 receptors, suggesting that receptors distinct from CB<sub>

63421</sub>

6343 or CB<sub>

63442</sub>

6345 are primarily responsible for the observed hypotension (<a href="#R51" rid="R51" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653443">

6346B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2004a</a>

6347). Interestingly, another recent study has demonstrated that the CB<sub>

63481</sub>

6349-selective cannabinoid antagonist AM281 prevented the hemodynamic changes induced by acute LPS injection in rats (<a href="#R578" rid="R578" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919695">

6350Kadoi et al., 2005a</a>

6351). Other results indicate that endocannabinoids may also contribute to endotoxin-induced hypotension indirectly, through CB<sub>

63521</sub>

6353-mediated prejunctional inhibition of sympathoexcitation (<a href="#R406" rid="R406" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919560">

6354Godlewski et al., 2004</a>

6355). In a different shock model in which continuous infusion of LPS in conscious rats causes marked peripheral vasodilatation and increased cardiac output, AM251 attenuated the tachycardic and hind quarter vasodilator effects of LPS. This result was attributed to modulation of <em>

6356&#x003b2;</em>

6357-adrenergic vasodilation, rather than suppression of a direct vasodilator effect by endocannabinoids (<a href="#R366" rid="R366" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653358">

6358Gardiner et al., 2005</a>

6359). Interestingly, in a recent study, <a href="#R782" rid="R782" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919707">

6360Matsuda et al. (2005)</a>

6361 demonstrated that AM251 improved mean arterial pressure and survival rate in models of severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis without affecting inflammatory changes, which suggests the involvement of cardiac or vascular CB<sub>

63621</sub>

6363 receptors in the hypotension associated with this condition.</p>

6364<p id="P165">

6365In hemorrhagic, cardiogenic, and endotoxic shock, the cannabinoid agonists HU-210, WIN 55,212-2, and THC improved endothelial function and/or survival (<a href="#R1250" rid="R1250" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919491">

6366Wagner et al., 1997</a>

6367, <a href="#R1247" rid="R1247" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919854">

63682001a</a>

6369, <a href="#R1248" rid="R1248" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919746">

63702003</a>

6371; <a href="#R1221" rid="R1221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920136">

6372Varga et al., 1998</a>

6373; <a href="#R1120" rid="R1120" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919315">

6374Smith et al., 2000</a>

6375, <a href="#R1121" rid="R1121" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918701">

63762001</a>

6377). Surprisingly, the use of cannabinoid receptor antagonists, including SR141716, AM281, AM251, and SR144528, also leads to survival benefits in endotoxic and septic shock or necrotizing pancreatitis (<a href="#R1221" rid="R1221" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920321">

6378Varga et al., 1998</a>

6379; <a href="#R1120" rid="R1120" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920388">

6380Smith et al., 2000</a>

6381, <a href="#R1121" rid="R1121" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919128">

63822001</a>

6383; <a href="#R145" rid="R145" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919725">

6384Cainazzo et al., 2002</a>

6385; <a href="#R578" rid="R578" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919227">

6386Kadoi et al., 2005a</a>

6387,<a href="#R579" rid="R579" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920065">

6388b</a>

6389; <a href="#R782" rid="R782" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919963">

6390Matsuda et al., 2005</a>

6391). In contrast, CB<sub>

63921</sub>

6393 receptor blockade increased mortality in hemorrhagic (<a href="#R1250" rid="R1250" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919188">

6394Wagner et al., 1997</a>

6395) and cardiogenic shock (<a href="#R1247" rid="R1247" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919074">

6396Wagner et al., 2001a</a>

6397, <a href="#R1248" rid="R1248" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919647">

63982003</a>

6399), despite the increase in blood pressure. In these latter conditions, endocannabinoid-mediated vasodilation may have survival value through improving tissue oxygenation by counteracting the excessive sympathetic vasoconstriction triggered by hemorrhage or myocardial infarction, and this would be removed by CB<sub>

64001</sub>

6401 blockade. In contrast, CB<sub>

64021</sub>

6403 blockade may improve survival in endotoxic shock by preventing the primary hypotensive response to LPS (reviewed in <a href="#R637" rid="R637" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918859">

6404Kunos et al., 2000</a>

6405; <a href="#R494" rid="R494" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919033">

6406Hiley and Ford, 2003</a>

6407, <a href="#R495" rid="R495" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918965">

64082004</a>

6409; <a href="#R922" rid="R922" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919650">

6410Pacher et al., 2005a</a>

6411,<a href="#R924" rid="R924" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919182">

6412c</a>

6413).</p>

6414<p id="P166">

6415It should also be kept in mind that in most of the above conditions, hemodynamic changes are triggered by overwhelming inflammatory reaction, increased oxidative stress, and activation of downstream effector pathways, eventually leading to cardiovascular dysfunction and failure (reviewed in <a href="#R306" rid="R306" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919359">

6416Evgenov and Liaudet, 2005</a>

6417; <a href="#R928" rid="R928" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919563">

6418Pacher et al., 2005e</a>

6419). Therefore, the well known immune-modulatory, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects of cannabinoids should not be overlooked in these conditions. Indeed, endocannabinoids and synthetic cannabinoid agonists decrease inflammatory cytokine release in endotoxin-stimulated cells and in endotoxin-challenged animals (reviewed in <a href="#R1262" rid="R1262" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918970">

6420Walter and Stella, 2004</a>

6421; <a href="#R612" rid="R612" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920270">

6422Klein et al., 2005</a>

6423). Surprisingly, SR141716 and the CB<sub>

64242</sub>

6425 antagonist SR144528 were also reported to have anti-inflammatory effects (<a href="#R1120" rid="R1120" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919731">

6426Smith et al., 2000</a>

6427, <a href="#R1121" rid="R1121" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920117">

64282001</a>

6429), which may be attributed to their inverse agonist properties or to CB<sub>

64301/2</sub>

6431 receptor-independent mechanisms (reviewed in <a href="#R57" rid="R57" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919441">

6432Begg et al., 2005</a>

6433; <a href="#R958" rid="R958" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918769">

6434Pertwee, 2005b</a>

6435,<a href="#R959" rid="R959" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_539174731">

6436c</a>

6437).</p>

6438<p id="P167" class="p p-last">

6439Collectively, it appears that both cannabinoids and antagonists of cannabinoid receptors may exert some beneficial effects in various rodent shock models. Further studies should establish the specificity of these effects and the relevance to various forms of circulatory shock in humans.</p>

6440</div>

6441<div id="S38" class="sec">

6442<p>

6443</p>

6444<h4 id="S38title" class="inline">

64453. Myocardial Reperfusion Injury </h4>

6446<p id="P168" class="p p-first">

6447The endocannabinoid system has been implicated in endotoxin-induced preconditioning against myocardial I/R injury (<a href="#R641" rid="R641" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919238">

6448Lagneux and Lamontagne, 2001</a>

6449). In this study, the effects of 90 min of low-flow ischemia followed by 60 min of reperfusion at normal flow were compared in isolated hearts from rats pretreated with LPS or saline. Endotoxin pretreatment enhanced functional recovery on reperfusion and reduced infarct size compared with controls, and pretreatment with the CB<sub>

64502</sub>

6451 antagonist SR144528 but not the CB<sub>

64521</sub>

6453 antagonist SR141716 abolished the beneficial effects of preconditioning (<a href="#R641" rid="R641" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918820">

6454Lagneux and Lamontagne, 2001</a>

6455). In a follow-up study, SR144528 but not SR141716 also abolished the infarct size-reducing effect of preconditioning induced by heat stress (<a href="#R575" rid="R575" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919640">

6456Joyeux et al., 2002</a>

6457). These initial studies have suggested that the protection was mediated by endocannabinoids acting on CB<sub>

64582</sub>

6459 receptors. In preconditioning induced by a brief period of ischemia (5 min), either CB<sub>

64602</sub>

6461 or CB<sub>

64621</sub>

6463 receptor blockade abolished the protection, and both CB<sub>

64641</sub>

6465 and CB<sub>

64662</sub>

6467 receptors were implicated in the preservation of endothelium-dependent, 5-HT-induced vasodilation by ischemic preconditioning (<a href="#R111" rid="R111" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919626">

6468Bouchard et al., 2003</a>

6469). Perfusion of isolated rat hearts with PEA or 2-AG but not anandamide afforded protection against ischemia by improving myocardial recovery and decreasing myocardial damage and infarct size (<a href="#R674" rid="R674" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919039">

6470Lepicier et al., 2003</a>

6471). The cardioprotective effect of both PEA and 2-AG were completely blocked by SR144528, whereas SR141716 partially inhibited the effect of 2-AG only (<a href="#R674" rid="R674" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918849">

6472Lepicier et al., 2003</a>

6473). Likewise, the selective CB<sub>

64741</sub>

6475 agonist ACEA and the selective CB<sub>

64762</sub>

6477 agonist JWH-015 both reduced infarct size in this model, and the CB<sub>

64782</sub>

6479 receptor-mediated cardioprotection by PEA involved activation of p38/extracellular signal-regulated kinases 1 and 2 and protein kinase C (<a href="#R674" rid="R674" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919946">

6480Lepicier et al., 2003</a>

6481). In another study using isolated perfused rat hearts subjected to ischemia and reperfusion, reduction of the infarct size by anandamide could be equally well antagonized by CB<sub>

64821</sub>

6483 or CB<sub>

64842</sub>

6485 antagonists but could not be mimicked by selective CB<sub>

64861</sub>

6487 or CB<sub>

64882</sub>

6489 agonists, suggesting the involvement of a site distinct from CB<sub>

64901</sub>

6491 or CB<sub>

64922</sub>

6493 receptors (<a href="#R1203" rid="R1203" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919083">

6494Underdown et al., 2005</a>

6495).</p>

6496<p id="P169" class="p p-last">

6497Others have used whole animal models of I/R injury induced by coronary occlusion/reocclusion in anesthetized rats. In this model, anandamide and HU-210 both decreased the incidence of ventricular arrhythmias and reduced infarct size through activation of CB<sub>

64982</sub>

6499 but not CB<sub>

65001</sub>

6501 receptors (<a href="#R631" rid="R631" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919437">

6502Krylatov et al., 2001</a>

6503, <a href="#R629" rid="R629" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919133">

65042002a</a>

6505,<a href="#R632" rid="R632" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919768">

6506b</a>

6507,<a href="#R633" rid="R633" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919757">

6508c</a>

6509; <a href="#R1199" rid="R1199" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919472">

6510Ugdyzhekova et al., 2001</a>

6511, <a href="#R1198" rid="R1198" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919581">

65122002</a>

6513). The moderately CB<sub>

65142</sub>

6515-selective agonist WIN 55,212-2 also reduced the extent of leukocyte-dependent myocardial damage in a more recent mouse study of myocardial I/R in vivo. This effect was abolished by the selective CB<sub>

65162</sub>

6517 receptor antagonist AM630 but was unaffected by AM251 (<a href="#R270" rid="R270" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919393">

6518Di Filippo et al., 2004</a>

6519). In summary, evidence to date indicates that endocannabinoids protect against myocardial ischemic injury models predominantly via CB<sub>

65202</sub>

6521 receptors.</p>

6522</div>

6523<div id="S39" class="sec">

6524<p>

6525</p>

6526<h4 id="S39title" class="inline">

65274. Atherosclerosis </h4>

6528<p id="P170" class="p p-first-last">

6529Chronic inflammation and the associated oxidative-nitrosative stress are key players in atherosclerosis and cardiovascular aging, and pharmacological modulation of these processes could be of therapeutic benefit (reviewed in <a href="#R233" rid="R233" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919568">

6530Csiszar et al., 2005</a>

6531; <a href="#R684" rid="R684" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919469">

6532Libby and Theroux, 2005</a>

6533). Using the apolipoprotein E knockout mouse model of atherosclerosis, <a href="#R1136" rid="R1136" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919558">

6534Steffens et al. (2005)</a>

6535 reported that orally administered THC significantly inhibited disease progression. Furthermore, CB<sub>

65362</sub>

6537 receptor expressing immune cells were present both in human and mouse atherosclerotic plaques, lymphoid cells isolated from THC-treated mice had diminished proliferation capacity and decreased interferon-<em>

6538&#x003b3;</em>

6539 production, and THC inhibited macrophage chemotaxis in vitro. Most importantly, all of these effects were completely blocked by a selective CB<sub>

65402</sub>

6541 receptor antagonist, suggesting that targeting CB<sub>

65422</sub>

6543 receptors may offer a new approach in the treatment of atherosclerosis (<a href="#R1042" rid="R1042" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920243">

6544Roth, 2005</a>

6545; <a href="#R1136" rid="R1136" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919674">

6546Steffens et al., 2005</a>

6547).</p>

6548</div>

6549<div id="S40" class="sec sec-last">

6550<p>

6551</p>

6552<h4 id="S40title" class="inline">

65535. Asthma </h4>

6554<p id="P171" class="p p-first">

6555The effect of marijuana on airway functions was among the first to be explored for potential therapeutic benefit (reviewed in <a href="#R673" rid="R673" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919115">

6556Lemberger, 1980</a>

6557; <a href="#R1164" rid="R1164" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919590">

6558Tashkin et al., 2002</a>

6559). Smoking marijuana and ingesting THC were both found to increase airway conductance in normal, healthy subjects (<a href="#R1166" rid="R1166" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919376">

6560Tashkin et al., 1973</a>

6561; <a href="#R1207" rid="R1207" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919755">

6562Vachon et al., 1973</a>

6563), and these effects lasted longer than the bronchodilator effect of the <em>

6564&#x003b2;</em>

6565-adrenergic agonist isoproterenol. Bronchodilation induced by smoked marijuana and oral THC was also documented in subjects with mild to moderate asthma and in asthmatic patients with methacholine- or exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (<a href="#R1167" rid="R1167" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919462">

6566Tashkin et al., 1974</a>

6567, <a href="#R1168" rid="R1168" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920052">

65681975</a>

6569). Bronchodilation without side effects was observed in asthmatic patients after a low dose (0.2 mg) of nebulized THC (<a href="#R1291" rid="R1291" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919068">

6570Williams et al., 1976</a>

6571; <a href="#R473" rid="R473" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920351">

6572Hartley et al., 1978</a>

6573). In contrast, aerosols containing larger doses of THC (5&#x02013;20 mg) caused paradoxical bronchoconstriction attributed to local irritation (<a href="#R1165" rid="R1165" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919533">

6574Tashkin et al., 1977</a>

6575). In another study of normal and asthmatic subjects, orally administered THC elicited only minimal and inconsistent bronchodilation associated with significant CNS side effects (<a href="#R2" rid="R2" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919378">

6576Abboud and Sanders, 1976</a>

6577). Nevertheless, most of these initial observations had suggested some therapeutic benefit of using cannabinoids in asthma.</p>

6578<p id="P172">

6579As for the mechanisms underlying THC-induced bronchodilation, the potential involvement of <em>

6580&#x003b2;</em>

6581-adrenergic and muscarinic receptors on airway smooth muscle could be excluded (<a href="#R595" rid="R595" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919064">

6582Kelly and Butcher, 1973</a>

6583; <a href="#R1088" rid="R1088" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920144">

6584Shapiro et al., 1977</a>

6585; <a href="#R673" rid="R673" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919766">

6586Lemberger, 1980</a>

6587). This conclusion was supported by the inability of THC to relax isolated rings of resting or precontracted human bronchioles (<a href="#R912" rid="R912" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653496">

6588Orzelek-O&#x02019;Neil et al., 1980a</a>

6589,<a href="#R913" rid="R913" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653366">

6590b</a>

6591), suggesting a more proximal site of action in the lung (<a href="#R164" rid="R164" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920215">

6592Cavero et al., 1972</a>

6593) or a central mechanism.</p>

6594<p id="P173">

6595More recently, <a href="#R146" rid="R146" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919827">

6596Calignano et al. (2000)</a>

6597 reported that CB<sub>

65981</sub>

6599 receptors are present on axon terminals innervating airway smooth muscle, and anandamide inhibited capsaicin-induced bronchospasm and cough in guinea pigs in an SR141716-sensitive manner. They also documented calcium-induced biosynthesis of anandamide in lung tissue, suggesting that locally generated anandamide participates in the intrinsic control of airway responsiveness by inhibiting prejunctional acetylcholine release. Indeed, SR141716 treatment was found to enhance capsaicin-evoked bronchospasm and cough. Interestingly, when airway smooth muscle was completely relaxed by vagotomy and atropine treatment, anandamide caused dose-dependent bronchoconstriction, which could be also prevented by CB<sub>

66001</sub>

6601 blockade. This effect was tentatively attributed to direct stimulation of putative cannabinoid receptors on the airway smooth muscle or a CB<sub>

66021</sub>

6603-mediated corelease of bronchoconstrictor neurotransmitters from nerve endings in the lung. In a follow-up study, presynaptic CB<sub>

66041</sub>

6605 receptors in the guinea pig lung were only found on noradrenergic terminals where their stimulation by WIN 55,212-2 inhibited norepinephrine release (<a href="#R1236" rid="R1236" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920261">

6606Vizi et al., 2001</a>

6607), consistent with the lack of a mediated CB<sub>

66081</sub>

6609-mediated effect on acetylcholine release in guinea pig trachea (<a href="#R1131" rid="R1131" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919280">

6610Spicuzza et al., 2000</a>

6611). In contrast to the findings of <a href="#R146" rid="R146" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919689">

6612Calignano et al. (2000)</a>

6613, <a href="#R1140" rid="R1140" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919135">

6614Stengel et al. (1998)</a>

6615 reported that anandamide given either intravenously or in aerosol did not affect airway resistance in guinea pigs, but possessed modest anti-inflammatory properties. It should be noted, however, that in this study bronchoconstriction was induced by a calcium ionophore rather than capsaicin. In an in vitro study of guinea pig airway smooth muscle (<a href="#R1310" rid="R1310" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920310">

6616Yoshihara et al., 2005</a>

6617), anandamide and palmitoylethanolamide inhibited contractions elicited by electrical field stimulation but not by neurokinin A, and also blocked capsaicin-capsaicin-induced release of substance P-like immunoreactivity. These effects were selectively inhibited by a CB<sub>

66182</sub>

6619 but not a CB<sub>

66201</sub>

6621 antagonist, or by maxi-K<sup>

6622+</sup>

6623 channel blockers, suggesting that CB<sub>

66242</sub>

6625 agonists may have therapeutic value in asthma (<a href="#R1310" rid="R1310" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920121">

6626Yoshihara et al., 2005</a>

6627). In a recent study, inhibition of anandamide transport potently suppressed capsaicin-induced cough in mice, suggesting that the anandamide transporter may be a target for peripherally acting antitussive medications (<a href="#R580" rid="R580" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919005">

6628Kamei et al., 2006</a>

6629). Diverse effects of endocannabinoids and synthetic agonist have also been reported on respiratory function and pulmonary circulation both in vivo and in vitro (<a href="#R1074" rid="R1074" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653509">

6630Schmid et al., 2003</a>

6631; <a href="#R1252" rid="R1252" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653485">

6632Wahn et al., 2005</a>

6633).</p>

6634<p id="P174">

6635Allergic asthma is currently viewed as a complex inflammatory disorder characterized by recruitment of eosinophils into the lung, mucus hypersecretion by goblet cells, elevated serum IgE, and airway hyperresponsiveness (reviewed in <a href="#R1292" rid="R1292" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919610">

6636Wills-Karp, 1999</a>

6637). Given the well known anti-inflammatory effects of cannabinoids, these effects could also be of therapeutic value. Indeed, in a murine model of allergic airway disease induced by ovalbumin sensitization, pretreatment with cannabinol or THC blunted the increase in IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 mRNA expression and decreased mucus overproduction and serum IgE levels (<a href="#R555" rid="R555" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920068">

6638Jan et al., 2003</a>

6639). Anti-inflammatory effects of WIN 55,212-2, THC, anandamide, and palmitoylethanolamide were also reported in a mouse model of LPS-induced pulmonary inflammation (<a href="#R68" rid="R68" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919868">

6640Berdyshev et al., 1998</a>

6641).</p>

6642<p id="P175" class="p p-last">

6643In conclusion, the effects of cannabinoids on respiratory function are rather complex, and evidence for their therapeutic potential in asthma is equivocal. The possibility remains that novel, nonpsychoactive cannabinoid analogs with long-lasting anti-inflammatory activity turn out to be useful adjuncts in the treatment of allergic asthma.</p>

6644</div>

6645</div>

6646<div id="S41" class="sec">

6647<h3 id="S41title">

6648E. Eye Disorders (Glaucoma and Retinopathy)</h3>

6649<p id="P176" class="p p-first">

6650Glaucoma, the leading cause of irreversible blindness in the United States, is characterized by an increase in intraocular pressure and consequent damage to the optic nerve. Despite the multitude of effective medications that can be used to decrease ocular hypertension (e.g., cholinergic agonists, <em>

6651&#x003b2;</em>

6652- and <em>

6653&#x003b1;</em>

6654<sub>

66552</sub>

6656-adrenoceptor agonists, dopaminergic agonists, prostaglandins, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors), some patients remain refractory to these drugs and may eventually become blind (reviewed in <a href="#R16" rid="R16" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920084">

6657Alward, 1998</a>

6658; <a href="#R229" rid="R229" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919935">

6659Crowston and Weinreb, 2005</a>

6660).</p>

6661<p id="P177">

6662A decrease in intraocular pressure in a small number of healthy marijuana smokers was a serendipitous finding (<a href="#R482" rid="R482" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653453">

6663Hepler and Frank, 1971</a>

6664), subsequently confirmed in a placebo-controlled, double-blind study of healthy volunteers who smoked either natural marijuana of known THC content or ingested synthetic THC (<a href="#R483" rid="R483" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919831">

6665Hepler et al., 1972</a>

6666). THC or marijuana decreased intraocular pressure whether administered orally, topically, or intravenously, with no major tolerance to their effect reported (<a href="#R1089" rid="R1089" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919287">

6667Shapiro, 1974</a>

6668; <a href="#R989" rid="R989" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919398">

6669Purnell and Gregg, 1975</a>

6670; <a href="#R234" rid="R234" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919190">

6671Cuendet et al., 1976</a>

6672; <a href="#R481" rid="R481" class=" bibr popnode">

6673Hepler et al., 1976</a>

6674; <a href="#R125" rid="R125" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920128">

6675Brown et al., 1977</a>

6676; <a href="#R824" rid="R824" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919163">

6677Merritt et al., 1980</a>

6678, <a href="#R825" rid="R825" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918753">

66791981a</a>

6680,<a href="#R826" rid="R826" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920168">

6681b</a>

6682). Most of these studies also reported various systemic side effects, such as hypotension, tachycardia, euphoria, and dysphoria, as well as other ocular effects, such as changes in pupil size, decreased tear production, and conjunctival hyperemia. Endocannabinoids and synthetic cannabinoid ligands have also been reported to reduce intraocular pressure when given topically or systemically, both in animals and humans (<a href="#R1089" rid="R1089" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918953">

6683Shapiro, 1974</a>

6684; <a href="#R299" rid="R299" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918995">

6685ElSohly et al., 1981</a>

6686, <a href="#R200" rid="R200" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919600">

66871984</a>

6688; <a href="#R191" rid="R191" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919473">

6689Colasanti et al., 1984a</a>

6690,b,c; <a href="#R944" rid="R944" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920099">

6691Pate et al., 1995</a>

6692; <a href="#R978" rid="R978" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919049">

6693Porcella et al., 1998</a>

6694; <a href="#R127" rid="R127" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919070">

6695Buchwald et al., 2002</a>

6696; <a href="#R643" rid="R643" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919867">

6697Laine et al., 2002a</a>

6698,<a href="#R644" rid="R644" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919230">

6699b</a>

6700; reviewed in <a href="#R558" rid="R558" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919609">

6701Jarvinen et al., 2002</a>

6702; <a href="#R180" rid="R180" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918972">

6703Chien et al., 2003</a>

6704; <a href="#R1184" rid="R1184" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920255">

6705Tomida et al., 2004</a>

6706).</p>

6707<p id="P178">

6708Early investigations into the mechanisms of the intraocular pressure-lowering effect of marijuana and THC implicated the sympathetic and central nervous systems in this effect (<a href="#R425" rid="R425" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918853">

6709Green and Pederson, 1973</a>

6710; <a href="#R426" rid="R426" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919202">

6711Green and Podos, 1974</a>

6712; <a href="#R422" rid="R422" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919193">

6713Green et al., 1977a</a>

6714,<a href="#R423" rid="R423" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918821">

6715b</a>

6716). However, in subsequent studies, the effect of a unilateral topical application of cannabinoids was limited to the treated eye, pointing toward a local site of action (<a href="#R191" rid="R191" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919382">

6717Colasanti et al., 1984a</a>

6718,<a href="#R192" rid="R192" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919629">

6719b</a>

6720,<a href="#R193" rid="R193" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919324">

6721c</a>

6722). Indeed, a CNS site of action could be ruled out by the lack of change in intraocular pressure upon intracerebroventricular or ventriculocisternal application of THC in rabbits (<a href="#R697" rid="R697" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919335">

6723Liu and Dacus, 1987</a>

6724).</p>

6725<p id="P179">

6726Multiple lines of evidence suggest that endocannabinoids and cannabinoid receptors, in particular CB<sub>

67271</sub>

6728, play an important role in the regulation of intraocular pressure, and topically applied cannabinoids and cannabinoid ligands may be of significant benefit in the treatment of glaucoma (reviewed in <a href="#R558" rid="R558" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919879">

6729Jarvinen et al., 2002</a>

6730; <a href="#R1184" rid="R1184" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919579">

6731Tomida et al., 2004</a>

6732). First, CB<sub>

67331</sub>

6734 receptors are expressed in the rat ciliary body (<a href="#R978" rid="R978" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919329">

6735Porcella et al., 1998</a>

6736), in human ciliary epithelium, ciliary muscle, ciliary body vessels, trabecular meshwork, Schlemm&#x02019;s canal, and retina (<a href="#R1144" rid="R1144" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919530">

6737Straiker et al., 1999a</a>

6738; <a href="#R980" rid="R980" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919809">

6739Porcella et al., 2000</a>

6740; <a href="#R1133" rid="R1133" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919825">

6741Stamer et al., 2001</a>

6742), and the retina of a variety of species (<a href="#R1145" rid="R1145" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919775">

6743Straiker et al., 1999b</a>

6744; <a href="#R1306" rid="R1306" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920327">

6745Yazulla et al., 1999</a>

6746, <a href="#R1307" rid="R1307" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919510">

67472000</a>

6748). Second, ocular CB<sub>

67491</sub>

6750 receptors are functionally active, as CB<sub>

67511</sub>

6752 receptor agonists (CP55,940 and WIN 55,212-2) applied topically lower intraocular pressure both in animals and humans, and their effect can be antagonized by SR141716 (<a href="#R945" rid="R945" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918689">

6753Pate et al., 1998</a>

6754; <a href="#R1126" rid="R1126" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919997">

6755Song and Slowey, 2000</a>

6756; <a href="#R981" rid="R981" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920017">

6757Porcella et al., 2001</a>

6758; <a href="#R180" rid="R180" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920111">

6759Chien et al., 2003</a>

6760; <a href="#R1147" rid="R1147" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918722">

6761Stumpff et al., 2005</a>

6762; reviewed in <a href="#R558" rid="R558" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918741">

6763Jarvinen et al., 2002</a>

6764). The CB<sub>

67652</sub>

6766 receptor agonist JWH-133 did not modify the intraocular pressure, suggesting that CB<sub>

67672</sub>

6768 receptors may play only a minor, if any, role (<a href="#R642" rid="R642" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919902">

6769Laine et al., 2003</a>

6770). CB<sub>

67711</sub>

6772 receptor signaling is also operational in the ocular trabecular meshwork (<a href="#R1147" rid="R1147" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919506">

6773Stumpff et al., 2005</a>

6774), and ciliary muscle (<a href="#R701" rid="R701" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920230">

6775Lograno and Romano, 2004</a>

6776). Third, endocannabinoids are detectable in ocular tissues including the retina, ciliary body, and choroids plexus (<a href="#R90" rid="R90" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919756">

6777Bisogno et al., 1999b</a>

6778; <a href="#R1144" rid="R1144" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920332">

6779Straiker et al., 1999a</a>

6780,<a href="#R1145" rid="R1145" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919911">

6781b</a>

6782; <a href="#R1133" rid="R1133" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919273">

6783Stamer et al., 2001</a>

6784; <a href="#R173" rid="R173" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919086">

6785Chen et al., 2005</a>

6786), and the levels of anandamide and especially 2-AG are significantly decreased in patients with glaucoma (<a href="#R173" rid="R173" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919957">

6787Chen et al., 2005</a>

6788).</p>

6789<p id="P180">

6790The cellular/molecular mechanisms responsible for the intraocular pressure-reducing effect of cannabinoids are not completely understood but may involve direct effects on ciliary processes such as vasodilation and reduction of capillary pressure and secretion and do not seem to be related to systemic reduction of arterial blood pressure (<a href="#R425" rid="R425" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920314">

6791Green and Pederson, 1973</a>

6792; <a href="#R624" rid="R624" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919383">

6793Korczyn, 1980</a>

6794). Cannabinoids may also inhibit calcium influx through presynaptic ion channels, thereby reducing norepinephrine release in the ciliary body, resulting in decreased aqueous humor production (<a href="#R1151" rid="R1151" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918964">

6795Sugrue, 1997</a>

6796). In addition, cannabinoids may improve the uveoscleral outflow by dilating blood vessels of the anterior uvea (<a href="#R978" rid="R978" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919699">

6797Porcella et al., 1998</a>

6798), most likely by induction of several outflow-facilitating mediators (<a href="#R1037" rid="R1037" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918945">

6799Rosch et al., 2006</a>

6800). Some evidence implicates prostanoids in the intraocular pressure-reducing effect of certain cannabinoids and anandamide (<a href="#R943" rid="R943" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919299">

6801Pate et al., 1996</a>

6802; <a href="#R424" rid="R424" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919060">

6803Green et al., 2001</a>

6804; <a href="#R1037" rid="R1037" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919883">

6805Rosch et al., 2006</a>

6806).</p>

6807<p id="P181">

6808Endocannabinoids as well as functional CB<sub>

68091</sub>

6810 receptors are present in the retina (<a href="#R90" rid="R90" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919914">

6811Bisogno et al., 1999b</a>

6812; <a href="#R1144" rid="R1144" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919007">

6813Straiker et al., 1999a</a>

6814,<a href="#R1145" rid="R1145" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919436">

6815b</a>

6816; <a href="#R311" rid="R311" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919586">

6817Fan and Yazulla, 2003</a>

6818; <a href="#R1069" rid="R1069" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919112">

6819Savinainen and Laitinen, 2004</a>

6820). Cannabinoids exert neuroprotective effects against retinal neurotoxicity (<a href="#R298" rid="R298" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919304">

6821El-Remessy et al., 2003</a>

6822), and cannabidiol helps to preserve the blood-retinal barrier in experimental diabetes (<a href="#R297" rid="R297" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919310">

6823El-Remessy et al., 2006</a>

6824). These effects could suggest their usefulness in various retinopathies. Unlike CB<sub>

68251</sub>

6826 receptors, CB<sub>

68272</sub>

6828 receptors were undetectable in human retina, although they were found in the rat retina (<a href="#R708" rid="R708" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920110">

6829Lu et al., 2000</a>

6830; <a href="#R980" rid="R980" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919264">

6831Porcella et al., 2000</a>

6832).</p>

6833<p id="P182" class="p p-last">

6834Taken together, these findings indicate that cannabinoids may have great potential in the treatment of glaucoma, if the difficulty in formulating a stable and effective topical preparation and the problem of systemic side effects are conquered. Because of their well known neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and antiangiogenic effects, cannabinoid analogs may also be considered for the treatment of inflammatory and degenerative eye disorders and diabetic retinopathy.</p>

6835</div>

6836<div id="S42" class="sec">

6837<h3 id="S42title">

6838F. Cancer</h3>

6839<p id="P183" class="p p-first">

6840The palliative effects of cannabinoids in cancer patients are well known and may include appetite stimulation, inhibition of nausea and emesis associated with chemo- or radiotherapy, pain relief, mood elevation, and relief from insomnia (reviewed in <a href="#R1260" rid="R1260" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919619">

6841Walsh et al., 2003</a>

6842; <a href="#R454" rid="R454" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920387">

6843Hall et al., 2005</a>

6844) (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/table/T1/" target="table" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="T1" rid-ob="ob-T1" co-legend-rid="">

6845<span>

6846Table 1</span>

6847</a>

6848). &#x00394;<sup>

68499</sup>

6850-THC (dronabinol, Marinol) and its synthetic derivative nabilone have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to control nausea in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy and to stimulate appetite in patients with AIDS (<a href="#R1260" rid="R1260" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918761">

6851Walsh et al., 2003</a>

6852; <a href="#R454" rid="R454" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920294">

6853Hall et al., 2005</a>

6854).</p>

6855<p id="P184">

6856Numerous recent studies have suggested that cannabinoids might directly inhibit cancer growth (reviewed in <a href="#R942" rid="R942" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653393">

6857Parolaro et al., 2002</a>

6858; <a href="#R449" rid="R449" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919281">

6859Guzm&#x000e1;n et al., 2002</a>

6860; <a href="#R448" rid="R448" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920019">

6861Guzm&#x000e1;n, 2003</a>

6862; <a href="#R571" rid="R571" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919907">

6863Jones and Howl, 2003</a>

6864; <a href="#R1224" rid="R1224" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919384">

6865Velasco et al., 2004</a>

6866; <a href="#R951" rid="R951" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918967">

6867Patsos et al., 2005</a>

6868). The proposed mechanisms are complex and may involve induction of apoptosis in tumor cells, antiproliferative action, and an antimetastatic effect through inhibition of angiogenesis and tumor cell migration (reviewed in <a href="#R83" rid="R83" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918680">

6869Bifulco and Di Marzo, 2002</a>

6870; <a href="#R942" rid="R942" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653457">

6871Parolaro et al., 2002</a>

6872; <a href="#R449" rid="R449" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920386">

6873Guzm&#x000e1;n et al., 2002</a>

6874; <a href="#R448" rid="R448" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919121">

6875Guzm&#x000e1;n, 2003</a>

6876; <a href="#R571" rid="R571" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919994">

6877Jones and Howl, 2003</a>

6878; <a href="#R1224" rid="R1224" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918737">

6879Velasco et al., 2004</a>

6880; <a href="#R951" rid="R951" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919981">

6881Patsos et al., 2005</a>

6882).</p>

6883<p id="P185">

6884Various cannabinoids, including cannabidiol, anandamide, and 2-AG, and endocannabinoid transport inhibitors have been shown to induce apoptotic cell death and to inhibit proliferation and migration in numerous murine and human tumor cell lines including glioma (C6, U87, U373, and H4), oligodendroglioma (Gos3), glioblastoma multiforme, astrocytoma (U373-MG, U87MG, and human grade IV astrocytoma), neuroblastoma (N18 TG2 and CHP100), pheochromocytoma (PC12), breast cancer (MCF-7, EFM-19, T47D, TSA-E1, and MDA-MB-231), prostate cancer (LNCaP, DU145, and PC3), colon carcinoma (SW 480), uterine cervix carcinoma (CxCa), thyroid cancer (KiMol), leukemia (CEM, HEL-92, HL60, and Jurkat cell lines), and lymphoid tumors (EL-4 and P815) tumor cells via CB<sub>

68851</sub>

6886/CB<sub>

68872</sub>

6888- and VR<sub>

68891</sub>

6890 receptor-dependent or independent (e.g., cyclooxygenase) mechanisms (<a href="#R253" rid="R253" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919356">

6891De Petrocellis et al., 1998</a>

6892; <a href="#R1058" rid="R1058" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919429">

6893S&#x000e1;nchez et al., 1998</a>

6894, <a href="#R1060" rid="R1060" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919580">

68952003</a>

6896; <a href="#R552" rid="R552" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918691">

6897Jacobsson et al., 2000</a>

6898; <a href="#R722" rid="R722" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919924">

6899Maccarrone et al., 2000b</a>

6900; <a href="#R1068" rid="R1068" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653372">

6901Sarker et al., 2000</a>

6902; <a href="#R797" rid="R797" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920185">

6903McKallip et al., 2002a</a>

6904,<a href="#R798" rid="R798" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919092">

6905b</a>

6906; <a href="#R332" rid="R332" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919480">

6907Fowler et al., 2003</a>

6908; <a href="#R572" rid="R572" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920066">

6909Jonsson et al., 2003</a>

6910; <a href="#R836" rid="R836" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920131">

6911Mimeault et al., 2003</a>

6912; <a href="#R85" rid="R85" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920071">

6913Bifulco et al., 2004</a>

6914; <a href="#R207" rid="R207" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919066">

6915Contassot et al., 2004a</a>

6916,<a href="#R208" rid="R208" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919311">

6917b</a>

6918; <a href="#R504" rid="R504" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918841">

6919Hinz et al., 2004</a>

6920; <a href="#R574" rid="R574" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918977">

6921Joseph et al., 2004</a>

6922; <a href="#R619" rid="R619" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919442">

6923Kogan et al., 2004</a>

6924; <a href="#R777" rid="R777" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920030">

6925Massi et al., 2004</a>

6926; <a href="#R894" rid="R894" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920219">

6927Nithipatikom et al., 2004</a>

6928; <a href="#R15" rid="R15" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919023">

6929Allister et al., 2005</a>

6930; <a href="#R294" rid="R294" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920188">

6931Ellert-Miklaszewska et al., 2005</a>

6932; <a href="#R489" rid="R489" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920064">

6933Herrera et al., 2005</a>

6934, <a href="#R488" rid="R488" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918788">

69352006</a>

6936; <a href="#R702" rid="R702" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919300">

6937Lombard et al., 2005</a>

6938; <a href="#R984" rid="R984" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919298">

6939Powles et al., 2005</a>

6940; <a href="#R1066" rid="R1066" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918732">

6941Sarfaraz et al., 2005</a>

6942; <a href="#R1206" rid="R1206" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920226">

6943Vaccani et al., 2005</a>

6944; <a href="#R157" rid="R157" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919993">

6945Carracedo et al., 2006</a>

6946; <a href="#R432" rid="R432" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918877">

6947Grimaldi et al., 2006</a>

6948; <a href="#R690" rid="R690" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488948">

6949Ligresti et al., 2006b</a>

6950). More importantly, systemic or local treatment with cannabinoids inhibited the growth of various types of tumor or tumor cell xenografts in vivo, including lung carcinoma (<a href="#R864" rid="R864" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919556">

6951Munson et al., 1975</a>

6952), glioma (<a href="#R357" rid="R357" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919835">

6953Galve-Roperh et al., 2000</a>

6954; <a href="#R1057" rid="R1057" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653388">

6955S&#x000e1;nchez et al., 2001a</a>

6956; <a href="#R777" rid="R777" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919522">

6957Massi et al., 2004</a>

6958), thyroid epithelioma (<a href="#R84" rid="R84" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919513">

6959Bifulco et al., 2001</a>

6960), lymphoma (<a href="#R797" rid="R797" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919229">

6961McKallip et al., 2002a</a>

6962), and skin carcinoma (<a href="#R160" rid="R160" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919450">

6963Casanova et al., 2003</a>

6964) in mice.</p>

6965<p id="P186">

6966The proapoptotic effect of cannabinoids in tumor cells is complex and may involve increased synthesis of the proapoptotic sphingolipid ceramide (<a href="#R357" rid="R357" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919541">

6967Galve-Roperh et al., 2000</a>

6968; <a href="#R407" rid="R407" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653350">

6969G&#x000f3;mez del Pulgar et al., 2002a</a>

6970,<a href="#R409" rid="R409" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653445">

6971b</a>

6972), ceramide-dependent up-regulation of the stress protein p8 and several downstream stress-related genes expressed in the endoplasmic reticulum (ATF-4, CHOP, and TRB3; <a href="#R157" rid="R157" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919595">

6973Carracedo et al., 2006</a>

6974), prolonged activation of the Raf-1/mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase signaling cascade (<a href="#R357" rid="R357" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920046">

6975Galve-Roperh et al., 2000</a>

6976), and inhibition of Akt (<a href="#R408" rid="R408" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919540">

6977G&#x000f3;mez del Pulgar et al., 2000</a>

6978; <a href="#R294" rid="R294" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919861">

6979Ellert-Miklaszewska et al., 2005</a>

6980), c-Jun NH<sub>

69812</sub>

6982-terminal kinase and p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (<a href="#R357" rid="R357" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919525">

6983Galve-Roperh et al., 2000</a>

6984; <a href="#R1067" rid="R1067" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920333">

6985Sarker et al., 2003</a>

6986; <a href="#R504" rid="R504" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918802">

6987Hinz et al., 2004</a>

6988; <a href="#R984" rid="R984" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918772">

6989Powles et al., 2005</a>

6990). As mentioned above, cannabinoids also inhibit the proliferation of various tumor cells, possibly through inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and the cAMP/protein kinase A pathway (<a href="#R816" rid="R816" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919240">

6991Melck et al., 1999</a>

6992), induction of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p27<sup>

6993kip1</sup>

6994 (<a href="#R982" rid="R982" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918974">

6995Portella et al., 2003</a>

6996), a decrease in epidermal growth factor receptor expression and/or the attenuation of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase activity (<a href="#R160" rid="R160" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919999">

6997Casanova et al., 2003</a>

6998; <a href="#R836" rid="R836" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919085">

6999Mimeault et al., 2003</a>

7000), and a decrease in the activity and/or expression of nerve growth factor or vascular endothelial growth factor tyrosine kinase receptors and prolactin (<a href="#R253" rid="R253" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919639">

7001De Petrocellis et al., 1998</a>

7002; <a href="#R815" rid="R815" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920162">

7003Melck et al., 2000</a>

7004; <a href="#R982" rid="R982" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919285">

7005Portella et al., 2003</a>

7006). In addition to their proapoptotic and antiproliferative effects in tumor cells, cannabinoids also inhibit the expression of proangiogenic mediators or their receptors (e.g., vascular endothelial growth factor) and reduce vascular hyperplasia and cell migration, which play crucial roles in tumor growth and metastasis formation (<a href="#R98" rid="R98" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918751">

7007Bl&#x000e1;zquez 2004</a>

7008;<a href="#R97" rid="R97" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918816">

7009et al., 2003</a>

7010, <a href="#R98" rid="R98" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919804">

70112004</a>

7012; <a href="#R160" rid="R160" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919998">

7013Casanova et al., 2003</a>

7014; <a href="#R982" rid="R982" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918940">

7015Portella et al., 2003</a>

7016).</p>

7017<p id="P187">

7018In sharp contrast to the above, <a href="#R472" rid="R472" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920094">

7019Hart et al. (2004)</a>

7020 have demonstrated that treatment of lung cancer (NCI-H292), squamous cell carcinoma (SCC-9), bladder carcinoma (5637), glioblastoma (U373-MG), astrocytoma (1321N1), and kidney cancer (A498) cells with nanomolar concentrations of cannabinoids such as THC, anandamide, HU-210, and WIN 55,212-2 leads to rapid epidermal growth factor receptor- and metalloprotease-dependent cancer cell proliferation. However, the same study also documented that at micromolar concentrations cannabinoids induced cancer cell apoptosis, in agreement with previous reports (<a href="#R472" rid="R472" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919177">

7021Hart et al., 2004</a>

7022). These results highlight the bimodal action of cannabinoids on cancer cell growth, with low concentrations being proproliferative and high concentrations having antiproliferative effects.</p>

7023<p id="P188">

7024The key role of the immune system in controlling the development of cancers is supported by findings that immunosuppressed individuals are at increased risk for developing cancer. For example, there is increased incidence of non-Hodgkin&#x02019;s lymphoma, Burkitt&#x02019;s lymphoma, Kaposi&#x02019;s sarcoma, and cervical cancer in AIDS patients and increased susceptibility to various lymphomas and solid tumors after organ transplantation (<a href="#R77" rid="R77" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919207">

7025Bhatia et al., 2001</a>

7026; <a href="#R1071" rid="R1071" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919973">

7027Scadden, 2003</a>

7028; <a href="#R5" rid="R5" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919047">

7029Abu-Elmagd et al., 2004</a>

7030; <a href="#R911" rid="R911" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653448">

7031Oruc et al., 2004</a>

7032). This concept is particularly important, because cannabinoids have well-known immunosuppressant effects (reviewed in <a href="#R612" rid="R612" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919733">

7033Klein, 2005</a>

7034), which may compromise antitumor immune responses. Indeed, THC enhances breast and lung cancer growth and metastasis by suppressing CB<sub>

70352</sub>

7036 receptor-mediated antitumor immune responses (<a href="#R1322" rid="R1322" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919160">

7037Zhu et al., 2000</a>

7038; <a href="#R799" rid="R799" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919944">

7039McKallip et al., 2005</a>

7040) and can also lead to increased susceptibility to infections with various pathogens such as herpes simplex virus, <em>

7041Legionella pneumophila,</em>

7042 and Fried leukemia virus (<a href="#R849" rid="R849" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919416">

7043Morahan et al., 1979</a>

7044; <a href="#R141" rid="R141" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919727">

7045Cabral et al., 1986</a>

7046; <a href="#R1129" rid="R1129" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919216">

7047Specter et al., 1991</a>

7048; <a href="#R616" rid="R616" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918824">

7049Klein et al., 2000b</a>

7050).</p>

7051<p id="P189" class="p p-last">

7052Epidemiological studies investigating the relationship of cannabis smoking and various forms of cancer have yielded inconsistent results, thus failing to resolve the conflicting findings in animal models of cancer or in cancer cell lines (<a href="#R1169" rid="R1169" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919729">

7053Taylor, 1988</a>

7054; <a href="#R154" rid="R154" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920325">

7055Caplan and Brigham, 1990</a>

7056; <a href="#R634" rid="R634" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919438">

7057Kuijten et al., 1992</a>

7058; <a href="#R437" rid="R437" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920404">

7059Grufferman et al., 1993</a>

7060; <a href="#R1101" rid="R1101" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919539">

7061Sidney et al., 1997</a>

7062; <a href="#R45" rid="R45" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920127">

7063Barsky et al., 1998</a>

7064; <a href="#R1319" rid="R1319" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919908">

7065Zhang et al., 1999</a>

7066; <a href="#R292" rid="R292" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919144">

7067Efird et al., 2004</a>

7068; <a href="#R699" rid="R699" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918721">

7069Llewellyn et al., 2004</a>

7070; <a href="#R1038" rid="R1038" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918851">

7071Rosenblatt et al., 2004</a>

7072; reviewed in <a href="#R454" rid="R454" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919723">

7073Hall et al., 2005</a>

7074). The variability of the effects of cannabinoids in different tumor models may be related to the differential expression of CB<sub>

70751</sub>

7076 and CB<sub>

70772</sub>

7078 receptors. Thus, cannabinoids may be effective in killing tumors that abundantly express cannabinoid receptors, such as gliomas, but may increase the growth and metastasis of other types of tumors, such as breast cancer, with no or low expression of cannabinoid receptors, due to the suppression of the antitumor immune response (<a href="#R799" rid="R799" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919345">

7079McKallip et al., 2005</a>

7080). Nevertheless, the majority of the findings to date are encouraging and suggest that cannabinoids may be useful not only as palliative therapy but also because of their ability to inhibit tumor growth and metastasis.</p>

7081</div>

7082<div id="S43" class="sec">

7083<h3 id="S43title">

7084G. Gastrointestinal and Liver Disorders</h3>

7085<p id="P190" class="p p-first">

7086Cannabis has been used empirically for centuries to stimulate appetite and decrease emesis and diarrhea. Recent evidence indicates that the endocannabinoid system plays an important role in the control of gastrointestinal motility and secretion both under physiological conditions and in various gastrointestinal disorders (reviewed in <a href="#R955" rid="R955" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918949">

7087Pertwee, 2001</a>

7088; <a href="#R970" rid="R970" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653500">

7089Pinto et al., 2002a</a>

7090,<a href="#R971" rid="R971" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920137">

7091b</a>

7092; <a href="#R269" rid="R269" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653504">

7093Di Carlo and Izzo, 2003</a>

7094; <a href="#R217" rid="R217" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919948">

7095Coutts and Izzo, 2004</a>

7096; <a href="#R288" rid="R288" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918728">

7097Duncan et al., 2005</a>

7098; <a href="#R776" rid="R776" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919900">

7099Massa et al., 2005</a>

7100). Unexpectedly, recent data also implicate endocannabinoids and their receptors in several aspects of acute and chronic liver disease, including hemodynamic changes, modulation of inflammatory processes, fibrosis, and altered brain function (reviewed in <a href="#R353" rid="R353" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920307">

7101Gabbay et al., 2005</a>

7102; <a href="#R561" rid="R561" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919129">

7103Jimenez, 2005</a>

7104).</p>

7105<p id="P191">

7106Numerous studies using autoradiography, immunohistochemistry, and/or reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction demonstrated colocalization of CB<sub>

71071</sub>

7108 receptors with cholinergic neurons across the enteric nervous system, including sensory and interneuronal as well as motoneural cell bodies of the myenteric plexus, in mice (<a href="#R772" rid="R772" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919657">

7109Mascolo et al., 2002</a>

7110; <a href="#R970" rid="R970" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653450">

7111Pinto et al., 2002a</a>

7112,<a href="#R971" rid="R971" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920231">

7113b</a>

7114; <a href="#R162" rid="R162" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919397">

7115Casu et al., 2003</a>

7116; <a href="#R546" rid="R546" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920258">

7117Izzo et al., 2003</a>

7118; <a href="#R1143" rid="R1143" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653447">

7119Storr et al., 2004</a>

7120), rats (<a href="#R7" rid="R7" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920161">

7121Adami et al., 2002</a>

7122; <a href="#R216" rid="R216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920178">

7123Coutts et al., 2002</a>

7124; <a href="#R1142" rid="R1142" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919666">

7125Storr et al., 2002</a>

7126; <a href="#R131" rid="R131" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637245">

7127Burdyga et al., 2004</a>

7128), guinea-pigs (<a href="#R216" rid="R216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920098">

7129Coutts et al., 2002</a>
