7130; <a href="#R729" rid="R729" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653514">

7131MacNaughton et al., 2004</a>

7132), and pigs (<a href="#R635" rid="R635" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918882">

7133Kulkarni-Narla and Brown, 2000</a>

7134). CB<sub>

71351</sub>

7136 receptors are also colocalized with neuropeptide Y and vasoactive intestinal peptide in a small population of submucous plexus neurons (<a href="#R635" rid="R635" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920288">

7137Kulkarni-Narla and Brown, 2000</a>

7138; <a href="#R216" rid="R216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918887">

7139Coutts et al., 2002</a>

7140). CB<sub>

71411</sub>

7142 receptor immunoreactivity was evident in normal human colonic epithelium, smooth muscle, and the sub-mucosal myenteric plexus (<a href="#R1302" rid="R1302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920087">

7143Wright et al., 2005</a>

7144). Both CB<sub>

71451</sub>

7146 and CB<sub>

71472</sub>

7148 receptors were found on plasma cells in the lamina propria, whereas only CB<sub>

71492</sub>

7150 were detectable on macrophages (<a href="#R1302" rid="R1302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920337">

7151Wright et al., 2005</a>

7152). Endocannabinoids are also present in the gastrointestinal tact. Indeed, 2-AG was originally isolated from gut tissue (<a href="#R805" rid="R805" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920093">

7153Mechoulam et al., 1995</a>

7154), and the intestinal content of anandamide was found to be regulated by feeding status (<a href="#R410" rid="R410" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_814637247">

7155Gomez et al., 2002</a>

7156).</p>

7157<p id="P192">

7158Although in earlier studies CB<sub>

71591</sub>

7160 receptor expression was undetectable in the liver relative to the brain (<a href="#R979" rid="R979" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919992">

7161Porcella et al., 2002</a>

7162), several recent studies revealed the presence of low levels of both CB<sub>

71631</sub>

7164 mRNA (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920385">

7165B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7166; <a href="#R830" rid="R830" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919837">

7167Michalopoulos et al., 2003</a>

7168; <a href="#R81" rid="R81" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918907">

7169Biecker et al., 2004</a>

7170; <a href="#R302" rid="R302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919407">

7171Engeli et al., 2005</a>

7172; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918804">

7173Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

7174; <a href="#R1171" rid="R1171" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919053">

7175Teixeira-Clerc et al., 2006</a>

7176) and CB<sub>

71771</sub>

7178 immunoreactivity (<a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918892">

7179Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

7180) in whole liver or in various types of cells present in the liver, including hepatocytes (<a href="#R830" rid="R830" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919502">

7181Michalopoulos et al., 2003</a>

7182; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919269">

7183Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

7184), stellate cells (<a href="#R1103" rid="R1103" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919623">

7185Siegmund et al., 2005</a>

7186; <a href="#R1171" rid="R1171" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920104">

7187Teixeira-Clerc et al., 2006</a>

7188), and vascular endothelial cells (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918871">

7189B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7190). CB<sub>

71912</sub>

7192 receptor mRNA was also detected in cirrhotic but not in normal liver tissue (<a href="#R577" rid="R577" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919062">

7193Julien et al., 2005</a>

7194). Endocannabinoids are detectable in the liver or liver cells both in animals and humans at levels similar to those in the brain and play an important role under various physiological and pathophysiological conditions (<a href="#R225" rid="R225" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919482">

7195Cravatt et al., 2004</a>

7196; <a href="#R639" rid="R639" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919722">

7197Kurabayashi et al., 2005</a>

7198; <a href="#R915" rid="R915" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920253">

7199Osei-Hyiaman et al., 2005b</a>

7200) (see also section III.A.3.).</p>

7201<p id="P193">

7202A functional role for endocannabinoids and CB<sub>

72031</sub>

7204 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract is supported by pharmacological studies demonstrating that anandamide and various CB<sub>

72051</sub>

7206 agonists (WIN 55,212-2, CP55,940, and ACEA) but not the CB<sub>

72072</sub>

7208-selective agonists JWH-133 inhibit gastrointestinal motility in rodents in vivo and in isolated ileum and colon from both experimental animals and humans (<a href="#R1098" rid="R1098" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919272">

7209Shook and Burks, 1989</a>

7210; <a href="#R961" rid="R961" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919303">

7211Pertwee et al., 1995</a>

7212, <a href="#R962" rid="R962" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919607">

72131996</a>

7214; <a href="#R218" rid="R218" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918833">

7215Coutts and Pertwee, 1997</a>

7216; <a href="#R789" rid="R789" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920223">

7217McCallum et al., 1999</a>

7218; <a href="#R743" rid="R743" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920237">

7219Mancinelli et al., 2001</a>

7220; <a href="#R745" rid="R745" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919423">

7221Mang et al., 2001</a>

7222; <a href="#R650" rid="R650" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919749">

7223Landi et al., 2002</a>

7224; <a href="#R742" rid="R742" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919589">

7225Manara et al., 2002</a>

7226; <a href="#R503" rid="R503" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919011">

7227Hinds et al., 2006</a>

7228). A similar role for endogenous substrates of FAAH is suggested by recent in vivo findings in mice, documenting inhibition of intestinal motility by the FAAH inhibitors <em>

7229N</em>

7230-arachidonoylserotonin and palmitoyliso-propylamide and by the FAAH substrates palmitoylethanolamide, oleamide, and oleoylethanolamide in wild-type but not in FAAH knockout mice (<a href="#R153" rid="R153" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919006">

7231Capasso et al., 2005</a>

7232). Furthermore, the effect of <em>

7233N</em>

7234-arachidonoylserotonin was reduced either by the CB<sub>

72351</sub>

7236 receptor antagonist SR141716 or by CB<sub>

72371</sub>

7238 deficiency, but not by the TRPV<sub>

72391</sub>

7240 receptor antagonist 5&#x02032;-iodoresiniferatoxin (<a href="#R153" rid="R153" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918830">

7241Capasso et al., 2005</a>

7242). Interestingly, in clinical trials using rimonabant for nicotine cessation or for the treatment of obesity, diarrhea was 2 to 2.4 times more frequent among subjects treated with the drug than with placebo, suggesting accelerated transit and/or enhanced secretion caused by CB<sub>

72431</sub>

7244 blockade (<a href="#R319" rid="R319" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653473">

7245Fernandez and Allison, 2004</a>

7246; <a href="#R1216" rid="R1216" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920209">

7247Van Gaal et al., 2005</a>

7248). This and some of the above experimental reports suggest the existence of an inhibitory endocannabinoid tone in the gastrointestinal tract. Multiple mechanisms, including reduction of acetylcholine release from enteric nerves, inhibition of nonadrenergic/noncholinergic excitatory transmission, activation of apamin-sensitive K<sup>

7249+</sup>

7250 channels, and modulation of adenosine release have been proposed to explain the CB<sub>

72511</sub>

7252-mediated reduction in enteric contractility and peristalsis (reviewed in <a href="#R217" rid="R217" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919668">

7253Coutts and Izzo, 2004</a>

7254).</p>

7255<p id="P194">

7256Activation of both CB<sub>

72571</sub>

7258 and CB<sub>

72592</sub>

7260 receptors may decrease the pathologically increased intestinal motility elicited by an inflammatory stimulus. In a mouse model of croton oil-induced intestinal inflammation, the increased efficacy of cannabinoids in inhibiting intestinal motility was attributed to up-regulation of intestinal CB<sub>

72611</sub>

7262 receptors (<a href="#R547" rid="R547" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918780">

7263Izzo et al., 2001a</a>

7264,<a href="#R548" rid="R548" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919878">

7265b</a>

7266). Conversely, the accelerated gastrointestinal transit induced by bacterial endotoxin in rats could be inhibited by CB<sub>

72672</sub>

7268 but not CB<sub>

72691</sub>

7270 receptor agonists (<a href="#R778" rid="R778" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920149">

7271Mathison et al., 2004</a>

7272). Interestingly, intestinal hypomotility in a mouse model of paralytic ileus has been linked, at least in part, to the enhancement of anandamide levels and CB<sub>

72731</sub>

7274 expression in the gut, and it could be attenuated by CB<sub>

72751</sub>

7276 receptor antagonists (<a href="#R772" rid="R772" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919531">

7277Mascolo et al., 2002</a>

7278). Additionally, there is evidence that CB<sub>

72791</sub>

7280 receptors are involved in the regulation of the lower esophageal sphincter, and CB<sub>

72811</sub>

7282 activation might be beneficial in gastroesophageal reflux disease (reviewed in <a href="#R217" rid="R217" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920018">

7283Coutts and Izzo, 2004</a>

7284; <a href="#R776" rid="R776" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920081">

7285Massa et al., 2005</a>

7286).</p>

7287<p id="P195" class="p">

7288The endocannabinoid system has also been implicated in the regulation of gastric acid and intestinal secretions. At high doses, THC decreased histamine-induced gastric acid secretion in isolated stomach preparations (<a href="#R1022" rid="R1022" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919860">

7289Rivas-V and Garcia, 1980</a>

7290) and in pylorus-ligated rats (<a href="#R1122" rid="R1122" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919050">

7291Sofia et al., 1978</a>

7292). Pentagastrin-induced gastric acid secretion was also inhibited by HU-210 and WIN 55,212-2, an effect that could be prevented by CB<sub>

72931</sub>

7294 blockade (<a href="#R211" rid="R211" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653367">

7295Coruzzi et al., 1999</a>

7296; <a href="#R7" rid="R7" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919814">

7297Adami et al., 2002</a>

7298). These studies suggest a role for CB<sub>

72991</sub>

7300 receptors located on preganglionic and postganglionic cholinergic pathways in the regulation of gastric acid secretion. The therapeutic relevance of this regulatory mechanism was highlighted by the CB<sub>

73011</sub>

7302 receptor-mediated antiulcer activity of ACEA or WIN 55,212-2 treatment in a rat model of aspirin- and cold/restraint stress-induced gastric ulcers (<a href="#R383" rid="R383" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653507">

7303Germano et al., 2001</a>

7304; <a href="#R1052" rid="R1052" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653479">

7305Rutkowska and Fereniec-Goltbiewska, 2006</a>

7306). WIN 55,212-2 also reduced intestinal secretions evoked by electrical field stimulation or capsaicin (<a href="#R729" rid="R729" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653373">

7307MacNaughton et al., 2004</a>

7308). Anandamide, the anandamide transport inhibitor VDM11, and the CB<sub>

73091</sub>

7310 agonist ACEA all inhibited intestinal secretion and fluid accumulation in mice treated with cholera toxin, whereas SR141716 exerted opposite effects (<a href="#R546" rid="R546" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919947">

7311Izzo et al., 2003</a>

7312). The ability of cannabinoids to inhibit gastrointestinal motility and secretion coupled with their anti-inflammatory properties strongly suggests that the modulation of this system could offer significant benefits in the treatment of various gastrointestinal pathological conditions, including inflammatory bowel disease (see below).</p>

7313<div id="S44" class="sec">

7314<p>

7315</p>

7316<h4 id="S44title" class="inline">

73171. Inflammatory Bowel Disease </h4>

7318<p id="P196" class="p p-first">

7319Idiopathic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) includes ulcerative colitis and Crohn&#x02019;s disease, and is characterized by intestinal inflammation presumably of autoimmune origin and a chronic relapsing course associated with local and systemic complications and affects &#x0003e;1 million people in the United States (<a href="#R700" rid="R700" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919598">

7320Loftus, 2004</a>

7321). Although the etiology of IBD remains unclear, it may involve complex genetic, environmental, and immunological interactions. The most common symptoms of IBD are abdominal pain and diarrhea, which eventually lead to malabsorption and malnutrition, and in approximately half of patients surgery is eventually required to remove the affected bowel segment. Despite recent therapeutic advances, patients with IBD are often unresponsive to available treatment options.</p>

7322<p id="P197">

7323As discussed above, the endocannabinoid system plays an important role in the control of gastrointestinal motility and secretion. Studies using animal models of IBD have suggested that targeting the endocannabinoid system may offer significant benefits in the treatment of IBD. Several studies have indicated that chemically induced intestinal inflammation is associated with the up-regulation of intestinal CB<sub>

73241</sub>

7325 receptors, which may represent a compensatory, protective mechanism. For example, in croton oil-treated mice, the ability of CB<sub>

73261</sub>

7327 agonists to inhibit intestinal motility is increased compared with that in control animals (<a href="#R547" rid="R547" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920054">

7328Izzo et al., 2001a</a>

7329). More importantly, the anandamide transport inhibitor VDM11 was also shown to inhibit gastrointestinal motility and secretions in cholera toxin-treated mice, which implicates endocannabinoids in this action and holds out the promise of a nonpsychoactive form of treatment (<a href="#R546" rid="R546" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918971">

7330Izzo et al., 2003</a>

7331). In a mouse model of colitis induced by 2,4-dinitrobenzene sulfonic acid and dextrane sulfate, <a href="#R775" rid="R775" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919649">

7332Massa et al. (2004)</a>

7333 have confirmed the up-regulation of CB<sub>

73341</sub>

7335 receptors in experimental colitis. Furthermore, they demonstrated that the inflammation was more severe in mice deficient in CB<sub>

73361</sub>

7337 receptors than in wild-type mice, whereas genetic ablation of FAAH resulted in protection against this chemically induced colitis (<a href="#R775" rid="R775" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918729">

7338Massa et al., 2004</a>

7339). In a recent study, the anandamide reuptake inhibitor VDM11 afforded protection against colitis in mice, and elevated anandamide levels have been measured in biopsy material from patients with ulcerative colitis (<a href="#R240" rid="R240" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919800">

7340D&#x02019;Argenio et al., 2006</a>

7341). These findings strongly support the natural protective role of the endocannabinoid system in this form of experimental IBD. In contrast, <a href="#R228" rid="R228" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919067">

7342Croci et al. (2003)</a>

7343 have reported a CB<sub>

73441</sub>

7345 receptor-independent protective effect of SR141716 against indomethacin-induced inflammation and ulcer formation in the small intestine of rats. Elevated levels of anandamide and desensitization of the presynaptic neural CB<sub>

73461</sub>

7347 receptor found in colonic longitudinal muscle strips from patients undergoing surgery for complicated diverticulitis suggest that the endocannabinoid system may be also involved in the pathophysiology of this frequent complication of colitis and/or colon cancer (<a href="#R440" rid="R440" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920034">

7348Guagnini et al., 2006</a>

7349).</p>

7350<p id="P198" class="p p-last">

7351Taken together, most of the above studies suggest that the endocannabinoid system in the gut is activated during inflammation, and endogenous anandamide may counteract inflammation (<a href="#R638" rid="R638" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919178">

7352Kunos and Pacher, 2004</a>

7353) (<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F6/" target="figure" class="fig-table-link figpopup" rid-figpopup="F6" rid-ob="ob-F6" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F6">

7354<span>

7355Fig. 6</span>

7356</a>

7357). The findings of <a href="#R775" rid="R775" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920101">

7358Massa et al. (2004)</a>

7359 and <a href="#R240" rid="R240" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919769">

7360D&#x02019;Argenio et al. (2006)</a>

7361 also suggest that inhibitors of FAAH or anandamide reuptake may amplify the natural protective action of endogenous anandamide, which warrants further studies to test such inhibitors in the treatment of experimental and, ultimately, human IBD (<a href="#R638" rid="R638" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920059">

7362Kunos and Pacher, 2004</a>

7363). Future studies should further explore the mechanisms of the anti-inflammatory effects of cannabinoids and the potential role of CB<sub>

73642</sub>

7365 receptors as therapeutic targets (<a href="#R778" rid="R778" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918814">

7366Mathison et al., 2004</a>

7367; <a href="#R1302" rid="R1302" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919465">

7368Wright et al., 2005</a>

7369).</p>

7370<!--fig ft0-->

7371<!--fig mode=article f1-->

7372<div class="fig iconblock whole_rhythm" id="F6" co-legend-rid="lgnd_F6">

7373<a href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F6/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F6" rid-ob="ob-F6">

7374<!--fig/graphic|fig/alternatives/graphic mode="anchored" m1-->

7375<div data-largeobj="" data-largeobj-link-rid="largeobj_idm139779462199168" class="figure">

7376<img loading="lazy" class="fig-image" alt="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f6.jpg" title="An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc.&#10;Object name is nihms38123f6.jpg" src="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/bin/nihms38123f6.jpg" />

7377</div>

7378<div id="largeobj_idm139779462199168" class="largeobj-link align_right" style="display: none">

7379<a target="object" rel="noopener" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F6/?report=objectonly">

7380Open in a separate window</a>

7381</div>

7382</a>

7383<div class="icnblk_cntnt" id="lgnd_F6">

7384<div>

7385<a class="figpopup" href="/pmc/articles/PMC2241751/figure/F6/" target="figure" rid-figpopup="F6" rid-ob="ob-F6">

7386Fig. 6</a>

7387</div>

7388<!--caption a7-->

7389<div class="caption">

7390<p id="__p7">

7391Cellular source and proposed targets of anti-inflammatory endocannabinoids in inflammatory bowel disease. a, cross-section of inflamed bowel with leukocyte infiltration [polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PNM), lymphocytes (Ly), macrophages, and mast cells]. b, in macrophages, LPS induces the production of TNF-<em>

7392&#x003b1;</em>

7393 and chemokines (such as MIP-2macrophage inflammatory protein-2 and CXCL-8) as well as anandamide. Anandamide is released to act as an autocrine mediator to inhibit TNF-<em>

7394&#x003b1;</em>

7395 and chemokine production via CB<sub>

73961</sub>

7397 or CB<sub>

73982</sub>

7399 receptors or both. Activation of CB<sub>

74001</sub>

7401 and CB<sub>

74022</sub>

7403 receptors may similarly inhibit TNF-<em>

7404&#x003b1;</em>

7405 production in mast cells, with these effects resulting in decreased leukocyte infiltration and inflammation. Paracrine activation of CB<sub>

74061</sub>

7407 receptors on extrinsic and intrinsic enteric neurons inhibits acetylcholine (ACh) and tachykinin release, respectively, resulting in inhibition of gut motility. These effects are amplified by treatment with a FAAH inhibitor, which prevents the breakdown of anandamide. Reproduced with permission from <a href="#R638" rid="R638" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919080">

7408Kunos and Pacher (2004)</a>

7409 <em>

7410Nat Med</em>

7411 <strong>

741210:</strong>

7413678&#x02013;679. &#x000a9; Nature Publishing Group.</p>

7414</div>

7415</div>

7416</div>

7417</div>

7418<div id="S45" class="sec sec-last">

7419<p>

7420</p>

7421<h4 id="S45title" class="inline">

74222. Acute and Chronic Liver Disease (Hepatitis and Liver Cirrhosis) </h4>

7423<p id="P199" class="p p-first">

7424Endocannabinoids and CB<sub>

74251</sub>

7426 receptors have been implicated in the systemic and portal vasodilation and hypotension associated with chronic liver cirrhosis (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918759">

7427B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7428; <a href="#R362" rid="R362" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653483">

7429Garcia et al., 2001</a>

7430; <a href="#R1036" rid="R1036" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918867">

7431Ros et al., 2002</a>

7432). These studies demonstrated that CB<sub>

74331</sub>

7434 receptor blockade with SR141716 reversed the hypotension and low peripheral resistance and decreased the elevated mesenteric blood flow and portal pressure in rats with biliary and carbon tetrachloride-induced cirrhosis, whereas these hemodynamic parameters were unaffected by SR141716 in noncirrhotic control subjects (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919774">

7435B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7436; <a href="#R1036" rid="R1036" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919401">

7437Ros et al., 2002</a>

7438). These findings suggested an increased endocannabinoid tone in cirrhosis, which could be attributed to both an up-regulation of CB<sub>

74391</sub>

7440 receptors in hepatic vascular endothelial cells and an increased production of anandamide by circulating monocytes (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919737">

7441B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7442). Increased expression of CB<sub>

74431</sub>

7444 receptors was also reported in whole liver from bile duct-ligated mice (<a href="#R81" rid="R81" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919226">

7445Biecker et al., 2004</a>

7446). This increase was greater when bile duct ligation was performed in NO synthase-3 knockout compared with wild-type mice, which may account for the similar level of portal hypertension in the two strains despite the much higher systemic blood pressure in the knockout mice (<a href="#R81" rid="R81" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919248">

7447Biecker et al., 2004</a>

7448). Increased anandamide-induced vasorelaxation mediated by CB<sub>

74491</sub>

7450 and TRPV<sub>

74511</sub>

7452 receptors was also reported in mesenteric arteries isolated from cirrhotic compared with control rats (<a href="#R280" rid="R280" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918915">

7453Domenicali et al., 2005</a>

7454). The increase in anandamide in monocytes from cirrhotic rats or humans is functionally important, as these cells elicit SR141716-sensitive hypotension when injected into normal recipient rats (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918758">

7455B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7456; <a href="#R1036" rid="R1036" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920141">

7457Ros et al., 2002</a>

7458). Plasma endotoxin levels progressively increase as liver function deteriorates in cirrhosis (<a href="#R710" rid="R710" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918843">

7459Lumsden et al., 1988</a>

7460; <a href="#R167" rid="R167" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918684">

7461Chan et al., 1997</a>

7462), and this effect is probably responsible for the elevated endocannabinoid production in plasma monocytes and platelets of cirrhotic animals and patients (<a href="#R50" rid="R50" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920166">

7463B&#x000e1;tkai et al., 2001</a>

7464; <a href="#R1036" rid="R1036" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919179">

7465Ros et al., 2002</a>

7466; <a href="#R693" rid="R693" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918697">

7467Liu et al., 2003</a>

7468; <a href="#R321" rid="R321" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919008">

7469Fernandez-Rodriguez et al., 2004</a>

7470). There is also recent experimental evidence implicating increased signaling through myocardial CB<sub>

74711</sub>

7472 receptors in the pathogenesis of cirrhotic cardiomyopathy (<a href="#R370" rid="R370" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919567">

7473Gaskari et al., 2005</a>

7474; <a href="#R924" rid="R924" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920197">

7475Pacher et al., 2005c</a>

7476).</p>

7477<p id="P200">

7478Beyond the vasculopathy of end-stage cirrhosis, the endocannabinoid system may also be involved in the pathogenesis of liver fibrosis. <a href="#R1103" rid="R1103" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920406">

7479Siegmund et al. (2005)</a>

7480 have recently reported that anandamide exerts antifibrogenic effects in vitro by inhibiting activated hepatic stellate cells at low micromolar concentrations and by inducing their necrosis at higher concentrations, via CB<sub>

74811/2</sub>

7482- and TRPV<sub>

74831</sub>

7484-independent mechanism(s). In a study by <a href="#R577" rid="R577" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919440">

7485Julien et al. (2005)</a>

7486, the liver fibrosis induced by carbon tetrachloride was more severe in CB<sub>

74872</sub>

7488 knockout mice compared with their wild-type littermates. Also, the expression of CB<sub>

74892</sub>

7490 receptors was found to be strongly induced in liver biopsy specimens from patients with active cirrhosis of various etiologies, particularly in non-parenchymal cells located within and at the edge of fibrous septa (<a href="#R577" rid="R577" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919550">

7491Julien et al., 2005</a>

7492). Furthermore, CB<sub>

74932</sub>

7494 receptor activation triggered growth inhibition and apoptosis in myofibroblasts and in activated hepatic stellate cells, highlighting the antifibrogenic role of CB<sub>

74952</sub>

7496 receptors during chronic liver injury (<a href="#R577" rid="R577" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919208">

7497Julien et al., 2005</a>

7498). However, chronic marijuana use has been associated with hepatotoxicity rather than hepatoprotection as expected from the above results (<a href="#R107" rid="R107" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919223">

7499Borini et al., 2004</a>

7500), and results of a recent epidemiological study indicate that daily marijuana smoking is a risk factor for progression of fibrosis among people with chronic hepatitis C infection (<a href="#R491" rid="R491" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919119">

7501Hezode et al., 2005</a>

7502). This finding has triggered an investigation into the possible profibrogenic role of CB<sub>

75031</sub>

7504 receptor activation, which is supported by the results of a preliminary study showing that the progression of experimental liver fibrosis induced by carbon tetrachloride is slower in mice with genetic ablation of CB<sub>

75051</sub>

7506 receptors or treated with CB<sub>

75071</sub>

7508 receptor antagonist SR141716 (<a href="#R1171" rid="R1171" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918947">

7509Teixeira-Clerc et al., 2006</a>

7510). These latter findings suggest a broader role of CB<sub>

75111</sub>

7512 receptors in the pathogenesis of cirrhosis and forecast additional potential benefits from the therapeutic use of a CB<sub>

75131</sub>

7514 antagonist in chronic liver disease.</p>

7515<p id="P201">

7516In contrast to the hepatotoxicity associated with chronic marijuana use, a synthetic, nonpsychotropic cannabinoid derivative (PRS-211,092) was reported to inhibit acute hepatitis induced by concanavalin A via negative cytokine regulation in mice (<a href="#R664" rid="R664" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920138">

7517Lavon et al., 2003</a>

7518). Interestingly, in animal models of acute hepatic failure-induced encephalopathy, both 2-AG and SR141716 have been reported to exert beneficial effects on neurological and cognitive function (<a href="#R353" rid="R353" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919938">

7519Gabbay et al., 2005</a>

7520; <a href="#R32" rid="R32" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919761">

7521Avraham et al., 2006</a>

7522). Cannabinoids may also be beneficial in intractable cholestatic pruritus (<a href="#R882" rid="R882" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920167">

7523Neff et al., 2002</a>

7524), which is associated with severe forms of liver disease, presumably by increasing the nociceptive threshold (<a href="#R388" rid="R388" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919551">

7525Gingold and Bergasa, 2003</a>

7526).</p>

7527<p id="P202" class="p p-last">

7528Collectively, the studies discussed in this section highlight the potential regulatory role of the endocannabinoid system in a variety of gastrointestinal and liver disorders, opening new avenues for their pharmacotherapy. It appears that CB<sub>

75291</sub>

7530 agonists and perhaps FAAH antagonists might be beneficial in reducing increased gastrointestinal motility, bowel inflammation, and associated diarrhea, whereas CB<sub>

75311</sub>

7532 antagonists could be used in the treatment of constipation. In chronic liver cirrhosis, CB<sub>

75331</sub>

7534 antagonists may not only attenuate or reverse the adverse hemodynamic consequences of cirrhosis, thus extending life until a suitable liver becomes available for transplantation, but also could have additional benefits by slowing the progression of fibrosis and the neurological decline associated with hepatic encephalopathy. Selective CB<sub>

75352</sub>

7536 receptor agonists might also be expected to protect against progression of liver fibrosis and perhaps against the chronic inflammation associated with IBD.</p>

7537</div>

7538</div>

7539<div id="S46" class="sec">

7540<h3 id="S46title">

7541H. Musculoskeletal Disorders</h3>

7542<div id="S47" class="sec sec-first">

7543<p>

7544</p>

7545<h4 id="S47title" class="inline">

75461. Arthritis </h4>

7547<p id="P203" class="p p-first">

7548Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic, inflammatory autoimmune disease affecting ~0.8% of adults worldwide. RA is more common in women, and it leads to joint destruction, deformity, loss of function, chronic pain, and reduced quality of life. When unchecked, it leads to substantial disability and premature death (<a href="#R902" rid="R902" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920028">

7549O&#x02019;Dell, 2004</a>

7550). Current medications used to treat rheumatoid arthritis are divided into three main classes: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, corticosteroids, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs such as methotrexate (<a href="#R902" rid="R902" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919535">

7551O&#x02019;Dell, 2004</a>

7552). A better understanding of the cytokine networks that are responsible for the ongoing inflammatory response in RA has led to the successful use of novel therapies that target TNF-<em>

7553&#x003b1;</em>

7554 and IL-1.</p>

7555<p id="P204">

7556The immunosuppressant and anti-inflammatory properties of cannabinoids are highly relevant for RA and other autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, autoimmune vasculitis, Sj&#x000f6;gren&#x02019;s syndrome, and ankylosing spondylitis). Indeed, ajulemic acid (THC-11-oic acid, CT-3, IP-751), a potent analog of the acid metabolites of THC (<a href="#R135" rid="R135" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918985">

7557Burstein, 2000</a>

7558, <a href="#R134" rid="R134" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919875">

75592005</a>

7560) and cannabidiol have been shown to have analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and immunosuppressive effects in animal models of arthritis (<a href="#R1330" rid="R1330" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919507">

7561Zurier et al., 1998</a>

7562; <a href="#R237" rid="R237" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918888">

7563Dajani et al., 1999</a>

7564; <a href="#R738" rid="R738" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918764">

7565Malfait et al., 2000</a>

7566). Chronic administration of ajulemic acid attenuated joint inflammation in a murine model of adjuvant-induced arthritis and suppressed prostaglandin production in vitro to a greater extent than the potent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, indomethacin (<a href="#R1330" rid="R1330" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919305">

7567Zurier et al., 1998</a>

7568). In another study, ajulemic acid caused less gastrointestinal ulcerations and was more effective in reducing adjuvant-induced arthritis than common nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents (<a href="#R237" rid="R237" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919278">

7569Dajani et al., 1999</a>

7570). As discussed earlier in this review, ajulemic acid is a high-affinity agonist for human cannabinoid receptors and has CB<sub>

75711</sub>

7572-mediated, potent antihyperalgesic activity in models of chronic neuropathic and inflammatory pain in the rat (<a href="#R290" rid="R290" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919200">

7573Dyson et al., 2005</a>

7574). Ajulemic acid also induces apoptosis in human T lymphocytes (<a href="#R80" rid="R80" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918976">

7575Bidinger et al., 2003</a>

7576) and suppresses IL-1<em>

7577&#x003b2;</em>

7578 production in human monocytes (<a href="#R1329" rid="R1329" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919543">

7579Zurier et al., 2003</a>

7580), which could contribute to its therapeutic effects in RA and other inflammatory disorders. Treatment with cannabidiol or its more potent dimethylheptyl derivative (HU-320) reduced an LPS-induced increase in serum TNF-<em>

7581&#x003b1;</em>

7582 and immune function and effectively blocked the progression of collagen-induced arthritis in mice (<a href="#R738" rid="R738" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918723">

7583Malfait et al., 2000</a>

7584; <a href="#R1152" rid="R1152" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918855">

7585Sumariwalla et al., 2004</a>

7586). Other studies described the antinociceptive effects of anandamide and THC in rats with arthritis (<a href="#R1123" rid="R1123" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919260">

7587Sofia et al., 1973</a>

7588; <a href="#R1116" rid="R1116" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919681">

7589Smith et al., 1998</a>

7590; <a href="#R219" rid="R219" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919789">

7591Cox and Welch, 2004</a>

7592). <a href="#R786" rid="R786" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920361">

7593Mbvundula et al. (2005</a>

7594, <a href="#R787" rid="R787" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919352">

75952006)</a>

7596 have recently reported that WIN 55,212-2 and HU-210 inhibited IL-1-stimulated NO production in bovine articular chondrocytes, in contrast to AM281 and AM630, which elicited an opposite effect. Anandamide, WIN 55212-2, and HU-210 also inhibited the release of sulfated glycosaminoglycans in bovine cartilage explants and IL-1a stimulated proteoglycan and collagen degradation (<a href="#R786" rid="R786" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919931">

7597Mbvundula et al., 2005</a>

7598, <a href="#R787" rid="R787" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919327">

75992006</a>

7600).</p>

7601<p id="P205" class="p p-last">

7602In a survey of 2969 people using cannabis for medicinal purposes, ~25% of subjects mentioned relief of arthritis symptoms as the main reason for cannabis smoking, which was surpassed only by chronic pain, MS, and depression (<a href="#R1274" rid="R1274" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918837">

7603Ware et al., 2003</a>

7604). Studies using cannabinoid-based extracts are also underway in patients with RA (<a href="#R1050" rid="R1050" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919137">

7605Russo, 2006</a>

7606). The potential benefit of cannabinoids in fibromyalgia, a syndrome of widespread musculoskeletal pain, nonrestorative sleep, disturbed mood, and fatigue of unknown etiology, has also been reviewed (<a href="#R1051" rid="R1051" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918693">

7607Russo, 2004</a>

7608).</p>

7609</div>

7610<div id="S48" class="sec sec-last">

7611<p>

7612</p>

7613<h4 id="S48title" class="inline">

76142. Osteoporosis </h4>

7615<p id="P206" class="p p-first">

7616Osteoporosis is a skeletal disorder characterized by low bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration of bone, leading to increased susceptibility to bone fractures. The associated fractures and the subsequent morbidity and mortality make osteoporosis an enormous public health concern. Osteoporosis is no longer considered an age-related disease, as it is increasingly recognized in children. Osteoporosis is thought to be a polygenic disorder, with vulnerability determined by multiple genes and environmental risk factors. It currently affects up to one in three women and 1 in 12 men worldwide (<a href="#R594" rid="R594" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919743">

7617Keen, 2003</a>

7618). Treatment options include general measures on lifestyle, calcium and vitamin D supplements, hormone therapy, raloxifene, and bisphosphonates.</p>

7619<p id="P207">

7620Cannabinoid receptors were first implicated in the regulation of bone mass by <a href="#R587" rid="R587" class=" bibr popnode">

7621Karsak et al. (2004)</a>

7622, who found that CB<sub>

76232</sub>

7624 knockout mice had markedly accelerated age-related trabecular bone loss and cortical expansion accompanied by increased activity of trabecular osteoblasts, increased numbers of osteoclasts, and decreased numbers of diaphyseal osteoblast precursors (<a href="#R903" rid="R903" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920058">

7625Ofek et al., 2006</a>

7626). CB<sub>

76272</sub>

7628 receptors were expressed in osteoblasts, osteocytes, and osteoclasts. The selective CB<sub>

76292</sub>

7630 agonist HU-308, but not the CB<sub>

76311</sub>

7632 agonist noladine ether, attenuated ovariectomy-induced bone loss and markedly stimulated cortical thickness through the suppression of osteoclast number and stimulation of endocortical bone formation (<a href="#R903" rid="R903" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918929">

7633Ofek et al., 2006</a>

7634). Furthermore, HU-308 dose dependently increased the number and activity of endocortical osteoblasts and restrained trabecular osteoclastogenesis by inhibiting proliferation of osteoclast precursors (<a href="#R903" rid="R903" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919235">

7635Ofek et al., 2006</a>

7636). These results, coupled with CB<sub>

76372</sub>

7638 but not CB<sub>

76391</sub>

7640 receptor mRNA expression during osteoblastic differentiation, suggested a role for CB<sub>

76412</sub>

7642 receptors in bone remodeling. Such a role of CB<sub>

76432</sub>

7644 but not CB<sub>

76451</sub>

7646 receptors is also supported by a recent genetic association study in human samples of postmenopausal osteoporosis patients and matched female control subjects (<a href="#R586" rid="R586" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919770">

7647Karsak et al., 2005</a>

7648).</p>

7649<p id="P208" class="p p-last">

7650In contrast, <a href="#R537" rid="R537" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918865">

7651Idris et al. (2005)</a>

7652 have recently reported that CB<sub>

76531</sub>

7654 receptor knockout mice or mice treated with antagonists of either CB<sub>

76551</sub>

7656 or CB<sub>

76572</sub>

7658 receptors were protected from ovariectomy-induced bone loss. Furthermore, cannabinoid antagonists promoted osteoclast apoptosis, inhibited osteoclast activity, and decreased the production of several osteoclast survival factors in vitro, suggesting that cannabinoid antagonists may be beneficial in the treatment of osteoporosis. Although the reason for the discrepancy between the above studies is not clear; they suggest a role for the endocannabinoid system in the regulation of bone mass.</p>

7659</div>

7660</div>

7661<div id="S49" class="sec sec-last">

7662<h3 id="S49title">

7663I. Endocannabinoids and Reproductive Functions</h3>

7664<p id="P209" class="p p-first">

7665There is abundant evidence that the endocannabinoid system is involved in reproductive functions in both males and females and in both animals and humans, as discussed in more detail in recent reviews (<a href="#R346" rid="R346" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920352">

7666Fride, 2004</a>

7667; <a href="#R939" rid="R939" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653428">

7668Park et al., 2004</a>

7669; <a href="#R1081" rid="R1081" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918963">

7670Schuel and Burkman, 2005</a>

7671; <a href="#R1187" rid="R1187" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918757">

7672Tranguch et al., 2005</a>

7673; <a href="#R1264" rid="R1264" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_393488952">

7674Wang et al., 2006</a>

7675). In males, marijuana, synthetic cannabinoids, and anandamide adversely affect the fertilizing capacity of sperm, which express functional CB<sub>

76761</sub>

7677 receptors (<a href="#R1041" rid="R1041" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918726">

7678Rossato et al., 2005</a>

7679; <a href="#R1081" rid="R1081" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918823">

7680Schuel and Burkman, 2005</a>

7681; <a href="#R1283" rid="R1283" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919259">

7682Whan et al., 2006</a>

7683). On the other hand, there is preclinical evidence to suggest that blockade of CB<sub>

76841</sub>

7685 may be useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (<a href="#R818" rid="R818" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919439">

7686Melis et al., 2004b</a>

7687, <a href="#R819" rid="R819" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918683">

76882006</a>

7689).</p>

7690<p id="P210" class="p p-last">

7691High levels of functional CB<sub>

76921</sub>

7693 receptor, anandamide, and FAAH are present in the preimplantation embryo and/or in the uterus (<a href="#R243" rid="R243" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918808">

7694Das et al., 1995</a>

7695; <a href="#R934" rid="R934" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919848">

7696Paria et al., 1995</a>

7697, <a href="#R935" rid="R935" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919132">

76982001</a>

7699; <a href="#R1076" rid="R1076" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919713">

7700Schmid et al., 1997</a>

7701; <a href="#R938" rid="R938" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919929">

7702Park et al., 2003</a>

7703; <a href="#R447" rid="R447" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918885">

7704Guo et al., 2005</a>

7705). Anandamide synthesized in the uterus exerts dose- and stage-specific effects on embryo development and implantation. A temporary reduction of anandamide levels is essential for embryo implantation, and higher anandamide levels are associated with uterine nonreceptivity and impairment of blastocyst formation, zona hatching, and trophoblast outgrowth via CB<sub>

77061</sub>

7707 receptors (<a href="#R243" rid="R243" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918959">

7708Das et al., 1995</a>

7709; <a href="#R934" rid="R934" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919840">

7710Paria et al., 1995</a>

7711, <a href="#R935" rid="R935" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919708">

77122001</a>

7713, <a href="#R936" rid="R936" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919150">

77142002</a>

7715; <a href="#R1076" rid="R1076" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919504">

7716Schmid et al., 1997</a>

7717; <a href="#R1266" rid="R1266" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919353">

7718Wang et al., 1999</a>

7719; <a href="#R447" rid="R447" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919015">

7720Guo et al., 2005</a>

7721). Consequently, cannabinoids may retard the development of embryos, eventually leading to fetal loss and pregnancy failure (<a href="#R99" rid="R99" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918771">

7722Bloch et al., 1978</a>

7723; <a href="#R1115" rid="R1115" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144920395">

7724Smith and Asch, 1987</a>

7725; <a href="#R939" rid="R939" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653370">

7726Park et al., 2004</a>

7727). Anandamide levels in the uterus are regulated by FAAH activity (<a href="#R934" rid="R934" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918768">

7728Paria et al., 1995</a>

7729, <a href="#R937" rid="R937" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918962">

77301999</a>

7731; <a href="#R1076" rid="R1076" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919526">

7732Schmid et al., 1997</a>

7733). Accordingly, pregnant women with low FAAH activity in lymphocytes were found to have an increased incidence of miscarriage (<a href="#R723" rid="R723" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918889">

7734Maccarrone et al., 2000c</a>

7735), and low FAAH activity also correlated with failure to maintain pregnancy after in vitro fertilization (<a href="#R719" rid="R719" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919333">

7736Maccarrone et al., 2002b</a>

7737). Finally, cannabinoids may also affect the levels of various hormones crucial for normal fertility and reproduction (<a href="#R126" rid="R126" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919501">

7738Brown and Dobs, 2002</a>

7739; <a href="#R939" rid="R939" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_311653506">

7740Park et al., 2004</a>

7741; <a href="#R1082" rid="R1082" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919511">

7742Scorticati et al., 2004</a>

7743; <a href="#R360" rid="R360" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144918896">

7744Gammon et al., 2005</a>

7745). Although such findings may suggest the potential usefulness of CB<sub>

77461</sub>

7747 antagonists in the treatment of infertility problems, a note of caution is warranted because CB<sub>

77481</sub>

7749 knockout mice were reported to have impaired oviductal transport of embryos, leading to embryo retention. This suggests that treatment with CB<sub>

77501</sub>

7751 antagonists may facilitate ectopic pregnancy (<a href="#R1265" rid="R1265" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919147">

7752Wang et al., 2004</a>

7753).</p>

7754</div>

7755</div>

7756<div id="S50" class="tsec sec">

7757<h2 class="head no_bottom_margin" id="S50title">

7758IV. Future Directions</h2>

7759<p id="P211" class="p p-first-last">

7760The length of this review, necessitated by the steady growth in the number of indications for the potential therapeutic use of cannabinoid-related medications, is a clear sign of the emerging importance of this field. This is further underlined by the quantity of articles in the public database dealing with the biology of cannabinoids, which numbered ~200 to 300/year throughout the 1970s to reach an astonishing 5900 in 2004. The growing interest in the underlying science has been matched by a growth in the number of cannabinoid drugs in pharmaceutical development from two in 1995 to 27 in 2004, with the most actively pursued therapeutic targets being pain, obesity, and multiple sclerosis (<a href="#R480" rid="R480" class=" bibr popnode tag_hotlink tag_tooltip" id="__tag_144919166">

7761Hensen, 2005</a>

7762). As in any rapidly growing area of research, not all the leads will turn out to be useful or even valid. Nevertheless, it is safe to predict that new therapeutic agents that affect the activity of the endocannaboinoid system will emerge and become members of our therapeutic armamentarium. The plant-derived cannabinoid preparation Sativex has already gained regulatory approval in Canada for the treatment of spasticity and pain associated with multiple sclerosis, and the CB<sub>

77631</sub>

7764 receptor antagonist rimonabant has been approved in Europe and is awaiting Food and Drug Administration approval in the United States for the treatment of the metabolic syndrome. Undoubtedly, these will be followed by new and improved compounds aimed at the same or additional targets in the endocannabinoid system. However, it may be only after the widespread therapeutic use of such compounds that some important side effects will emerge. Although this occurrence would be undesirable from a health care perspective, such side effects may shed further light on the biological functions of endocannabinoids in health and disease.</p>

7765</div>

7766<div id="S52" class="tsec sec">

7767<h2 class="head no_bottom_margin" id="S52title">

7768Acknowledgments</h2>

7769<div class="sec">

7770<p id="__p10">

7771We are indebted to Kimberly Bochniak for help with the list of references. P.P. dedicates this review to his beloved mother, Iren.</p>

7772<p id="__p11">

7773Work from the authors&#x02019; laboratory was supported by the Intramural Research Program of the National Institutes of Health/National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.</p>

7774</div>

7775</div>

7997<span class="ref-journal">

8009</li>

8010<li id="R7">

8011<span class="citation">

8012Adami M, Frati P, Bertini S, Kulkarni-Narla A, Brown DR, de Caro G, Coruzzi G, Soldani G. Gastric antisecretory role and immunohistochemical localization of cannabinoid receptors in the rat stomach. <span>

8013<span class="ref-journal">

8014Br J Pharmacol. </span>

80152002;<span class="ref-vol">

8016135</span>

30430 [<a href="/pubmed/9433882" ref="reftype=pubmed&amp;article-id=2241751&amp;issue-id=161221&amp;journal-id=319&amp;FROM=Article%7CCitationRef&amp;TO=Entrez%7CPubMed%7CRecord">

30580

30581<script>

30582

30583 (function($){

30584 $('.skiplink').each(function(i, item){

30585 var href = $($(item).attr('href'));

30586 href.attr('tabindex', '-1').addClass('skiptarget'); // ensure the target can receive focus

30587 $(item).on('click', function(event){

30588 event.preventDefault();

30589 $.scrollTo(href, 0, {

30590 onAfter: function(){

30591 href.focus();

30592 }

30593 });

30594 });

30595 });

30596 })(jQuery);

30597</script>
